{"hand, foot and mouth diseasenum_articles": "313", "hand, foot and mouth disease": [{"archive_id": "7835796", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease update - Viet Nam: (HC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7835796", "date": "2018-11-01 11:34:43", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE UPDATE(12): UK (OLDHAM, ROCHDALE)\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 25 Oct 2018\nSource: Rochdale Online [edited]\nhttps://www.rochdaleonline.co.uk/news-features/2/news-headlines/123327/parents-warned-of-the-dangers-of-hand-foot-and-mouth-disease\n\n\nA surge in cases of hand-foot-mouth disease in Oldham and Rochdale [Greater Manchester] has prompted health professionals in our region to warn parents to look out for the signs.\n\nIt causes red spots on the tongue and mouth and a rash to the fingers and soles of the feet.\n\nThe illness is very contagious and common in children under 10. Most cases don't need medical attention, but mums and dads are being told if symptoms don't ease after a week to speak to a doctor.\n\nThere's been a recent spate of cases in Heywood, Middleton and Rochdale. The 1st signs are a high temperature, loss of appetite, a cough, and a sore throat. After a couple of days, spots can develop inside the mouth and on the tongue and they can become painful ulcers that make eating and drinking difficult. A rash can then develop on the hands and feet. They can become blisters, which are itchy and uncomfortable.\n\nHealth experts say the best way to treat the illness is to keep the child at home and keep them hydrated.\n\nIf ulcers in the mouth are painful, soft foods and paracetamol are recommended. Symptoms should last between a week and 10 days, and most cases won't need medical attention.\n\nIf symptoms last longer or children show signs of dehydration, have fits, a very high temperature, are unusually tired or unrousable, or if their skin is painful, red, swollen, or hot to the touch, then parents are being told to speak to the doctor.\n\nTo minimise the spread of the illness, health experts say you should wash your hands and disinfect contaminated surfaces.\n\nThere's more information at https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/hand-foot-mouth-disease/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) is most common in children under 10, especially those under 4 years of age. HFMD is extremely contagious; it often spreads among groups of children, particularly in nurseries and schools. The viruses that cause the disease are usually spread in mucus or saliva droplets, when someone who has it coughs or sneezes. It can also be transmitted by direct contact with the fluid from the blisters of a person infected with the virus. An infected person can also spread the virus if they don't wash their hands properly after going to the toilet, as the virus can be passed in faeces.\n\nPatients are most contagious while they still have blisters and mouth ulcers, which is usually for up to 7 to 10 days. However patients can continue to pass the virus in their faeces for several weeks, and may still be mildly infectious during this time.\n\nHFMD is spread very easily. There are some things you can do to reduce your risk of catching or spreading it:\n- wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before you eat and after you go to the toilet;\n- cover mouth and nose when you cough or sneeze. Use a tissue and wash your hands afterwards;\n- clean surfaces that may have been in contact with saliva or faeces with cleaning products containing bleach;\n- dispose properly of used tissues and nappies after changing your baby;\n- wash soiled clothing, towels, and bedding at a hot temperature;\n- don't share cups, utensils, or towels with people who are infected;\n- don't deliberately pierce blisters.\n- try to avoid contact with other people -- particularly pregnant women -- as much as you can while you have symptoms.\n- Mod.UBA\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nGreater Manchester, England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31512]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (11): USA 20181026.6108435\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Viet Nam, USA (CT), Australia (QL) 20181020.6100738\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): Europe (Ireland ex Mallorca, Spain) 20181009.6081390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Viet Nam (HC) 20180929.6059772\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07): Southeast Asia (Singapore) USA (VA) 20180819.5975210\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): USA 20180729.5934295\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (05): China (HK) EV71 20180529.5821814\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): China 20180518.5804254\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): China 20180430.5774368\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Caribbean (Cayman Islands) 20180221.5641051\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Japan, research 20180130.5594550\n2017\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Caribbean, WHO (Western Pacific), USA (midwest) 20171103.5423054\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): comment 20170906.5299733\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Thailand (BT) 20170904.5294390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - Malaysia: (SK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6280762", "date": "2018-11-01 11:34:43", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE UPDATE(12): UK (OLDHAM, ROCHDALE)\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 25 Oct 2018\nSource: Rochdale Online [edited]\nhttps://www.rochdaleonline.co.uk/news-features/2/news-headlines/123327/parents-warned-of-the-dangers-of-hand-foot-and-mouth-disease\n\n\nA surge in cases of hand-foot-mouth disease in Oldham and Rochdale [Greater Manchester] has prompted health professionals in our region to warn parents to look out for the signs.\n\nIt causes red spots on the tongue and mouth and a rash to the fingers and soles of the feet.\n\nThe illness is very contagious and common in children under 10. Most cases don't need medical attention, but mums and dads are being told if symptoms don't ease after a week to speak to a doctor.\n\nThere's been a recent spate of cases in Heywood, Middleton and Rochdale. The 1st signs are a high temperature, loss of appetite, a cough, and a sore throat. After a couple of days, spots can develop inside the mouth and on the tongue and they can become painful ulcers that make eating and drinking difficult. A rash can then develop on the hands and feet. They can become blisters, which are itchy and uncomfortable.\n\nHealth experts say the best way to treat the illness is to keep the child at home and keep them hydrated.\n\nIf ulcers in the mouth are painful, soft foods and paracetamol are recommended. Symptoms should last between a week and 10 days, and most cases won't need medical attention.\n\nIf symptoms last longer or children show signs of dehydration, have fits, a very high temperature, are unusually tired or unrousable, or if their skin is painful, red, swollen, or hot to the touch, then parents are being told to speak to the doctor.\n\nTo minimise the spread of the illness, health experts say you should wash your hands and disinfect contaminated surfaces.\n\nThere's more information at https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/hand-foot-mouth-disease/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) is most common in children under 10, especially those under 4 years of age. HFMD is extremely contagious; it often spreads among groups of children, particularly in nurseries and schools. The viruses that cause the disease are usually spread in mucus or saliva droplets, when someone who has it coughs or sneezes. It can also be transmitted by direct contact with the fluid from the blisters of a person infected with the virus. An infected person can also spread the virus if they don't wash their hands properly after going to the toilet, as the virus can be passed in faeces.\n\nPatients are most contagious while they still have blisters and mouth ulcers, which is usually for up to 7 to 10 days. However patients can continue to pass the virus in their faeces for several weeks, and may still be mildly infectious during this time.\n\nHFMD is spread very easily. There are some things you can do to reduce your risk of catching or spreading it:\n- wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before you eat and after you go to the toilet;\n- cover mouth and nose when you cough or sneeze. Use a tissue and wash your hands afterwards;\n- clean surfaces that may have been in contact with saliva or faeces with cleaning products containing bleach;\n- dispose properly of used tissues and nappies after changing your baby;\n- wash soiled clothing, towels, and bedding at a hot temperature;\n- don't share cups, utensils, or towels with people who are infected;\n- don't deliberately pierce blisters.\n- try to avoid contact with other people -- particularly pregnant women -- as much as you can while you have symptoms.\n- Mod.UBA\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nGreater Manchester, England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31512]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (11): USA 20181026.6108435\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Viet Nam, USA (CT), Australia (QL) 20181020.6100738\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): Europe (Ireland ex Mallorca, Spain) 20181009.6081390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Viet Nam (HC) 20180929.6059772\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07): Southeast Asia (Singapore) USA (VA) 20180819.5975210\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): USA 20180729.5934295\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (05): China (HK) EV71 20180529.5821814\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): China 20180518.5804254\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): China 20180430.5774368\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Caribbean (Cayman Islands) 20180221.5641051\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Japan, research 20180130.5594550\n2017\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Caribbean, WHO (Western Pacific), USA (midwest) 20171103.5423054\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): comment 20170906.5299733\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Thailand (BT) 20170904.5294390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - [edited]\nhttps://www.rochdaleonline.co.uk/news-features/2/news-headlines/123327/parents-warned-of-the-dangers-of-hand-foot-and-mouth-disease\n\n\nA surge in cases of hand-foot-mouth disease in Oldham and Rochdale [Greater Manchester] has prompted health professionals in our region to warn parents to look out for the signs.\n\nIt causes red spots on the tongue and mouth and a rash to the fingers and soles of the feet.\n\nThe illness is very contagious and common in children under 10. Most cases don't need medical attention, but mums and dads are being told if symptoms don't ease after a week to speak to a doctor.\n\nThere's been a recent spate of cases in Heywood, Middleton and Rochdale. The 1st signs are a high temperature, loss of appetite, a cough, and a sore throat. After a couple of days, spots can develop inside the mouth and on the tongue and they can become painful ulcers that make eating and drinking difficult. A rash can then develop on the hands and feet. They can become blisters, which are itchy and uncomfortable.\n\nHealth experts say the best way to treat the illness is to keep the child at home and keep them hydrated.\n\nIf ulcers in the mouth are painful, soft foods and paracetamol are recommended. Symptoms should last between a week and 10 days, and most cases won't need medical attention.\n\nIf symptoms last longer or children show signs of dehydration, have fits, a very high temperature, are unusually tired or unrousable, or if their skin is painful, red, swollen, or hot to the touch, then parents are being told to speak to the doctor.\n\nTo minimise the spread of the illness, health experts say you should wash your hands and disinfect contaminated surfaces.\n\nThere's more information at https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/hand-foot-mouth-disease/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) is most common in children under 10, especially those under 4 years of age. HFMD is extremely contagious; it often spreads among groups of children, particularly in nurseries and schools. The viruses that cause the disease are usually spread in mucus or saliva droplets, when someone who has it coughs or sneezes. It can also be transmitted by direct contact with the fluid from the blisters of a person infected with the virus. An infected person can also spread the virus if they don't wash their hands properly after going to the toilet, as the virus can be passed in faeces.\n\nPatients are most contagious while they still have blisters and mouth ulcers, which is usually for up to 7 to 10 days. However patients can continue to pass the virus in their faeces for several weeks, and may still be mildly infectious during this time.\n\nHFMD is spread very easily. There are some things you can do to reduce your risk of catching or spreading it:\n- wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before you eat and after you go to the toilet;\n- cover mouth and nose when you cough or sneeze. Use a tissue and wash your hands afterwards;\n- clean surfaces that may have been in contact with saliva or faeces with cleaning products containing bleach;\n- dispose properly of used tissues and nappies after changing your baby;\n- wash soiled clothing, towels, and bedding at a hot temperature;\n- don't share cups, utensils, or towels with people who are infected;\n- don't deliberately pierce blisters.\n- try to avoid contact with other people -- particularly pregnant women -- as much as you can while you have symptoms.\n- Mod.UBA\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nGreater Manchester, England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31512]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (11): USA 20181026.6108435\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Viet Nam, USA (CT), Australia (QL) 20181020.6100738\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): Europe (Ireland ex Mallorca, Spain) 20181009.6081390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Viet Nam (HC) 20180929.6059772\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07): Southeast Asia (Singapore) USA (VA) 20180819.5975210\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): USA 20180729.5934295\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (05): China (HK) EV71 20180529.5821814\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): China 20180518.5804254\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): China 20180430.5774368\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Caribbean (Cayman Islands) 20180221.5641051\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Japan, research 20180130.5594550\n2017\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Caribbean, WHO (Western Pacific), USA (midwest) 20171103.5423054\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): comment 20170906.5299733\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Thailand (BT) 20170904.5294390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6172851", "date": "2018-11-01 11:34:43", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE UPDATE(12): UK (OLDHAM, ROCHDALE)\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 25 Oct 2018\nSource: Rochdale Online [edited]\nhttps://www.rochdaleonline.co.uk/news-features/2/news-headlines/123327/parents-warned-of-the-dangers-of-hand-foot-and-mouth-disease\n\n\nA surge in cases of hand-foot-mouth disease in Oldham and Rochdale [Greater Manchester] has prompted health professionals in our region to warn parents to look out for the signs.\n\nIt causes red spots on the tongue and mouth and a rash to the fingers and soles of the feet.\n\nThe illness is very contagious and common in children under 10. Most cases don't need medical attention, but mums and dads are being told if symptoms don't ease after a week to speak to a doctor.\n\nThere's been a recent spate of cases in Heywood, Middleton and Rochdale. The 1st signs are a high temperature, loss of appetite, a cough, and a sore throat. After a couple of days, spots can develop inside the mouth and on the tongue and they can become painful ulcers that make eating and drinking difficult. A rash can then develop on the hands and feet. They can become blisters, which are itchy and uncomfortable.\n\nHealth experts say the best way to treat the illness is to keep the child at home and keep them hydrated.\n\nIf ulcers in the mouth are painful, soft foods and paracetamol are recommended. Symptoms should last between a week and 10 days, and most cases won't need medical attention.\n\nIf symptoms last longer or children show signs of dehydration, have fits, a very high temperature, are unusually tired or unrousable, or if their skin is painful, red, swollen, or hot to the touch, then parents are being told to speak to the doctor.\n\nTo minimise the spread of the illness, health experts say you should wash your hands and disinfect contaminated surfaces.\n\nThere's more information at https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/hand-foot-mouth-disease/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) is most common in children under 10, especially those under 4 years of age. HFMD is extremely contagious; it often spreads among groups of children, particularly in nurseries and schools. The viruses that cause the disease are usually spread in mucus or saliva droplets, when someone who has it coughs or sneezes. It can also be transmitted by direct contact with the fluid from the blisters of a person infected with the virus. An infected person can also spread the virus if they don't wash their hands properly after going to the toilet, as the virus can be passed in faeces.\n\nPatients are most contagious while they still have blisters and mouth ulcers, which is usually for up to 7 to 10 days. However patients can continue to pass the virus in their faeces for several weeks, and may still be mildly infectious during this time.\n\nHFMD is spread very easily. There are some things you can do to reduce your risk of catching or spreading it:\n- wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before you eat and after you go to the toilet;\n- cover mouth and nose when you cough or sneeze. Use a tissue and wash your hands afterwards;\n- clean surfaces that may have been in contact with saliva or faeces with cleaning products containing bleach;\n- dispose properly of used tissues and nappies after changing your baby;\n- wash soiled clothing, towels, and bedding at a hot temperature;\n- don't share cups, utensils, or towels with people who are infected;\n- don't deliberately pierce blisters.\n- try to avoid contact with other people -- particularly pregnant women -- as much as you can while you have symptoms.\n- Mod.UBA\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nGreater Manchester, England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31512]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (11): USA 20181026.6108435\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Viet Nam, USA (CT), Australia (QL) 20181020.6100738\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): Europe (Ireland ex Mallorca, Spain) 20181009.6081390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Viet Nam (HC) 20180929.6059772\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07): Southeast Asia (Singapore) USA (VA) 20180819.5975210\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): USA 20180729.5934295\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (05): China (HK) EV71 20180529.5821814\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): China 20180518.5804254\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): China 20180430.5774368\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Caribbean (Cayman Islands) 20180221.5641051\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Japan, research 20180130.5594550\n2017\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Caribbean, WHO (Western Pacific), USA (midwest) 20171103.5423054\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): comment 20170906.5299733\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Thailand (BT) 20170904.5294390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - ["2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rochdale", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6131121", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease update (14): Ireland, China (Hong Kong)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6131121", "date": "2018-11-01 11:34:43", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE UPDATE(12): UK (OLDHAM, ROCHDALE)\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 25 Oct 2018\nSource: Rochdale Online [edited]\nhttps://www.rochdaleonline.co.uk/news-features/2/news-headlines/123327/parents-warned-of-the-dangers-of-hand-foot-and-mouth-disease\n\n\nA surge in cases of hand-foot-mouth disease in Oldham and Rochdale [Greater Manchester] has prompted health professionals in our region to warn parents to look out for the signs.\n\nIt causes red spots on the tongue and mouth and a rash to the fingers and soles of the feet.\n\nThe illness is very contagious and common in children under 10. Most cases don't need medical attention, but mums and dads are being told if symptoms don't ease after a week to speak to a doctor.\n\nThere's been a recent spate of cases in Heywood, Middleton and Rochdale. The 1st signs are a high temperature, loss of appetite, a cough, and a sore throat. After a couple of days, spots can develop inside the mouth and on the tongue and they can become painful ulcers that make eating and drinking difficult. A rash can then develop on the hands and feet. They can become blisters, which are itchy and uncomfortable.\n\nHealth experts say the best way to treat the illness is to keep the child at home and keep them hydrated.\n\nIf ulcers in the mouth are painful, soft foods and paracetamol are recommended. Symptoms should last between a week and 10 days, and most cases won't need medical attention.\n\nIf symptoms last longer or children show signs of dehydration, have fits, a very high temperature, are unusually tired or unrousable, or if their skin is painful, red, swollen, or hot to the touch, then parents are being told to speak to the doctor.\n\nTo minimise the spread of the illness, health experts say you should wash your hands and disinfect contaminated surfaces.\n\nThere's more information at https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/hand-foot-mouth-disease/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) is most common in children under 10, especially those under 4 years of age. HFMD is extremely contagious; it often spreads among groups of children, particularly in nurseries and schools. The viruses that cause the disease are usually spread in mucus or saliva droplets, when someone who has it coughs or sneezes. It can also be transmitted by direct contact with the fluid from the blisters of a person infected with the virus. An infected person can also spread the virus if they don't wash their hands properly after going to the toilet, as the virus can be passed in faeces.\n\nPatients are most contagious while they still have blisters and mouth ulcers, which is usually for up to 7 to 10 days. However patients can continue to pass the virus in their faeces for several weeks, and may still be mildly infectious during this time.\n\nHFMD is spread very easily. There are some things you can do to reduce your risk of catching or spreading it:\n- wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before you eat and after you go to the toilet;\n- cover mouth and nose when you cough or sneeze. Use a tissue and wash your hands afterwards;\n- clean surfaces that may have been in contact with saliva or faeces with cleaning products containing bleach;\n- dispose properly of used tissues and nappies after changing your baby;\n- wash soiled clothing, towels, and bedding at a hot temperature;\n- don't share cups, utensils, or towels with people who are infected;\n- don't deliberately pierce blisters.\n- try to avoid contact with other people -- particularly pregnant women -- as much as you can while you have symptoms.\n- Mod.UBA\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nGreater Manchester, England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31512]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (11): USA 20181026.6108435\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Viet Nam, USA (CT), Australia (QL) 20181020.6100738\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): Europe (Ireland ex Mallorca, Spain) 20181009.6081390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Viet Nam (HC) 20180929.6059772\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07): Southeast Asia (Singapore) USA (VA) 20180819.5975210\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): USA 20180729.5934295\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (05): China (HK) EV71 20180529.5821814\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): China 20180518.5804254\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): China 20180430.5774368\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Caribbean (Cayman Islands) 20180221.5641051\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Japan, research 20180130.5594550\n2017\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Caribbean, WHO (Western Pacific), USA (midwest) 20171103.5423054\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): comment 20170906.5299733\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Thailand (BT) 20170904.5294390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - Mexico 20170704.5150139\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249\nHand, foot, & mouth disease update (05): Thailand (SK) 20170623.5125187\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): Australia (VI) 20170520.5050110\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): Pakistan (PB), comment 20170316.4905767\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Thailand, Viet Nam 20170303.4875744\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Southeast Asia, UK, USA, Domin. and soles of the feet.\n\nThe illness is very contagious and common in children under 10. HFMD is extremely contagious; it often spreads among groups of children, particularly in nurseries and schools. The viruses that cause the disease are usually spread in mucus or saliva droplets, when someone who has it coughs or sneezes. It can also be transmitted by direct contact with the fluid from the blisters of a person infected with the virus. An infected person can also spread the virus if they don't wash their hands properly after going to the toilet, as the virus can be passed in faeces.\n\nPatients are most contagious while they still have blisters and mouth ulcers, which is usually for up to 7 to 10 days. However patients can continue to pass the virus in their faeces for several weeks, and may still be mildly infectious during this time.\n\nHFMD is spread very easily. There are some things you can do to reduce your risk of catching or spreading it:\n- wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before you eat and after you go to the toilet;\n- cover mouth and nose when you cough or sneeze. Use a tissue and wash your hands afterwards;\n- clean surfaces that may have been in contact with saliva or faeces with cleaning products containing bleach;\n- dispose properly of used tissues and nappies after changing your baby;\n- wash soiled clothing, towels, and bedding at a hot temperature;\n- don't share cups, utensils, or towels with people who are infected;\n- don't deliberately pierce blisters.\n- try to avoid contact with other people -- particularly pregnant women -- as much as you can while you have symptoms.\n- Mod.UBA\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nGreater Manchester, England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31512]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (11): USA 20181026.6108435\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Viet Nam, USA (CT), Australia (QL) 20181020.6100738\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): Europe (Ireland ex Mallorca, Spain) 20181009.6081390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Viet Nam (HC) 20180929.6059772\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07): Southeast Asia (Singapore) USA (VA) 20180819.5975210\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): USA 20180729.5934295\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (05): China (HK) EV71 20180529.5821814\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): China 20180518.5804254\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): China 20180430.5774368\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Caribbean (Cayman Islands) 20180221.5641051\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Japan, research 20180130.5594550\n2017\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Caribbean, WHO (Western Pacific), USA (midwest) 20171103.5423054\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): comment 20170906.5299733\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Thailand (BT) 20170904.5294390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - The viruses that cause the disease are usually spread in mucus or saliva droplets, when someone who has it coughs or sneezes. However patients can continue to pass the virus in their faeces for several weeks, and may still be mildly infectious during this time.\n\nHFMD is spread very easily. ROCHDALE)\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious [edited]\nhttps://www.rochdaleonline.co.uk/news-features/2/news-headlines/123327/parents-warned-of-the-dangers-of-hand-foot-and-mouth-disease\n\n\nA surge in cases of hand-foot-mouth disease in Oldham and Rochdale [Greater Manchester] has prompted health professionals in our region to warn parents to look out for the signs.\n\nIt causes red spots on the tongue and mouth and a rash to the fingers and soles of the feet.\n\nThe illness is very contagious and common in children under 10. Most cases don't need medical attention, but mums and dads are being told if symptoms don't ease after a week to speak to a doctor.\n\nThere's been a recent spate of cases in Heywood, Middleton and Rochdale. The 1st signs are a high temperature, loss of appetite, a cough, and a sore throat. After a couple of days, spots can develop inside the mouth and on the tongue and they can become painful ulcers that make eating and drinking difficult. A rash can then develop on the hands and feet. They can become blisters, which are itchy and uncomfortable.\n\nHealth experts say the best way to treat the illness is to keep the child at home and keep them hydrated.\n\nIf ulcers in the mouth are painful, soft foods and paracetamol are recommended. Symptoms should last between a week and 10 days, and most cases won't need medical attention.\n\nIf symptoms last longer or children show signs of dehydration, have fits, a very high temperature, are unusually tired or unrousable, or if their skin is painful, red, swollen, or hot to the touch, then parents are being told to speak to the doctor.\n\nTo minimise the spread of the illness, health experts say you should wash your hands and disinfect contaminated surfaces.\n\nThere's more information at https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/hand-foot-mouth-disease/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) is most common in children under 10, especially those under 4 years of age. HFMD is extremely contagious; it often spreads among groups of children, particularly in nurseries and schools. The viruses that cause the disease are usually spread in mucus or saliva droplets, when someone who has it coughs or sneezes. It can also be transmitted by direct contact with the fluid from the blisters of a person infected with the virus. An infected person can also spread the virus if they don't wash their hands properly after going to the toilet, as the virus can be passed in faeces.\n\nPatients are most contagious while they still have blisters and mouth ulcers, which is usually for up to 7 to 10 days. However patients can continue to pass the virus in their faeces for several weeks, and may still be mildly infectious during this time.\n\nHFMD is spread very easily. There are some things you can do to reduce your risk of catching or spreading it:\n- wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before you eat and after you go to the toilet;\n- cover mouth and nose when you cough or sneeze. Use a tissue and wash your hands afterwards;\n- clean surfaces that may have been in contact with saliva or faeces with cleaning products containing bleach;\n- dispose properly of used tissues and nappies after changing your baby;\n- wash soiled clothing, towels, and bedding at a hot temperature;\n- don't share cups, utensils, or towels with people who are infected;\n- don't deliberately pierce blisters.\n- try to avoid contact with other people -- particularly pregnant women -- as much as you can while you have symptoms.\n- Mod.UBA\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nGreater Manchester, England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31512]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (11): USA 20181026.6108435\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Viet Nam, USA (CT), Australia (QL) 20181020.6100738\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): Europe (Ireland ex Mallorca, Spain) 20181009.6081390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Viet Nam (HC) 20180929.6059772\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07): Southeast Asia (Singapore) USA (VA) 20180819.5975210\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): USA 20180729.5934295\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (05): China (HK) EV71 20180529.5821814\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): China 20180518.5804254\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): China 20180430.5774368\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Caribbean (Cayman Islands) 20180221.5641051\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Japan, research 20180130.5594550\n2017\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Caribbean, WHO (Western Pacific), USA (midwest) 20171103.5423054\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): comment 20170906.5299733\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Thailand (BT) 20170904.5294390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6100738", "date": "2018-04-30 09:58:10", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE UPDATE (03): CHINA\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 26 Apr 2018 14:00 UTC+8\nSource: Shine, Xinhua News Agency report [edited]\nhttps://www.shine.cn/news/nation/1804263743/\n\n\nMore than 140 000 people have been infected with hand-foot-mouth disease [HFMD] and 6 died from the disease in China this year [2018], according to China's Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\n\nAs of 20 Apr 2018, a total of 141 978 cases had been reported, with 6 deaths and 581 in critical condition. The disease incidence rate was lower than the same period of last year [2017], the CDC said in a statement.\n\nZhang Jing, researcher with the CDC, said HFMD was a common infectious disease that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old.\n\nDuring the peak season for HFMD, from April to June, the CDC said measures are needed to closely monitor and prevent transmission of the disease, especially at primary schools and kindergartens.\n\nQian Suyun, doctor at Beijing Children's Hospital, reminded parents and teachers to take children to hospital as soon as they show symptoms such as fever, vomiting, irritation, and limb weakness.\n\nThe disease can be transmitted through close contact with excreta and respiratory secretions, among others.\n\n[Editor: Wang Qingchu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED mail Hand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Caribbean (Cayman Islands) 20180221.5641051 for a discussion of this generally mild disease.\n\nComplications affecting the brain, lung, or heart may occur in rare cases where the infection is caused by a more severe virus strain. Complications include viral or \"aseptic\" meningitis (https://www.cdc.gov/meningitis/viral.html), but it is rare. It causes fever, headache, stiff neck, or back pain and may require the infected person to be hospitalized for a few days. Encephalitis (inflammation of the brain) or polio-like paralysis can occur, but this is even rarer. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/155]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Caribbean (Cayman Islands) 20180221.5641051\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Japan, research 20180130.5594550\n2017\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Caribbean, WHO (Western Pacific), USA (midwest) 20171103.5423054\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): comment 20170906.5299733\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Thailand (BT) 20170904.5294390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - Mexico 20170704.5150139\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249\nHand, foot, & mouth disease update (05): Thailand (SK) 20170623.5125187\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): Australia (VI) 20170520.5050110\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): Pakistan (PB), comment 20170316.4905767\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Thailand, Viet Nam 20170303.4875744\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Southeast Asia, UK, USA, Domin. "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE UPDATE (03): CHINA\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 26 Apr 2018 14:00 UTC+8\nSource: Shine, Xinhua News Agency report [edited]\nhttps://www.shine.cn/news/nation/1804263743/\n\n\nMore than 140 000 people have been infected with hand-foot-mouth disease [HFMD] and 6 died from the disease in China this year [2018], according to China's Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\n\nAs of 20 Apr 2018, a total of 141 978 cases had been reported, with 6 deaths and 581 in critical condition. The disease incidence rate was lower than the same period of last year [2017], the CDC said in a statement.\n\nZhang Jing, researcher with the CDC, said HFMD was a common infectious disease that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old.\n\nDuring the peak season for HFMD, from April to June, the CDC said measures are needed to closely monitor and prevent transmission of the disease, especially at primary schools and kindergartens.\n\nQian Suyun, doctor at Beijing Children's Hospital, reminded parents and teachers to take children to hospital as soon as they show symptoms such as fever, vomiting, irritation, and limb weakness.\n\nThe disease can be transmitted through close contact with excreta and respiratory secretions, among others.\n\n[Editor: Wang Qingchu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED mail Hand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Caribbean (Cayman Islands) 20180221.5641051 for a discussion of this generally mild disease.\n\nComplications affecting the brain, lung, or heart may occur in rare cases where the infection is caused by a more severe virus strain. Complications include viral or \"aseptic\" meningitis (https://www.cdc.gov/meningitis/viral.html), but it is rare. It causes fever, headache, stiff neck, or back pain and may require the infected person to be hospitalized for a few days. Encephalitis (inflammation of the brain) or polio-like paralysis can occur, but this is even rarer. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/155]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Caribbean (Cayman Islands) 20180221.5641051\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Japan, research 20180130.5594550\n2017\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Caribbean, WHO (Western Pacific), USA (midwest) 20171103.5423054\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): comment 20170906.5299733\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Thailand (BT) 20170904.5294390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - Mexico 20170704.5150139\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249\nHand, foot, & mouth disease update (05): Thailand (SK) 20170623.5125187\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): Australia (VI) 20170520.5050110\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): Pakistan (PB), comment 20170316.4905767\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Thailand, Viet Nam 20170303.4875744\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Southeast Asia, UK, USA, Domin. FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE UPDATE (03): CHINA\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 26 Apr 2018 14:00 UTC+8\nSource: Shine, Xinhua News Agency report [edited]\nhttps://www.shine.cn/news/nation/1804263743/\n\n\nMore than 140 000 people have been infected with hand-foot-mouth disease [HFMD] and 6 died from the disease in China this year [2018], according to China's Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\n\nAs of 20 Apr 2018, a total of 141 978 cases had been reported, with 6 deaths and 581 in critical condition. The disease incidence rate was lower than the same period of last year [2017], the CDC said in a statement.\n\nZhang Jing, researcher with the CDC, said HFMD was a common infectious disease that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old.\n\nDuring the peak season for HFMD, from April to June, the CDC said measures are needed to closely monitor and prevent transmission of the disease, especially at primary schools and kindergartens.\n\nQian Suyun, doctor at Beijing Children's Hospital, reminded parents and teachers to take children to hospital as soon as they show symptoms such as fever, vomiting, irritation, and limb weakness.\n\nThe disease can be transmitted through close contact with excreta and respiratory secretions, among others.\n\n[Editor: Wang Qingchu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED mail Hand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Caribbean (Cayman Islands) 20180221.5641051 for a discussion of this generally mild disease.\n\nComplications affecting the brain, lung, or heart may occur in rare cases where the infection is caused by a more severe virus strain. Complications include viral or \"aseptic\" meningitis (https://www.cdc.gov/meningitis/viral.html), but it is rare. It causes fever, headache, stiff neck, or back pain and may require the infected person to be hospitalized for a few days. been infected with hand-foot-mouth disease [HFMD] and 6 died from the disease in China this year [2018], according to China's Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\n\nAs of 20 Apr 2018, a total of 141 978 cases had been reported, with 6 deaths and 581 in critical condition. The disease incidence rate was lower than the same period of last year [2017], the CDC said in a statement.\n\nZhang Jing, researcher with the CDC, said HFMD was a common infectious disease that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old.\n\nDuring the peak season for HFMD, from April to June, the CDC said measures are needed to closely monitor and prevent transmission of the disease, especially at primary schools and kindergartens.\n\nQian Suyun, doctor at Beijing Children's Hospital, reminded parents and teachers to take children to hospital as soon as they show symptoms such as fever, vomiting, irritation, and limb weakness.\n\nThe disease can be transmitted through close contact with excreta and respiratory secretions, among others.\n\n[Editor: Wang Qingchu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED mail Hand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Caribbean (Cayman Islands) 20180221.5641051 for a discussion of this generally mild disease.\n\nComplications affecting the brain, lung, or heart may occur in rare cases where the infection is caused by a more severe virus strain. Complications include viral or \"aseptic\" meningitis (https://www.cdc.gov/meningitis/viral.html), but it is rare. It causes fever, headache, stiff neck, or back pain and may require the infected person to be hospitalized for a few days. Encephalitis (inflammation of the brain) or polio-like paralysis can occur, but this is even rarer. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/155]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Caribbean (Cayman Islands) 20180221.5641051\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Japan, research 20180130.5594550\n2017\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (10): Caribbean, WHO (Western Pacific), USA (midwest) 20171103.5423054\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (09): comment 20170906.5299733\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (08): Thailand (BT) 20170904.5294390\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - Mexico 20170704.5150139\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249\nHand, foot, & mouth disease update (05): Thailand (SK) 20170623.5125187\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): Australia (VI) 20170520.5050110\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): Pakistan (PB), comment 20170316.4905767\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Thailand, Viet Nam 20170303.4875744\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Southeast Asia, UK, USA, Domin. "5641051", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Caribbean (Cayman Islands)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5641051", "date": "2017-09-04 22:15:44", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE UPDATE (08): THAILAND (BAN TAK)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017\nSource: The Nation [edited]\nhttp://www.nationmultimedia.com/detail/breakingnews/30325707\n\n\nA 3-year-old girl has died of hand foot and mouth disease (HFMD) after she contracted it from a nursery in a tambon in Tak's Ban Tak district.\n\nWP, 42, said her daughter died on Sun [3 Sep 2017], 2 days after she was admitted to Somdejphrajaotaksin Maharaj Hospital. She was transferred there from a district hospital after her condition did not improve. She died of heart failure. WP said her daughter went to the nursery of the Tambon Thongfah Administrative Organisation for the 1st time this year [2017]. She said the nursery was closed for a week following the spread of HFMD there.\n\nBut after the nursery was reopened just for one day, kids contracted the disease, so the nursery was closed for another week, she said. She said her daughter fell ill with a severe headache, stomach pains, and vomiting after the nursery was closed for the 2nd time.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report describes only briefly the symptoms experienced by the child before succumbing to heart failure.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the _Enterovirus_ genus (group), including polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\n\nCoxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of hand, foot, and mouth disease, but other coxsackieviruses can also cause the illness. Enterovirus 71 (EV71) has also been associated with cases and outbreaks of hand, foot, and mouth disease. Less often, EV71 has been associated with severe disease, such as encephalitis. Several types of enteroviruses may be identified in outbreaks of hand, foot and mouth disease; however, most of the time, one or 2 enteroviruses are identified.\n\nSince the initial description of EV71 in 1974 [1], outbreaks of infection with this virus have occurred periodically throughout the world [2-8]. EV71 infection manifests most frequently as the childhood exanthem known as \"hand, foot, and mouth disease\" (HFMD), and it is clinically indistinguishable from HFMD caused by Coxsackie virus A16 (CA16). A molecular study of the evolution of human enteroviruses has shown that EV71 and CA16 have a close genetic relationship, and, together with CA7 and CA14, they form a distinct genetic subgroup within cluster A of the _Enterovirus_ genus of the family Picornaviridae [9]. Despite the close genetic relationship between EV71 and CA16, EV71 has a propensity to cause neurological disease during acute infection [2, 3], a feature not observed in CA16 infections. Children under 4 years of age are particularly susceptible to the most severe forms of EV71-associated neurological disease, including meningitis, brain-stem and/or cerebellar encephalitis, and poliomyelitis-like paralysis. The neurological complications of EV71 infection may occasionally cause permanent paralysis or death. Several large epidemics of severe EV71 infection in young children, including numerous cases of fatal brain-stem encephalitis, have recently been reported in Southeast Asia [10-12; excerpted and edited from Peter McMinn et al. Neurological Manifestations of Enterovirus 71 Infection in Children during an Outbreak of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease in Western Australia. Clinical Infectious Diseases, Volume 32, Issue 2, 15 January 2001, Pages 236-242, https://doi.org/10.1086/318454\n(https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/32/2/236/319948/Neurological-Manifestations-of-Enterovirus-71). See paper for references cited above.]\n\nAlso see Hand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249 for information on an earlier outbreak in the country this year [2017]. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMaps:\nThailand: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/151\nBan Tak, Tak, Thailand: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63089]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - Mexico 20170704.5150139\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249\nHand, foot, & mouth disease update (05): Thailand (SK) 20170623.5125187\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): Australia (VI) 20170520.5050110\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): Pakistan (PB), comment 20170316.4905767\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Thailand, Viet Nam 20170303.4875744\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Southeast Asia, UK, USA, Domin. Rep. RFI 20170218.4847712\n2016\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (HK): 20161007.4543101\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HK) 20160522.4237221\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China: (BJ, GX) vaccine 20160329.4124126\n2015\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (06): (HK) update, children residential home 20151202.3834826\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (05): (HK) update, school outbreaks, EV71 20151126.3821764\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (04): (HK) school outbreaks 20151118.3799693\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (HK) school outbreak 20150927.3674603\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HK) police recruits 20150829.3609404\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (HK) 20150623.3459638\n.................................................sb/lk/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "enterovirus 71 infection", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "poliomyelitis", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "1974-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-01-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Domin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WP", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5594550", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Japan, research", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5594550", "date": "2017-09-04 22:15:44", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE UPDATE (08): THAILAND (BAN TAK)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017\nSource: The Nation [edited]\nhttp://www.nationmultimedia.com/detail/breakingnews/30325707\n\n\nA 3-year-old girl has died of hand foot and mouth disease (HFMD) after she contracted it from a nursery in a tambon in Tak's Ban Tak district.\n\nWP, 42, said her daughter died on Sun [3 Sep 2017], 2 days after she was admitted to Somdejphrajaotaksin Maharaj Hospital. She was transferred there from a district hospital after her condition did not improve. She died of heart failure. WP said her daughter went to the nursery of the Tambon Thongfah Administrative Organisation for the 1st time this year [2017]. She said the nursery was closed for a week following the spread of HFMD there.\n\nBut after the nursery was reopened just for one day, kids contracted the disease, so the nursery was closed for another week, she said. She said her daughter fell ill with a severe headache, stomach pains, and vomiting after the nursery was closed for the 2nd time.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report describes only briefly the symptoms experienced by the child before succumbing to heart failure.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the _Enterovirus_ genus (group), including polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\n\nCoxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of hand, foot, and mouth disease, but other coxsackieviruses can also cause the illness. Enterovirus 71 (EV71) has also been associated with cases and outbreaks of hand, foot, and mouth disease. Less often, EV71 has been associated with severe disease, such as encephalitis. Several types of enteroviruses may be identified in outbreaks of hand, foot and mouth disease; however, most of the time, one or 2 enteroviruses are identified.\n\nSince the initial description of EV71 in 1974 [1], outbreaks of infection with this virus have occurred periodically throughout the world [2-8]. EV71 infection manifests most frequently as the childhood exanthem known as \"hand, foot, and mouth disease\" (HFMD), and it is clinically indistinguishable from HFMD caused by Coxsackie virus A16 (CA16). A molecular study of the evolution of human enteroviruses has shown that EV71 and CA16 have a close genetic relationship, and, together with CA7 and CA14, they form a distinct genetic subgroup within cluster A of the _Enterovirus_ genus of the family Picornaviridae [9]. Despite the close genetic relationship between EV71 and CA16, EV71 has a propensity to cause neurological disease during acute infection [2, 3], a feature not observed in CA16 infections. Children under 4 years of age are particularly susceptible to the most severe forms of EV71-associated neurological disease, including meningitis, brain-stem and/or cerebellar encephalitis, and poliomyelitis-like paralysis. The neurological complications of EV71 infection may occasionally cause permanent paralysis or death. Several large epidemics of severe EV71 infection in young children, including numerous cases of fatal brain-stem encephalitis, have recently been reported in Southeast Asia [10-12; excerpted and edited from Peter McMinn et al. Neurological Manifestations of Enterovirus 71 Infection in Children during an Outbreak of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease in Western Australia. Clinical Infectious Diseases, Volume 32, Issue 2, 15 January 2001, Pages 236-242, https://doi.org/10.1086/318454\n(https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/32/2/236/319948/Neurological-Manifestations-of-Enterovirus-71). See paper for references cited above.]\n\nAlso see Hand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249 for information on an earlier outbreak in the country this year [2017]. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMaps:\nThailand: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/151\nBan Tak, Tak, Thailand: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63089]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - Mexico 20170704.5150139\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249\nHand, foot, & mouth disease update (05): Thailand (SK) 20170623.5125187\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): Australia (VI) 20170520.5050110\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): Pakistan (PB), comment 20170316.4905767\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Thailand, Viet Nam 20170303.4875744\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Southeast Asia, UK, USA, Domin. Pacific Region", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5509064", "date": "2017-09-04 22:15:44", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE UPDATE (08): THAILAND (BAN TAK)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017\nSource: The Nation [edited]\nhttp://www.nationmultimedia.com/detail/breakingnews/30325707\n\n\nA 3-year-old girl has died of hand foot and mouth disease (HFMD) after she contracted it from a nursery in a tambon in Tak's Ban Tak district.\n\nWP, 42, said her daughter died on Sun [3 Sep 2017], 2 days after she was admitted to Somdejphrajaotaksin Maharaj Hospital. She was transferred there from a district hospital after her condition did not improve. She died of heart failure. WP said her daughter went to the nursery of the Tambon Thongfah Administrative Organisation for the 1st time this year [2017]. She said the nursery was closed for a week following the spread of HFMD there.\n\nBut after the nursery was reopened just for one day, kids contracted the disease, so the nursery was closed for another week, she said. She said her daughter fell ill with a severe headache, stomach pains, and vomiting after the nursery was closed for the 2nd time.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report describes only briefly the symptoms experienced by the child before succumbing to heart failure.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the _Enterovirus_ genus (group), including polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\n\nCoxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of hand, foot, and mouth disease, but other coxsackieviruses can also cause the illness. Enterovirus 71 (EV71) has also been associated with cases and outbreaks of hand, foot, and mouth disease. Less often, EV71 has been associated with severe disease, such as encephalitis. Several types of enteroviruses may be identified in outbreaks of hand, foot and mouth disease; however, most of the time, one or 2 enteroviruses are identified.\n\nSince the initial description of EV71 in 1974 [1], outbreaks of infection with this virus have occurred periodically throughout the world [2-8]. EV71 infection manifests most frequently as the childhood exanthem known as \"hand, foot, and mouth disease\" (HFMD), and it is clinically indistinguishable from HFMD caused by Coxsackie virus A16 (CA16). A molecular study of the evolution of human enteroviruses has shown that EV71 and CA16 have a close genetic relationship, and, together with CA7 and CA14, they form a distinct genetic subgroup within cluster A of the _Enterovirus_ genus of the family Picornaviridae [9]. Despite the close genetic relationship between EV71 and CA16, EV71 has a propensity to cause neurological disease during acute infection [2, 3], a feature not observed in CA16 infections. Children under 4 years of age are particularly susceptible to the most severe forms of EV71-associated neurological disease, including meningitis, brain-stem and/or cerebellar encephalitis, and poliomyelitis-like paralysis. The neurological complications of EV71 infection may occasionally cause permanent paralysis or death. Several large epidemics of severe EV71 infection in young children, including numerous cases of fatal brain-stem encephalitis, have recently been reported in Southeast Asia [10-12; excerpted and edited from Peter McMinn et al. Neurological Manifestations of Enterovirus 71 Infection in Children during an Outbreak of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease in Western Australia. Clinical Infectious Diseases, Volume 32, Issue 2, 15 January 2001, Pages 236-242, https://doi.org/10.1086/318454\n(https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/32/2/236/319948/Neurological-Manifestations-of-Enterovirus-71). See paper for references cited above.]\n\nAlso see Hand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249 for information on an earlier outbreak in the country this year [2017]. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMaps:\nThailand: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/151\nBan Tak, Tak, Thailand: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63089]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - Mexico 20170704.5150139\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249\nHand, foot, & mouth disease update (05): Thailand (SK) 20170623.5125187\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): Australia (VI) 20170520.5050110\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): Pakistan (PB), comment 20170316.4905767\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Thailand, Viet Nam 20170303.4875744\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Southeast Asia, UK, USA, Domin. Children under 4 years of age are particularly susceptible to the most severe forms of EV71-associated neurological disease, including meningitis, brain-stem and/or cerebellar encephalitis, and poliomyelitis-like paralysis. The neurological complications of EV71 infection may occasionally cause permanent paralysis or death. Several large epidemics of severe EV71 infection in young children, including numerous cases of fatal brain-stem encephalitis, have recently been reported in Southeast Asia [10-12; excerpted and edited from Peter McMinn et al. Neurological Manifestations of Enterovirus 71 Infection in Children during an Outbreak of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease in Western Australia. Clinical Infectious Diseases, Volume 32, Issue 2, 15 January 2001, Pages 236-242, https://doi.org/10.1086/318454\n(https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/32/2/236/319948/Neurological-Manifestations-of-Enterovirus-71). See paper for references cited above.]\n\nAlso see Hand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249 for information on an earlier outbreak in the country this year [2017]. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMaps:\nThailand: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/151\nBan Tak, Tak, Thailand: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63089]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - Mexico 20170704.5150139\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249\nHand, foot, & mouth disease update (05): Thailand (SK) 20170623.5125187\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): Australia (VI) 20170520.5050110\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): Pakistan (PB), comment 20170316.4905767\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Thailand, Viet Nam 20170303.4875744\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Southeast Asia, UK, USA, Domin. "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "1974-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-01-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5299733", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease update (09): comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5299733", "date": "2017-09-04 22:15:44", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE UPDATE (08): THAILAND (BAN TAK)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017\nSource: The Nation [edited]\nhttp://www.nationmultimedia.com/detail/breakingnews/30325707\n\n\nA 3-year-old girl has died of hand foot and mouth disease (HFMD) after she contracted it from a nursery in a tambon in Tak's Ban Tak district.\n\nWP, 42, said her daughter died on Sun [3 Sep 2017], 2 days after she was admitted to Somdejphrajaotaksin Maharaj Hospital. She was transferred there from a district hospital after her condition did not improve. She died of heart failure. WP said her daughter went to the nursery of the Tambon Thongfah Administrative Organisation for the 1st time this year [2017]. She said the nursery was closed for a week following the spread of HFMD there.\n\nBut after the nursery was reopened just for one day, kids contracted the disease, so the nursery was closed for another week, she said. She said her daughter fell ill with a severe headache, stomach pains, and vomiting after the nursery was closed for the 2nd time.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report describes only briefly the symptoms experienced by the child before succumbing to heart failure.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the _Enterovirus_ genus (group), including polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\n\nCoxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of hand, foot, and mouth disease, but other coxsackieviruses can also cause the illness. Enterovirus 71 (EV71) has also been associated with cases and outbreaks of hand, foot, and mouth disease. Less often, EV71 has been associated with severe disease, such as encephalitis. Several types of enteroviruses may be identified in outbreaks of hand, foot and mouth disease; however, most of the time, one or 2 enteroviruses are identified.\n\nSince the initial description of EV71 in 1974 [1], outbreaks of infection with this virus have occurred periodically throughout the world [2-8]. EV71 infection manifests most frequently as the childhood exanthem known as \"hand, foot, and mouth disease\" (HFMD), and it is clinically indistinguishable from HFMD caused by Coxsackie virus A16 (CA16). A molecular study of the evolution of human enteroviruses has shown that EV71 and CA16 have a close genetic relationship, and, together with CA7 and CA14, they form a distinct genetic subgroup within cluster A of the _Enterovirus_ genus of the family Picornaviridae [9]. Despite the close genetic relationship between EV71 and CA16, EV71 has a propensity to cause neurological disease during acute infection [2, 3], a feature not observed in CA16 infections. Children under 4 years of age are particularly susceptible to the most severe forms of EV71-associated neurological disease, including meningitis, brain-stem and/or cerebellar encephalitis, and poliomyelitis-like paralysis. The neurological complications of EV71 infection may occasionally cause permanent paralysis or death. Several large epidemics of severe EV71 infection in young children, including numerous cases of fatal brain-stem encephalitis, have recently been reported in Southeast Asia [10-12; excerpted and edited from Peter McMinn et al. Neurological Manifestations of Enterovirus 71 Infection in Children during an Outbreak of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease in Western Australia. Clinical Infectious Diseases, Volume 32, Issue 2, 15 January 2001, Pages 236-242, https://doi.org/10.1086/318454\n(https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/32/2/236/319948/Neurological-Manifestations-of-Enterovirus-71). See paper for references cited above.]\n\nAlso see Hand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249 for information on an earlier outbreak in the country this year [2017]. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMaps:\nThailand: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/151\nBan Tak, Tak, Thailand: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63089]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - Mexico 20170704.5150139\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249\nHand, foot, & mouth disease update (05): Thailand (SK) 20170623.5125187\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (04): Australia (VI) 20170520.5050110\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (03): Pakistan (PB), comment 20170316.4905767\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Thailand, Viet Nam 20170303.4875744\nHand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Southeast Asia, UK, USA, Domin. Several types of enteroviruses may be identified in outbreaks of hand, foot and mouth disease; however, most of the time, one or 2 enteroviruses are identified.\n\nSince the initial description of EV71 in 1974 [1], outbreaks of infection with this virus have occurred periodically throughout the world [2-8]. EV71 infection manifests most frequently as the childhood exanthem known as \"hand, foot, and mouth disease\" (HFMD), and it is clinically indistinguishable from HFMD caused by Coxsackie virus A16 (CA16). A molecular study of the evolution of human enteroviruses has shown that EV71 and CA16 have a close genetic relationship, and, together with CA7 and CA14, they form a distinct genetic subgroup within cluster A of the _Enterovirus_ genus of the family Picornaviridae [9]. Despite the close genetic relationship between EV71 and CA16, EV71 has a propensity to cause neurological disease during acute infection [2, 3], a feature not observed in CA16 infections. The neurological complications of EV71 infection may occasionally cause permanent paralysis or death. China (03): (HK) school outbreak 20150927.3674603\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HK) police recruits 20150829.3609404\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (HK) 20150623.3459638\n.................................................sb/lk/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "enterovirus 71 infection", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "poliomyelitis", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "1974-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-01-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Domin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WP", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5150139", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease update (07) - Mexico", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5150139", "date": "2016-10-30 12:05:51", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS, GRENADA\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (Northern Mariana Islands)\n[2] Grenada: daycare and preschools\n\n******\n[1] Northern Mariana Islands\nDate: Thu 27 Oct 2016\nSource: Marianas Variety [edited]\nhttp://www.mvariety.com/cnmi/cnmi-news/local/90277-chcc-issues-hand-foot-mouth-disease-advisory\n\n\nCommonwealth Healthcare Corp. [CHCC] Chief Executive Officer Esther Muna says there have been 7 cases of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) confirmed at the Commonwealth Health Center's emergency department in the past month, and 1 case at the hospital's Children's Clinic.\n\nBut there have been no cases identified since 20 Oct 2016, she said.\n\nHFMD is a viral infection that can be spread through close personal contact, coughing or sneezing, contact with feces or sharing of straws, cups, and other contaminated surfaces.\n\nIt is usually a mild, common childhood disease with limited consequences, according to CHCC.\n\n\"The viral illness usually affects infants and children younger than age 5.\n\n\"Of the 8 cases diagnosed at CHC in the last month, 5 or 63 percent were under the age of 5.\"\n\nSometimes adults can get the illness, but this is much less common.\n\nHFMD symptoms include a fever, reduced appetite and sore throat.\n\nOne or 2 days after the fever, painful sores can develop in the mouth (called herpangina). They are usually in the back of the mouth as small red spots that blister and become ulcers. A skin rash with red spots and at times blisters can occur on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet.\n\n\"Not everyone will develop all the symptoms. Some people may show no symptoms but still pass on the virus.\"\n\nAccording to CHCC, \"A person with HFMD is most contagious during the 1st week of illness.\"\n\nThere is no vaccine for HFMD, but members of the public can prevent/reduce their risk of being infected by:\n- Washing their hands often with soap and water.\n- Cleaning and disinfecting touched surfaces including toys.\n- Avoid close contact including kissing, hugging, or sharing utensils/cups with a person suffering from HFMD.\n\n\"For the painful mouth sores, you can use over-the-counter mouthwashes or sprays that numb mouth pain. Take over-the-counter Tylenol or Ibuprofen to relieve pain and fever. Aspirin should not be given to children.\"\n\nCommunity members are advised to stay home if they have HFMD. Talk to your primary care doctor if you are unsure when you should return to work. It also applies to taking children back to school and/or daycare.\n\n[Byline: Bryan Manabat]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Northern Mariana Islands (United States) can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/381. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Grenada: daycare and preschools\nDate: Thu 27 Oct 2016\nSource: Jamaica Observer [edited]\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Health-ministry-confirms-outbreak-of-hand--foot-and-mouth-disease-in-Grenada\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health on Thursday [27 Oct 2016] confirmed reports of an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) at some daycare and preschool centres across the island [Grenada, in the Caribbean].\n\nChief Medical Officer, Dr George Mitchell, says the ministry has received reports of 12 cases and going forward public education and direct intervention will be the main focus.\n\n\"Several education/information brochures relating to the disease are being distributed in electronic and print format to the various institutions,\" Mitchell said in a release.\n\nMedical practitioners have also been reminded that the disease is endemic in Grenada and they need to notify the ministry once a case is diagnosed.\n\nRecords at the Ministry of Health indicate that during the same period last year [2015] there were similar outbreaks of the disease among toddlers.\n\n\"Already, health surveillance and public health teams are gathering information and at the same time responding to reports of mild outbreaks among children at daycare and pre and primary schools.\n\nThe release said while a decision has not been made to close the institutions, health authorities are reminding parents and operators of daycares and kindergartens that frequent hand washing is still the best way of managing the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Grenada can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34. - Mod.LK]\n\n[HFMD is frequently reported, and is generally a mild disease, predominantly of children. It is often caused by coxsackie virus A16, but other enteroviruses may be implicated. Virus spreads quickly in daycare and other such facilities, increasing risk for children in that age group. They usually build up immunity to the virus after being exposed, but older children and adults may become infected. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps can be found at:\nNorthern Mariana Islands [United States]: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/381\nGrenada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34 -
