USA (03): (WA) 20160430.4191162\nHand foot & mouth disease - USA (02): (CA) coxsackievirus 20160413.4158388\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (CA) fitness club 20160306.4072937\n.................................................sb/lk/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grenada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5144249", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5144249", "date": "2016-10-30 12:05:51", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS, GRENADA\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (Northern Mariana Islands)\n[2] Grenada: daycare and preschools\n\n******\n[1] Northern Mariana Islands\nDate: Thu 27 Oct 2016\nSource: Marianas Variety [edited]\nhttp://www.mvariety.com/cnmi/cnmi-news/local/90277-chcc-issues-hand-foot-mouth-disease-advisory\n\n\nCommonwealth Healthcare Corp. [CHCC] Chief Executive Officer Esther Muna says there have been 7 cases of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) confirmed at the Commonwealth Health Center's emergency department in the past month, and 1 case at the hospital's Children's Clinic.\n\nBut there have been no cases identified since 20 Oct 2016, she said.\n\nHFMD is a viral infection that can be spread through close personal contact, coughing or sneezing, contact with feces or sharing of straws, cups, and other contaminated surfaces.\n\nIt is usually a mild, common childhood disease with limited consequences, according to CHCC.\n\n\"The viral illness usually affects infants and children younger than age 5.\n\n\"Of the 8 cases diagnosed at CHC in the last month, 5 or 63 percent were under the age of 5.\"\n\nSometimes adults can get the illness, but this is much less common.\n\nHFMD symptoms include a fever, reduced appetite and sore throat.\n\nOne or 2 days after the fever, painful sores can develop in the mouth (called herpangina). They are usually in the back of the mouth as small red spots that blister and become ulcers. A skin rash with red spots and at times blisters can occur on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet.\n\n\"Not everyone will develop all the symptoms. Some people may show no symptoms but still pass on the virus.\"\n\nAccording to CHCC, \"A person with HFMD is most contagious during the 1st week of illness.\"\n\nThere is no vaccine for HFMD, but members of the public can prevent/reduce their risk of being infected by:\n- Washing their hands often with soap and water.\n- Cleaning and disinfecting touched surfaces including toys.\n- Avoid close contact including kissing, hugging, or sharing utensils/cups with a person suffering from HFMD.\n\n\"For the painful mouth sores, you can use over-the-counter mouthwashes or sprays that numb mouth pain. Take over-the-counter Tylenol or Ibuprofen to relieve pain and fever. Aspirin should not be given to children.\"\n\nCommunity members are advised to stay home if they have HFMD. Talk to your primary care doctor if you are unsure when you should return to work. It also applies to taking children back to school and/or daycare.\n\n[Byline: Bryan Manabat]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Northern Mariana Islands (United States) can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/381. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Grenada: daycare and preschools\nDate: Thu 27 Oct 2016\nSource: Jamaica Observer [edited]\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Health-ministry-confirms-outbreak-of-hand--foot-and-mouth-disease-in-Grenada\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health on Thursday [27 Oct 2016] confirmed reports of an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) at some daycare and preschool centres across the island [Grenada, in the Caribbean].\n\nChief Medical Officer, Dr George Mitchell, says the ministry has received reports of 12 cases and going forward public education and direct intervention will be the main focus.\n\n\"Several education/information brochures relating to the disease are being distributed in electronic and print format to the various institutions,\" Mitchell said in a release.\n\nMedical practitioners have also been reminded that the disease is endemic in Grenada and they need to notify the ministry once a case is diagnosed.\n\nRecords at the Ministry of Health indicate that during the same period last year [2015] there were similar outbreaks of the disease among toddlers.\n\n\"Already, health surveillance and public health teams are gathering information and at the same time responding to reports of mild outbreaks among children at daycare and pre and primary schools.\n\nThe release said while a decision has not been made to close the institutions, health authorities are reminding parents and operators of daycares and kindergartens that frequent hand washing is still the best way of managing the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Grenada can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34. - Mod.LK]\n\n[HFMD is frequently reported, and is generally a mild disease, predominantly of children. It is often caused by coxsackie virus A16, but other enteroviruses may be implicated. Virus spreads quickly in daycare and other such facilities, increasing risk for children in that age group. They usually build up immunity to the virus after being exposed, but older children and adults may become infected. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps can be found at:\nNorthern Mariana Islands [United States]: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/381\nGrenada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34 - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (11): (WI) school 20161024.4581707\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (09): (WI,AZ) 20161007.4542511\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (08): (CT, OH) 20161001.4529788\nHand, foot & mouth disease: St Maarten, USA (CT) 20160922.4508252\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (07): (KS) 20160818.4423843\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (06): (NC, KS) 20160728.4377209\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (05): (IA) 20160717.4351506\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (04): (CA) 20160505.4204778\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (03): (WA) 20160430.4191162\nHand foot & mouth disease - USA (02): (CA) coxsackievirus 20160413.4158388\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (CA) fitness club 20160306.4072937\n.................................................sb/lk/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grenada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5125187", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot, & mouth disease update (05): Thailand (SK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5125187", "date": "2016-10-30 12:05:51", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS, GRENADA\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (Northern Mariana Islands)\n[2] Grenada: daycare and preschools\n\n******\n[1] Northern Mariana Islands\nDate: Thu 27 Oct 2016\nSource: Marianas Variety [edited]\nhttp://www.mvariety.com/cnmi/cnmi-news/local/90277-chcc-issues-hand-foot-mouth-disease-advisory\n\n\nCommonwealth Healthcare Corp. [CHCC] Chief Executive Officer Esther Muna says there have been 7 cases of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) confirmed at the Commonwealth Health Center's emergency department in the past month, and 1 case at the hospital's Children's Clinic.\n\nBut there have been no cases identified since 20 Oct 2016, she said.\n\nHFMD is a viral infection that can be spread through close personal contact, coughing or sneezing, contact with feces or sharing of straws, cups, and other contaminated surfaces.\n\nIt is usually a mild, common childhood disease with limited consequences, according to CHCC.\n\n\"The viral illness usually affects infants and children younger than age 5.\n\n\"Of the 8 cases diagnosed at CHC in the last month, 5 or 63 percent were under the age of 5.\"\n\nSometimes adults can get the illness, but this is much less common.\n\nHFMD symptoms include a fever, reduced appetite and sore throat.\n\nOne or 2 days after the fever, painful sores can develop in the mouth (called herpangina). They are usually in the back of the mouth as small red spots that blister and become ulcers. A skin rash with red spots and at times blisters can occur on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet.\n\n\"Not everyone will develop all the symptoms. Some people may show no symptoms but still pass on the virus.\"\n\nAccording to CHCC, \"A person with HFMD is most contagious during the 1st week of illness.\"\n\nThere is no vaccine for HFMD, but members of the public can prevent/reduce their risk of being infected by:\n- Washing their hands often with soap and water.\n- Cleaning and disinfecting touched surfaces including toys.\n- Avoid close contact including kissing, hugging, or sharing utensils/cups with a person suffering from HFMD.\n\n\"For the painful mouth sores, you can use over-the-counter mouthwashes or sprays that numb mouth pain. Take over-the-counter Tylenol or Ibuprofen to relieve pain and fever. Aspirin should not be given to children.\"\n\nCommunity members are advised to stay home if they have HFMD. Talk to your primary care doctor if you are unsure when you should return to work. It also applies to taking children back to school and/or daycare.\n\n[Byline: Bryan Manabat]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Northern Mariana Islands (United States) can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/381. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Grenada: daycare and preschools\nDate: Thu 27 Oct 2016\nSource: Jamaica Observer [edited]\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Health-ministry-confirms-outbreak-of-hand--foot-and-mouth-disease-in-Grenada\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health on Thursday [27 Oct 2016] confirmed reports of an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) at some daycare and preschool centres across the island [Grenada, in the Caribbean].\n\nChief Medical Officer, Dr George Mitchell, says the ministry has received reports of 12 cases and going forward public education and direct intervention will be the main focus.\n\n\"Several education/information brochures relating to the disease are being distributed in electronic and print format to the various institutions,\" Mitchell said in a release.\n\nMedical practitioners have also been reminded that the disease is endemic in Grenada and they need to notify the ministry once a case is diagnosed.\n\nRecords at the Ministry of Health indicate that during the same period last year [2015] there were similar outbreaks of the disease among toddlers.\n\n\"Already, health surveillance and public health teams are gathering information and at the same time responding to reports of mild outbreaks among children at daycare and pre and primary schools.\n\nThe release said while a decision has not been made to close the institutions, health authorities are reminding parents and operators of daycares and kindergartens that frequent hand washing is still the best way of managing the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Grenada can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Grenada: daycare and preschools\nDate: Thu 27 Oct 2016\nSource: Jamaica Observer [edited]\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Health-ministry-confirms-outbreak-of-hand--foot-and-mouth-disease-in-Grenada\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health on Thursday [27 Oct 2016] confirmed reports of an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) at some daycare and preschool centres across the island [Grenada, in the Caribbean].\n\nChief Medical Officer, Dr George Mitchell, says the ministry has received reports of 12 cases and going forward public education and direct intervention will be the main focus.\n\n\"Several education/information brochures relating to the disease are being distributed in electronic and print format to the various institutions,\" Mitchell said in a release.\n\nMedical practitioners have also been reminded that the disease is endemic in Grenada and they need to notify the ministry once a case is diagnosed.\n\nRecords at the Ministry of Health indicate that during the same period last year [2015] there were similar outbreaks of the disease among toddlers.\n\n\"Already, health surveillance and public health teams are gathering information and at the same time responding to reports of mild outbreaks among children at daycare and pre and primary schools.\n\nThe release said while a decision has not been made to close the institutions, health authorities are reminding parents and operators of daycares and kindergartens that frequent hand washing is still the best way of managing the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Grenada can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34. - Mod.LK]\n\n[HFMD is frequently reported, and is generally a mild disease, predominantly of children. It is often caused by coxsackie virus A16, but other enteroviruses may be implicated. Virus spreads quickly in daycare and other such facilities, increasing risk for children in that age group. They usually build up immunity to the virus after being exposed, but older children and adults may become infected. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps can be found at:\nNorthern Mariana Islands [United States]: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/381\nGrenada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34 - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (11): (WI) school 20161024.4581707\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (09): (WI,AZ) 20161007.4542511\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (08): (CT, OH) 20161001.4529788\nHand, foot & mouth disease: St Maarten, USA (CT) 20160922.4508252\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (07): (KS) 20160818.4423843\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (06): (NC, KS) 20160728.4377209\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (05): (IA) 20160717.4351506\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (04): (CA) 20160505.4204778\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (03): (WA) 20160430.4191162\nHand foot & mouth disease - USA (02): (CA) coxsackievirus 20160413.4158388\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (CA) fitness club 20160306.4072937\n.................................................sb/lk/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grenada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4847712", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease update (01): Southeast Asia, UK, USA, Domin. Rep. RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4847712", "date": "2016-10-30 12:05:51", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS, GRENADA\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (Northern Mariana Islands)\n[2] Grenada: daycare and preschools\n\n******\n[1] Northern Mariana Islands\nDate: Thu 27 Oct 2016\nSource: Marianas Variety [edited]\nhttp://www.mvariety.com/cnmi/cnmi-news/local/90277-chcc-issues-hand-foot-mouth-disease-advisory\n\n\nCommonwealth Healthcare Corp. [CHCC] Chief Executive Officer Esther Muna says there have been 7 cases of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) confirmed at the Commonwealth Health Center's emergency department in the past month, and 1 case at the hospital's Children's Clinic.\n\nBut there have been no cases identified since 20 Oct 2016, she said.\n\nHFMD is a viral infection that can be spread through close personal contact, coughing or sneezing, contact with feces or sharing of straws, cups, and other contaminated surfaces.\n\nIt is usually a mild, common childhood disease with limited consequences, according to CHCC.\n\n\"The viral illness usually affects infants and children younger than age 5.\n\n\"Of the 8 cases diagnosed at CHC in the last month, 5 or 63 percent were under the age of 5.\"\n\nSometimes adults can get the illness, but this is much less common.\n\nHFMD symptoms include a fever, reduced appetite and sore throat.\n\nOne or 2 days after the fever, painful sores can develop in the mouth (called herpangina). They are usually in the back of the mouth as small red spots that blister and become ulcers. A skin rash with red spots and at times blisters can occur on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet.\n\n\"Not everyone will develop all the symptoms. Some people may show no symptoms but still pass on the virus.\"\n\nAccording to CHCC, \"A person with HFMD is most contagious during the 1st week of illness.\"\n\nThere is no vaccine for HFMD, but members of the public can prevent/reduce their risk of being infected by:\n- Washing their hands often with soap and water.\n- Cleaning and disinfecting touched surfaces including toys.\n- Avoid close contact including kissing, hugging, or sharing utensils/cups with a person suffering from HFMD.\n\n\"For the painful mouth sores, you can use over-the-counter mouthwashes or sprays that numb mouth pain. Take over-the-counter Tylenol or Ibuprofen to relieve pain and fever. Aspirin should not be given to children.\"\n\nCommunity members are advised to stay home if they have HFMD. Talk to your primary care doctor if you are unsure when you should return to work. It also applies to taking children back to school and/or daycare.\n\n[Byline: Bryan Manabat]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Northern Mariana Islands (United States) can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/381. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Grenada: daycare and preschools\nDate: Thu 27 Oct 2016\nSource: Jamaica Observer [edited]\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Health-ministry-confirms-outbreak-of-hand--foot-and-mouth-disease-in-Grenada\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health on Thursday [27 Oct 2016] confirmed reports of an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) at some daycare and preschool centres across the island [Grenada, in the Caribbean].\n\nChief Medical Officer, Dr George Mitchell, says the ministry has received reports of 12 cases and going forward public education and direct intervention will be the main focus.\n\n\"Several education/information brochures relating to the disease are being distributed in electronic and print format to the various institutions,\" Mitchell said in a release.\n\nMedical practitioners have also been reminded that the disease is endemic in Grenada and they need to notify the ministry once a case is diagnosed.\n\nRecords at the Ministry of Health indicate that during the same period last year [2015] there were similar outbreaks of the disease among toddlers.\n\n\"Already, health surveillance and public health teams are gathering information and at the same time responding to reports of mild outbreaks among children at daycare and pre and primary schools.\n\nThe release said while a decision has not been made to close the institutions, health authorities are reminding parents and operators of daycares and kindergartens that frequent hand washing is still the best way of managing the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Grenada can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34. - USA (11): (WI) school", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4581707", "date": "2016-08-18 13:05:28", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA (07): (KANSAS)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 16 Aug 2016 1:17 PM CDT\nSource: KWCH12 [edited]\nhttp://www.kwch.com/content/news/Wichita-woman-claims-kids-got-hand-foot-and-mouth-at-city-park-390337802.html\n\n\nA Wichita woman says her 5 kids and 10 other kids she knows, all contracted hand-foot-mouth disease while at a city water park.\n\n\"I have 5 kids and they all have it. Each and every one of them,\" said [JW]. \"All of a sudden they got a really high fever, that's the 1st stage of it, a super high fever, and they shake like this, really bad, I mean they shake crazy.\"\n\nShe says her doctor confirmed the disease and told her she got it at a water park. She says 10 other kids, her nieces and nephews, and other friends also got it.\n\n\"Do you see his feet? I mean his skin is peeling. Yeah, this is awful,\" she said talking about her 1-year-old son.\n\nShe believes they all contracted it at Riverside Park's splash pad.\n\n\"This is supposed to be a safe place for kids to play. Not just that, but they're playing in the water and then they're going to the playground and stuff and if they're contaminated with it, then they're touching things and they're contaminating the playground as well,\" said [JW].\n\nWe called the City of Wichita to find out how much it tests and how often it tests the water at Riverside Park. We were told the water is tested every single day and at no time during the time in question was the water anything but safe.\n\n\"From what we have, the information we have, is the water has been treated and is safe,\" said Troy Houtman, the city's Parks and Rec Director.\n\nHoutman says to his knowledge, no one called the city, until we called Tuesday morning [10 Aug 2016], to report a concern.\n\n\"We don't even know for sure if this is where it came from, but we want to double check and make sure and cross all of our t's and dot all of our \"i's\" and make sure that it's safe,\" said Houtman.\n\nAnd that includes testing the playground equipment as well.\n\n[AW] says her kids have had hand-foot-mouth [disease] before, but says she's not worried about the potential disease.\n\n\"It's too late now. If it is in there, they've already been exposed, so we'll just let them have fun,\" said [AW].\n\nBut for [JW] and her kids fun is the furthest from their minds. \"They said it has to pass. They don't give you any medicine. It burns. It blisters on the hands feet and mouth, and in the mouth,\" she said.\n\nIf you have a concern about any of the Wichita parks, contact the Wichita Parks and Recreation Department, by calling (316) 268-4361.\n\n[Byline: Scott Evans]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED-mail posting Hand, foot & mouth disease - If it is in there, they've already been exposed, so we'll just let them have fun,\" said [AW].\n\nBut for [JW] and her kids fun is the furthest from their minds. \"They said it has to pass. They don't give you any medicine. It burns. It blisters on the hands feet and mouth, and in the mouth,\" she said.\n\nIf you have a concern about any of the Wichita parks, contact the Wichita Parks and Recreation Department, by calling (316) 268-4361.\n\n[Byline: Scott Evans]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED-mail posting Hand, foot & mouth disease - USA (10): (IL) University of Illinois", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4574189", "date": "2016-08-18 13:05:28", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA (07): (KANSAS)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 16 Aug 2016 1:17 PM CDT\nSource: KWCH12 [edited]\nhttp://www.kwch.com/content/news/Wichita-woman-claims-kids-got-hand-foot-and-mouth-at-city-park-390337802.html\n\n\nA Wichita woman says her 5 kids and 10 other kids she knows, all contracted hand-foot-mouth disease while at a city water park.\n\n\"I have 5 kids and they all have it. Each and every one of them,\" said [JW]. \"All of a sudden they got a really high fever, that's the 1st stage of it, a super high fever, and they shake like this, really bad, I mean they shake crazy.\"\n\nShe says her doctor confirmed the disease and told her she got it at a water park. She says 10 other kids, her nieces and nephews, and other friends also got it.\n\n\"Do you see his feet? I mean his skin is peeling. Yeah, this is awful,\" she said talking about her 1-year-old son.\n\nShe believes they all contracted it at Riverside Park's splash pad.\n\n\"This is supposed to be a safe place for kids to play. Not just that, but they're playing in the water and then they're going to the playground and stuff and if they're contaminated with it, then they're touching things and they're contaminating the playground as well,\" said [JW].\n\nWe called the City of Wichita to find out how much it tests and how often it tests the water at Riverside Park. We were told the water is tested every single day and at no time during the time in question was the water anything but safe.\n\n\"From what we have, the information we have, is the water has been treated and is safe,\" said Troy Houtman, the city's Parks and Rec Director.\n\nHoutman says to his knowledge, no one called the city, until we called Tuesday morning [10 Aug 2016], to report a concern.\n\n\"We don't even know for sure if this is where it came from, but we want to double check and make sure and cross all of our t's and dot all of our \"i's\" and make sure that it's safe,\" said Houtman.\n\nAnd that includes testing the playground equipment as well.\n\n[AW] says her kids have had hand-foot-mouth [disease] before, but says she's not worried about the potential disease.\n\n\"It's too late now. If it is in there, they've already been exposed, so we'll just let them have fun,\" said [AW].\n\nBut for [JW] and her kids fun is the furthest from their minds. \"They said it has to pass. They don't give you any medicine. It burns. It blisters on the hands feet and mouth, and in the mouth,\" she said.\n\nIf you have a concern about any of the Wichita parks, contact the Wichita Parks and Recreation Department, by calling (316) 268-4361.\n\n[Byline: Scott Evans]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED-mail posting Hand, foot & mouth disease - We were told the water is tested every single day and at no time during the time in question was the water anything but safe.\n\n\"From what we have, the information we have, is the water has been treated and is safe,\" said Troy Houtman, the city's Parks and Rec Director.\n\nHoutman says to his knowledge, no one called the city, until we called Tuesday morning [10 Aug 2016], to report a concern.\n\n\"We don't even know for sure if this is where it came from, but we want to double check and make sure and cross all of our t's and dot all of our \"i's\" and make sure that it's safe,\" said Houtman.\n\nAnd that includes testing the playground equipment as well.\n\n[AW] says her kids have had hand-foot-mouth [disease] before, but says she's not worried about the potential disease.\n\n\"It's too late now. If it is in there, they've already been exposed, so we'll just let them have fun,\" said [AW].\n\nBut for [JW] and her kids fun is the furthest from their minds. \"They said it has to pass. They don't give you any medicine. It burns. St Maarten, USA (CT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4508252", "date": "2016-08-18 13:05:28", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA (07): (KANSAS)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 16 Aug 2016 1:17 PM CDT\nSource: KWCH12 [edited]\nhttp://www.kwch.com/content/news/Wichita-woman-claims-kids-got-hand-foot-and-mouth-at-city-park-390337802.html\n\n\nA Wichita woman says her 5 kids and 10 other kids she knows, all contracted hand-foot-mouth disease while at a city water park.\n\n\"I have 5 kids and they all have it. Each and every one of them,\" said [JW]. \"All of a sudden they got a really high fever, that's the 1st stage of it, a super high fever, and they shake like this, really bad, I mean they shake crazy.\"\n\nShe says her doctor confirmed the disease and told her she got it at a water park. She says 10 other kids, her nieces and nephews, and other friends also got it.\n\n\"Do you see his feet? I mean his skin is peeling. Yeah, this is awful,\" she said talking about her 1-year-old son.\n\nShe believes they all contracted it at Riverside Park's splash pad.\n\n\"This is supposed to be a safe place for kids to play. Not just that, but they're playing in the water and then they're going to the playground and stuff and if they're contaminated with it, then they're touching things and they're contaminating the playground as well,\" said [JW].\n\nWe called the City of Wichita to find out how much it tests and how often it tests the water at Riverside Park. We were told the water is tested every single day and at no time during the time in question was the water anything but safe.\n\n\"From what we have, the information we have, is the water has been treated and is safe,\" said Troy Houtman, the city's Parks and Rec Director.\n\nHoutman says to his knowledge, no one called the city, until we called Tuesday morning [10 Aug 2016], to report a concern.\n\n\"We don't even know for sure if this is where it came from, but we want to double check and make sure and cross all of our t's and dot all of our \"i's\" and make sure that it's safe,\" said Houtman.\n\nAnd that includes testing the playground equipment as well.\n\n[AW] says her kids have had hand-foot-mouth [disease] before, but says she's not worried about the potential disease.\n\n\"It's too late now. If it is in there, they've already been exposed, so we'll just let them have fun,\" said [AW].\n\nBut for [JW] and her kids fun is the furthest from their minds. \"They said it has to pass. They don't give you any medicine. It burns. It blisters on the hands feet and mouth, and in the mouth,\" she said.\n\nIf you have a concern about any of the Wichita parks, contact the Wichita Parks and Recreation Department, by calling (316) 268-4361.\n\n[Byline: Scott Evans]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED-mail posting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Asia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4413599", "date": "2016-06-10 17:16:40", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - SINGAPORE (02)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Jun 2016\nSource: AsiaOne Health\nhttp://health.asiaone.com/health/health-news/hfmd-cases-reported-hits-more-18000\n\n\nHFMD [hand, foot and mouth disease] cases reported exceed 18 000\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nSingapore could be heading for one of its worst hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) outbreaks, with infections hitting near-record numbers over the past few months. The 18 241 infections so far is the 2nd highest for the 1st 21 weeks of a year, exceeded only by the 21 102 in 2012. In contrast, the median number for the 1st 21 weeks over the past 5 years is 8193.\n\nAssociate Professor Chong Chia Yin, senior infectious disease consultant at KK Women's and Children's Hospital, said more than 200 children have been hospitalised at KKH for HFMD this year [2016]. She said: \"Most of these children were admitted for fever and poor feeding, mild dehydration or febrile fits due to their high fever. None suffered serious complications.\"\n\nSerious complications are rare, but the infection could damage the brain, lungs or heart. Symptoms of HFMD include fever, ulcers in the mouth and tongue, blisters on hand, feet and bum, poor appetite and lethargy. A child can get dehydrated from not drinking enough because it hurts to do so.\n\nDuring an outbreak of HFMD in 2000-2001 associated with the more dangerous EV71 strain, there were 7 deaths.\n\nThe current epidemic has been fuelled in part by parents who send their sick kids to childcare centres, and refuse to take them home when asked to. Marjorie Zaccheus, principal of Presbyterian Community Services Tampines Childcare Centre, which has been hit by a spate of cases, said that when she suspects a child has HFMD, she keeps them away from other children and asks their parents to take them home. \"The parents say they are coming but they don't turn up until closing time. Others don't answer the phone,\" said Madam Zaccheus. She said holding full-time jobs is no excuse.\n\nThe children are checked for fever and ulcers or rash when they arrive. But Madam Zaccheus said sometimes, the person bringing the child is not a parent or guardian. \"In these cases, I have to accept them. I have no alternative.\" But the centre, which has 79 children, does not have the resources to effectively quarantine a sick child. It had 20 cases in the last month and a half.\n\n[A parent], 38, whose daughter, aged 3, was one of the 20 infected, said: \"It's irresponsible for parents to leave a sick child here.\" He added: \"Not only is the child already uncomfortable because of the sickness, they would feel lonely and isolated if they have to be separated from the other children.\" Despite the high rates of infection at the centre, many parents have chosen not to keep their children away.\n\nAdults too can get HFMD, and it is usually more severe. [The parent] recalls when his wife caught the infection from their infant son some years back. She was sick in bed for a week with a high fever and had a hard time eating because her mouth was full of ulcers.\n\n[byline: salma@sph.com.sg and rkurohi@sph.com.sg]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See discussion of HFMD in Singapore in ProMED-mail post Hand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20160505.4203981. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/150.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (HC) 20160516.4225752\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20160505.4203981\nHand foot & mouth disease - Australia: (NS) coxsackievirus, corr. 20160413.4158303\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China: (BJ, GX) vaccine 20160329.4124126\n2015\n---\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand (02): alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4388808", "date": "2016-06-10 17:16:40", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - SINGAPORE (02)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Jun 2016\nSource: AsiaOne Health\nhttp://health.asiaone.com/health/health-news/hfmd-cases-reported-hits-more-18000\n\n\nHFMD [hand, foot and mouth disease] cases reported exceed 18 000\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nSingapore could be heading for one of its worst hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) outbreaks, with infections hitting near-record numbers over the past few months. The 18 241 infections so far is the 2nd highest for the 1st 21 weeks of a year, exceeded only by the 21 102 in 2012. In contrast, the median number for the 1st 21 weeks over the past 5 years is 8193.\n\nAssociate Professor Chong Chia Yin, senior infectious disease consultant at KK Women's and Children's Hospital, said more than 200 children have been hospitalised at KKH for HFMD this year [2016]. She said: \"Most of these children were admitted for fever and poor feeding, mild dehydration or febrile fits due to their high fever. None suffered serious complications.\"\n\nSerious complications are rare, but the infection could damage the brain, lungs or heart. Symptoms of HFMD include fever, ulcers in the mouth and tongue, blisters on hand, feet and bum, poor appetite and lethargy. A child can get dehydrated from not drinking enough because it hurts to do so.\n\nDuring an outbreak of HFMD in 2000-2001 associated with the more dangerous EV71 strain, there were 7 deaths.\n\nThe current epidemic has been fuelled in part by parents who send their sick kids to childcare centres, and refuse to take them home when asked to. Marjorie Zaccheus, principal of Presbyterian Community Services Tampines Childcare Centre, which has been hit by a spate of cases, said that when she suspects a child has HFMD, she keeps them away from other children and asks their parents to take them home. \"The parents say they are coming but they don't turn up until closing time. Others don't answer the phone,\" said Madam Zaccheus. She said holding full-time jobs is no excuse.\n\nThe children are checked for fever and ulcers or rash when they arrive. But Madam Zaccheus said sometimes, the person bringing the child is not a parent or guardian. \"In these cases, I have to accept them. I have no alternative.\" But the centre, which has 79 children, does not have the resources to effectively quarantine a sick child. It had 20 cases in the last month and a half.\n\n[A parent], 38, whose daughter, aged 3, was one of the 20 infected, said: \"It's irresponsible for parents to leave a sick child here.\" He added: \"Not only is the child already uncomfortable because of the sickness, they would feel lonely and isolated if they have to be separated from the other children.\" Despite the high rates of infection at the centre, many parents have chosen not to keep their children away.\n\nAdults too can get HFMD, and it is usually more severe. [The parent] recalls when his wife caught the infection from their infant son some years back. She was sick in bed for a week with a high fever and had a hard time eating because her mouth was full of ulcers.\n\n[byline: salma@sph.com.sg and rkurohi@sph.com.sg]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See discussion of HFMD in Singapore in ProMED-mail post Hand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (HK) increased incidence 20131005.1984319\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20130823.1898229\nand other items in the archives\n.................................................sb/lk/je/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-16 00:00:00", "8193-03-16 00:00:00", "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4377209", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - USA (06): (NC, KS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4377209", "date": "2016-06-10 17:16:40", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - SINGAPORE (02)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Jun 2016\nSource: AsiaOne Health\nhttp://health.asiaone.com/health/health-news/hfmd-cases-reported-hits-more-18000\n\n\nHFMD [hand, foot and mouth disease] cases reported exceed 18 000\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nSingapore could be heading for one of its worst hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) outbreaks, with infections hitting near-record numbers over the past few months. The 18 241 infections so far is the 2nd highest for the 1st 21 weeks of a year, exceeded only by the 21 102 in 2012. In contrast, the median number for the 1st 21 weeks over the past 5 years is 8193.\n\nAssociate Professor Chong Chia Yin, senior infectious disease consultant at KK Women's and Children's Hospital, said more than 200 children have been hospitalised at KKH for HFMD this year [2016]. She said: \"Most of these children were admitted for fever and poor feeding, mild dehydration or febrile fits due to their high fever. None suffered serious complications.\"\n\nSerious complications are rare, but the infection could damage the brain, lungs or heart. Symptoms of HFMD include fever, ulcers in the mouth and tongue, blisters on hand, feet and bum, poor appetite and lethargy. A child can get dehydrated from not drinking enough because it hurts to do so.\n\nDuring an outbreak of HFMD in 2000-2001 associated with the more dangerous EV71 strain, there were 7 deaths.\n\nThe current epidemic has been fuelled in part by parents who send their sick kids to childcare centres, and refuse to take them home when asked to. Marjorie Zaccheus, principal of Presbyterian Community Services Tampines Childcare Centre, which has been hit by a spate of cases, said that when she suspects a child has HFMD, she keeps them away from other children and asks their parents to take them home. \"The parents say they are coming but they don't turn up until closing time. Others don't answer the phone,\" said Madam Zaccheus. She said holding full-time jobs is no excuse.\n\nThe children are checked for fever and ulcers or rash when they arrive. But Madam Zaccheus said sometimes, the person bringing the child is not a parent or guardian. \"In these cases, I have to accept them. I have no alternative.\" But the centre, which has 79 children, does not have the resources to effectively quarantine a sick child. It had 20 cases in the last month and a half.\n\n[A parent], 38, whose daughter, aged 3, was one of the 20 infected, said: \"It's irresponsible for parents to leave a sick child here.\" He added: \"Not only is the child already uncomfortable because of the sickness, they would feel lonely and isolated if they have to be separated from the other children.\" Despite the high rates of infection at the centre, many parents have chosen not to keep their children away.\n\nAdults too can get HFMD, and it is usually more severe. [The parent] recalls when his wife caught the infection from their infant son some years back. She was sick in bed for a week with a high fever and had a hard time eating because her mouth was full of ulcers.\n\n[byline: salma@sph.com.sg and rkurohi@sph.com.sg]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See discussion of HFMD in Singapore in ProMED-mail post Hand, foot & mouth disease - In contrast, the median number for the 1st 21 weeks over the past 5 years is 8193.\n\nAssociate Professor Chong Chia Yin, senior infectious disease consultant at KK Women's and Children's Hospital, said more than 200 children have been hospitalised at KKH for HFMD this year [2016]. Others don't answer the phone,\" said Madam Zaccheus. She said holding full-time jobs is no excuse.\n\nThe children are checked for fever and ulcers or rash when they arrive. But Madam Zaccheus said sometimes, the person bringing the child is not a parent or guardian. \"In these cases, I have to accept them. I have no alternative.\" But the centre, which has 79 children, does not have the resources to effectively quarantine a sick child. It had 20 cases in the last month and a half.\n\n[A parent], 38, whose daughter, aged 3, was one of the 20 infected, said: \"It's irresponsible for parents to leave a sick child here.\" He added: \"Not only is the child already uncomfortable because of the sickness, they would feel lonely and isolated if they have to be separated from the other children.\" Despite the high rates of infection at the centre, many parents have chosen not to keep their children away.\n\nAdults too can get HFMD, and it is usually more severe. [The parent] recalls when his wife caught the infection from their infant son some years back. She was sick in bed for a week with a high fever and had a hard time eating because her mouth was full of ulcers.\n\n[byline: salma@sph.com.sg and rkurohi@sph.com.sg]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See discussion of HFMD in Singapore in ProMED-mail post Hand, foot & mouth disease - None suffered serious complications.\"\n\nSerious complications are rare, but the infection could damage the brain, lungs or heart. [The parent] recalls when his wife caught the infection from their infant son some years back. China (03): (HK) increased incidence 20131005.1984319\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20130823.1898229\nand other items in the archives\n.................................................sb/lk/je/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-16 00:00:00", "8193-03-16 00:00:00", "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4295321", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia: alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4295321", "date": "2016-06-10 17:16:40", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - SINGAPORE (02)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Jun 2016\nSource: AsiaOne Health\nhttp://health.asiaone.com/health/health-news/hfmd-cases-reported-hits-more-18000\n\n\nHFMD [hand, foot and mouth disease] cases reported exceed 18 000\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nSingapore could be heading for one of its worst hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) outbreaks, with infections hitting near-record numbers over the past few months. The 18 241 infections so far is the 2nd highest for the 1st 21 weeks of a year, exceeded only by the 21 102 in 2012. In contrast, the median number for the 1st 21 weeks over the past 5 years is 8193.\n\nAssociate Professor Chong Chia Yin, senior infectious disease consultant at KK Women's and Children's Hospital, said more than 200 children have been hospitalised at KKH for HFMD this year [2016]. She said: \"Most of these children were admitted for fever and poor feeding, mild dehydration or febrile fits due to their high fever. None suffered serious complications.\"\n\nSerious complications are rare, but the infection could damage the brain, lungs or heart. Symptoms of HFMD include fever, ulcers in the mouth and tongue, blisters on hand, feet and bum, poor appetite and lethargy. A child can get dehydrated from not drinking enough because it hurts to do so.\n\nDuring an outbreak of HFMD in 2000-2001 associated with the more dangerous EV71 strain, there were 7 deaths.\n\nThe current epidemic has been fuelled in part by parents who send their sick kids to childcare centres, and refuse to take them home when asked to. Marjorie Zaccheus, principal of Presbyterian Community Services Tampines Childcare Centre, which has been hit by a spate of cases, said that when she suspects a child has HFMD, she keeps them away from other children and asks their parents to take them home. \"The parents say they are coming but they don't turn up until closing time. Others don't answer the phone,\" said Madam Zaccheus. She said holding full-time jobs is no excuse.\n\nThe children are checked for fever and ulcers or rash when they arrive. But Madam Zaccheus said sometimes, the person bringing the child is not a parent or guardian. \"In these cases, I have to accept them. I have no alternative.\" But the centre, which has 79 children, does not have the resources to effectively quarantine a sick child. It had 20 cases in the last month and a half.\n\n[A parent], 38, whose daughter, aged 3, was one of the 20 infected, said: \"It's irresponsible for parents to leave a sick child here.\" He added: \"Not only is the child already uncomfortable because of the sickness, they would feel lonely and isolated if they have to be separated from the other children.\" Despite the high rates of infection at the centre, many parents have chosen not to keep their children away.\n\nAdults too can get HFMD, and it is usually more severe. [The parent] recalls when his wife caught the infection from their infant son some years back. She was sick in bed for a week with a high fever and had a hard time eating because her mouth was full of ulcers.\n\n[byline: salma@sph.com.sg and rkurohi@sph.com.sg]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See discussion of HFMD in Singapore in ProMED-mail post Hand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20160505.4203981. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/150.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (HC) 20160516.4225752\nHand, foot & mouth disease - In contrast, the median number for the 1st 21 weeks over the past 5 years is 8193.\n\nAssociate Professor Chong Chia Yin, senior infectious disease consultant at KK Women's and Children's Hospital, said more than 200 children have been hospitalised at KKH for HFMD this year [2016]. China (02): (HK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4237221", "date": "2016-04-12 17:45:16", "main_text": "HAND FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES) COXSACKIEVIRUS\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[There is a correction of this report: Hand foot & mouth disease - Australia: (NS) coxsackievirus, corr. 20160413.4158303]\n\nDate: 12 Apr 2016\nSource: KSBY [edited]\nhttp://www.ksby.com/story/31697033/head-foot-and-mouth-disease-outbreak-on-the-central-coast\n\n\nA variation of coxsackievirus [causing] hand, foot and mouth disease [HFMD] is affecting many local children, doctors say. The airborne virus is highly contagious and causes those affected to develop blisters on their hands, feet, and mouths. These lesions can be accompanied by a fever, sore throat, and severe discomfort. The blisters, which can last up to a week and be quite painful, can make doing everyday activities difficult.\n\n\"She couldn't walk for a couple days because she had so many blisters on her feet,\" says a local mom about her one-year-old daughter. \"So she was in the stroller or in our arms, which was really hard. It's just really hard to see our kid in pain and not really be able to do anything to help them.\"\n\nAlthough people of any age can catch it, the virus is especially common among very young populations. \"Eventually, 100 percent of the children will be exposed to the coxsackievirus virus,\" says Dr. Rene Bravo of Bravo Pediatrics. However, this does not mean all children will develop symptoms. About 20 percent of those exposed to the virus will catch it.\n\nDr. Bravo recommends that children who catch the virus be taken out of school or daycare to prevent the spread of the disease. \"Wait until the blisters heal and no new one shows up, and then you are welcome to come back to daycare,\" says owner of Little Blossoms Daycare and Preschool.\n\nAlthough there is no immediate cure, at-home treatments can be used to make the affected person more comfortable. According to Dr. Bravo, over-the-counter medicines like Tylenol and Advil can help with pain, while calamine lotion can help calm the skin. If you suspect that your child has hand, foot and mouth disease, take a picture on your phone and email it to your pediatrician to save yourself a trip into the doctor's office.\n\n[Byline: Amanda Starrantino]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common human syndrome caused by highly contagious intestinal viruses. HFMD is often confused with foot-and-mouth disease (also called hoof-and-mouth disease), which affects cattle, sheep, and swine. However, the 2 diseases are caused by different viruses and are not related. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by an enterovirus, most commonly coxsackievirus A16. However, other enteroviruses like coxsackievirus A10 or A6 have also been detected in outbreaks. Internationally, enterovirus 71 is another common etiologic agent.\n\nHFMD is highly contagious and is transmitted by nasopharyngeal secretions such as saliva or nasal mucus, by direct contact, or by fecal-oral transmission. Preventive measures include avoiding direct contact with infected individuals (including keeping infected children home from school), proper cleaning of shared utensils, disinfecting contaminated surfaces, and proper hand hygiene. These measures have been shown to be effective in decreasing the transmission of the viruses responsible for HFMD.\n\nA diagnosis usually can be made by the presenting signs and symptoms alone. If the diagnosis is unclear, a throat swab or stool specimen may be taken to identify the virus by culture.\n\nMedications are usually not needed as hand, foot and mouth disease is a viral disease that typically gets better on its own. Currently, there is no specific curative treatment for hand, foot and mouth disease.\n\nReference: Sarma, N (March-April 2013): \"Hand, foot and mouth disease: current scenario and Indian perspective.\" Indian Journal of Dermatology, Venereology, and Leprology 79 (2): 165-175. doi:10.4103/0378-6323.107631. PMID 23442455.\n\nDisease management typically focuses on achieving symptomatic relief. Pain from the sores may be eased with the use of analgesic medications. Infection in older children, adolescents, and adults is typically mild and lasts approximately one week but may occasionally run a longer course. Fever reducers and lukewarm baths can help decrease body temperature.\n\nA minority of individuals with hand, foot and mouth disease may require hospital admission due to uncommon neurologic complications such as inflammation of the brain, inflammation of the meninges, or acute flaccid paralysis. Non-neurologic complications such as inflammation of the heart, fluid in the lungs, or bleeding into the lungs may also occur.\n\nCurrently, there is no vaccine available against coxsackievirus-associated HFMD. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China: (BJ, GX) vaccine 20160329.4124126\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Canada (02): ex Dominican Republic, sups., RFI 20160307.4074052\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Canada: ex Mexico (QR) resort 20160229.4057670\n2015\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (06): (HK) update, children residential home 20151202.3834826\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Oman 20151116.3794098\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02): treatment delay, RFI 20150916.3649429\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (HK) school outbreak 20150927.3674603\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Cambodia 20140424.2427419\n2013\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India: (MH) etiologic agents 20131128.2080891\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia: (SK) 20131009.1992927\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (HK) increased incidence 20131005.1984319\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20130823.1898229\n.................................................sb/uba/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tylenol", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dominican Republic", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4225752", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (HC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4225752", "date": "2016-04-12 17:45:16", "main_text": "HAND FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES) COXSACKIEVIRUS\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[There is a correction of this report: Hand foot & mouth disease - Australia: (NS) coxsackievirus, corr. 20160413.4158303]\n\nDate: 12 Apr 2016\nSource: KSBY [edited]\nhttp://www.ksby.com/story/31697033/head-foot-and-mouth-disease-outbreak-on-the-central-coast\n\n\nA variation of coxsackievirus [causing] hand, foot and mouth disease [HFMD] is affecting many local children, doctors say. The airborne virus is highly contagious and causes those affected to develop blisters on their hands, feet, and mouths. These lesions can be accompanied by a fever, sore throat, and severe discomfort. The blisters, which can last up to a week and be quite painful, can make doing everyday activities difficult.\n\n\"She couldn't walk for a couple days because she had so many blisters on her feet,\" says a local mom about her one-year-old daughter. \"So she was in the stroller or in our arms, which was really hard. It's just really hard to see our kid in pain and not really be able to do anything to help them.\"\n\nAlthough people of any age can catch it, the virus is especially common among very young populations. \"Eventually, 100 percent of the children will be exposed to the coxsackievirus virus,\" says Dr. Rene Bravo of Bravo Pediatrics. However, this does not mean all children will develop symptoms. About 20 percent of those exposed to the virus will catch it.\n\nDr. Bravo recommends that children who catch the virus be taken out of school or daycare to prevent the spread of the disease. \"Wait until the blisters heal and no new one shows up, and then you are welcome to come back to daycare,\" says owner of Little Blossoms Daycare and Preschool.\n\nAlthough there is no immediate cure, at-home treatments can be used to make the affected person more comfortable. According to Dr. Bravo, over-the-counter medicines like Tylenol and Advil can help with pain, while calamine lotion can help calm the skin. If you suspect that your child has hand, foot and mouth disease, take a picture on your phone and email it to your pediatrician to save yourself a trip into the doctor's office.\n\n[Byline: Amanda Starrantino]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common human syndrome caused by highly contagious intestinal viruses. HFMD is often confused with foot-and-mouth disease (also called hoof-and-mouth disease), which affects cattle, sheep, and swine. However, the 2 diseases are caused by different viruses and are not related. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by an enterovirus, most commonly coxsackievirus A16. However, other enteroviruses like coxsackievirus A10 or A6 have also been detected in outbreaks. Internationally, enterovirus 71 is another common etiologic agent.\n\nHFMD is highly contagious and is transmitted by nasopharyngeal secretions such as saliva or nasal mucus, by direct contact, or by fecal-oral transmission. Preventive measures include avoiding direct contact with infected individuals (including keeping infected children home from school), proper cleaning of shared utensils, disinfecting contaminated surfaces, and proper hand hygiene. These measures have been shown to be effective in decreasing the transmission of the viruses responsible for HFMD.\n\nA diagnosis usually can be made by the presenting signs and symptoms alone. If the diagnosis is unclear, a throat swab or stool specimen may be taken to identify the virus by culture.\n\nMedications are usually not needed as hand, foot and mouth disease is a viral disease that typically gets better on its own. Currently, there is no specific curative treatment for hand, foot and mouth disease.\n\nReference: Sarma, N (March-April 2013): \"Hand, foot and mouth disease: current scenario and Indian perspective.\" Indian Journal of Dermatology, Venereology, and Leprology 79 (2): 165-175. doi:10.4103/0378-6323.107631. PMID 23442455.\n\nDisease management typically focuses on achieving symptomatic relief. Pain from the sores may be eased with the use of analgesic medications. Infection in older children, adolescents, and adults is typically mild and lasts approximately one week but may occasionally run a longer course. Fever reducers and lukewarm baths can help decrease body temperature.\n\nA minority of individuals with hand, foot and mouth disease may require hospital admission due to uncommon neurologic complications such as inflammation of the brain, inflammation of the meninges, or acute flaccid paralysis. Non-neurologic complications such as inflammation of the heart, fluid in the lungs, or bleeding into the lungs may also occur.\n\nCurrently, there is no vaccine available against coxsackievirus-associated HFMD. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China: (BJ, GX) vaccine 20160329.4124126\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (HK) increased incidence 20131005.1984319\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20130823.1898229\n.................................................sb/uba/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tylenol", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dominican Republic", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4204778", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - USA (04): (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4204778", "date": "2016-04-12 17:45:16", "main_text": "HAND FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES) COXSACKIEVIRUS\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[There is a correction of this report: Hand foot & mouth disease - Australia: (NS) coxsackievirus, corr. 20160413.4158303]\n\nDate: 12 Apr 2016\nSource: KSBY [edited]\nhttp://www.ksby.com/story/31697033/head-foot-and-mouth-disease-outbreak-on-the-central-coast\n\n\nA variation of coxsackievirus [causing] hand, foot and mouth disease [HFMD] is affecting many local children, doctors say. The airborne virus is highly contagious and causes those affected to develop blisters on their hands, feet, and mouths. These lesions can be accompanied by a fever, sore throat, and severe discomfort. The blisters, which can last up to a week and be quite painful, can make doing everyday activities difficult.\n\n\"She couldn't walk for a couple days because she had so many blisters on her feet,\" says a local mom about her one-year-old daughter. \"So she was in the stroller or in our arms, which was really hard. It's just really hard to see our kid in pain and not really be able to do anything to help them.\"\n\nAlthough people of any age can catch it, the virus is especially common among very young populations. \"Eventually, 100 percent of the children will be exposed to the coxsackievirus virus,\" says Dr. Rene Bravo of Bravo Pediatrics. However, this does not mean all children will develop symptoms. About 20 percent of those exposed to the virus will catch it.\n\nDr. Bravo recommends that children who catch the virus be taken out of school or daycare to prevent the spread of the disease. \"Wait until the blisters heal and no new one shows up, and then you are welcome to come back to daycare,\" says owner of Little Blossoms Daycare and Preschool.\n\nAlthough there is no immediate cure, at-home treatments can be used to make the affected person more comfortable. According to Dr. Bravo, over-the-counter medicines like Tylenol and Advil can help with pain, while calamine lotion can help calm the skin. If you suspect that your child has hand, foot and mouth disease, take a picture on your phone and email it to your pediatrician to save yourself a trip into the doctor's office.\n\n[Byline: Amanda Starrantino]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common human syndrome caused by highly contagious intestinal viruses. HFMD is often confused with foot-and-mouth disease (also called hoof-and-mouth disease), which affects cattle, sheep, and swine. However, the 2 diseases are caused by different viruses and are not related. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by an enterovirus, most commonly coxsackievirus A16. However, other enteroviruses like coxsackievirus A10 or A6 have also been detected in outbreaks. Internationally, enterovirus 71 is another common etiologic agent.\n\nHFMD is highly contagious and is transmitted by nasopharyngeal secretions such as saliva or nasal mucus, by direct contact, or by fecal-oral transmission. Preventive measures include avoiding direct contact with infected individuals (including keeping infected children home from school), proper cleaning of shared utensils, disinfecting contaminated surfaces, and proper hand hygiene. These measures have been shown to be effective in decreasing the transmission of the viruses responsible for HFMD.\n\nA diagnosis usually can be made by the presenting signs and symptoms alone. If the diagnosis is unclear, a throat swab or stool specimen may be taken to identify the virus by culture.\n\nMedications are usually not needed as hand, foot and mouth disease is a viral disease that typically gets better on its own. Currently, there is no specific curative treatment for hand, foot and mouth disease.\n\nReference: Sarma, N (March-April 2013): \"Hand, foot and mouth disease: current scenario and Indian perspective.\" Indian Journal of Dermatology, Venereology, and Leprology 79 (2): 165-175. doi:10.4103/0378-6323.107631. PMID 23442455.\n\nDisease management typically focuses on achieving symptomatic relief. Pain from the sores may be eased with the use of analgesic medications. Infection in older children, adolescents, and adults is typically mild and lasts approximately one week but may occasionally run a longer course. Fever reducers and lukewarm baths can help decrease body temperature.\n\nA minority of individuals with hand, foot and mouth disease may require hospital admission due to uncommon neurologic complications such as inflammation of the brain, inflammation of the meninges, or acute flaccid paralysis. Non-neurologic complications such as inflammation of the heart, fluid in the lungs, or bleeding into the lungs may also occur.\n\nCurrently, there is no vaccine available against coxsackievirus-associated HFMD. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China: (BJ, GX) vaccine 20160329.4124126\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (HK) increased incidence 20131005.1984319\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20130823.1898229\n.................................................sb/uba/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tylenol", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dominican Republic", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4203981", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4203981", "date": "2016-04-12 17:45:16", "main_text": "HAND FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES) COXSACKIEVIRUS\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[There is a correction of this report: Hand foot & mouth disease - Australia: (NS) coxsackievirus, corr. 20160413.4158303]\n\nDate: 12 Apr 2016\nSource: KSBY [edited]\nhttp://www.ksby.com/story/31697033/head-foot-and-mouth-disease-outbreak-on-the-central-coast\n\n\nA variation of coxsackievirus [causing] hand, foot and mouth disease [HFMD] is affecting many local children, doctors say. The airborne virus is highly contagious and causes those affected to develop blisters on their hands, feet, and mouths. These lesions can be accompanied by a fever, sore throat, and severe discomfort. The blisters, which can last up to a week and be quite painful, can make doing everyday activities difficult.\n\n\"She couldn't walk for a couple days because she had so many blisters on her feet,\" says a local mom about her one-year-old daughter. \"So she was in the stroller or in our arms, which was really hard. It's just really hard to see our kid in pain and not really be able to do anything to help them.\"\n\nAlthough people of any age can catch it, the virus is especially common among very young populations. \"Eventually, 100 percent of the children will be exposed to the coxsackievirus virus,\" says Dr. Rene Bravo of Bravo Pediatrics. However, this does not mean all children will develop symptoms. About 20 percent of those exposed to the virus will catch it.\n\nDr. Bravo recommends that children who catch the virus be taken out of school or daycare to prevent the spread of the disease. \"Wait until the blisters heal and no new one shows up, and then you are welcome to come back to daycare,\" says owner of Little Blossoms Daycare and Preschool.\n\nAlthough there is no immediate cure, at-home treatments can be used to make the affected person more comfortable. According to Dr. Bravo, over-the-counter medicines like Tylenol and Advil can help with pain, while calamine lotion can help calm the skin. If you suspect that your child has hand, foot and mouth disease, take a picture on your phone and email it to your pediatrician to save yourself a trip into the doctor's office.\n\n[Byline: Amanda Starrantino]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common human syndrome caused by highly contagious intestinal viruses. HFMD is often confused with foot-and-mouth disease (also called hoof-and-mouth disease), which affects cattle, sheep, and swine. However, the 2 diseases are caused by different viruses and are not related. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by an enterovirus, most commonly coxsackievirus A16. However, other enteroviruses like coxsackievirus A10 or A6 have also been detected in outbreaks. Internationally, enterovirus 71 is another common etiologic agent.\n\nHFMD is highly contagious and is transmitted by nasopharyngeal secretions such as saliva or nasal mucus, by direct contact, or by fecal-oral transmission. Preventive measures include avoiding direct contact with infected individuals (including keeping infected children home from school), proper cleaning of shared utensils, disinfecting contaminated surfaces, and proper hand hygiene. These measures have been shown to be effective in decreasing the transmission of the viruses responsible for HFMD.\n\nA diagnosis usually can be made by the presenting signs and symptoms alone. If the diagnosis is unclear, a throat swab or stool specimen may be taken to identify the virus by culture.\n\nMedications are usually not needed as hand, foot and mouth disease is a viral disease that typically gets better on its own. Currently, there is no specific curative treatment for hand, foot and mouth disease.\n\nReference: Sarma, N (March-April 2013): \"Hand, foot and mouth disease: current scenario and Indian perspective.\" Indian Journal of Dermatology, Venereology, and Leprology 79 (2): 165-175. doi:10.4103/0378-6323.107631. PMID 23442455.\n\nDisease management typically focuses on achieving symptomatic relief. Pain from the sores may be eased with the use of analgesic medications. Infection in older children, adolescents, and adults is typically mild and lasts approximately one week but may occasionally run a longer course. Fever reducers and lukewarm baths can help decrease body temperature.\n\nA minority of individuals with hand, foot and mouth disease may require hospital admission due to uncommon neurologic complications such as inflammation of the brain, inflammation of the meninges, or acute flaccid paralysis. Non-neurologic complications such as inflammation of the heart, fluid in the lungs, or bleeding into the lungs may also occur.\n\nCurrently, there is no vaccine available against coxsackievirus-associated HFMD. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China: (BJ, GX) vaccine 20160329.4124126\nHand, foot & mouth disease -
