The airborne virus is highly contagious and causes those affected to develop blisters on their hands, feet, and mouths. These lesions can be accompanied by a fever, sore throat, and severe discomfort. The blisters, which can last up to a week and be quite painful, can make doing everyday activities difficult.\n\n\"She couldn't walk for a couple days because she had so many blisters on her feet,\" says a local mom about her one-year-old daughter. \"So she was in the stroller or in our arms, which was really hard. It's just really hard to see our kid in pain and not really be able to do anything to help them.\"\n\nAlthough people of any age can catch it, the virus is especially common among very young populations. \"Eventually, 100 percent of the children will be exposed to the coxsackievirus virus,\" says Dr. Rene Bravo of Bravo Pediatrics. However, this does not mean all children will develop symptoms. About 20 percent of those exposed to the virus will catch it.\n\nDr. Bravo recommends that children who catch the virus be taken out of school or daycare to prevent the spread of the disease. \"Wait until the blisters heal and no new one shows up, and then you are welcome to come back to daycare,\" says owner of Little Blossoms Daycare and Preschool.\n\nAlthough there is no immediate cure, at-home treatments can be used to make the affected person more comfortable. According to Dr. Bravo, over-the-counter medicines like Tylenol and Advil can help with pain, while calamine lotion can help calm the skin. If you suspect that your child has hand, foot and mouth disease, take a picture on your phone and email it to your pediatrician to save yourself a trip into the doctor's office.\n\n[Byline: Amanda Starrantino]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common human syndrome caused by highly contagious intestinal viruses. HFMD is often confused with foot-and-mouth disease (also called hoof-and-mouth disease), which affects cattle, sheep, and swine. However, the 2 diseases are caused by different viruses and are not related. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by an enterovirus, most commonly coxsackievirus A16. However, other enteroviruses like coxsackievirus A10 or A6 have also been detected in outbreaks. Internationally, enterovirus 71 is another common etiologic agent.\n\nHFMD is highly contagious and is transmitted by nasopharyngeal secretions such as saliva or nasal mucus, by direct contact, or by fecal-oral transmission. Preventive measures include avoiding direct contact with infected individuals (including keeping infected children home from school), proper cleaning of shared utensils, disinfecting contaminated surfaces, and proper hand hygiene. These measures have been shown to be effective in decreasing the transmission of the viruses responsible for HFMD.\n\nA diagnosis usually can be made by the presenting signs and symptoms alone. If the diagnosis is unclear, a throat swab or stool specimen may be taken to identify the virus by culture.\n\nMedications are usually not needed as hand, foot and mouth disease is a viral disease that typically gets better on its own. Currently, there is no specific curative treatment for hand, foot and mouth disease.\n\nReference: Sarma, N (March-April 2013): \"Hand, foot and mouth disease: current scenario and Indian perspective.\" Indian Journal of Dermatology, Venereology, and Leprology 79 (2): 165-175. doi:10.4103/0378-6323.107631. PMID 23442455.\n\nDisease management typically focuses on achieving symptomatic relief. Pain from the sores may be eased with the use of analgesic medications. Infection in older children, adolescents, and adults is typically mild and lasts approximately one week but may occasionally run a longer course. Fever reducers and lukewarm baths can help decrease body temperature.\n\nA minority of individuals with hand, foot and mouth disease may require hospital admission due to uncommon neurologic complications such as inflammation of the brain, inflammation of the meninges, or acute flaccid paralysis. Non-neurologic complications such as inflammation of the heart, fluid in the lungs, or bleeding into the lungs may also occur.\n\nCurrently, there is no vaccine available against coxsackievirus-associated HFMD. - Australia: (NS) coxsackievirus, corr. 20160413.4158303]\n\nDate: 12 Apr 2016\nSource: KSBY [edited]\nhttp://www.ksby.com/story/31697033/head-foot-and-mouth-disease-outbreak-on-the-central-coast\n\n\nA variation of coxsackievirus [causing] hand, foot and mouth disease [HFMD] is affecting many local children, doctors say. The airborne virus is highly contagious and causes those affected to develop blisters on their hands, feet, and mouths. These lesions can be accompanied by a fever, sore throat, and severe discomfort. The blisters, which can last up to a week and be quite painful, can make doing everyday activities difficult.\n\n\"She couldn't walk for a couple days because she had so many blisters on her feet,\" says a local mom about her one-year-old daughter. \"So she was in the stroller or in our arms, which was really hard. It's just really hard to see our kid in pain and not really be able to do anything to help them.\"\n\nAlthough people of any age can catch it, the virus is especially common among very young populations. \"Eventually, 100 percent of the children will be exposed to the coxsackievirus virus,\" says Dr. Rene Bravo of Bravo Pediatrics. However, this does not mean all children will develop symptoms. About 20 percent of those exposed to the virus will catch it.\n\nDr. Bravo recommends that children who catch the virus be taken out of school or daycare to prevent the spread of the disease. \"Wait until the blisters heal and no new one shows up, and then you are welcome to come back to daycare,\" says owner of Little Blossoms Daycare and Preschool.\n\nAlthough there is no immediate cure, at-home treatments can be used to make the affected person more comfortable. According to Dr. Bravo, over-the-counter medicines like Tylenol and Advil can help with pain, while calamine lotion can help calm the skin. If you suspect that your child has hand, foot and mouth disease, take a picture on your phone and email it to your pediatrician to save yourself a trip into the doctor's office.\n\n[Byline: Amanda Starrantino]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common human syndrome caused by highly contagious intestinal viruses. HFMD is often confused with foot-and-mouth disease (also called hoof-and-mouth disease), which affects cattle, sheep, and swine. However, the 2 diseases are caused by different viruses and are not related. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by an enterovirus, most commonly coxsackievirus A16. However, other enteroviruses like coxsackievirus A10 or A6 have also been detected in outbreaks. Internationally, enterovirus 71 is another common etiologic agent.\n\nHFMD is highly contagious and is transmitted by nasopharyngeal secretions such as saliva or nasal mucus, by direct contact, or by fecal-oral transmission. Preventive measures include avoiding direct contact with infected individuals (including keeping infected children home from school), proper cleaning of shared utensils, disinfecting contaminated surfaces, and proper hand hygiene. These measures have been shown to be effective in decreasing the transmission of the viruses responsible for HFMD.\n\nA diagnosis usually can be made by the presenting signs and symptoms alone. If the diagnosis is unclear, a throat swab or stool specimen may be taken to identify the virus by culture.\n\nMedications are usually not needed as hand, foot and mouth disease is a viral disease that typically gets better on its own. Currently, there is no specific curative treatment for hand, foot and mouth disease.\n\nReference: Sarma, N (March-April 2013): \"Hand, foot and mouth disease: current scenario and Indian perspective.\" Indian Journal of Dermatology, Venereology, and Leprology 79 (2): 165-175. doi:10.4103/0378-6323.107631. PMID 23442455.\n\nDisease management typically focuses on achieving symptomatic relief. Pain from the sores may be eased with the use of analgesic medications. Infection in older children, adolescents, and adults is typically mild and lasts approximately one week but may occasionally run a longer course. Fever reducers and lukewarm baths can help decrease body temperature.\n\nA minority of individuals with hand, foot and mouth disease may require hospital admission due to uncommon neurologic complications such as inflammation of the brain, inflammation of the meninges, or acute flaccid paralysis. Non-neurologic complications such as inflammation of the heart, fluid in the lungs, or bleeding into the lungs may also occur.\n\nCurrently, there is no vaccine available against coxsackievirus-associated HFMD. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China: (BJ, GX) vaccine 20160329.4124126\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Australia: (NS) coxsackievirus, corr.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4158303", "date": "2016-04-12 17:45:16", "main_text": "HAND FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES) COXSACKIEVIRUS\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[There is a correction of this report: Hand foot & mouth disease - Australia: (NS) coxsackievirus, corr. 20160413.4158303]\n\nDate: 12 Apr 2016\nSource: KSBY [edited]\nhttp://www.ksby.com/story/31697033/head-foot-and-mouth-disease-outbreak-on-the-central-coast\n\n\nA variation of coxsackievirus [causing] hand, foot and mouth disease [HFMD] is affecting many local children, doctors say. The airborne virus is highly contagious and causes those affected to develop blisters on their hands, feet, and mouths. These lesions can be accompanied by a fever, sore throat, and severe discomfort. The blisters, which can last up to a week and be quite painful, can make doing everyday activities difficult.\n\n\"She couldn't walk for a couple days because she had so many blisters on her feet,\" says a local mom about her one-year-old daughter. \"So she was in the stroller or in our arms, which was really hard. It's just really hard to see our kid in pain and not really be able to do anything to help them.\"\n\nAlthough people of any age can catch it, the virus is especially common among very young populations. \"Eventually, 100 percent of the children will be exposed to the coxsackievirus virus,\" says Dr. Rene Bravo of Bravo Pediatrics. However, this does not mean all children will develop symptoms. About 20 percent of those exposed to the virus will catch it.\n\nDr. Bravo recommends that children who catch the virus be taken out of school or daycare to prevent the spread of the disease. \"Wait until the blisters heal and no new one shows up, and then you are welcome to come back to daycare,\" says owner of Little Blossoms Daycare and Preschool.\n\nAlthough there is no immediate cure, at-home treatments can be used to make the affected person more comfortable. According to Dr. Bravo, over-the-counter medicines like Tylenol and Advil can help with pain, while calamine lotion can help calm the skin. If you suspect that your child has hand, foot and mouth disease, take a picture on your phone and email it to your pediatrician to save yourself a trip into the doctor's office.\n\n[Byline: Amanda Starrantino]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common human syndrome caused by highly contagious intestinal viruses. HFMD is often confused with foot-and-mouth disease (also called hoof-and-mouth disease), which affects cattle, sheep, and swine. However, the 2 diseases are caused by different viruses and are not related. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by an enterovirus, most commonly coxsackievirus A16. However, other enteroviruses like coxsackievirus A10 or A6 have also been detected in outbreaks. Internationally, enterovirus 71 is another common etiologic agent.\n\nHFMD is highly contagious and is transmitted by nasopharyngeal secretions such as saliva or nasal mucus, by direct contact, or by fecal-oral transmission. Preventive measures include avoiding direct contact with infected individuals (including keeping infected children home from school), proper cleaning of shared utensils, disinfecting contaminated surfaces, and proper hand hygiene. These measures have been shown to be effective in decreasing the transmission of the viruses responsible for HFMD.\n\nA diagnosis usually can be made by the presenting signs and symptoms alone. If the diagnosis is unclear, a throat swab or stool specimen may be taken to identify the virus by culture.\n\nMedications are usually not needed as hand, foot and mouth disease is a viral disease that typically gets better on its own. Currently, there is no specific curative treatment for hand, foot and mouth disease.\n\nReference: Sarma, N (March-April 2013): \"Hand, foot and mouth disease: current scenario and Indian perspective.\" Indian Journal of Dermatology, Venereology, and Leprology 79 (2): 165-175. doi:10.4103/0378-6323.107631. PMID 23442455.\n\nDisease management typically focuses on achieving symptomatic relief. Pain from the sores may be eased with the use of analgesic medications. Infection in older children, adolescents, and adults is typically mild and lasts approximately one week but may occasionally run a longer course. Fever reducers and lukewarm baths can help decrease body temperature.\n\nA minority of individuals with hand, foot and mouth disease may require hospital admission due to uncommon neurologic complications such as inflammation of the brain, inflammation of the meninges, or acute flaccid paralysis. Non-neurologic complications such as inflammation of the heart, fluid in the lungs, or bleeding into the lungs may also occur.\n\nCurrently, there is no vaccine available against coxsackievirus-associated HFMD. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China: (BJ, GX) vaccine 20160329.4124126\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Australia: (NS) coxsackievirus", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4154905", "date": "2016-04-12 17:45:16", "main_text": "HAND FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES) COXSACKIEVIRUS\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[There is a correction of this report: Hand foot & mouth disease - Australia: (NS) coxsackievirus, corr. 20160413.4158303]\n\nDate: 12 Apr 2016\nSource: KSBY [edited]\nhttp://www.ksby.com/story/31697033/head-foot-and-mouth-disease-outbreak-on-the-central-coast\n\n\nA variation of coxsackievirus [causing] hand, foot and mouth disease [HFMD] is affecting many local children, doctors say. The airborne virus is highly contagious and causes those affected to develop blisters on their hands, feet, and mouths. These lesions can be accompanied by a fever, sore throat, and severe discomfort. The blisters, which can last up to a week and be quite painful, can make doing everyday activities difficult.\n\n\"She couldn't walk for a couple days because she had so many blisters on her feet,\" says a local mom about her one-year-old daughter. \"So she was in the stroller or in our arms, which was really hard. It's just really hard to see our kid in pain and not really be able to do anything to help them.\"\n\nAlthough people of any age can catch it, the virus is especially common among very young populations. \"Eventually, 100 percent of the children will be exposed to the coxsackievirus virus,\" says Dr. Rene Bravo of Bravo Pediatrics. However, this does not mean all children will develop symptoms. About 20 percent of those exposed to the virus will catch it.\n\nDr. Bravo recommends that children who catch the virus be taken out of school or daycare to prevent the spread of the disease. \"Wait until the blisters heal and no new one shows up, and then you are welcome to come back to daycare,\" says owner of Little Blossoms Daycare and Preschool.\n\nAlthough there is no immediate cure, at-home treatments can be used to make the affected person more comfortable. According to Dr. Bravo, over-the-counter medicines like Tylenol and Advil can help with pain, while calamine lotion can help calm the skin. If you suspect that your child has hand, foot and mouth disease, take a picture on your phone and email it to your pediatrician to save yourself a trip into the doctor's office.\n\n[Byline: Amanda Starrantino]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common human syndrome caused by highly contagious intestinal viruses. HFMD is often confused with foot-and-mouth disease (also called hoof-and-mouth disease), which affects cattle, sheep, and swine. However, the 2 diseases are caused by different viruses and are not related. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by an enterovirus, most commonly coxsackievirus A16. However, other enteroviruses like coxsackievirus A10 or A6 have also been detected in outbreaks. Internationally, enterovirus 71 is another common etiologic agent.\n\nHFMD is highly contagious and is transmitted by nasopharyngeal secretions such as saliva or nasal mucus, by direct contact, or by fecal-oral transmission. Preventive measures include avoiding direct contact with infected individuals (including keeping infected children home from school), proper cleaning of shared utensils, disinfecting contaminated surfaces, and proper hand hygiene. These measures have been shown to be effective in decreasing the transmission of the viruses responsible for HFMD.\n\nA diagnosis usually can be made by the presenting signs and symptoms alone. If the diagnosis is unclear, a throat swab or stool specimen may be taken to identify the virus by culture.\n\nMedications are usually not needed as hand, foot and mouth disease is a viral disease that typically gets better on its own. Currently, there is no specific curative treatment for hand, foot and mouth disease.\n\nReference: Sarma, N (March-April 2013): \"Hand, foot and mouth disease: current scenario and Indian perspective.\" Indian Journal of Dermatology, Venereology, and Leprology 79 (2): 165-175. doi:10.4103/0378-6323.107631. PMID 23442455.\n\nDisease management typically focuses on achieving symptomatic relief. Pain from the sores may be eased with the use of analgesic medications. Infection in older children, adolescents, and adults is typically mild and lasts approximately one week but may occasionally run a longer course. Fever reducers and lukewarm baths can help decrease body temperature.\n\nA minority of individuals with hand, foot and mouth disease may require hospital admission due to uncommon neurologic complications such as inflammation of the brain, inflammation of the meninges, or acute flaccid paralysis. Non-neurologic complications such as inflammation of the heart, fluid in the lungs, or bleeding into the lungs may also occur.\n\nCurrently, there is no vaccine available against coxsackievirus-associated HFMD. - Bhutan", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4140713", "date": "2015-11-18 14:47:16", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (04): (HONG KONG) SCHOOL OUTBREAKS\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 Nov 2015\nSource: 7th Space Interactive, HKSAR Government report [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/520440/chp_investigates_three_outbreaks_of_hand_foot_and_mouth_disease.html\n\n\nThe [Hong Kong] Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health is today [16 Nov 2015] investigating 3 outbreaks of hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) at 2 secondary schools in Wan Chai District and Central and Western District, and a kindergarten on Lamma Island, and hence appealed to the public to maintain strict personal and environmental hygiene.\n\nThe 1st case involved a secondary school in Wan Chai District affecting 19 male students and a staff member. The affected students, aged from 11 to 17, have developed fever, rash, and vesicles on their hands or feet, as well as oral ulcers, since [23 Oct 2015]. All of them sought medical attention while 1 student required hospitalisation and has been discharged. The nasopharyngeal swab of the hospitalised student tested positive for enterovirus (EV) by the hospital.\n\nThe 2nd case involved a secondary school in Central and Western District affecting 25 male students. The affected students, aged from 14 to 17, have developed similar symptoms since [31 Oct 2015]. All of them sought medical attention but did not require hospitalisation.\n\nThe 3rd case involved a kindergarten on Lamma Island affecting 23 pupils. The affected pupils, 10 boys and 13 girls aged from 3 to 5, have developed similar symptoms since [4 Nov 2015]. All of them sought medical attention but did not require hospitalisation.\n\nAll of the affected persons are now in a stable condition.\n\nOfficers of the CHP have conducted site visits and advised the staff of the schools on necessary infection control and preventive measures. The schools have been put under medical surveillance. Investigations are ongoing.\n\n\"HFMD is common in children and is usually caused by EVs such as coxsackievirus and EV-71. It is clinically characterised by maculopapular rash or vesicular lesions occurring on the palms, soles and other parts of the body such as the buttocks and thighs. Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Sometimes patients present mainly with painful ulcers at the back of the mouth, namely herpangina, without rash on the hands or feet,\" a spokesman for the CHP said.\n\nTo prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures: maintain good air circulation; wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials; keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing; cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly; clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently with diluted household bleach (by adding one part of household bleach containing 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water; children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted; avoid going to overcrowded places; and parents should maintain close communication with schools to let them know the latest situation of the sick children.\n\nThe public may visit the CHP's page on HFMD and EV-71 infection (http://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/16354.html) for more information.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of hand-foot-mouth disease, please see moderator comments in the prior ProMED-mail post Hand, foot & mouth disease - Oman 20151116.3794098. - Mod.ML\n\nMaps of Hong Kong can be seen at http://www.travelchinaguide.com/images/map/hongkong/hongkong-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20140430.2440155\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Cambodia 20140424.2427419\n2013\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India: (MH) etiologic agents 20131128.2080891\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia: (SK) 20131009.1992927\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (HK) increased incidence 20131005.1984319\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20130823.1898229\n2012\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand (02): EV71 fatality 20120727.1217890\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand: (BM) 20120714.1201907\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong ] Centre for Health Protection", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lamma Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4124126", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - China: (BJ, GX) vaccine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4124126", "date": "2015-11-18 14:47:16", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (04): (HONG KONG) SCHOOL OUTBREAKS\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 Nov 2015\nSource: 7th Space Interactive, HKSAR Government report [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/520440/chp_investigates_three_outbreaks_of_hand_foot_and_mouth_disease.html\n\n\nThe [Hong Kong] Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health is today [16 Nov 2015] investigating 3 outbreaks of hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) at 2 secondary schools in Wan Chai District and Central and Western District, and a kindergarten on Lamma Island, and hence appealed to the public to maintain strict personal and environmental hygiene.\n\nThe 1st case involved a secondary school in Wan Chai District affecting 19 male students and a staff member. The affected students, aged from 11 to 17, have developed fever, rash, and vesicles on their hands or feet, as well as oral ulcers, since [23 Oct 2015]. All of them sought medical attention while 1 student required hospitalisation and has been discharged. The nasopharyngeal swab of the hospitalised student tested positive for enterovirus (EV) by the hospital.\n\nThe 2nd case involved a secondary school in Central and Western District affecting 25 male students. The affected students, aged from 14 to 17, have developed similar symptoms since [31 Oct 2015]. All of them sought medical attention but did not require hospitalisation.\n\nThe 3rd case involved a kindergarten on Lamma Island affecting 23 pupils. The affected pupils, 10 boys and 13 girls aged from 3 to 5, have developed similar symptoms since [4 Nov 2015]. All of them sought medical attention but did not require hospitalisation.\n\nAll of the affected persons are now in a stable condition.\n\nOfficers of the CHP have conducted site visits and advised the staff of the schools on necessary infection control and preventive measures. The schools have been put under medical surveillance. Investigations are ongoing.\n\n\"HFMD is common in children and is usually caused by EVs such as coxsackievirus and EV-71. It is clinically characterised by maculopapular rash or vesicular lesions occurring on the palms, soles and other parts of the body such as the buttocks and thighs. Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Sometimes patients present mainly with painful ulcers at the back of the mouth, namely herpangina, without rash on the hands or feet,\" a spokesman for the CHP said.\n\nTo prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures: maintain good air circulation; wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials; keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing; cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly; clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently with diluted household bleach (by adding one part of household bleach containing 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water; children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted; avoid going to overcrowded places; and parents should maintain close communication with schools to let them know the latest situation of the sick children.\n\nThe public may visit the CHP's page on HFMD and EV-71 infection (http://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/16354.html) for more information.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of hand-foot-mouth disease, please see moderator comments in the prior ProMED-mail post Hand, foot & mouth disease - Oman 20151116.3794098. - Mod.ML\n\nMaps of Hong Kong can be seen at http://www.travelchinaguide.com/images/map/hongkong/hongkong-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand (02): EV71 fatality 20120727.1217890\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand: (BM) 20120714.1201907\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong ] Centre for Health Protection", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lamma Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3834826", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - China (06): (HK) update, children residential home", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3834826", "date": "2015-11-18 14:47:16", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (04): (HONG KONG) SCHOOL OUTBREAKS\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 Nov 2015\nSource: 7th Space Interactive, HKSAR Government report [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/520440/chp_investigates_three_outbreaks_of_hand_foot_and_mouth_disease.html\n\n\nThe [Hong Kong] Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health is today [16 Nov 2015] investigating 3 outbreaks of hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) at 2 secondary schools in Wan Chai District and Central and Western District, and a kindergarten on Lamma Island, and hence appealed to the public to maintain strict personal and environmental hygiene.\n\nThe 1st case involved a secondary school in Wan Chai District affecting 19 male students and a staff member. The affected students, aged from 11 to 17, have developed fever, rash, and vesicles on their hands or feet, as well as oral ulcers, since [23 Oct 2015]. All of them sought medical attention while 1 student required hospitalisation and has been discharged. The nasopharyngeal swab of the hospitalised student tested positive for enterovirus (EV) by the hospital.\n\nThe 2nd case involved a secondary school in Central and Western District affecting 25 male students. The affected students, aged from 14 to 17, have developed similar symptoms since [31 Oct 2015]. All of them sought medical attention but did not require hospitalisation.\n\nThe 3rd case involved a kindergarten on Lamma Island affecting 23 pupils. The affected pupils, 10 boys and 13 girls aged from 3 to 5, have developed similar symptoms since [4 Nov 2015]. All of them sought medical attention but did not require hospitalisation.\n\nAll of the affected persons are now in a stable condition.\n\nOfficers of the CHP have conducted site visits and advised the staff of the schools on necessary infection control and preventive measures. The schools have been put under medical surveillance. Investigations are ongoing.\n\n\"HFMD is common in children and is usually caused by EVs such as coxsackievirus and EV-71. It is clinically characterised by maculopapular rash or vesicular lesions occurring on the palms, soles and other parts of the body such as the buttocks and thighs. Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Sometimes patients present mainly with painful ulcers at the back of the mouth, namely herpangina, without rash on the hands or feet,\" a spokesman for the CHP said.\n\nTo prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures: maintain good air circulation; wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials; keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing; cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly; clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently with diluted household bleach (by adding one part of household bleach containing 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water; children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted; avoid going to overcrowded places; and parents should maintain close communication with schools to let them know the latest situation of the sick children.\n\nThe public may visit the CHP's page on HFMD and EV-71 infection (http://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/16354.html) for more information.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of hand-foot-mouth disease, please see moderator comments in the prior ProMED-mail post Hand, foot & mouth disease - Oman 20151116.3794098. - Mod.ML\n\nMaps of Hong Kong can be seen at http://www.travelchinaguide.com/images/map/hongkong/hongkong-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (05): (HK) update, school outbreaks, EV71", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3821764", "date": "2015-11-18 14:47:16", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (04): (HONG KONG) SCHOOL OUTBREAKS\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 Nov 2015\nSource: 7th Space Interactive, HKSAR Government report [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/520440/chp_investigates_three_outbreaks_of_hand_foot_and_mouth_disease.html\n\n\nThe [Hong Kong] Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health is today [16 Nov 2015] investigating 3 outbreaks of hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) at 2 secondary schools in Wan Chai District and Central and Western District, and a kindergarten on Lamma Island, and hence appealed to the public to maintain strict personal and environmental hygiene.\n\nThe 1st case involved a secondary school in Wan Chai District affecting 19 male students and a staff member. The affected students, aged from 11 to 17, have developed fever, rash, and vesicles on their hands or feet, as well as oral ulcers, since [23 Oct 2015]. All of them sought medical attention while 1 student required hospitalisation and has been discharged. The nasopharyngeal swab of the hospitalised student tested positive for enterovirus (EV) by the hospital.\n\nThe 2nd case involved a secondary school in Central and Western District affecting 25 male students. The affected students, aged from 14 to 17, have developed similar symptoms since [31 Oct 2015]. All of them sought medical attention but did not require hospitalisation.\n\nThe 3rd case involved a kindergarten on Lamma Island affecting 23 pupils. The affected pupils, 10 boys and 13 girls aged from 3 to 5, have developed similar symptoms since [4 Nov 2015]. All of them sought medical attention but did not require hospitalisation.\n\nAll of the affected persons are now in a stable condition.\n\nOfficers of the CHP have conducted site visits and advised the staff of the schools on necessary infection control and preventive measures. The schools have been put under medical surveillance. Investigations are ongoing.\n\n\"HFMD is common in children and is usually caused by EVs such as coxsackievirus and EV-71. It is clinically characterised by maculopapular rash or vesicular lesions occurring on the palms, soles and other parts of the body such as the buttocks and thighs. Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Sometimes patients present mainly with painful ulcers at the back of the mouth, namely herpangina, without rash on the hands or feet,\" a spokesman for the CHP said.\n\nTo prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures: maintain good air circulation; wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials; keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing; cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly; clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently with diluted household bleach (by adding one part of household bleach containing 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water; children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted; avoid going to overcrowded places; and parents should maintain close communication with schools to let them know the latest situation of the sick children.\n\nThe public may visit the CHP's page on HFMD and EV-71 infection (http://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/16354.html) for more information.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of hand-foot-mouth disease, please see moderator comments in the prior ProMED-mail post Hand, foot & mouth disease - Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Viet Nam (03): update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3797744", "date": "2015-09-12 18:18:14", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - INDIA: (KARNATAKA) SPREADING\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Sep 2015\nSource: The Times of India [summ., edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bengaluru/Infection-spreads-among-kids-docs-say-dont-worry/articleshow/48909183.cms\n\n\nRamyashree (name changed), age 4, of Vijayanagar [Karnataka state] has been in bed for 2 days with blisters on her feet, arms and mouth and mild fever. She has been spending her days away from friends, school and neighbours as prescribed by her dermatologist. Ramyashree has been diagnosed with hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD), a contagious viral infection.\n\n\"Quite a few children are getting this infection. The pediatrician asked me to keep my child in a separate room and maintain hygiene,\" said the girl's mother. Though several children like Ramyashree are affected by HFMD in the city [Bengaluru (Bangalore)], causing concern among parents -- especially following the spread of messages about it on WhatsApp -- doctors say there's nothing to worry as it is common among kids and an annual phenomenon.\n\n\"Hand, foot and mouth disease is common among young children and is characterized by sores in the mouth and rashes on the hands, feet and buttocks. It is most commonly caused by Coxsackie virus A16. The illness spreads by contact with an infected person. It is mainly breaking out in schools as children come in contact with others in school. In the past few days, I have been seeing around 6 to 7 new cases every day,\" said Dr Ramu DS, pediatric consultant of BGS Hospital.\n\nHe added, \"There is no specific treatment. However, antipyretics can be used for fever and pain. Children should take plenty of fluids. In general, the disease clears up by itself within 7 to 10 days. It is contagious and patients should limit their exposure to others.\"\n\nAllaying fears of its spread, Dr HN Usha, senior pediatrician at St Martha's Hospital, said, \"No. The hand, foot and mouth disease is not spreading like an epidemic. Last year, the number of cases was much more. It is a viral disease so we treat it symptomatically. We give local painkillers as it interferes with feeding in children.\"\n\nEchoing her view, district health officer Rajani M said, \"There is no need to panic. It is essentially a zoonotic disease. Every year, some sporadic cases are seen. The spread of infection depends on maintenance of personal hygiene. There is no vaccine for this infection. But it is not an outbreak. Schools need not be closed. Only the child affected should be kept at home for a week's rest.\"\n\n[Byline: Sreemoyee Chatterjee]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[India has experienced annual outbreaks of HFMD affecting young children, rather than the more extensive outbreaks of illness affecting infants. It is unclear whether this is due to social factors or the prevalent virus. Further information would be appreciated. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap map of Karnataka State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/307]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HK) police recruits 20150829.3609404\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand (02): EV71 fatality 20120727.1217890\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand: (BM) 20120714.1201907\n.................................................sb/cp/je/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Karnataka State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bangkok", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3794098", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Oman", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3794098", "date": "2015-09-12 18:18:14", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - INDIA: (KARNATAKA) SPREADING\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Sep 2015\nSource: The Times of India [summ., edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bengaluru/Infection-spreads-among-kids-docs-say-dont-worry/articleshow/48909183.cms\n\n\nRamyashree (name changed), age 4, of Vijayanagar [Karnataka state] has been in bed for 2 days with blisters on her feet, arms and mouth and mild fever. She has been spending her days away from friends, school and neighbours as prescribed by her dermatologist. Ramyashree has been diagnosed with hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD), a contagious viral infection.\n\n\"Quite a few children are getting this infection. The pediatrician asked me to keep my child in a separate room and maintain hygiene,\" said the girl's mother. Though several children like Ramyashree are affected by HFMD in the city [Bengaluru (Bangalore)], causing concern among parents -- especially following the spread of messages about it on WhatsApp -- doctors say there's nothing to worry as it is common among kids and an annual phenomenon.\n\n\"Hand, foot and mouth disease is common among young children and is characterized by sores in the mouth and rashes on the hands, feet and buttocks. It is most commonly caused by Coxsackie virus A16. The illness spreads by contact with an infected person. It is mainly breaking out in schools as children come in contact with others in school. In the past few days, I have been seeing around 6 to 7 new cases every day,\" said Dr Ramu DS, pediatric consultant of BGS Hospital.\n\nHe added, \"There is no specific treatment. However, antipyretics can be used for fever and pain. Children should take plenty of fluids. In general, the disease clears up by itself within 7 to 10 days. It is contagious and patients should limit their exposure to others.\"\n\nAllaying fears of its spread, Dr HN Usha, senior pediatrician at St Martha's Hospital, said, \"No. The hand, foot and mouth disease is not spreading like an epidemic. Last year, the number of cases was much more. It is a viral disease so we treat it symptomatically. We give local painkillers as it interferes with feeding in children.\"\n\nEchoing her view, district health officer Rajani M said, \"There is no need to panic. It is essentially a zoonotic disease. Every year, some sporadic cases are seen. The spread of infection depends on maintenance of personal hygiene. There is no vaccine for this infection. But it is not an outbreak. Schools need not be closed. Only the child affected should be kept at home for a week's rest.\"\n\n[Byline: Sreemoyee Chatterjee]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[India has experienced annual outbreaks of HFMD affecting young children, rather than the more extensive outbreaks of illness affecting infants. It is unclear whether this is due to social factors or the prevalent virus. Further information would be appreciated. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap map of Karnataka State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/307]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HK) police recruits 20150829.3609404\nHand, foot & mouth disease - The pediatrician asked me to keep my child in a separate room and maintain hygiene,\" said the girl's mother. Though several children like Ramyashree are affected by HFMD in the city [Bengaluru (Bangalore)], causing concern among parents -- especially following the spread of messages about it on WhatsApp -- doctors say there's nothing to worry as it is common among kids and an annual phenomenon.\n\n\"Hand, foot and mouth disease is common among young children and is characterized by sores in the mouth and rashes on the hands, feet and buttocks. However, antipyretics can be used for fever and pain. Children should take plenty of fluids. In general, the disease clears up by itself within 7 to 10 days. It is contagious and patients should limit their exposure to others.\"\n\nAllaying fears of its spread, Dr HN Usha, senior pediatrician at St Martha's Hospital, said, \"No. The hand, foot and mouth disease is not spreading like an epidemic. Last year, the number of cases was much more. It is a viral disease so we treat it symptomatically. We give local painkillers as it interferes with feeding in children.\"\n\nEchoing her view, district health officer Rajani M said, \"There is no need to panic. It is essentially a zoonotic disease. Every year, some sporadic cases are seen. The spread of infection depends on maintenance of personal hygiene. There is no vaccine for this infection. But it is not an outbreak. Schools need not be closed. Only the child affected should be kept at home for a week's rest.\"\n\n[Byline: Sreemoyee Chatterjee]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[India has experienced annual outbreaks of HFMD affecting young children, rather than the more extensive outbreaks of illness affecting infants. She has been spending her days away from friends, school and neighbours as prescribed by her dermatologist. Ramyashree has been diagnosed with hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD), a contagious viral infection.\n\n\"Quite a few children are getting this infection. The pediatrician asked me to keep my child in a separate room and maintain hygiene,\" said the girl's mother. Though several children like Ramyashree are affected by HFMD in the city [Bengaluru (Bangalore)], causing concern among parents -- especially following the spread of messages about it on WhatsApp -- doctors say there's nothing to worry as it is common among kids and an annual phenomenon.\n\n\"Hand, foot and mouth disease is common among young children and is characterized by sores in the mouth and rashes on the hands, feet and buttocks. It is most commonly caused by Coxsackie virus A16. The illness spreads by contact with an infected person. It is mainly breaking out in schools as children come in contact with others in school. In the past few days, I have been seeing around 6 to 7 new cases every day,\" said Dr Ramu DS, pediatric consultant of BGS Hospital.\n\nHe added, \"There is no specific treatment. However, antipyretics can be used for fever and pain. Children should take plenty of fluids. In general, the disease clears up by itself within 7 to 10 days. It is contagious and patients should limit their exposure to others.\"\n\nAllaying fears of its spread, Dr HN Usha, senior pediatrician at St Martha's Hospital, said, \"No. The hand, foot and mouth disease is not spreading like an epidemic. Last year, the number of cases was much more. It is a viral disease so we treat it symptomatically. We give local painkillers as it interferes with feeding in children.\"\n\nEchoing her view, district health officer Rajani M said, \"There is no need to panic. It is essentially a zoonotic disease. Every year, some sporadic cases are seen. The spread of infection depends on maintenance of personal hygiene. There is no vaccine for this infection. But it is not an outbreak. Schools need not be closed. Only the child affected should be kept at home for a week's rest.\"\n\n[Byline: Sreemoyee Chatterjee]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[India has experienced annual outbreaks of HFMD affecting young children, rather than the more extensive outbreaks of illness affecting infants. Philippines (04): increasing incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3663696", "date": "2015-09-12 18:18:14", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - INDIA: (KARNATAKA) SPREADING\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Sep 2015\nSource: The Times of India [summ., edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bengaluru/Infection-spreads-among-kids-docs-say-dont-worry/articleshow/48909183.cms\n\n\nRamyashree (name changed), age 4, of Vijayanagar [Karnataka state] has been in bed for 2 days with blisters on her feet, arms and mouth and mild fever. She has been spending her days away from friends, school and neighbours as prescribed by her dermatologist. Ramyashree has been diagnosed with hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD), a contagious viral infection.\n\n\"Quite a few children are getting this infection. The pediatrician asked me to keep my child in a separate room and maintain hygiene,\" said the girl's mother. Though several children like Ramyashree are affected by HFMD in the city [Bengaluru (Bangalore)], causing concern among parents -- especially following the spread of messages about it on WhatsApp -- doctors say there's nothing to worry as it is common among kids and an annual phenomenon.\n\n\"Hand, foot and mouth disease is common among young children and is characterized by sores in the mouth and rashes on the hands, feet and buttocks. It is most commonly caused by Coxsackie virus A16. The illness spreads by contact with an infected person. It is mainly breaking out in schools as children come in contact with others in school. In the past few days, I have been seeing around 6 to 7 new cases every day,\" said Dr Ramu DS, pediatric consultant of BGS Hospital.\n\nHe added, \"There is no specific treatment. However, antipyretics can be used for fever and pain. Children should take plenty of fluids. In general, the disease clears up by itself within 7 to 10 days. It is contagious and patients should limit their exposure to others.\"\n\nAllaying fears of its spread, Dr HN Usha, senior pediatrician at St Martha's Hospital, said, \"No. The hand, foot and mouth disease is not spreading like an epidemic. Last year, the number of cases was much more. It is a viral disease so we treat it symptomatically. We give local painkillers as it interferes with feeding in children.\"\n\nEchoing her view, district health officer Rajani M said, \"There is no need to panic. It is essentially a zoonotic disease. Every year, some sporadic cases are seen. The spread of infection depends on maintenance of personal hygiene. There is no vaccine for this infection. But it is not an outbreak. Schools need not be closed. Only the child affected should be kept at home for a week's rest.\"\n\n[Byline: Sreemoyee Chatterjee]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[India has experienced annual outbreaks of HFMD affecting young children, rather than the more extensive outbreaks of illness affecting infants. It is unclear whether this is due to social factors or the prevalent virus. Further information would be appreciated. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap map of Karnataka State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/307]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HK) police recruits 20150829.3609404\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02): treatment delay, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3649429", "date": "2015-09-12 18:18:14", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - INDIA: (KARNATAKA) SPREADING\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Sep 2015\nSource: The Times of India [summ., edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bengaluru/Infection-spreads-among-kids-docs-say-dont-worry/articleshow/48909183.cms\n\n\nRamyashree (name changed), age 4, of Vijayanagar [Karnataka state] has been in bed for 2 days with blisters on her feet, arms and mouth and mild fever. She has been spending her days away from friends, school and neighbours as prescribed by her dermatologist. Ramyashree has been diagnosed with hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD), a contagious viral infection.\n\n\"Quite a few children are getting this infection. The pediatrician asked me to keep my child in a separate room and maintain hygiene,\" said the girl's mother. Though several children like Ramyashree are affected by HFMD in the city [Bengaluru (Bangalore)], causing concern among parents -- especially following the spread of messages about it on WhatsApp -- doctors say there's nothing to worry as it is common among kids and an annual phenomenon.\n\n\"Hand, foot and mouth disease is common among young children and is characterized by sores in the mouth and rashes on the hands, feet and buttocks. It is most commonly caused by Coxsackie virus A16. The illness spreads by contact with an infected person. It is mainly breaking out in schools as children come in contact with others in school. In the past few days, I have been seeing around 6 to 7 new cases every day,\" said Dr Ramu DS, pediatric consultant of BGS Hospital.\n\nHe added, \"There is no specific treatment. However, antipyretics can be used for fever and pain. Children should take plenty of fluids. In general, the disease clears up by itself within 7 to 10 days. It is contagious and patients should limit their exposure to others.\"\n\nAllaying fears of its spread, Dr HN Usha, senior pediatrician at St Martha's Hospital, said, \"No. The hand, foot and mouth disease is not spreading like an epidemic. Last year, the number of cases was much more. It is a viral disease so we treat it symptomatically. We give local painkillers as it interferes with feeding in children.\"\n\nEchoing her view, district health officer Rajani M said, \"There is no need to panic. It is essentially a zoonotic disease. Every year, some sporadic cases are seen. The spread of infection depends on maintenance of personal hygiene. There is no vaccine for this infection. But it is not an outbreak. Schools need not be closed. Only the child affected should be kept at home for a week's rest.\"\n\n[Byline: Sreemoyee Chatterjee]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[India has experienced annual outbreaks of HFMD affecting young children, rather than the more extensive outbreaks of illness affecting infants. It is unclear whether this is due to social factors or the prevalent virus. Further information would be appreciated. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap map of Karnataka State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/307]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HK) police recruits 20150829.3609404\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand (02): EV71 fatality 20120727.1217890\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand: (BM) 20120714.1201907\n.................................................sb/cp/je/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Karnataka State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bangkok", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3631251", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Philippines (03): recurrence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3631251", "date": "2015-06-23 18:04:37", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (HONG KONG)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 24 Jun 2015\nSource: 7th Space [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/511377/chp_investigates_hand_foot_and_mouth_disease_outbreak_at_residential_child_care_centre.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health is today (23 Jun 2015) investigating an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) at a residential child care centre in Causeway Bay, and hence appealed to the public to maintain strict personal and environmental hygiene.\n\nThe affected persons comprise 26 children -- 15 boys and 11 girls -- aged from 9 to 35 months, and a staff member. They have developed fever, oral ulcers and rash on their hands or feet since 14 June 2014. All of those affected sought medical attention, while 3 children were admitted to Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital for management, and 2 of them have been discharged. They are all currently in stable condition.\n\nThe rectal swab of an affected child tested positive for enterovirus (EV) upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch. Officers of the CHP have conducted a site visit and advised the staff of the residential child care centre on necessary infection control and preventive measures. The centre has been put under medical surveillance. Investigations are ongoing.\n\n\"HFMD is common in children and is usually caused by EVs such as Coxsackie virus and EV71. It is clinically characterised by maculopapular rash or vesicular lesions occurring on the palms, soles and other parts of the body such as the buttocks and thighs. Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Sometimes patients present mainly with painful ulcers at the back of the mouth, namely herpangina, without rash on the hands or feet,\" a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nTo prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures:\n* Maintain good air circulation;\n* Wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials;\n* Keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing;\n* Cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly;\n* Clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently with diluted household bleach (by adding 1 part of household bleach containing 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water;\n* Children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted;\n* Avoid going to overcrowded places; and\n* Parents should maintain close communication with schools to let them know the latest situation of the sick children.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The WHO Surveillance Summary includes information from countries where transmission of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) occurs and case counts are routinely reported.\n\nNorthern Hemisphere/ China: As of 31 May, there were reported 630 391 cases of HFMD, including 26 deaths in China for 2015. From 1 to 31 May 2015, 304 863 cases of HFMD had been reported, a 42 percent decrease compared with the same period in 2014 (528 777). The number of HFMD cases reported monthly in 2015 is following the seasonal pattern displayed in 2012, 2013 and 2014 (Figure 1). It is likely that the figures for Hong Kong (SARI) follow the same seasonal pattern as elsewhere in China http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/hfmd_biweekly_20150616.pdf?ua=1.\n\nHFMD usually begins with a low-grade fever and general fatigue. A rash of tiny, painful red spots will appear within a couple of days and will soon begin to blister and sometimes form ulcers. These spots may appear:\n- inside the mouth (on the tongue, gums, or cheeks)\n- on the palms of the hands or on the fingers\n- on the soles of the feet or on the toes\n- on the buttocks\n\nThe rash is not generally itchy and, in some cases, may develop on other parts of the body. Lymph nodes in the neck may also become swollen. The virus can cause the throat to feel sore and painful. Rarely, dehydration may occur as the pain due to the blisters in the mouth can make drinking difficult. Infection by EV71 has been known to cause encephalitis or viral meningitis in rare cases.\n\nChildren and adolescents are the most commonly affected people. Adults are rarely infected, although pregnant women who have not been exposed to the virus before have a higher chance of becoming infected. Daycare centres, parks, nursery schools, and other places where children play with each other are potential sites for the infection to be transmitted among children. HFMD is most common in the summer and early fall.\n\nA pregnant woman who is infected may show mild or no signs of illness. If she is infected just before her delivery, the infection can be transmitted to the newborn, resulting in only a mild illness in the baby. Rarely, multiple-organ infections occur.\n\nDuring the acute phase, a person can infect others through secretions from the nose and throat. Discharge due to coughing and sneezing can cause the virus to be transmitted easily. Young children, who tend to drool, can also transmit the infection through their saliva.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease affects mainly children 5 years old and under, is caused by different types of enterovirus and in most forms is normally not severe. However, 1 type of hand, foot, and mouth disease, caused by the virus EV71, can have dramatic effects, including nerve damage, paralysis or death. EV71 also appears to be very pathogenic, and in recent years has caused large and worrying outbreaks in children in Asian countries, especially in China. (https://www.fredhutch.org/en/labs/vaccine-and-infectious-disease/news/publication-spotlight/new_insights_into_hand_foot_and_mouth_disease.html). - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HK) 20140701.2580144\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China: (Beijing) 20140630.2577434\nHerpangina & hand, foot & mouth disease - China: (Beijing) 20140623.2556756\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20140610.2530751\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03) 20140608.2527551\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02) 20140518.2481104\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20140430.2440155\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Cambodia 20140424.2427419\n2013\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India: (MH) etiologic agents 20131128.2080891\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia: (SK) 20131009.1992927\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (HK) increased incidence 20131005.1984319\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20130823.1898229\n2012\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand (02): EV71 fatality 20120727.1217890\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand: (BM) 20120714.1201907\n.................................................sb/cp/pg/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2015-06-23 00:00:00", "2014-06-14 00:00:00", "2021-05-31 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3609404", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HK) police recruits", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3609404", "date": "2015-06-23 18:04:37", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (HONG KONG)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 24 Jun 2015\nSource: 7th Space [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/511377/chp_investigates_hand_foot_and_mouth_disease_outbreak_at_residential_child_care_centre.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health is today (23 Jun 2015) investigating an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) at a residential child care centre in Causeway Bay, and hence appealed to the public to maintain strict personal and environmental hygiene.\n\nThe affected persons comprise 26 children -- 15 boys and 11 girls -- aged from 9 to 35 months, and a staff member. They have developed fever, oral ulcers and rash on their hands or feet since 14 June 2014. All of those affected sought medical attention, while 3 children were admitted to Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital for management, and 2 of them have been discharged. They are all currently in stable condition.\n\nThe rectal swab of an affected child tested positive for enterovirus (EV) upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch. Officers of the CHP have conducted a site visit and advised the staff of the residential child care centre on necessary infection control and preventive measures. The centre has been put under medical surveillance. Investigations are ongoing.\n\n\"HFMD is common in children and is usually caused by EVs such as Coxsackie virus and EV71. It is clinically characterised by maculopapular rash or vesicular lesions occurring on the palms, soles and other parts of the body such as the buttocks and thighs. Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Sometimes patients present mainly with painful ulcers at the back of the mouth, namely herpangina, without rash on the hands or feet,\" a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nTo prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures:\n* Maintain good air circulation;\n* Wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials;\n* Keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing;\n* Cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly;\n* Clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently with diluted household bleach (by adding 1 part of household bleach containing 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water;\n* Children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted;\n* Avoid going to overcrowded places; and\n* Parents should maintain close communication with schools to let them know the latest situation of the sick children.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The WHO Surveillance Summary includes information from countries where transmission of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) occurs and case counts are routinely reported.\n\nNorthern Hemisphere/ China: As of 31 May, there were reported 630 391 cases of HFMD, including 26 deaths in China for 2015. From 1 to 31 May 2015, 304 863 cases of HFMD had been reported, a 42 percent decrease compared with the same period in 2014 (528 777). The number of HFMD cases reported monthly in 2015 is following the seasonal pattern displayed in 2012, 2013 and 2014 (Figure 1). It is likely that the figures for Hong Kong (SARI) follow the same seasonal pattern as elsewhere in China http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/hfmd_biweekly_20150616.pdf?ua=1.\n\nHFMD usually begins with a low-grade fever and general fatigue. A rash of tiny, painful red spots will appear within a couple of days and will soon begin to blister and sometimes form ulcers. These spots may appear:\n- inside the mouth (on the tongue, gums, or cheeks)\n- on the palms of the hands or on the fingers\n- on the soles of the feet or on the toes\n- on the buttocks\n\nThe rash is not generally itchy and, in some cases, may develop on other parts of the body. Lymph nodes in the neck may also become swollen. The virus can cause the throat to feel sore and painful. Rarely, dehydration may occur as the pain due to the blisters in the mouth can make drinking difficult. Infection by EV71 has been known to cause encephalitis or viral meningitis in rare cases.\n\nChildren and adolescents are the most commonly affected people. Adults are rarely infected, although pregnant women who have not been exposed to the virus before have a higher chance of becoming infected. Daycare centres, parks, nursery schools, and other places where children play with each other are potential sites for the infection to be transmitted among children. HFMD is most common in the summer and early fall.\n\nA pregnant woman who is infected may show mild or no signs of illness. If she is infected just before her delivery, the infection can be transmitted to the newborn, resulting in only a mild illness in the baby. Rarely, multiple-organ infections occur.\n\nDuring the acute phase, a person can infect others through secretions from the nose and throat. Discharge due to coughing and sneezing can cause the virus to be transmitted easily. Young children, who tend to drool, can also transmit the infection through their saliva.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease affects mainly children 5 years old and under, is caused by different types of enterovirus and in most forms is normally not severe. However, 1 type of hand, foot, and mouth disease, caused by the virus EV71, can have dramatic effects, including nerve damage, paralysis or death. EV71 also appears to be very pathogenic, and in recent years has caused large and worrying outbreaks in children in Asian countries, especially in China. (https://www.fredhutch.org/en/labs/vaccine-and-infectious-disease/news/publication-spotlight/new_insights_into_hand_foot_and_mouth_disease.html). - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20140610.2530751\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03) 20140608.2527551\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02) 20140518.2481104\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20140430.2440155\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Cambodia 20140424.2427419\n2013\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India: (MH) etiologic agents 20131128.2080891\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia: (SK) 20131009.1992927\nHand, foot & mouth disease -
