Thailand: (BM) 20120714.1201907\n.................................................sb/cp/pg/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2015-06-23 00:00:00", "2014-06-14 00:00:00", "2021-05-31 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3604388", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Philippines (02): alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3604388", "date": "2015-06-23 18:04:37", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (HONG KONG)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 24 Jun 2015\nSource: 7th Space [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/511377/chp_investigates_hand_foot_and_mouth_disease_outbreak_at_residential_child_care_centre.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health is today (23 Jun 2015) investigating an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) at a residential child care centre in Causeway Bay, and hence appealed to the public to maintain strict personal and environmental hygiene.\n\nThe affected persons comprise 26 children -- 15 boys and 11 girls -- aged from 9 to 35 months, and a staff member. They have developed fever, oral ulcers and rash on their hands or feet since 14 June 2014. All of those affected sought medical attention, while 3 children were admitted to Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital for management, and 2 of them have been discharged. They are all currently in stable condition.\n\nThe rectal swab of an affected child tested positive for enterovirus (EV) upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch. Officers of the CHP have conducted a site visit and advised the staff of the residential child care centre on necessary infection control and preventive measures. The centre has been put under medical surveillance. Investigations are ongoing.\n\n\"HFMD is common in children and is usually caused by EVs such as Coxsackie virus and EV71. It is clinically characterised by maculopapular rash or vesicular lesions occurring on the palms, soles and other parts of the body such as the buttocks and thighs. Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Sometimes patients present mainly with painful ulcers at the back of the mouth, namely herpangina, without rash on the hands or feet,\" a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nTo prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures:\n* Maintain good air circulation;\n* Wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials;\n* Keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing;\n* Cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly;\n* Clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently with diluted household bleach (by adding 1 part of household bleach containing 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water;\n* Children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted;\n* Avoid going to overcrowded places; and\n* Parents should maintain close communication with schools to let them know the latest situation of the sick children.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The WHO Surveillance Summary includes information from countries where transmission of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) occurs and case counts are routinely reported.\n\nNorthern Hemisphere/ China: As of 31 May, there were reported 630 391 cases of HFMD, including 26 deaths in China for 2015. From 1 to 31 May 2015, 304 863 cases of HFMD had been reported, a 42 percent decrease compared with the same period in 2014 (528 777). The number of HFMD cases reported monthly in 2015 is following the seasonal pattern displayed in 2012, 2013 and 2014 (Figure 1). It is likely that the figures for Hong Kong (SARI) follow the same seasonal pattern as elsewhere in China http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/hfmd_biweekly_20150616.pdf?ua=1.\n\nHFMD usually begins with a low-grade fever and general fatigue. A rash of tiny, painful red spots will appear within a couple of days and will soon begin to blister and sometimes form ulcers. These spots may appear:\n- inside the mouth (on the tongue, gums, or cheeks)\n- on the palms of the hands or on the fingers\n- on the soles of the feet or on the toes\n- on the buttocks\n\nThe rash is not generally itchy and, in some cases, may develop on other parts of the body. Lymph nodes in the neck may also become swollen. The virus can cause the throat to feel sore and painful. Rarely, dehydration may occur as the pain due to the blisters in the mouth can make drinking difficult. Infection by EV71 has been known to cause encephalitis or viral meningitis in rare cases.\n\nChildren and adolescents are the most commonly affected people. Adults are rarely infected, although pregnant women who have not been exposed to the virus before have a higher chance of becoming infected. Daycare centres, parks, nursery schools, and other places where children play with each other are potential sites for the infection to be transmitted among children. HFMD is most common in the summer and early fall.\n\nA pregnant woman who is infected may show mild or no signs of illness. If she is infected just before her delivery, the infection can be transmitted to the newborn, resulting in only a mild illness in the baby. Rarely, multiple-organ infections occur.\n\nDuring the acute phase, a person can infect others through secretions from the nose and throat. Discharge due to coughing and sneezing can cause the virus to be transmitted easily. Young children, who tend to drool, can also transmit the infection through their saliva.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease affects mainly children 5 years old and under, is caused by different types of enterovirus and in most forms is normally not severe. However, 1 type of hand, foot, and mouth disease, caused by the virus EV71, can have dramatic effects, including nerve damage, paralysis or death. EV71 also appears to be very pathogenic, and in recent years has caused large and worrying outbreaks in children in Asian countries, especially in China. (https://www.fredhutch.org/en/labs/vaccine-and-infectious-disease/news/publication-spotlight/new_insights_into_hand_foot_and_mouth_disease.html). - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - They have developed fever, oral ulcers and rash on their hands or feet since 14 June 2014. All of those affected sought medical attention, while 3 children were admitted to Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital for management, and 2 of them have been discharged. They are all currently in stable condition.\n\nThe rectal swab of an affected child tested positive for enterovirus (EV) upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch. Officers of the CHP have conducted a site visit and advised the staff of the residential child care centre on necessary infection control and preventive measures. The centre has been put under medical surveillance. Investigations are ongoing.\n\n\"HFMD is common in children and is usually caused by EVs such as Coxsackie virus and EV71. It is clinically characterised by maculopapular rash or vesicular lesions occurring on the palms, soles and other parts of the body such as the buttocks and thighs. Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Sometimes patients present mainly with painful ulcers at the back of the mouth, namely herpangina, without rash on the hands or feet,\" a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nTo prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures:\n* Maintain good air circulation;\n* Wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials;\n* Keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing;\n* Cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly;\n* Clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently with diluted household bleach (by adding 1 part of household bleach containing 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water;\n* Children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted;\n* Avoid going to overcrowded places; and\n* Parents should maintain close communication with schools to let them know the latest situation of the sick children.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The WHO Surveillance Summary includes information from countries where transmission of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) occurs and case counts are routinely reported.\n\nNorthern Hemisphere/ China: As of 31 May, there were reported 630 391 cases of HFMD, including 26 deaths in China for 2015. From 1 to 31 May 2015, 304 863 cases of HFMD had been reported, a 42 percent decrease compared with the same period in 2014 (528 777). The number of HFMD cases reported monthly in 2015 is following the seasonal pattern displayed in 2012, 2013 and 2014 (Figure 1). It is likely that the figures for Hong Kong (SARI) follow the same seasonal pattern as elsewhere in China http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/hfmd_biweekly_20150616.pdf?ua=1.\n\nHFMD usually begins with a low-grade fever and general fatigue. A rash of tiny, painful red spots will appear within a couple of days and will soon begin to blister and sometimes form ulcers. These spots may appear:\n- inside the mouth (on the tongue, gums, or cheeks)\n- on the palms of the hands or on the fingers\n- on the soles of the feet or on the toes\n- on the buttocks\n\nThe rash is not generally itchy and, in some cases, may develop on other parts of the body. Lymph nodes in the neck may also become swollen. The virus can cause the throat to feel sore and painful. Rarely, dehydration may occur as the pain due to the blisters in the mouth can make drinking difficult. Thailand: (Bangkok)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3561564", "date": "2015-06-23 18:04:37", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (HONG KONG)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 24 Jun 2015\nSource: 7th Space [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/511377/chp_investigates_hand_foot_and_mouth_disease_outbreak_at_residential_child_care_centre.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health is today (23 Jun 2015) investigating an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) at a residential child care centre in Causeway Bay, and hence appealed to the public to maintain strict personal and environmental hygiene.\n\nThe affected persons comprise 26 children -- 15 boys and 11 girls -- aged from 9 to 35 months, and a staff member. They have developed fever, oral ulcers and rash on their hands or feet since 14 June 2014. All of those affected sought medical attention, while 3 children were admitted to Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital for management, and 2 of them have been discharged. They are all currently in stable condition.\n\nThe rectal swab of an affected child tested positive for enterovirus (EV) upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch. Officers of the CHP have conducted a site visit and advised the staff of the residential child care centre on necessary infection control and preventive measures. The centre has been put under medical surveillance. Investigations are ongoing.\n\n\"HFMD is common in children and is usually caused by EVs such as Coxsackie virus and EV71. It is clinically characterised by maculopapular rash or vesicular lesions occurring on the palms, soles and other parts of the body such as the buttocks and thighs. Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Sometimes patients present mainly with painful ulcers at the back of the mouth, namely herpangina, without rash on the hands or feet,\" a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nTo prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures:\n* Maintain good air circulation;\n* Wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials;\n* Keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing;\n* Cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly;\n* Clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently with diluted household bleach (by adding 1 part of household bleach containing 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water;\n* Children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted;\n* Avoid going to overcrowded places; and\n* Parents should maintain close communication with schools to let them know the latest situation of the sick children.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The WHO Surveillance Summary includes information from countries where transmission of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) occurs and case counts are routinely reported.\n\nNorthern Hemisphere/ China: As of 31 May, there were reported 630 391 cases of HFMD, including 26 deaths in China for 2015. From 1 to 31 May 2015, 304 863 cases of HFMD had been reported, a 42 percent decrease compared with the same period in 2014 (528 777). The number of HFMD cases reported monthly in 2015 is following the seasonal pattern displayed in 2012, 2013 and 2014 (Figure 1). It is likely that the figures for Hong Kong (SARI) follow the same seasonal pattern as elsewhere in China http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/hfmd_biweekly_20150616.pdf?ua=1.\n\nHFMD usually begins with a low-grade fever and general fatigue. A rash of tiny, painful red spots will appear within a couple of days and will soon begin to blister and sometimes form ulcers. These spots may appear:\n- inside the mouth (on the tongue, gums, or cheeks)\n- on the palms of the hands or on the fingers\n- on the soles of the feet or on the toes\n- on the buttocks\n\nThe rash is not generally itchy and, in some cases, may develop on other parts of the body. Lymph nodes in the neck may also become swollen. The virus can cause the throat to feel sore and painful. Rarely, dehydration may occur as the pain due to the blisters in the mouth can make drinking difficult. Infection by EV71 has been known to cause encephalitis or viral meningitis in rare cases.\n\nChildren and adolescents are the most commonly affected people. Adults are rarely infected, although pregnant women who have not been exposed to the virus before have a higher chance of becoming infected. Daycare centres, parks, nursery schools, and other places where children play with each other are potential sites for the infection to be transmitted among children. HFMD is most common in the summer and early fall.\n\nA pregnant woman who is infected may show mild or no signs of illness. If she is infected just before her delivery, the infection can be transmitted to the newborn, resulting in only a mild illness in the baby. Rarely, multiple-organ infections occur.\n\nDuring the acute phase, a person can infect others through secretions from the nose and throat. Discharge due to coughing and sneezing can cause the virus to be transmitted easily. Young children, who tend to drool, can also transmit the infection through their saliva.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease affects mainly children 5 years old and under, is caused by different types of enterovirus and in most forms is normally not severe. However, 1 type of hand, foot, and mouth disease, caused by the virus EV71, can have dramatic effects, including nerve damage, paralysis or death. EV71 also appears to be very pathogenic, and in recent years has caused large and worrying outbreaks in children in Asian countries, especially in China. (https://www.fredhutch.org/en/labs/vaccine-and-infectious-disease/news/publication-spotlight/new_insights_into_hand_foot_and_mouth_disease.html). - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HK) 20140701.2580144\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China: (Beijing) 20140630.2577434\nHerpangina & hand, foot & mouth disease - China: (Beijing) 20140623.2556756\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand: (BM) 20120714.1201907\n.................................................sb/cp/pg/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2015-06-23 00:00:00", "2014-06-14 00:00:00", "2021-05-31 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3543505", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Philippines", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3543505", "date": "2015-06-23 18:04:37", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (HONG KONG)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 24 Jun 2015\nSource: 7th Space [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/511377/chp_investigates_hand_foot_and_mouth_disease_outbreak_at_residential_child_care_centre.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health is today (23 Jun 2015) investigating an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) at a residential child care centre in Causeway Bay, and hence appealed to the public to maintain strict personal and environmental hygiene.\n\nThe affected persons comprise 26 children -- 15 boys and 11 girls -- aged from 9 to 35 months, and a staff member. They have developed fever, oral ulcers and rash on their hands or feet since 14 June 2014. All of those affected sought medical attention, while 3 children were admitted to Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital for management, and 2 of them have been discharged. They are all currently in stable condition.\n\nThe rectal swab of an affected child tested positive for enterovirus (EV) upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch. Officers of the CHP have conducted a site visit and advised the staff of the residential child care centre on necessary infection control and preventive measures. The centre has been put under medical surveillance. Investigations are ongoing.\n\n\"HFMD is common in children and is usually caused by EVs such as Coxsackie virus and EV71. It is clinically characterised by maculopapular rash or vesicular lesions occurring on the palms, soles and other parts of the body such as the buttocks and thighs. Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Sometimes patients present mainly with painful ulcers at the back of the mouth, namely herpangina, without rash on the hands or feet,\" a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nTo prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures:\n* Maintain good air circulation;\n* Wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials;\n* Keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing;\n* Cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly;\n* Clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently with diluted household bleach (by adding 1 part of household bleach containing 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water;\n* Children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted;\n* Avoid going to overcrowded places; and\n* Parents should maintain close communication with schools to let them know the latest situation of the sick children.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The WHO Surveillance Summary includes information from countries where transmission of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) occurs and case counts are routinely reported.\n\nNorthern Hemisphere/ China: As of 31 May, there were reported 630 391 cases of HFMD, including 26 deaths in China for 2015. From 1 to 31 May 2015, 304 863 cases of HFMD had been reported, a 42 percent decrease compared with the same period in 2014 (528 777). The number of HFMD cases reported monthly in 2015 is following the seasonal pattern displayed in 2012, 2013 and 2014 (Figure 1). It is likely that the figures for Hong Kong (SARI) follow the same seasonal pattern as elsewhere in China http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/hfmd_biweekly_20150616.pdf?ua=1.\n\nHFMD usually begins with a low-grade fever and general fatigue. A rash of tiny, painful red spots will appear within a couple of days and will soon begin to blister and sometimes form ulcers. These spots may appear:\n- inside the mouth (on the tongue, gums, or cheeks)\n- on the palms of the hands or on the fingers\n- on the soles of the feet or on the toes\n- on the buttocks\n\nThe rash is not generally itchy and, in some cases, may develop on other parts of the body. Lymph nodes in the neck may also become swollen. The virus can cause the throat to feel sore and painful. Rarely, dehydration may occur as the pain due to the blisters in the mouth can make drinking difficult. Infection by EV71 has been known to cause encephalitis or viral meningitis in rare cases.\n\nChildren and adolescents are the most commonly affected people. Adults are rarely infected, although pregnant women who have not been exposed to the virus before have a higher chance of becoming infected. Daycare centres, parks, nursery schools, and other places where children play with each other are potential sites for the infection to be transmitted among children. HFMD is most common in the summer and early fall.\n\nA pregnant woman who is infected may show mild or no signs of illness. If she is infected just before her delivery, the infection can be transmitted to the newborn, resulting in only a mild illness in the baby. Rarely, multiple-organ infections occur.\n\nDuring the acute phase, a person can infect others through secretions from the nose and throat. Discharge due to coughing and sneezing can cause the virus to be transmitted easily. Young children, who tend to drool, can also transmit the infection through their saliva.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease affects mainly children 5 years old and under, is caused by different types of enterovirus and in most forms is normally not severe. However, 1 type of hand, foot, and mouth disease, caused by the virus EV71, can have dramatic effects, including nerve damage, paralysis or death. EV71 also appears to be very pathogenic, and in recent years has caused large and worrying outbreaks in children in Asian countries, especially in China. (https://www.fredhutch.org/en/labs/vaccine-and-infectious-disease/news/publication-spotlight/new_insights_into_hand_foot_and_mouth_disease.html). - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20140610.2530751\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03) 20140608.2527551\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02) 20140518.2481104\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20140430.2440155\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Cambodia 20140424.2427419\n2013\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India: (MH) etiologic agents 20131128.2080891\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia: (SK) 20131009.1992927\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (HK) increased incidence 20131005.1984319\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20130823.1898229\n2012\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand (02): EV71 fatality 20120727.1217890\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand: (BM) 20120714.1201907\n.................................................sb/cp/pg/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2015-06-23 00:00:00", "2014-06-14 00:00:00", "2021-05-31 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3475303", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. They are all currently in stable condition.\n\nThe rectal swab of an affected child tested positive for enterovirus (EV) upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch. Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Sometimes patients present mainly with painful ulcers at the back of the mouth, namely herpangina, without rash on the hands or feet,\" a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nTo prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures:\n* Maintain good air circulation;\n* Wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials;\n* Keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing;\n* Cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly;\n* Clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently with diluted household bleach (by adding 1 part of household bleach containing 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water;\n* Children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted;\n* Avoid going to overcrowded places; and\n* Parents should maintain close communication with schools to let them know the latest situation of the sick children.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The WHO Surveillance Summary includes information from countries where transmission of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) occurs and case counts are routinely reported.\n\nNorthern Hemisphere/ China: As of 31 May, there were reported 630 391 cases of HFMD, including 26 deaths in China for 2015. From 1 to 31 May 2015, 304 863 cases of HFMD had been reported, a 42 percent decrease compared with the same period in 2014 (528 777). The number of HFMD cases reported monthly in 2015 is following the seasonal pattern displayed in 2012, 2013 and 2014 (Figure 1). It is likely that the figures for Hong Kong (SARI) follow the same seasonal pattern as elsewhere in China http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/hfmd_biweekly_20150616.pdf?ua=1.\n\nHFMD usually begins with a low-grade fever and general fatigue. A rash of tiny, painful red spots will appear within a couple of days and will soon begin to blister and sometimes form ulcers. These spots may appear:\n- inside the mouth (on the tongue, gums, or cheeks)\n- on the palms of the hands or on the fingers\n- on the soles of the feet or on the toes\n- on the buttocks\n\nThe rash is not generally itchy and, in some cases, may develop on other parts of the body. Thailand: (BM) 20120714.1201907\n.................................................sb/cp/pg/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2015-06-23 00:00:00", "2014-06-14 00:00:00", "2021-05-31 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3445720", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore (03): epidemiology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3445720", "date": "2014-07-01 16:31:16", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (02): (HONG KONG)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Jun 2014\nSource: Hong Kong SAR Government [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/462853/two_cases_of_severe_paediatric_enterovirus_infection_under_chp_investigation.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [5 Jun 2014] investigating 2 cases of severe pediatric enterovirus (EV) infection and hence urged the public to stay vigilant.\n\nThe 1st case involved a 2-month-old boy with good past health. He presented with fever and malaise since 2 Jun 2014. He was taken to the Accident and Emergency Department of Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital on 3 Jun 2014 and was admitted on the same day. He is now in stable condition. The clinical diagnosis was encephalitis. His cerebrospinal fluid was tested positive for enterovirus upon preliminary laboratory testing by Prince of Wales Hospital. Initial enquiries by the CHP revealed that the patient had no recent travel history. His home contacts remained asymptomatic. The CHP investigation is continuing.\n\nThe 2nd case involved a 4-year-old boy with good past health. He presented with fever, cough, throat ulcer as well as rash and vesicles over hands and feet since 20 May 2014. He was taken to the Accident and Emergency Department of Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital on 24 May 2014 and was admitted on the same day. He was noted to have increased drowsiness and developed hypotonia on 26 May 2014. He is now in stable condition. The clinical diagnosis was encephalitis. His throat swab tested positive for enterovirus 71 (EV71) upon preliminary laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch. Initial enquiries by the CHP revealed that the patient had no recent travel history. Three of his home contacts had recovered from hand, foot and mouth disease, and the other home contacts remained asymptomatic. The CHP investigation is continuing.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[At least one of these 2 pediatric cases was shown to be caused by enterovirus 71 (EV 71), which may cause a particularly severe form of HFMD with central nervous system manifestations.\n\nAlthough no commercial EV71 vaccine is yet available, a recent publication suggests a vaccine may be in the offing (Li R, Liu L, Mo Z, et al: An inactivated Enterovirus 71 vaccine in healthy children. N Engl J Med 2014; 370:829-837). The abstract is shown below:\n\n\"We conducted a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase 3 trial involving healthy children 6 to 71 months of age in Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, China. Two doses of an inactivated EV71 vaccine or placebo were administered intramuscularly, with a 4-week interval between doses, and children were monitored for up to 11 months. The primary end point was protection against hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by EV71.\n\nA total of 12 000 children were randomly assigned to receive vaccine or placebo. Serum neutralizing antibodies were assessed in 549 children who received the vaccine. The seroconversion rate was 100 percent 4 weeks after the 2 vaccinations, with a geometric mean titer of 170.6. Over the course of 2 epidemic seasons, the vaccine efficacy was 97.4 percent (95 percent confidence interval [CI], 92.9 to 99.0) according to the intention-to-treat analysis and 97.3 percent (95 percent CI, 92.6 to 99.0) according to the per-protocol analysis. Adverse events, such as fever (which occurred in 41.6 percent of the participants who received vaccine vs. 35.2 percent of those who received placebo) were significantly more common in the week after vaccination among children who received the vaccine than among those who received placebo.\" - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China: (Beijing) 20140630.2577434\nHerpangina & hand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore (02): epidemiology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3247661", "date": "2014-07-01 16:31:16", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (02): (HONG KONG)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Jun 2014\nSource: Hong Kong SAR Government [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/462853/two_cases_of_severe_paediatric_enterovirus_infection_under_chp_investigation.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [5 Jun 2014] investigating 2 cases of severe pediatric enterovirus (EV) infection and hence urged the public to stay vigilant.\n\nThe 1st case involved a 2-month-old boy with good past health. He presented with fever and malaise since 2 Jun 2014. He was taken to the Accident and Emergency Department of Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital on 3 Jun 2014 and was admitted on the same day. He is now in stable condition. The clinical diagnosis was encephalitis. His cerebrospinal fluid was tested positive for enterovirus upon preliminary laboratory testing by Prince of Wales Hospital. Initial enquiries by the CHP revealed that the patient had no recent travel history. His home contacts remained asymptomatic. The CHP investigation is continuing.\n\nThe 2nd case involved a 4-year-old boy with good past health. He presented with fever, cough, throat ulcer as well as rash and vesicles over hands and feet since 20 May 2014. He was taken to the Accident and Emergency Department of Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital on 24 May 2014 and was admitted on the same day. He was noted to have increased drowsiness and developed hypotonia on 26 May 2014. He is now in stable condition. The clinical diagnosis was encephalitis. His throat swab tested positive for enterovirus 71 (EV71) upon preliminary laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch. Initial enquiries by the CHP revealed that the patient had no recent travel history. Three of his home contacts had recovered from hand, foot and mouth disease, and the other home contacts remained asymptomatic. The CHP investigation is continuing.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[At least one of these 2 pediatric cases was shown to be caused by enterovirus 71 (EV 71), which may cause a particularly severe form of HFMD with central nervous system manifestations.\n\nAlthough no commercial EV71 vaccine is yet available, a recent publication suggests a vaccine may be in the offing (Li R, Liu L, Mo Z, et al: An inactivated Enterovirus 71 vaccine in healthy children. N Engl J Med 2014; 370:829-837). The abstract is shown below:\n\n\"We conducted a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase 3 trial involving healthy children 6 to 71 months of age in Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, China. Two doses of an inactivated EV71 vaccine or placebo were administered intramuscularly, with a 4-week interval between doses, and children were monitored for up to 11 months. The primary end point was protection against hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by EV71.\n\nA total of 12 000 children were randomly assigned to receive vaccine or placebo. Serum neutralizing antibodies were assessed in 549 children who received the vaccine. The seroconversion rate was 100 percent 4 weeks after the 2 vaccinations, with a geometric mean titer of 170.6. Over the course of 2 epidemic seasons, the vaccine efficacy was 97.4 percent (95 percent confidence interval [CI], 92.9 to 99.0) according to the intention-to-treat analysis and 97.3 percent (95 percent CI, 92.6 to 99.0) according to the per-protocol analysis. Adverse events, such as fever (which occurred in 41.6 percent of the participants who received vaccine vs. 35.2 percent of those who received placebo) were significantly more common in the week after vaccination among children who received the vaccine than among those who received placebo.\" - He presented with fever and malaise since 2 Jun 2014. He was taken to the Accident and Emergency Department of Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital on 3 Jun 2014 and was admitted on the same day. He is now in stable condition. The clinical diagnosis was encephalitis. His cerebrospinal fluid was tested positive for enterovirus upon preliminary laboratory testing by Prince of Wales Hospital. Initial enquiries by the CHP revealed that the patient had no recent travel history. His home contacts remained asymptomatic. N Engl J Med 2014; 370:829-837). The abstract is shown below:\n\n\"We conducted a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase 3 trial involving healthy children 6 to 71 months of age in Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, China. Two doses of an inactivated EV71 vaccine or placebo were administered intramuscularly, with a 4-week interval between doses, and children were monitored for up to 11 months. The primary end point was protection against hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by EV71.\n\nA total of 12 000 children were randomly assigned to receive vaccine or placebo. Serum neutralizing antibodies were assessed in 549 children who received the vaccine. The seroconversion rate was 100 percent 4 weeks after the 2 vaccinations, with a geometric mean titer of 170.6. Over the course of 2 epidemic seasons, the vaccine efficacy was 97.4 percent (95 percent confidence interval [CI], 92.9 to 99.0) according to the intention-to-treat analysis and 97.3 percent (95 percent CI, 92.6 to 99.0) according to the per-protocol analysis. Adverse events, such as fever (which occurred in 41.6 percent of the participants who received vaccine vs. 35.2 percent of those who received placebo) were significantly more common in the week after vaccination among children who received the vaccine than among those who received placebo.\" - The CHP investigation is continuing.\n\nThe 2nd case involved a 4-year-old boy with good past health. He presented with fever, cough, throat ulcer as well as rash and vesicles over hands and feet since 20 May 2014. He was taken to the Accident and Emergency Department of Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital on 24 May 2014 and was admitted on the same day. He was noted to have increased drowsiness and developed hypotonia on 26 May 2014. He is now in stable condition. The clinical diagnosis was encephalitis. His throat swab tested positive for enterovirus 71 (EV71) upon preliminary laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch. Initial enquiries by the CHP revealed that the patient had no recent travel history. Three of his home contacts had recovered from hand, foot and mouth disease, and the other home contacts remained asymptomatic. The CHP investigation is continuing.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[At least one of these 2 pediatric cases was shown to be caused by enterovirus 71 (EV 71), which may cause a particularly severe form of HFMD with central nervous system manifestations.\n\nAlthough no commercial EV71 vaccine is yet available, a recent publication suggests a vaccine may be in the offing (Li R, Liu L, Mo Z, et al: An inactivated Enterovirus 71 vaccine in healthy children. N Engl J Med 2014; 370:829-837). The abstract is shown below:\n\n\"We conducted a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase 3 trial involving healthy children 6 to 71 months of age in Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, China. Two doses of an inactivated EV71 vaccine or placebo were administered intramuscularly, with a 4-week interval between doses, and children were monitored for up to 11 months. The primary end point was protection against hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by EV71.\n\nA total of 12 000 children were randomly assigned to receive vaccine or placebo. Serum neutralizing antibodies were assessed in 549 children who received the vaccine. The seroconversion rate was 100 percent 4 weeks after the 2 vaccinations, with a geometric mean titer of 170.6. Over the course of 2 epidemic seasons, the vaccine efficacy was 97.4 percent (95 percent confidence interval [CI], 92.9 to 99.0) according to the intention-to-treat analysis and 97.3 percent (95 percent CI, 92.6 to 99.0) according to the per-protocol analysis. Adverse events, such as fever (which occurred in 41.6 percent of the participants who received vaccine vs. 35.2 percent of those who received placebo) were significantly more common in the week after vaccination among children who received the vaccine than among those who received placebo.\" - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China: (Beijing) 20140630.2577434\nHerpangina & hand, foot & mouth disease - India: (Mumbai)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2912056", "date": "2014-07-01 16:31:16", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (02): (HONG KONG)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Jun 2014\nSource: Hong Kong SAR Government [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/462853/two_cases_of_severe_paediatric_enterovirus_infection_under_chp_investigation.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [5 Jun 2014] investigating 2 cases of severe pediatric enterovirus (EV) infection and hence urged the public to stay vigilant.\n\nThe 1st case involved a 2-month-old boy with good past health. He presented with fever and malaise since 2 Jun 2014. He was taken to the Accident and Emergency Department of Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital on 3 Jun 2014 and was admitted on the same day. He is now in stable condition. The clinical diagnosis was encephalitis. His cerebrospinal fluid was tested positive for enterovirus upon preliminary laboratory testing by Prince of Wales Hospital. Initial enquiries by the CHP revealed that the patient had no recent travel history. His home contacts remained asymptomatic. The CHP investigation is continuing.\n\nThe 2nd case involved a 4-year-old boy with good past health. He presented with fever, cough, throat ulcer as well as rash and vesicles over hands and feet since 20 May 2014. He was taken to the Accident and Emergency Department of Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital on 24 May 2014 and was admitted on the same day. He was noted to have increased drowsiness and developed hypotonia on 26 May 2014. He is now in stable condition. The clinical diagnosis was encephalitis. His throat swab tested positive for enterovirus 71 (EV71) upon preliminary laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch. Initial enquiries by the CHP revealed that the patient had no recent travel history. Three of his home contacts had recovered from hand, foot and mouth disease, and the other home contacts remained asymptomatic. The CHP investigation is continuing.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[At least one of these 2 pediatric cases was shown to be caused by enterovirus 71 (EV 71), which may cause a particularly severe form of HFMD with central nervous system manifestations.\n\nAlthough no commercial EV71 vaccine is yet available, a recent publication suggests a vaccine may be in the offing (Li R, Liu L, Mo Z, et al: An inactivated Enterovirus 71 vaccine in healthy children. N Engl J Med 2014; 370:829-837). The abstract is shown below:\n\n\"We conducted a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase 3 trial involving healthy children 6 to 71 months of age in Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, China. Two doses of an inactivated EV71 vaccine or placebo were administered intramuscularly, with a 4-week interval between doses, and children were monitored for up to 11 months. The primary end point was protection against hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by EV71.\n\nA total of 12 000 children were randomly assigned to receive vaccine or placebo. Serum neutralizing antibodies were assessed in 549 children who received the vaccine. The seroconversion rate was 100 percent 4 weeks after the 2 vaccinations, with a geometric mean titer of 170.6. Over the course of 2 epidemic seasons, the vaccine efficacy was 97.4 percent (95 percent confidence interval [CI], 92.9 to 99.0) according to the intention-to-treat analysis and 97.3 percent (95 percent CI, 92.6 to 99.0) according to the per-protocol analysis. Adverse events, such as fever (which occurred in 41.6 percent of the participants who received vaccine vs. 35.2 percent of those who received placebo) were significantly more common in the week after vaccination among children who received the vaccine than among those who received placebo.\" - He presented with fever and malaise since 2 Jun 2014. He was taken to the Accident and Emergency Department of Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital on 3 Jun 2014 and was admitted on the same day. He is now in stable condition. The clinical diagnosis was encephalitis. His cerebrospinal fluid was tested positive for enterovirus upon preliminary laboratory testing by Prince of Wales Hospital. Initial enquiries by the CHP revealed that the patient had no recent travel history. His home contacts remained asymptomatic. The CHP investigation is continuing.\n\nThe 2nd case involved a 4-year-old boy with good past health. He presented with fever, cough, throat ulcer as well as rash and vesicles over hands and feet since 20 May 2014. He was taken to the Accident and Emergency Department of Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital on 24 May 2014 and was admitted on the same day. He was noted to have increased drowsiness and developed hypotonia on 26 May 2014. He is now in stable condition. The clinical diagnosis was encephalitis. His throat swab tested positive for enterovirus 71 (EV71) upon preliminary laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch. Initial enquiries by the CHP revealed that the patient had no recent travel history. Three of his home contacts had recovered from hand, foot and mouth disease, and the other home contacts remained asymptomatic. The CHP investigation is continuing.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[At least one of these 2 pediatric cases was shown to be caused by enterovirus 71 (EV 71), which may cause a particularly severe form of HFMD with central nervous system manifestations.\n\nAlthough no commercial EV71 vaccine is yet available, a recent publication suggests a vaccine may be in the offing (Li R, Liu L, Mo Z, et al: An inactivated Enterovirus 71 vaccine in healthy children. N Engl J Med 2014; 370:829-837). The abstract is shown below:\n\n\"We conducted a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase 3 trial involving healthy children 6 to 71 months of age in Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, China. Two doses of an inactivated EV71 vaccine or placebo were administered intramuscularly, with a 4-week interval between doses, and children were monitored for up to 11 months. The primary end point was protection against hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by EV71.\n\nA total of 12 000 children were randomly assigned to receive vaccine or placebo. Serum neutralizing antibodies were assessed in 549 children who received the vaccine. The seroconversion rate was 100 percent 4 weeks after the 2 vaccinations, with a geometric mean titer of 170.6. Adverse events, such as fever (which occurred in 41.6 percent of the participants who received vaccine vs. 35.2 percent of those who received placebo) were significantly more common in the week after vaccination among children who received the vaccine than among those who received placebo.\" - China: (Beijing)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2577434", "date": "2013-11-28 20:39:20", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - INDIA: (MAHARASHTRA) ETIOLOGIC AGENTS\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 23 Nov 2013\nSource: The Times of India, Pune [edited]\nhttp://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-11-23/pune/44389035_1_niv-samples-mouth-ulcers\n\n\nScientists from the [Pune]city-based National Institute of Virology (NIV) have confirmed the presence of enterovirus which, they said, has been causing hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) in children in Pune [Maharashtra state; the city was formerly known as Poona]. The contagious viral illness has been spreading among children below 5 years of age in the last 2 months. Of the 79 samples drawn by the scientists, 40 per cent tested positive for enterovirus.\n\n\"The circulating virus in the city, causing HFMD in infants and children, is enterovirus. The infection caused by the virus is usually mild. Hence, there is no need to panic,\" said senior scientist D T Mourya, director of NIV. The viral infection, benign but irritating, is characterised by painful rashes along with throat [pain] and fever. Coxsackieviruses and enteroviruses are the major causative agents of HFMD in India. This is the 1st time that the Virology Institute investigated HFMD cases in Pune after doctors reported a spurt [of cases] since October [2013]. Earlier, it had carried out HFMD investigations in Kerala, West Bengal, Odisha, Gujarat and Tamil Nadu in 2009-2010. Scientist V Gopalkrishna, Deputy Director of NIV, who spearheaded the HFMD study along with paediatricians, said, \"79 clinical samples comprising throat swabs, rectal swabs, vesicular swabs and blood samples were collected from children below 7 years of age with suspected HFMD in Pune who went to paediatricians' clinics and hospitals for treatment in the last 2 months. Nearly 40 per cent of the samples tested positive for the etiological agent enterovirus. Now, cases are on the decline.\" Paediatricians from Shaishav clinic, Chiranjeev clinic, Bharati Hospital and Ajinkya Hospital from the city were involved in this study with NIV scientists.\n\n\"If a child is not eating and shows loss of appetite and has mouth ulcers, then it is time to consult a doctor,\" said paediatrician Sharad Agarkhedkar. Paediatrician Jayant Navarange, who is part of the NIV study and has been treating kids with HFMD in the last 2 months, said, \"HFMD is contagious. Hence, infected children should stay away from schools till they completely recover,\" he added.\n\n[Byline: Umesh Isalkar]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is a common viral illness that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old. However, it can sometimes occur in adults. Symptoms of HFMD include fever, blister-like sores in the mouth (herpangina) and a skin rash. HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. This group of viruses includes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of HFMD in the United States, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness. Enterovirus 71 has been associated with more severe outbreaks of HFMD (see: http://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/about/index.html).\n\nHFMD is prevalent globally and infects children in all communities. Since normally the infection is mild and of short duration, there has been little incentive to identify the specific etiologic agent. Normally ProMED-mail does not record these outbreaks unless the specific etiologic agent has been identified, or there is some unusual feature. The outbreak in Pune is exceptional in that the etiologic agents have been identified. Curiously the etiologic agent was only identified in less than 40 per cent of cases.\n\nThe Western Pacific Region of WHO routinely publishes data on the incidence of HFMD throughout East Asia (but not India) [see: http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/HFMD/en/]. The most recent update (13 Nov 2013) reported that HFMD is declining. Hong Kong (China), Macao (China), Japan and Republic of Korea (South Korea) have reported a higher cumulative number of cases in 2013 than in 2012 for the same time period. The recent trend, following seasonal patterns, is showing a decrease in China, Hong Kong (China), Macao (China), Japan, Republic of Korea, Singapore and Viet Nam.\n\nChina: Monthly average of cases has decreased from September (183 187 cases and 14 deaths) to October (134 032 cases and 8 deaths) 2013. There were 1 651 959 cases with 265 deaths reported up to the end of October in 2013.\n\nHong Kong (China): Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. Based on the 3 week moving average, weekly trends in hospitalized cases, general practitioners, and general outpatient clinics decreased. In the week 27 Oct to 2 Nov 2013, 4 HFMD inpatients (relative to 5 cases in the same period in 2012) were reported by the Hospital Authority; 0.1 cases per 1000 consultations among general out-patient clinics and 0.9 cases per 1000 consultations among general practitioners.\n\nMacao (China): Weekly trend has decreased based on the 3 week moving average. 19 cases were reported from 29 Oct to 4 Nov 2013 compared with 30 cases in the same period for 2012. The cumulative report for 2013 to the week ending 4 Nov was 2078 cases.\n\nJapan: Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. The weekly trend decreased based on the 3 week moving average. 4071 cases (1.29 cases per sentinel unit) were reported from 14 to 20 Oct 2013 compared with 1998 cases in the same period for 2012. Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 20 Oct was 281 149 cases.\n\nRepublic of Korea (South Korea): Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. The weekly trend is decreasing based on the 3 week moving average; 3.0 cases per 1000 outpatients for the week ending 5 Oct 2013. Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 5 Oct was 6.3 cases per 1000 outpatients.\n\nSingapore: The weekly trend increased based on the 3 week moving average; 914 cases were reported between 27 Oct to 2 Nov 2013 (relative to 265 for the same period in 2012). Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 2 Nov 2013 was 26 473 cases.\n\nViet Nam: The weekly number of reported cases during 7 to 13 Oct 2013 was 1610 relative to 1656 during the previous week. 63 109 cases with 19 deaths have been reported from across 63 provinces up to 13 Oct 2013.\n\nIt is unfortunate that there is so little determination of the etiologic agent(s) involved.\n\nFor further information on the HFMD situation or its surveillance, please visit the following links:\nChina (in Chinese): http://www.moh.gov.cn/wsb/pyqxx/list.shtml\nHong Kong (China): http://www.chp.gov.hk/en/data/1/26/44/292/1303.html\nJapan: http://www.nih.go.jp/niid/en/survaillance-data-table-english.html\nRepublic of Korea: http://www.cdc.go.kr/CDC/info/CdcKrInfo0301.jsp?menuIds=HOME001-MNU0004-MNU0036-MNU0037&q_type=B&q_value=2013\nSingapore: http://www.moh.gov.sg/content/moh_web/home/diseases_and_conditions/h/hfmd.html\nThailand: http://www.boe.moph.go.th/index.php\n- Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1*Oa.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia: (SK) 20131009.1992927\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (HK) increased incidence 20131005.1984319\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Maldives 20130228.1564772\n2011\n----\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Viet Nam (04): HCM 20110613.1804\n2006\n----\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak)(04) 20060319.0854\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak)(03) 20060313.0792\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Brunei 20060308.0744\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) 20060303.0671\n2005\n----\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Taiwan (central) (02) 20050531.1503\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Taiwan (Central) 20050523.1417\n2000\n----\nHand, foot and mouth disease - South Korea: comment 20000615.0969\n.................................................sb/cp/jejw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2078-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "1656-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pune", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kerala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Republic of Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "weekly", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Odisha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gujarat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macao", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2556756", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Herpangina & hand, foot & mouth disease - The contagious viral illness has been spreading among children below 5 years of age in the last 2 months. Of the 79 samples drawn by the scientists, 40 per cent tested positive for enterovirus.\n\n\"The circulating virus in the city, causing HFMD in infants and children, is enterovirus. The infection caused by the virus is usually mild. Hence, there is no need to panic,\" said senior scientist D T Mourya, director of NIV. The viral infection, benign but irritating, is characterised by painful rashes along with throat [pain] and fever. Coxsackieviruses and enteroviruses are the major causative agents of HFMD in India. This is the 1st time that the Virology Institute investigated HFMD cases in Pune after doctors reported a spurt [of cases] since October [2013]. Earlier, it had carried out HFMD investigations in Kerala, West Bengal, Odisha, Gujarat and Tamil Nadu in 2009-2010. Scientist V Gopalkrishna, Deputy Director of NIV, who spearheaded the HFMD study along with paediatricians, said, \"79 clinical samples comprising throat swabs, rectal swabs, vesicular swabs and blood samples were collected from children below 7 years of age with suspected HFMD in Pune who went to paediatricians' clinics and hospitals for treatment in the last 2 months. Nearly 40 per cent of the samples tested positive for the etiological agent enterovirus. Now, cases are on the decline.\" Paediatricians from Shaishav clinic, Chiranjeev clinic, Bharati Hospital and Ajinkya Hospital from the city were involved in this study with NIV scientists.\n\n\"If a child is not eating and shows loss of appetite and has mouth ulcers, then it is time to consult a doctor,\" said paediatrician Sharad Agarkhedkar. Paediatrician Jayant Navarange, who is part of the NIV study and has been treating kids with HFMD in the last 2 months, said, \"HFMD is contagious. Hence, infected children should stay away from schools till they completely recover,\" he added.\n\n[Byline: Umesh Isalkar]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is a common viral illness that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old. However, it can sometimes occur in adults. Symptoms of HFMD include fever, blister-like sores in the mouth (herpangina) and a skin rash. HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. This group of viruses includes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of HFMD in the United States, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness. Enterovirus 71 has been associated with more severe outbreaks of HFMD (see: http://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/about/index.html).\n\nHFMD is prevalent globally and infects children in all communities. Since normally the infection is mild and of short duration, there has been little incentive to identify the specific etiologic agent. Normally ProMED-mail does not record these outbreaks unless the specific etiologic agent has been identified, or there is some unusual feature. The outbreak in Pune is exceptional in that the etiologic agents have been identified. Curiously the etiologic agent was only identified in less than 40 per cent of cases.\n\nThe Western Pacific Region of WHO routinely publishes data on the incidence of HFMD throughout East Asia (but not India) [see: http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/HFMD/en/]. The most recent update (13 Nov 2013) reported that HFMD is declining. Hong Kong (China), Macao (China), Japan and Republic of Korea (South Korea) have reported a higher cumulative number of cases in 2013 than in 2012 for the same time period. The recent trend, following seasonal patterns, is showing a decrease in China, Hong Kong (China), Macao (China), Japan, Republic of Korea, Singapore and Viet Nam.\n\nChina: Monthly average of cases has decreased from September (183 187 cases and 14 deaths) to October (134 032 cases and 8 deaths) 2013. There were 1 651 959 cases with 265 deaths reported up to the end of October in 2013.\n\nHong Kong (China): Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. Based on the 3 week moving average, weekly trends in hospitalized cases, general practitioners, and general outpatient clinics decreased. In the week 27 Oct to 2 Nov 2013, 4 HFMD inpatients (relative to 5 cases in the same period in 2012) were reported by the Hospital Authority; 0.1 cases per 1000 consultations among general out-patient clinics and 0.9 cases per 1000 consultations among general practitioners.\n\nMacao (China): Weekly trend has decreased based on the 3 week moving average. 19 cases were reported from 29 Oct to 4 Nov 2013 compared with 30 cases in the same period for 2012. The cumulative report for 2013 to the week ending 4 Nov was 2078 cases.\n\nJapan: Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. The weekly trend decreased based on the 3 week moving average. 4071 cases (1.29 cases per sentinel unit) were reported from 14 to 20 Oct 2013 compared with 1998 cases in the same period for 2012. Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 20 Oct was 281 149 cases.\n\nRepublic of Korea (South Korea): Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. The weekly trend is decreasing based on the 3 week moving average; 3.0 cases per 1000 outpatients for the week ending 5 Oct 2013. Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 5 Oct was 6.3 cases per 1000 outpatients.\n\nSingapore: The weekly trend increased based on the 3 week moving average; 914 cases were reported between 27 Oct to 2 Nov 2013 (relative to 265 for the same period in 2012). Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 2 Nov 2013 was 26 473 cases.\n\nViet Nam: The weekly number of reported cases during 7 to 13 Oct 2013 was 1610 relative to 1656 during the previous week. 63 109 cases with 19 deaths have been reported from across 63 provinces up to 13 Oct 2013.\n\nIt is unfortunate that there is so little determination of the etiologic agent(s) involved.\n\nFor further information on the HFMD situation or its surveillance, please visit the following links:\nChina (in Chinese): http://www.moh.gov.cn/wsb/pyqxx/list.shtml\nHong Kong (China): http://www.chp.gov.hk/en/data/1/26/44/292/1303.html\nJapan: http://www.nih.go.jp/niid/en/survaillance-data-table-english.html\nRepublic of Korea: http://www.cdc.go.kr/CDC/info/CdcKrInfo0301.jsp?menuIds=HOME001-MNU0004-MNU0036-MNU0037&q_type=B&q_value=2013\nSingapore: http://www.moh.gov.sg/content/moh_web/home/diseases_and_conditions/h/hfmd.html\nThailand: http://www.boe.moph.go.th/index.php\n- Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1*Oa.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia: (SK) 20131009.1992927\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (HK) increased incidence 20131005.1984319\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Maldives 20130228.1564772\n2011\n----\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Viet Nam (04): HCM 20110613.1804\n2006\n----\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak)(04) 20060319.0854\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak)(03) 20060313.0792\nHand, foot and mouth disease - South Korea: comment 20000615.0969\n.................................................sb/cp/jejw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2078-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "1656-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pune", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kerala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Republic of Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "weekly", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Odisha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gujarat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macao", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2530751", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2530751", "date": "2013-11-28 20:39:20", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - INDIA: (MAHARASHTRA) ETIOLOGIC AGENTS\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 23 Nov 2013\nSource: The Times of India, Pune [edited]\nhttp://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-11-23/pune/44389035_1_niv-samples-mouth-ulcers\n\n\nScientists from the [Pune]city-based National Institute of Virology (NIV) have confirmed the presence of enterovirus which, they said, has been causing hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) in children in Pune [Maharashtra state; the city was formerly known as Poona]. The contagious viral illness has been spreading among children below 5 years of age in the last 2 months. Of the 79 samples drawn by the scientists, 40 per cent tested positive for enterovirus.\n\n\"The circulating virus in the city, causing HFMD in infants and children, is enterovirus. The infection caused by the virus is usually mild. Hence, there is no need to panic,\" said senior scientist D T Mourya, director of NIV. The viral infection, benign but irritating, is characterised by painful rashes along with throat [pain] and fever. Coxsackieviruses and enteroviruses are the major causative agents of HFMD in India. This is the 1st time that the Virology Institute investigated HFMD cases in Pune after doctors reported a spurt [of cases] since October [2013]. Earlier, it had carried out HFMD investigations in Kerala, West Bengal, Odisha, Gujarat and Tamil Nadu in 2009-2010. Scientist V Gopalkrishna, Deputy Director of NIV, who spearheaded the HFMD study along with paediatricians, said, \"79 clinical samples comprising throat swabs, rectal swabs, vesicular swabs and blood samples were collected from children below 7 years of age with suspected HFMD in Pune who went to paediatricians' clinics and hospitals for treatment in the last 2 months. Nearly 40 per cent of the samples tested positive for the etiological agent enterovirus. Now, cases are on the decline.\" Paediatricians from Shaishav clinic, Chiranjeev clinic, Bharati Hospital and Ajinkya Hospital from the city were involved in this study with NIV scientists.\n\n\"If a child is not eating and shows loss of appetite and has mouth ulcers, then it is time to consult a doctor,\" said paediatrician Sharad Agarkhedkar. Paediatrician Jayant Navarange, who is part of the NIV study and has been treating kids with HFMD in the last 2 months, said, \"HFMD is contagious. Hence, infected children should stay away from schools till they completely recover,\" he added.\n\n[Byline: Umesh Isalkar]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is a common viral illness that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old. However, it can sometimes occur in adults. Symptoms of HFMD include fever, blister-like sores in the mouth (herpangina) and a skin rash. HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. This group of viruses includes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of HFMD in the United States, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness. Enterovirus 71 has been associated with more severe outbreaks of HFMD (see: http://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/about/index.html).\n\nHFMD is prevalent globally and infects children in all communities. Since normally the infection is mild and of short duration, there has been little incentive to identify the specific etiologic agent. Normally ProMED-mail does not record these outbreaks unless the specific etiologic agent has been identified, or there is some unusual feature. The outbreak in Pune is exceptional in that the etiologic agents have been identified. Curiously the etiologic agent was only identified in less than 40 per cent of cases.\n\nThe Western Pacific Region of WHO routinely publishes data on the incidence of HFMD throughout East Asia (but not India) [see: http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/HFMD/en/]. The most recent update (13 Nov 2013) reported that HFMD is declining. Hong Kong (China), Macao (China), Japan and Republic of Korea (South Korea) have reported a higher cumulative number of cases in 2013 than in 2012 for the same time period. The recent trend, following seasonal patterns, is showing a decrease in China, Hong Kong (China), Macao (China), Japan, Republic of Korea, Singapore and Viet Nam.\n\nChina: Monthly average of cases has decreased from September (183 187 cases and 14 deaths) to October (134 032 cases and 8 deaths) 2013. There were 1 651 959 cases with 265 deaths reported up to the end of October in 2013.\n\nHong Kong (China): Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. Based on the 3 week moving average, weekly trends in hospitalized cases, general practitioners, and general outpatient clinics decreased. In the week 27 Oct to 2 Nov 2013, 4 HFMD inpatients (relative to 5 cases in the same period in 2012) were reported by the Hospital Authority; 0.1 cases per 1000 consultations among general out-patient clinics and 0.9 cases per 1000 consultations among general practitioners.\n\nMacao (China): Weekly trend has decreased based on the 3 week moving average. 19 cases were reported from 29 Oct to 4 Nov 2013 compared with 30 cases in the same period for 2012. The cumulative report for 2013 to the week ending 4 Nov was 2078 cases.\n\nJapan: Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. The weekly trend decreased based on the 3 week moving average. 4071 cases (1.29 cases per sentinel unit) were reported from 14 to 20 Oct 2013 compared with 1998 cases in the same period for 2012. Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 20 Oct was 281 149 cases.\n\nRepublic of Korea (South Korea): Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. The weekly trend is decreasing based on the 3 week moving average; 3.0 cases per 1000 outpatients for the week ending 5 Oct 2013. Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 5 Oct was 6.3 cases per 1000 outpatients.\n\nSingapore: The weekly trend increased based on the 3 week moving average; 914 cases were reported between 27 Oct to 2 Nov 2013 (relative to 265 for the same period in 2012). Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 2 Nov 2013 was 26 473 cases.\n\nViet Nam: The weekly number of reported cases during 7 to 13 Oct 2013 was 1610 relative to 1656 during the previous week. 63 109 cases with 19 deaths have been reported from across 63 provinces up to 13 Oct 2013.\n\nIt is unfortunate that there is so little determination of the etiologic agent(s) involved.\n\nFor further information on the HFMD situation or its surveillance, please visit the following links:\nChina (in Chinese): http://www.moh.gov.cn/wsb/pyqxx/list.shtml\nHong Kong (China): http://www.chp.gov.hk/en/data/1/26/44/292/1303.html\nJapan: http://www.nih.go.jp/niid/en/survaillance-data-table-english.html\nRepublic of Korea: http://www.cdc.go.kr/CDC/info/CdcKrInfo0301.jsp?menuIds=HOME001-MNU0004-MNU0036-MNU0037&q_type=B&q_value=2013\nSingapore: http://www.moh.gov.sg/content/moh_web/home/diseases_and_conditions/h/hfmd.html\nThailand: http://www.boe.moph.go.th/index.php\n- Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1*Oa.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease -
