South Korea: comment 20000615.0969\n.................................................sb/cp/jejw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2078-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "1656-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pune", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kerala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Republic of Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "weekly", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Odisha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gujarat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macao", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2481104", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2481104", "date": "2013-11-28 20:39:20", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - INDIA: (MAHARASHTRA) ETIOLOGIC AGENTS\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 23 Nov 2013\nSource: The Times of India, Pune [edited]\nhttp://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-11-23/pune/44389035_1_niv-samples-mouth-ulcers\n\n\nScientists from the [Pune]city-based National Institute of Virology (NIV) have confirmed the presence of enterovirus which, they said, has been causing hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) in children in Pune [Maharashtra state; the city was formerly known as Poona]. The contagious viral illness has been spreading among children below 5 years of age in the last 2 months. Of the 79 samples drawn by the scientists, 40 per cent tested positive for enterovirus.\n\n\"The circulating virus in the city, causing HFMD in infants and children, is enterovirus. The infection caused by the virus is usually mild. Hence, there is no need to panic,\" said senior scientist D T Mourya, director of NIV. The viral infection, benign but irritating, is characterised by painful rashes along with throat [pain] and fever. Coxsackieviruses and enteroviruses are the major causative agents of HFMD in India. This is the 1st time that the Virology Institute investigated HFMD cases in Pune after doctors reported a spurt [of cases] since October [2013]. Earlier, it had carried out HFMD investigations in Kerala, West Bengal, Odisha, Gujarat and Tamil Nadu in 2009-2010. Scientist V Gopalkrishna, Deputy Director of NIV, who spearheaded the HFMD study along with paediatricians, said, \"79 clinical samples comprising throat swabs, rectal swabs, vesicular swabs and blood samples were collected from children below 7 years of age with suspected HFMD in Pune who went to paediatricians' clinics and hospitals for treatment in the last 2 months. Nearly 40 per cent of the samples tested positive for the etiological agent enterovirus. Now, cases are on the decline.\" Paediatricians from Shaishav clinic, Chiranjeev clinic, Bharati Hospital and Ajinkya Hospital from the city were involved in this study with NIV scientists.\n\n\"If a child is not eating and shows loss of appetite and has mouth ulcers, then it is time to consult a doctor,\" said paediatrician Sharad Agarkhedkar. Paediatrician Jayant Navarange, who is part of the NIV study and has been treating kids with HFMD in the last 2 months, said, \"HFMD is contagious. Hence, infected children should stay away from schools till they completely recover,\" he added.\n\n[Byline: Umesh Isalkar]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is a common viral illness that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old. However, it can sometimes occur in adults. Symptoms of HFMD include fever, blister-like sores in the mouth (herpangina) and a skin rash. HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. This group of viruses includes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of HFMD in the United States, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness. Enterovirus 71 has been associated with more severe outbreaks of HFMD (see: http://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/about/index.html).\n\nHFMD is prevalent globally and infects children in all communities. Since normally the infection is mild and of short duration, there has been little incentive to identify the specific etiologic agent. Normally ProMED-mail does not record these outbreaks unless the specific etiologic agent has been identified, or there is some unusual feature. The outbreak in Pune is exceptional in that the etiologic agents have been identified. Curiously the etiologic agent was only identified in less than 40 per cent of cases.\n\nThe Western Pacific Region of WHO routinely publishes data on the incidence of HFMD throughout East Asia (but not India) [see: http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/HFMD/en/]. The most recent update (13 Nov 2013) reported that HFMD is declining. Hong Kong (China), Macao (China), Japan and Republic of Korea (South Korea) have reported a higher cumulative number of cases in 2013 than in 2012 for the same time period. The recent trend, following seasonal patterns, is showing a decrease in China, Hong Kong (China), Macao (China), Japan, Republic of Korea, Singapore and Viet Nam.\n\nChina: Monthly average of cases has decreased from September (183 187 cases and 14 deaths) to October (134 032 cases and 8 deaths) 2013. There were 1 651 959 cases with 265 deaths reported up to the end of October in 2013.\n\nHong Kong (China): Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. Based on the 3 week moving average, weekly trends in hospitalized cases, general practitioners, and general outpatient clinics decreased. In the week 27 Oct to 2 Nov 2013, 4 HFMD inpatients (relative to 5 cases in the same period in 2012) were reported by the Hospital Authority; 0.1 cases per 1000 consultations among general out-patient clinics and 0.9 cases per 1000 consultations among general practitioners.\n\nMacao (China): Weekly trend has decreased based on the 3 week moving average. 19 cases were reported from 29 Oct to 4 Nov 2013 compared with 30 cases in the same period for 2012. The cumulative report for 2013 to the week ending 4 Nov was 2078 cases.\n\nJapan: Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. The weekly trend decreased based on the 3 week moving average. 4071 cases (1.29 cases per sentinel unit) were reported from 14 to 20 Oct 2013 compared with 1998 cases in the same period for 2012. Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 20 Oct was 281 149 cases.\n\nRepublic of Korea (South Korea): Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. The weekly trend is decreasing based on the 3 week moving average; 3.0 cases per 1000 outpatients for the week ending 5 Oct 2013. Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 5 Oct was 6.3 cases per 1000 outpatients.\n\nSingapore: The weekly trend increased based on the 3 week moving average; 914 cases were reported between 27 Oct to 2 Nov 2013 (relative to 265 for the same period in 2012). Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 2 Nov 2013 was 26 473 cases.\n\nViet Nam: The weekly number of reported cases during 7 to 13 Oct 2013 was 1610 relative to 1656 during the previous week. 63 109 cases with 19 deaths have been reported from across 63 provinces up to 13 Oct 2013.\n\nIt is unfortunate that there is so little determination of the etiologic agent(s) involved.\n\nFor further information on the HFMD situation or its surveillance, please visit the following links:\nChina (in Chinese): http://www.moh.gov.cn/wsb/pyqxx/list.shtml\nHong Kong (China): http://www.chp.gov.hk/en/data/1/26/44/292/1303.html\nJapan: http://www.nih.go.jp/niid/en/survaillance-data-table-english.html\nRepublic of Korea: http://www.cdc.go.kr/CDC/info/CdcKrInfo0301.jsp?menuIds=HOME001-MNU0004-MNU0036-MNU0037&q_type=B&q_value=2013\nSingapore: http://www.moh.gov.sg/content/moh_web/home/diseases_and_conditions/h/hfmd.html\nThailand: http://www.boe.moph.go.th/index.php\n- Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1*Oa.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia: (SK) 20131009.1992927\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (HK) increased incidence 20131005.1984319\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Maldives 20130228.1564772\n2011\n----\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Viet Nam (04): HCM 20110613.1804\n2006\n----\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak)(04) 20060319.0854\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak)(03) 20060313.0792\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Brunei 20060308.0744\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) 20060303.0671\n2005\n----\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Taiwan (central) (02) 20050531.1503\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Taiwan (Central) 20050523.1417\n2000\n----\nHand, foot and mouth disease - South Korea: comment 20000615.0969\n.................................................sb/cp/jejw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2078-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "1656-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pune", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kerala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Republic of Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "weekly", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Odisha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gujarat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macao", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2440155", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Cambodia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2427419", "date": "2013-11-28 20:39:20", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - INDIA: (MAHARASHTRA) ETIOLOGIC AGENTS\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 23 Nov 2013\nSource: The Times of India, Pune [edited]\nhttp://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-11-23/pune/44389035_1_niv-samples-mouth-ulcers\n\n\nScientists from the [Pune]city-based National Institute of Virology (NIV) have confirmed the presence of enterovirus which, they said, has been causing hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) in children in Pune [Maharashtra state; the city was formerly known as Poona]. The contagious viral illness has been spreading among children below 5 years of age in the last 2 months. Of the 79 samples drawn by the scientists, 40 per cent tested positive for enterovirus.\n\n\"The circulating virus in the city, causing HFMD in infants and children, is enterovirus. The infection caused by the virus is usually mild. Hence, there is no need to panic,\" said senior scientist D T Mourya, director of NIV. The viral infection, benign but irritating, is characterised by painful rashes along with throat [pain] and fever. Coxsackieviruses and enteroviruses are the major causative agents of HFMD in India. This is the 1st time that the Virology Institute investigated HFMD cases in Pune after doctors reported a spurt [of cases] since October [2013]. Earlier, it had carried out HFMD investigations in Kerala, West Bengal, Odisha, Gujarat and Tamil Nadu in 2009-2010. Scientist V Gopalkrishna, Deputy Director of NIV, who spearheaded the HFMD study along with paediatricians, said, \"79 clinical samples comprising throat swabs, rectal swabs, vesicular swabs and blood samples were collected from children below 7 years of age with suspected HFMD in Pune who went to paediatricians' clinics and hospitals for treatment in the last 2 months. Nearly 40 per cent of the samples tested positive for the etiological agent enterovirus. Now, cases are on the decline.\" Paediatricians from Shaishav clinic, Chiranjeev clinic, Bharati Hospital and Ajinkya Hospital from the city were involved in this study with NIV scientists.\n\n\"If a child is not eating and shows loss of appetite and has mouth ulcers, then it is time to consult a doctor,\" said paediatrician Sharad Agarkhedkar. Paediatrician Jayant Navarange, who is part of the NIV study and has been treating kids with HFMD in the last 2 months, said, \"HFMD is contagious. Hence, infected children should stay away from schools till they completely recover,\" he added.\n\n[Byline: Umesh Isalkar]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is a common viral illness that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old. However, it can sometimes occur in adults. Symptoms of HFMD include fever, blister-like sores in the mouth (herpangina) and a skin rash. HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. This group of viruses includes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of HFMD in the United States, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness. Enterovirus 71 has been associated with more severe outbreaks of HFMD (see: http://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/about/index.html).\n\nHFMD is prevalent globally and infects children in all communities. Since normally the infection is mild and of short duration, there has been little incentive to identify the specific etiologic agent. Normally ProMED-mail does not record these outbreaks unless the specific etiologic agent has been identified, or there is some unusual feature. The outbreak in Pune is exceptional in that the etiologic agents have been identified. Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 20 Oct was 281 149 cases.\n\nRepublic of Korea (South Korea): Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. The weekly trend is decreasing based on the 3 week moving average; 3.0 cases per 1000 outpatients for the week ending 5 Oct 2013. Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 5 Oct was 6.3 cases per 1000 outpatients.\n\nSingapore: The weekly trend increased based on the 3 week moving average; 914 cases were reported between 27 Oct to 2 Nov 2013 (relative to 265 for the same period in 2012). Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 2 Nov 2013 was 26 473 cases.\n\nViet Nam: The weekly number of reported cases during 7 to 13 Oct 2013 was 1610 relative to 1656 during the previous week. 63 109 cases with 19 deaths have been reported from across 63 provinces up to 13 Oct 2013.\n\nIt is unfortunate that there is so little determination of the etiologic agent(s) involved.\n\nFor further information on the HFMD situation or its surveillance, please visit the following links:\nChina (in Chinese): http://www.moh.gov.cn/wsb/pyqxx/list.shtml\nHong Kong (China): http://www.chp.gov.hk/en/data/1/26/44/292/1303.html\nJapan: http://www.nih.go.jp/niid/en/survaillance-data-table-english.html\nRepublic of Korea: http://www.cdc.go.kr/CDC/info/CdcKrInfo0301.jsp?menuIds=HOME001-MNU0004-MNU0036-MNU0037&q_type=B&q_value=2013\nSingapore: http://www.moh.gov.sg/content/moh_web/home/diseases_and_conditions/h/hfmd.html\nThailand: http://www.boe.moph.go.th/index.php\n- Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1*Oa.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South Korea: comment 20000615.0969\n.................................................sb/cp/jejw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2078-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "1656-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pune", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kerala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Republic of Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "weekly", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Odisha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gujarat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macao", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2080891", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - India: (MH) etiologic agents", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2080891", "date": "2013-11-28 20:39:20", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - INDIA: (MAHARASHTRA) ETIOLOGIC AGENTS\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 23 Nov 2013\nSource: The Times of India, Pune [edited]\nhttp://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-11-23/pune/44389035_1_niv-samples-mouth-ulcers\n\n\nScientists from the [Pune]city-based National Institute of Virology (NIV) have confirmed the presence of enterovirus which, they said, has been causing hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) in children in Pune [Maharashtra state; the city was formerly known as Poona]. The contagious viral illness has been spreading among children below 5 years of age in the last 2 months. Of the 79 samples drawn by the scientists, 40 per cent tested positive for enterovirus.\n\n\"The circulating virus in the city, causing HFMD in infants and children, is enterovirus. The infection caused by the virus is usually mild. Hence, there is no need to panic,\" said senior scientist D T Mourya, director of NIV. The viral infection, benign but irritating, is characterised by painful rashes along with throat [pain] and fever. Coxsackieviruses and enteroviruses are the major causative agents of HFMD in India. This is the 1st time that the Virology Institute investigated HFMD cases in Pune after doctors reported a spurt [of cases] since October [2013]. Earlier, it had carried out HFMD investigations in Kerala, West Bengal, Odisha, Gujarat and Tamil Nadu in 2009-2010. Scientist V Gopalkrishna, Deputy Director of NIV, who spearheaded the HFMD study along with paediatricians, said, \"79 clinical samples comprising throat swabs, rectal swabs, vesicular swabs and blood samples were collected from children below 7 years of age with suspected HFMD in Pune who went to paediatricians' clinics and hospitals for treatment in the last 2 months. Nearly 40 per cent of the samples tested positive for the etiological agent enterovirus. Now, cases are on the decline.\" Paediatricians from Shaishav clinic, Chiranjeev clinic, Bharati Hospital and Ajinkya Hospital from the city were involved in this study with NIV scientists.\n\n\"If a child is not eating and shows loss of appetite and has mouth ulcers, then it is time to consult a doctor,\" said paediatrician Sharad Agarkhedkar. Paediatrician Jayant Navarange, who is part of the NIV study and has been treating kids with HFMD in the last 2 months, said, \"HFMD is contagious. Hence, infected children should stay away from schools till they completely recover,\" he added.\n\n[Byline: Umesh Isalkar]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is a common viral illness that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old. However, it can sometimes occur in adults. Symptoms of HFMD include fever, blister-like sores in the mouth (herpangina) and a skin rash. HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. This group of viruses includes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of HFMD in the United States, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness. Enterovirus 71 has been associated with more severe outbreaks of HFMD (see: http://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/about/index.html).\n\nHFMD is prevalent globally and infects children in all communities. Since normally the infection is mild and of short duration, there has been little incentive to identify the specific etiologic agent. Normally ProMED-mail does not record these outbreaks unless the specific etiologic agent has been identified, or there is some unusual feature. The outbreak in Pune is exceptional in that the etiologic agents have been identified. Curiously the etiologic agent was only identified in less than 40 per cent of cases.\n\nThe Western Pacific Region of WHO routinely publishes data on the incidence of HFMD throughout East Asia (but not India) [see: http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/HFMD/en/]. The most recent update (13 Nov 2013) reported that HFMD is declining. Hong Kong (China), Macao (China), Japan and Republic of Korea (South Korea) have reported a higher cumulative number of cases in 2013 than in 2012 for the same time period. The recent trend, following seasonal patterns, is showing a decrease in China, Hong Kong (China), Macao (China), Japan, Republic of Korea, Singapore and Viet Nam.\n\nChina: Monthly average of cases has decreased from September (183 187 cases and 14 deaths) to October (134 032 cases and 8 deaths) 2013. There were 1 651 959 cases with 265 deaths reported up to the end of October in 2013.\n\nHong Kong (China): Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. Based on the 3 week moving average, weekly trends in hospitalized cases, general practitioners, and general outpatient clinics decreased. In the week 27 Oct to 2 Nov 2013, 4 HFMD inpatients (relative to 5 cases in the same period in 2012) were reported by the Hospital Authority; 0.1 cases per 1000 consultations among general out-patient clinics and 0.9 cases per 1000 consultations among general practitioners.\n\nMacao (China): Weekly trend has decreased based on the 3 week moving average. 19 cases were reported from 29 Oct to 4 Nov 2013 compared with 30 cases in the same period for 2012. The cumulative report for 2013 to the week ending 4 Nov was 2078 cases.\n\nJapan: Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. The weekly trend decreased based on the 3 week moving average. 4071 cases (1.29 cases per sentinel unit) were reported from 14 to 20 Oct 2013 compared with 1998 cases in the same period for 2012. Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 20 Oct was 281 149 cases.\n\nRepublic of Korea (South Korea): Surveillance for HFMD is conducted through sentinel reporting units. The weekly trend is decreasing based on the 3 week moving average; 3.0 cases per 1000 outpatients for the week ending 5 Oct 2013. Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 5 Oct was 6.3 cases per 1000 outpatients.\n\nSingapore: The weekly trend increased based on the 3 week moving average; 914 cases were reported between 27 Oct to 2 Nov 2013 (relative to 265 for the same period in 2012). Cumulative total for 2013 to the week ending 2 Nov 2013 was 26 473 cases.\n\nViet Nam: The weekly number of reported cases during 7 to 13 Oct 2013 was 1610 relative to 1656 during the previous week. 63 109 cases with 19 deaths have been reported from across 63 provinces up to 13 Oct 2013.\n\nIt is unfortunate that there is so little determination of the etiologic agent(s) involved.\n\nFor further information on the HFMD situation or its surveillance, please visit the following links:\nChina (in Chinese): http://www.moh.gov.cn/wsb/pyqxx/list.shtml\nHong Kong (China): http://www.chp.gov.hk/en/data/1/26/44/292/1303.html\nJapan: http://www.nih.go.jp/niid/en/survaillance-data-table-english.html\nRepublic of Korea: http://www.cdc.go.kr/CDC/info/CdcKrInfo0301.jsp?menuIds=HOME001-MNU0004-MNU0036-MNU0037&q_type=B&q_value=2013\nSingapore: http://www.moh.gov.sg/content/moh_web/home/diseases_and_conditions/h/hfmd.html\nThailand: http://www.boe.moph.go.th/index.php\n- Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1*Oa.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia: (SK) 20131009.1992927\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (HK) increased incidence 20131005.1984319\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Maldives 20130228.1564772\n2011\n----\nHand, foot and mouth disease - South Korea: comment 20000615.0969\n.................................................sb/cp/jejw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2078-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "1656-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pune", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kerala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Republic of Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "weekly", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Odisha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gujarat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macao", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1992927", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia: (SK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1992927", "date": "2013-06-06 17:26:13", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - NEW ZEALAND (02): (AUCKLAND)\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 6 Jun 2013\nSource: 3 News [edited]\nhttp://www.3news.co.nz/Starship-admissions-up-on-diseases-spread/tabid/423/articleID/300475/Default.aspx\n\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is being blamed for an increase in admissions at Auckland's Starship Children's Hospital, as many as 3 a day. The current strain is unusual in that it is infecting adults as well as children, says Dr Michael Shepherd, clinical director of Starship's emergency department. \"The strain we've got at the moment is more severe,\" he said on Firstline this morning [6 Jun 2013].\n\nDr Shepherd says HFMD is a fairly common disease that most children will get at some stage but isn't usually as serious as some other infectious diseases, which is partly why it persists, says Dr Shepherd. \"We've tended to focus vaccines on illnesses that cause long-term consequences. HFMD hasn't quite reached that threshold. We worry more about measles and chickenpox, and things like that. I think that it's pretty unpleasant to get it, but I think in terms of seriousness, it doesn't cause a whole range of long-term consequences. But I think it's causing quite a lot of distress and problems for the community generally, particularly with kids being out of daycare and off school.\"\n\nHFMD typically manifests as a rash on a child's hands, feet and mouth, but the current strain seems to affect other parts of the body too. \"It can be a more diffuse rash, a bit more all over your body,\" says Dr Shepherd. \"The rash is typically a blistering-type rash, a little bit like chicken pox. Often the mouth lesions are the real problem in terms of getting fluid into kids; it's very painful.\"\n\nThe worst thing that can happen is that a victim's nails can fall off. Dr Shepherd says it's \"pretty dramatic\" and unusual, but they do grow back again. \"If you think your child had HFMD, it would be nice if you didn't take them to daycare,\" he says. \"We ask people to keep them away until their fever has gone away and until they're not getting any new lesions and the old ones have scabbed over or started to heal up.\"\n\n[Byline: Dan Satherley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD occurs worldwide, and several different enteroviruses have been associated with outbreaks of HFMD. Since 1997, however, large outbreaks of HFMD caused by human enterovirus 71 have been reported, mostly in children in east and Southeast Asia, and cases of flaccid paralysis have occurred in Cambodia associated with a particular strain of human enterovirus 71. In these outbreaks, most children have typical symptoms of HFMD and recover without complications. However, a small number of children with this disease have developed severe complications requiring prolonged hospitalization or, rarely, death. These cases have been associated with prevalence of a particular strain of human enterovirus 71, a genogroup C4a strain. This strain was 1st identified in Cambodia and more recently detected in Australia.\n\nIt would be relevant to establish whether this strain is responsible for the current outbreak of HFMD in Auckland. Exceptionally, cases of poliomyelitis-like flaccid paralysis have been associated with this particular strain. Further information would be welcomed. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiF.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - New Zealand: (BP) 20130509.1701696\nHand, foot and mouth disease - China (03): (HK) increased incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1984319", "date": "2013-06-06 17:26:13", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - NEW ZEALAND (02): (AUCKLAND)\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 6 Jun 2013\nSource: 3 News [edited]\nhttp://www.3news.co.nz/Starship-admissions-up-on-diseases-spread/tabid/423/articleID/300475/Default.aspx\n\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is being blamed for an increase in admissions at Auckland's Starship Children's Hospital, as many as 3 a day. The current strain is unusual in that it is infecting adults as well as children, says Dr Michael Shepherd, clinical director of Starship's emergency department. \"The strain we've got at the moment is more severe,\" he said on Firstline this morning [6 Jun 2013].\n\nDr Shepherd says HFMD is a fairly common disease that most children will get at some stage but isn't usually as serious as some other infectious diseases, which is partly why it persists, says Dr Shepherd. \"We've tended to focus vaccines on illnesses that cause long-term consequences. HFMD hasn't quite reached that threshold. We worry more about measles and chickenpox, and things like that. I think that it's pretty unpleasant to get it, but I think in terms of seriousness, it doesn't cause a whole range of long-term consequences. But I think it's causing quite a lot of distress and problems for the community generally, particularly with kids being out of daycare and off school.\"\n\nHFMD typically manifests as a rash on a child's hands, feet and mouth, but the current strain seems to affect other parts of the body too. \"It can be a more diffuse rash, a bit more all over your body,\" says Dr Shepherd. \"The rash is typically a blistering-type rash, a little bit like chicken pox. Often the mouth lesions are the real problem in terms of getting fluid into kids; it's very painful.\"\n\nThe worst thing that can happen is that a victim's nails can fall off. Dr Shepherd says it's \"pretty dramatic\" and unusual, but they do grow back again. \"If you think your child had HFMD, it would be nice if you didn't take them to daycare,\" he says. \"We ask people to keep them away until their fever has gone away and until they're not getting any new lesions and the old ones have scabbed over or started to heal up.\"\n\n[Byline: Dan Satherley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD occurs worldwide, and several different enteroviruses have been associated with outbreaks of HFMD. Since 1997, however, large outbreaks of HFMD caused by human enterovirus 71 have been reported, mostly in children in east and Southeast Asia, and cases of flaccid paralysis have occurred in Cambodia associated with a particular strain of human enterovirus 71. In these outbreaks, most children have typical symptoms of HFMD and recover without complications. However, a small number of children with this disease have developed severe complications requiring prolonged hospitalization or, rarely, death. These cases have been associated with prevalence of a particular strain of human enterovirus 71, a genogroup C4a strain. This strain was 1st identified in Cambodia and more recently detected in Australia.\n\nIt would be relevant to establish whether this strain is responsible for the current outbreak of HFMD in Auckland. Exceptionally, cases of poliomyelitis-like flaccid paralysis have been associated with this particular strain. Further information would be welcomed. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiF.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - New Zealand: (BP) 20130509.1701696\nHand, foot and mouth disease - South Korea: comment 20000615.0969\n.................................................sb/cp/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "measles", "poliomyelitis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cambodia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Auckland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1898229", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1898229", "date": "2013-06-06 17:26:13", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - NEW ZEALAND (02): (AUCKLAND)\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 6 Jun 2013\nSource: 3 News [edited]\nhttp://www.3news.co.nz/Starship-admissions-up-on-diseases-spread/tabid/423/articleID/300475/Default.aspx\n\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is being blamed for an increase in admissions at Auckland's Starship Children's Hospital, as many as 3 a day. The current strain is unusual in that it is infecting adults as well as children, says Dr Michael Shepherd, clinical director of Starship's emergency department. \"The strain we've got at the moment is more severe,\" he said on Firstline this morning [6 Jun 2013].\n\nDr Shepherd says HFMD is a fairly common disease that most children will get at some stage but isn't usually as serious as some other infectious diseases, which is partly why it persists, says Dr Shepherd. \"We've tended to focus vaccines on illnesses that cause long-term consequences. HFMD hasn't quite reached that threshold. We worry more about measles and chickenpox, and things like that. I think that it's pretty unpleasant to get it, but I think in terms of seriousness, it doesn't cause a whole range of long-term consequences. But I think it's causing quite a lot of distress and problems for the community generally, particularly with kids being out of daycare and off school.\"\n\nHFMD typically manifests as a rash on a child's hands, feet and mouth, but the current strain seems to affect other parts of the body too. \"It can be a more diffuse rash, a bit more all over your body,\" says Dr Shepherd. \"The rash is typically a blistering-type rash, a little bit like chicken pox. Often the mouth lesions are the real problem in terms of getting fluid into kids; it's very painful.\"\n\nThe worst thing that can happen is that a victim's nails can fall off. Dr Shepherd says it's \"pretty dramatic\" and unusual, but they do grow back again. \"If you think your child had HFMD, it would be nice if you didn't take them to daycare,\" he says. \"We ask people to keep them away until their fever has gone away and until they're not getting any new lesions and the old ones have scabbed over or started to heal up.\"\n\n[Byline: Dan Satherley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD occurs worldwide, and several different enteroviruses have been associated with outbreaks of HFMD. Since 1997, however, large outbreaks of HFMD caused by human enterovirus 71 have been reported, mostly in children in east and Southeast Asia, and cases of flaccid paralysis have occurred in Cambodia associated with a particular strain of human enterovirus 71. In these outbreaks, most children have typical symptoms of HFMD and recover without complications. However, a small number of children with this disease have developed severe complications requiring prolonged hospitalization or, rarely, death. These cases have been associated with prevalence of a particular strain of human enterovirus 71, a genogroup C4a strain. This strain was 1st identified in Cambodia and more recently detected in Australia.\n\nIt would be relevant to establish whether this strain is responsible for the current outbreak of HFMD in Auckland. Exceptionally, cases of poliomyelitis-like flaccid paralysis have been associated with this particular strain. Further information would be welcomed. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiF.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - New Zealand: (BP) 20130509.1701696\nHand, foot and mouth disease - HFMD hasn't quite reached that threshold. We worry more about measles and chickenpox, and things like that. I think that it's pretty unpleasant to get it, but I think in terms of seriousness, it doesn't cause a whole range of long-term consequences. But I think it's causing quite a lot of distress and problems for the community generally, particularly with kids being out of daycare and off school.\"\n\nHFMD typically manifests as a rash on a child's hands, feet and mouth, but the current strain seems to affect other parts of the body too. \"It can be a more diffuse rash, a bit more all over your body,\" says Dr Shepherd. \"The rash is typically a blistering-type rash, a little bit like chicken pox. Often the mouth lesions are the real problem in terms of getting fluid into kids; it's very painful.\"\n\nThe worst thing that can happen is that a victim's nails can fall off. This strain was 1st identified in Cambodia and more recently detected in Australia.\n\nIt would be relevant to establish whether this strain is responsible for the current outbreak of HFMD in Auckland. The current strain is unusual in that it is infecting adults as well as children, says Dr Michael Shepherd, clinical director of Starship's emergency department. \"The strain we've got at the moment is more severe,\" he said on Firstline this morning [6 Jun 2013].\n\nDr Shepherd says HFMD is a fairly common disease that most children will get at some stage but isn't usually as serious as some other infectious diseases, which is partly why it persists, says Dr Shepherd. \"We've tended to focus vaccines on illnesses that cause long-term consequences. HFMD hasn't quite reached that threshold. We worry more about measles and chickenpox, and things like that. I think that it's pretty unpleasant to get it, but I think in terms of seriousness, it doesn't cause a whole range of long-term consequences. But I think it's causing quite a lot of distress and problems for the community generally, particularly with kids being out of daycare and off school.\"\n\nHFMD typically manifests as a rash on a child's hands, feet and mouth, but the current strain seems to affect other parts of the body too. \"It can be a more diffuse rash, a bit more all over your body,\" says Dr Shepherd. \"The rash is typically a blistering-type rash, a little bit like chicken pox. Often the mouth lesions are the real problem in terms of getting fluid into kids; it's very painful.\"\n\nThe worst thing that can happen is that a victim's nails can fall off. In these outbreaks, most children have typical symptoms of HFMD and recover without complications. However, a small number of children with this disease have developed severe complications requiring prolonged hospitalization or, rarely, death. These cases have been associated with prevalence of a particular strain of human enterovirus 71, a genogroup C4a strain. This strain was 1st identified in Cambodia and more recently detected in Australia.\n\nIt would be relevant to establish whether this strain is responsible for the current outbreak of HFMD in Auckland. New Zealand (03): (AU)  Coxsackievirus A6", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1763975", "date": "2013-06-06 17:26:13", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - NEW ZEALAND (02): (AUCKLAND)\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 6 Jun 2013\nSource: 3 News [edited]\nhttp://www.3news.co.nz/Starship-admissions-up-on-diseases-spread/tabid/423/articleID/300475/Default.aspx\n\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is being blamed for an increase in admissions at Auckland's Starship Children's Hospital, as many as 3 a day. The current strain is unusual in that it is infecting adults as well as children, says Dr Michael Shepherd, clinical director of Starship's emergency department. \"The strain we've got at the moment is more severe,\" he said on Firstline this morning [6 Jun 2013].\n\nDr Shepherd says HFMD is a fairly common disease that most children will get at some stage but isn't usually as serious as some other infectious diseases, which is partly why it persists, says Dr Shepherd. \"We've tended to focus vaccines on illnesses that cause long-term consequences. HFMD hasn't quite reached that threshold. We worry more about measles and chickenpox, and things like that. I think that it's pretty unpleasant to get it, but I think in terms of seriousness, it doesn't cause a whole range of long-term consequences. But I think it's causing quite a lot of distress and problems for the community generally, particularly with kids being out of daycare and off school.\"\n\nHFMD typically manifests as a rash on a child's hands, feet and mouth, but the current strain seems to affect other parts of the body too. \"It can be a more diffuse rash, a bit more all over your body,\" says Dr Shepherd. \"The rash is typically a blistering-type rash, a little bit like chicken pox. Often the mouth lesions are the real problem in terms of getting fluid into kids; it's very painful.\"\n\nThe worst thing that can happen is that a victim's nails can fall off. Dr Shepherd says it's \"pretty dramatic\" and unusual, but they do grow back again. \"If you think your child had HFMD, it would be nice if you didn't take them to daycare,\" he says. \"We ask people to keep them away until their fever has gone away and until they're not getting any new lesions and the old ones have scabbed over or started to heal up.\"\n\n[Byline: Dan Satherley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD occurs worldwide, and several different enteroviruses have been associated with outbreaks of HFMD. Since 1997, however, large outbreaks of HFMD caused by human enterovirus 71 have been reported, mostly in children in east and Southeast Asia, and cases of flaccid paralysis have occurred in Cambodia associated with a particular strain of human enterovirus 71. In these outbreaks, most children have typical symptoms of HFMD and recover without complications. However, a small number of children with this disease have developed severe complications requiring prolonged hospitalization or, rarely, death. These cases have been associated with prevalence of a particular strain of human enterovirus 71, a genogroup C4a strain. This strain was 1st identified in Cambodia and more recently detected in Australia.\n\nIt would be relevant to establish whether this strain is responsible for the current outbreak of HFMD in Auckland. Exceptionally, cases of poliomyelitis-like flaccid paralysis have been associated with this particular strain. Further information would be welcomed. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiF.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - New Zealand: (BP) 20130509.1701696\nHand, foot and mouth disease - South Korea: comment 20000615.0969\n.................................................sb/cp/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "measles", "poliomyelitis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cambodia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Auckland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1758982", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - New Zealand (02): (AU)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1758982", "date": "2013-06-06 17:26:13", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - NEW ZEALAND (02): (AUCKLAND)\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 6 Jun 2013\nSource: 3 News [edited]\nhttp://www.3news.co.nz/Starship-admissions-up-on-diseases-spread/tabid/423/articleID/300475/Default.aspx\n\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is being blamed for an increase in admissions at Auckland's Starship Children's Hospital, as many as 3 a day. The current strain is unusual in that it is infecting adults as well as children, says Dr Michael Shepherd, clinical director of Starship's emergency department. \"The strain we've got at the moment is more severe,\" he said on Firstline this morning [6 Jun 2013].\n\nDr Shepherd says HFMD is a fairly common disease that most children will get at some stage but isn't usually as serious as some other infectious diseases, which is partly why it persists, says Dr Shepherd. \"We've tended to focus vaccines on illnesses that cause long-term consequences. HFMD hasn't quite reached that threshold. We worry more about measles and chickenpox, and things like that. I think that it's pretty unpleasant to get it, but I think in terms of seriousness, it doesn't cause a whole range of long-term consequences. But I think it's causing quite a lot of distress and problems for the community generally, particularly with kids being out of daycare and off school.\"\n\nHFMD typically manifests as a rash on a child's hands, feet and mouth, but the current strain seems to affect other parts of the body too. \"It can be a more diffuse rash, a bit more all over your body,\" says Dr Shepherd. \"The rash is typically a blistering-type rash, a little bit like chicken pox. Often the mouth lesions are the real problem in terms of getting fluid into kids; it's very painful.\"\n\nThe worst thing that can happen is that a victim's nails can fall off. Dr Shepherd says it's \"pretty dramatic\" and unusual, but they do grow back again. \"If you think your child had HFMD, it would be nice if you didn't take them to daycare,\" he says. \"We ask people to keep them away until their fever has gone away and until they're not getting any new lesions and the old ones have scabbed over or started to heal up.\"\n\n[Byline: Dan Satherley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD occurs worldwide, and several different enteroviruses have been associated with outbreaks of HFMD. Since 1997, however, large outbreaks of HFMD caused by human enterovirus 71 have been reported, mostly in children in east and Southeast Asia, and cases of flaccid paralysis have occurred in Cambodia associated with a particular strain of human enterovirus 71. In these outbreaks, most children have typical symptoms of HFMD and recover without complications. However, a small number of children with this disease have developed severe complications requiring prolonged hospitalization or, rarely, death. These cases have been associated with prevalence of a particular strain of human enterovirus 71, a genogroup C4a strain. This strain was 1st identified in Cambodia and more recently detected in Australia.\n\nIt would be relevant to establish whether this strain is responsible for the current outbreak of HFMD in Auckland. Exceptionally, cases of poliomyelitis-like flaccid paralysis have been associated with this particular strain. Further information would be welcomed. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiF.]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - New Zealand: (BP) 20130509.1701696\nHand, foot and mouth disease - South Korea: comment 20000615.0969\n.................................................sb/cp/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "measles", "poliomyelitis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cambodia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Auckland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1701696", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - New Zealand: (BP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1701696", "date": "2012-09-18 18:49:12", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA (04)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 Sep 2012\nSource: The Washington Post [edited]\nhttp://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/a-more-virulent-version-of-hand-foot-and-mouth-disease-hits-kids--and-parents/2012/09/16/63807780-f5f0-11e1-8398-0327ab83ab91_story.html\n\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease, or HFMD, is a common childhood virus that pediatricians, daycare centers, and preschools see throughout summer and early fall. It causes fevers, rashes on hands and feet, and blisterlike sores in the mouth, which can make drinking and eating extremely uncomfortable. It usually clears up on its own in about a week.\n\nNow, though, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is reporting that an unusual version has hit the country, with more severe fevers and rashes, some leading to hospitalization for dehydration and pain.\n\nThe severe strain was 1st noticed in Alabama, Connecticut, California, and Nevada last winter [2011-2012], which was odd because HFMD typically appears in summer and early fall.\n\nAlthough several pediatricians in the Washington area say they haven't seen the atypical virus, \"it's pretty much all over the country at this point,\" says Steven Oberste, laboratory chief in CDC's viral disease division.\n\nHFMD is usually caused by coxsackievirus A16; the more severe illness is caused by coxsackievirus A6, which has popped up in this country only a few times in the past 40 years, according to the CDC. Both are spread through saliva, mucus, fluid from the blisters, and stool.\n\nThe CDC has received about 100-150 reports of severe cases. \"Since there's no required reporting of hand-foot-mouth disease, it's difficult to estimate how many cases are out there,\" Oberste says. \"We have 100-150 reports, but clearly it's a lot more than that.\"\n\nMelissa Arca, a pediatrician in Sacramento, where the disease seems to have hit hard, says there were times during the summer when she saw 3 or 4 children every day with severe HFMD, and she only works half days at her clinic. Researchers don't know if the A6 wave has peaked with the end of summer, so they're unsure whether the new school year will cause a spike in cases. Outbreaks of HFMD occur around the globe, but in recent years they have mostly been in Asia, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nDaniel Levy, a pediatrician in Owings Mills, Maryland, says that he has seen a normal amount of HFMD and the cases don't seem any more severe than usual. Pediatricians at Children's National Medical Center and one in Columbia Heights both echoed Levy's experience. \"I have yet to see any child hospitalized or sent to the ER [for HFMD] in my career; it is just not that serious,\" Levy says. \"It sounds a lot worse than it is.\"\n\nThe A6 version is odd, for a number of reasons. It causes more severe rashes up the legs, around the mouth and, especially for toddlers, on the buttocks. Arca reports that in some cases, after the rash has gone away, the skin can peel and the fingernails and toenails can fall off. \"It's scary, but they'll grow back,\" she says.\n\nAlso, more adults than usual seem to be catching the new strain, according to the CDC. That's probably because A6 has circulated only sporadically in the United States since 1970, so fewer adults were exposed to it when they were younger, according to Oberste. A6 was big in Japan in the spring and summer of 2011.\n\n[Byline: Rachel Saslow]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The coxsackie A6 virus has circulated sporadically in the USA, and may produce somewhat more severe disease. A ProMED-mail report of 14 Aug 2012 (archive no. 20120816.1248050) quoted Phil Ulibarri, public information officer for the Washoe county, Nevada, health district saying, \"This [coxsackie A6] strain is not [affecting] just the hands, feet, and mouth. It's also seen on the elbows, the knees, the arms, buttocks, legs, and in the genital area.\" Enterovirus 71, another virus that causes HFMD, has been circulating in Asia, causing a more severe form of the disease in a small proportion of infected children, with neurological involvement and fatalities. - Mod.TY]\n\n[As hand, foot and mouth disease is not an officially reportable disease in the USA, it is hard to judge the order of magnitude of this current outbreak in comparison with previous years' outbreaks as reporting has been inconsistent. The observation that disease associated with the coxsackievirus A6 strain is more severe than previously seen is most likely correct as these types of events usually precipitate enhanced reports of cases. When there is something unusual from the expected -- a change in the clinical picture, or a change in the key epidemiologic parameters of person, place and/or time of outbreak it usually leads to increases in the number of cases reported. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (03): (NV), Coxsackie A6 20120816.1248050\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (02): (NC) 20120508.1126671\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AL) Coxsackie A6 virus 20120211.1039435\n2011\n---\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AR) 20110519.1513\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (02): (TX), daycare facilities 20111028.3210\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AR) 20110519.1513\nLegionellosis - USA: (CA) conference, susp. 20110214.0494\n2004\n---\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (OH) 20040526.1416\n.................................................mpp/ty/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-08-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alabama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Owings Mills", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Columbia Heights", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sacramento", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1564772", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot and mouth disease - Maldives", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1564772", "date": "2012-09-18 18:49:12", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA (04)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 Sep 2012\nSource: The Washington Post [edited]\nhttp://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/a-more-virulent-version-of-hand-foot-and-mouth-disease-hits-kids--and-parents/2012/09/16/63807780-f5f0-11e1-8398-0327ab83ab91_story.html\n\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease, or HFMD, is a common childhood virus that pediatricians, daycare centers, and preschools see throughout summer and early fall. That's probably because A6 has circulated only sporadically in the United States since 1970, so fewer adults were exposed to it when they were younger, according to Oberste. A6 was big in Japan in the spring and summer of 2011.\n\n[Byline: Rachel Saslow]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The coxsackie A6 virus has circulated sporadically in the USA, and may produce somewhat more severe disease. A ProMED-mail report of 14 Aug 2012 (archive no. 20120816.1248050) quoted Phil Ulibarri, public information officer for the Washoe county, Nevada, health district saying, \"This [coxsackie A6] strain is not [affecting] just the hands, feet, and mouth. It's also seen on the elbows, the knees, the arms, buttocks, legs, and in the genital area.\" Enterovirus 71, another virus that causes HFMD, has been circulating in Asia, causing a more severe form of the disease in a small proportion of infected children, with neurological involvement and fatalities. - Mod.TY]\n\n[As hand, foot and mouth disease is not an officially reportable disease in the USA, it is hard to judge the order of magnitude of this current outbreak in comparison with previous years' outbreaks as reporting has been inconsistent. USA (OH) 20040526.1416\n.................................................mpp/ty/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-08-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alabama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Owings Mills", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Columbia Heights", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sacramento", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1402131", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (12): travel advice", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1402131", "date": "2012-09-18 18:49:12", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA (04)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 Sep 2012\nSource: The Washington Post [edited]\nhttp://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/a-more-virulent-version-of-hand-foot-and-mouth-disease-hits-kids--and-parents/2012/09/16/63807780-f5f0-11e1-8398-0327ab83ab91_story.html\n\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease, or HFMD, is a common childhood virus that pediatricians, daycare centers, and preschools see throughout summer and early fall. It causes fevers, rashes on hands and feet, and blisterlike sores in the mouth, which can make drinking and eating extremely uncomfortable. It usually clears up on its own in about a week.\n\nNow, though, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is reporting that an unusual version has hit the country, with more severe fevers and rashes, some leading to hospitalization for dehydration and pain.\n\nThe severe strain was 1st noticed in Alabama, Connecticut, California, and Nevada last winter [2011-2012], which was odd because HFMD typically appears in summer and early fall.\n\nAlthough several pediatricians in the Washington area say they haven't seen the atypical virus, \"it's pretty much all over the country at this point,\" says Steven Oberste, laboratory chief in CDC's viral disease division.\n\nHFMD is usually caused by coxsackievirus A16; the more severe illness is caused by coxsackievirus A6, which has popped up in this country only a few times in the past 40 years, according to the CDC. Both are spread through saliva, mucus, fluid from the blisters, and stool.\n\nThe CDC has received about 100-150 reports of severe cases. \"Since there's no required reporting of hand-foot-mouth disease, it's difficult to estimate how many cases are out there,\" Oberste says. \"We have 100-150 reports, but clearly it's a lot more than that.\"\n\nMelissa Arca, a pediatrician in Sacramento, where the disease seems to have hit hard, says there were times during the summer when she saw 3 or 4 children every day with severe HFMD, and she only works half days at her clinic. Researchers don't know if the A6 wave has peaked with the end of summer, so they're unsure whether the new school year will cause a spike in cases. Outbreaks of HFMD occur around the globe, but in recent years they have mostly been in Asia, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nDaniel Levy, a pediatrician in Owings Mills, Maryland, says that he has seen a normal amount of HFMD and the cases don't seem any more severe than usual. Pediatricians at Children's National Medical Center and one in Columbia Heights both echoed Levy's experience. \"I have yet to see any child hospitalized or sent to the ER [for HFMD] in my career; it is just not that serious,\" Levy says. \"It sounds a lot worse than it is.\"\n\nThe A6 version is odd, for a number of reasons. It causes more severe rashes up the legs, around the mouth and, especially for toddlers, on the buttocks. Arca reports that in some cases, after the rash has gone away, the skin can peel and the fingernails and toenails can fall off. \"It's scary, but they'll grow back,\" she says.\n\nAlso, more adults than usual seem to be catching the new strain, according to the CDC. That's probably because A6 has circulated only sporadically in the United States since 1970, so fewer adults were exposed to it when they were younger, according to Oberste. A6 was big in Japan in the spring and summer of 2011.\n\n[Byline: Rachel Saslow]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The coxsackie A6 virus has circulated sporadically in the USA, and may produce somewhat more severe disease. A ProMED-mail report of 14 Aug 2012 (archive no. 20120816.1248050) quoted Phil Ulibarri, public information officer for the Washoe county, Nevada, health district saying, \"This [coxsackie A6] strain is not [affecting] just the hands, feet, and mouth. It's also seen on the elbows, the knees, the arms, buttocks, legs, and in the genital area.\" Enterovirus 71, another virus that causes HFMD, has been circulating in Asia, causing a more severe form of the disease in a small proportion of infected children, with neurological involvement and fatalities. - Mod.TY]\n\n[As hand, foot and mouth disease is not an officially reportable disease in the USA, it is hard to judge the order of magnitude of this current outbreak in comparison with previous years' outbreaks as reporting has been inconsistent. The observation that disease associated with the coxsackievirus A6 strain is more severe than previously seen is most likely correct as these types of events usually precipitate enhanced reports of cases. When there is something unusual from the expected -- a change in the clinical picture, or a change in the key epidemiologic parameters of person, place and/or time of outbreak it usually leads to increases in the number of cases reported. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (03): (NV), Coxsackie A6 20120816.1248050\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (02): (NC) 20120508.1126671\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AL) Coxsackie A6 virus 20120211.1039435\n2011\n---\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AR) 20110519.1513\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (02): (TX), daycare facilities 20111028.3210\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AR) 20110519.1513\nLegionellosis - USA: (CA) conference, susp. 20110214.0494\n2004\n---\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (OH) 20040526.1416\n.................................................mpp/ty/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-08-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alabama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Owings Mills", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Columbia Heights", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sacramento", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1370930", "headline": "PRO> Hand, foot & mouth disease - China: Beijing, vaccine development", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1370930", "date": "2012-09-18 18:49:12", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA (04)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 Sep 2012\nSource: The Washington Post [edited]\nhttp://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/a-more-virulent-version-of-hand-foot-and-mouth-disease-hits-kids--and-parents/2012/09/16/63807780-f5f0-11e1-8398-0327ab83ab91_story.html\n\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease, or HFMD, is a common childhood virus that pediatricians, daycare centers, and preschools see throughout summer and early fall. It causes fevers, rashes on hands and feet, and blisterlike sores in the mouth, which can make drinking and eating extremely uncomfortable. It usually clears up on its own in about a week.\n\nNow, though, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is reporting that an unusual version has hit the country, with more severe fevers and rashes, some leading to hospitalization for dehydration and pain.\n\nThe severe strain was 1st noticed in Alabama, Connecticut, California, and Nevada last winter [2011-2012], which was odd because HFMD typically appears in summer and early fall.\n\nAlthough several pediatricians in the Washington area say they haven't seen the atypical virus, \"it's pretty much all over the country at this point,\" says Steven Oberste, laboratory chief in CDC's viral disease division.\n\nHFMD is usually caused by coxsackievirus A16; the more severe illness is caused by coxsackievirus A6, which has popped up in this country only a few times in the past 40 years, according to the CDC. Both are spread through saliva, mucus, fluid from the blisters, and stool.\n\nThe CDC has received about 100-150 reports of severe cases. \"Since there's no required reporting of hand-foot-mouth disease, it's difficult to estimate how many cases are out there,\" Oberste says. \"We have 100-150 reports, but clearly it's a lot more than that.\"\n\nMelissa Arca, a pediatrician in Sacramento, where the disease seems to have hit hard, says there were times during the summer when she saw 3 or 4 children every day with severe HFMD, and she only works half days at her clinic. Researchers don't know if the A6 wave has peaked with the end of summer, so they're unsure whether the new school year will cause a spike in cases. Outbreaks of HFMD occur around the globe, but in recent years they have mostly been in Asia, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nDaniel Levy, a pediatrician in Owings Mills, Maryland, says that he has seen a normal amount of HFMD and the cases don't seem any more severe than usual. Pediatricians at Children's National Medical Center and one in Columbia Heights both echoed Levy's experience. \"I have yet to see any child hospitalized or sent to the ER [for HFMD] in my career; it is just not that serious,\" Levy says. \"It sounds a lot worse than it is.\"\n\nThe A6 version is odd, for a number of reasons. It causes more severe rashes up the legs, around the mouth and, especially for toddlers, on the buttocks. Arca reports that in some cases, after the rash has gone away, the skin can peel and the fingernails and toenails can fall off. \"It's scary, but they'll grow back,\" she says.\n\nAlso, more adults than usual seem to be catching the new strain, according to the CDC. That's probably because A6 has circulated only sporadically in the United States since 1970, so fewer adults were exposed to it when they were younger, according to Oberste. A6 was big in Japan in the spring and summer of 2011.\n\n[Byline: Rachel Saslow]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The coxsackie A6 virus has circulated sporadically in the USA, and may produce somewhat more severe disease. A ProMED-mail report of 14 Aug 2012 (archive no. 20120816.1248050) quoted Phil Ulibarri, public information officer for the Washoe county, Nevada, health district saying, \"This [coxsackie A6] strain is not [affecting] just the hands, feet, and mouth. It's also seen on the elbows, the knees, the arms, buttocks, legs, and in the genital area.\" Enterovirus 71, another virus that causes HFMD, has been circulating in Asia, causing a more severe form of the disease in a small proportion of infected children, with neurological involvement and fatalities. - Mod.TY]\n\n[As hand, foot and mouth disease is not an officially reportable disease in the USA, it is hard to judge the order of magnitude of this current outbreak in comparison with previous years' outbreaks as reporting has been inconsistent. The observation that disease associated with the coxsackievirus A6 strain is more severe than previously seen is most likely correct as these types of events usually precipitate enhanced reports of cases. When there is something unusual from the expected -- a change in the clinical picture, or a change in the key epidemiologic parameters of person, place and/or time of outbreak it usually leads to increases in the number of cases reported. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (03): (NV), Coxsackie A6 20120816.1248050\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (02): (NC) 20120508.1126671\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AL) Coxsackie A6 virus 20120211.1039435\n2011\n---\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AR) 20110519.1513\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (02): (TX), daycare facilities 20111028.3210\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AR) 20110519.1513\nLegionellosis - USA: (CA) conference, susp. 20110214.0494\n2004\n---\nHand, foot & mouth disease - It causes fevers, rashes on hands and feet, and blisterlike sores in the mouth, which can make drinking and eating extremely uncomfortable. Researchers don't know if the A6 wave has peaked with the end of summer, so they're unsure whether the new school year will cause a spike in cases. It causes more severe rashes up the legs, around the mouth and, especially for toddlers, on the buttocks. Arca reports that in some cases, after the rash has gone away, the skin can peel and the fingernails and toenails can fall off. \"It's scary, but they'll grow back,\" she says.\n\nAlso, more adults than usual seem to be catching the new strain, according to the CDC. That's probably because A6 has circulated only sporadically in the United States since 1970, so fewer adults were exposed to it when they were younger, according to Oberste.
