USA (OH) 20040526.1416\n.................................................mpp/ty/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-08-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alabama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Owings Mills", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Columbia Heights", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sacramento", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1298802", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - USA (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1298802", "date": "2012-09-18 18:49:12", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA (04)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 Sep 2012\nSource: The Washington Post [edited]\nhttp://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/a-more-virulent-version-of-hand-foot-and-mouth-disease-hits-kids--and-parents/2012/09/16/63807780-f5f0-11e1-8398-0327ab83ab91_story.html\n\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease, or HFMD, is a common childhood virus that pediatricians, daycare centers, and preschools see throughout summer and early fall. It causes fevers, rashes on hands and feet, and blisterlike sores in the mouth, which can make drinking and eating extremely uncomfortable. It usually clears up on its own in about a week.\n\nNow, though, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is reporting that an unusual version has hit the country, with more severe fevers and rashes, some leading to hospitalization for dehydration and pain.\n\nThe severe strain was 1st noticed in Alabama, Connecticut, California, and Nevada last winter [2011-2012], which was odd because HFMD typically appears in summer and early fall.\n\nAlthough several pediatricians in the Washington area say they haven't seen the atypical virus, \"it's pretty much all over the country at this point,\" says Steven Oberste, laboratory chief in CDC's viral disease division.\n\nHFMD is usually caused by coxsackievirus A16; the more severe illness is caused by coxsackievirus A6, which has popped up in this country only a few times in the past 40 years, according to the CDC. Both are spread through saliva, mucus, fluid from the blisters, and stool.\n\nThe CDC has received about 100-150 reports of severe cases. \"Since there's no required reporting of hand-foot-mouth disease, it's difficult to estimate how many cases are out there,\" Oberste says. \"We have 100-150 reports, but clearly it's a lot more than that.\"\n\nMelissa Arca, a pediatrician in Sacramento, where the disease seems to have hit hard, says there were times during the summer when she saw 3 or 4 children every day with severe HFMD, and she only works half days at her clinic. Researchers don't know if the A6 wave has peaked with the end of summer, so they're unsure whether the new school year will cause a spike in cases. Outbreaks of HFMD occur around the globe, but in recent years they have mostly been in Asia, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nDaniel Levy, a pediatrician in Owings Mills, Maryland, says that he has seen a normal amount of HFMD and the cases don't seem any more severe than usual. Pediatricians at Children's National Medical Center and one in Columbia Heights both echoed Levy's experience. \"I have yet to see any child hospitalized or sent to the ER [for HFMD] in my career; it is just not that serious,\" Levy says. \"It sounds a lot worse than it is.\"\n\nThe A6 version is odd, for a number of reasons. It causes more severe rashes up the legs, around the mouth and, especially for toddlers, on the buttocks. Arca reports that in some cases, after the rash has gone away, the skin can peel and the fingernails and toenails can fall off. \"It's scary, but they'll grow back,\" she says.\n\nAlso, more adults than usual seem to be catching the new strain, according to the CDC. That's probably because A6 has circulated only sporadically in the United States since 1970, so fewer adults were exposed to it when they were younger, according to Oberste. A6 was big in Japan in the spring and summer of 2011.\n\n[Byline: Rachel Saslow]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The coxsackie A6 virus has circulated sporadically in the USA, and may produce somewhat more severe disease. A ProMED-mail report of 14 Aug 2012 (archive no. 20120816.1248050) quoted Phil Ulibarri, public information officer for the Washoe county, Nevada, health district saying, \"This [coxsackie A6] strain is not [affecting] just the hands, feet, and mouth. It's also seen on the elbows, the knees, the arms, buttocks, legs, and in the genital area.\" Enterovirus 71, another virus that causes HFMD, has been circulating in Asia, causing a more severe form of the disease in a small proportion of infected children, with neurological involvement and fatalities. - Mod.TY]\n\n[As hand, foot and mouth disease is not an officially reportable disease in the USA, it is hard to judge the order of magnitude of this current outbreak in comparison with previous years' outbreaks as reporting has been inconsistent. The observation that disease associated with the coxsackievirus A6 strain is more severe than previously seen is most likely correct as these types of events usually precipitate enhanced reports of cases. When there is something unusual from the expected -- a change in the clinical picture, or a change in the key epidemiologic parameters of person, place and/or time of outbreak it usually leads to increases in the number of cases reported. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (03): (NV), Coxsackie A6 20120816.1248050\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (02): (NC) 20120508.1126671\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AL) Coxsackie A6 virus 20120211.1039435\n2011\n---\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AR) 20110519.1513\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (02): (TX), daycare facilities 20111028.3210\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AR) 20110519.1513\nLegionellosis - USA: (CA) conference, susp. 20110214.0494\n2004\n---\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (OH) 20040526.1416\n.................................................mpp/ty/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-08-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alabama", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Owings Mills", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Columbia Heights", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sacramento", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1248050", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - USA (03): (NV), Coxsackie A6"}, {"archive_id": "1228715", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Philippines (02): 2nd EV71 case"}, {"archive_id": "1218572", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand (03): 2nd EV71 fatality"}, {"archive_id": "1217890", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand (02): EV71 fatality"}, {"archive_id": "1217788", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Worldwide (02): and vitamin A defic."}, {"archive_id": "1213695", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Philippines, Thailand:  EV-71 cases"}, {"archive_id": "1202583", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (Hunan)"}, {"archive_id": "1201907", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand: (BM)"}, {"archive_id": "1199237", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (11)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1199237", "date": "2012-05-19 16:20:54", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - MALAYSIA (02)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 18 May 2012\nSource: The Star Online [edited]\nhttp://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2012/5/18/nation/20120518150140&sec=nation\n\n\nMild cases of hand, foot and mouth disease on the rise\n------------------------------------------------------\nPETALING JAYA (Selangor): The hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) endemic increased to 1468 new cases between 6 and 12 May 2012, compared to the previous weeks 1147 cases, but most cases are mild. Health Ministry director general Datuk Seri Dr Hasan Abdul Rahman said this week. Selangor had the highest number of HMFD cases (354 cases), followed by Sarawak (343 cases), Johor (195 cases), Penang (128 cases), Kuala Lumpur (100 cases) and Sabah (91 cases). Other states reported less than 60 cases.\n\nMost of the cases reported are mild. This week, 180 cases nationwide have been hospitalised for observation and rehydration treatment and no deaths were reported, the Health Ministry Director said in a statement on Friday [18 May 2012]. The increase in cases had been observed since January this year, and 17 221 cases have been reported since then. Dr Hasan added that the Ministry's measures to curb the spread were to temporarily shut down premises or institutions where HMFD was spreading, and urged medical practitioners to report HFMD cases to the ministry. He also advised the public to take precautionary measures through maintaining cleanliness, taking children with HFMD symptoms for treatment and keeping the infected children away from public places.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HelthMap alerts\n<promed@promemail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease is a common viral illness that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old. However, it can sometimes occur in adults. Symptoms of hand, foot, and mouth disease include fever, mouth sores, and a skin rash. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. Unfortunately this report does not identify the causative agent (or agents) responsible for this outbreak of HFMD. The uniformly mild symptoms observed suggests that this outbreak is not caused by human enterovirus 71, which in the past has been accompanied by cases of severe disease in Malaysia.\n\nHFMD usually starts with a fever, poor appetite, a vague feeling of being unwell (malaise), and sore throat. One or 2 days after fever starts, painful sores usually develop in the mouth (herpangina). They begin as small red spots that blister and that often become ulcers. The sores are often in the back of the mouth. A skin rash develops over 1 to 2 days. The rash has flat or raised red spots, sometimes with blisters. The rash is usually on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet; it may also appear on the knees, elbows, buttocks or genital area. Some people, especially young children, may get dehydrated if they are not able to swallow enough liquids because of painful mouth sores.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is spread from person to person by direct contact with the infectious viruses that cause this disease. These viruses are found in the nose and throat secretions (such as saliva, sputum, or nasal mucus), fluid in blisters, and stool of infected persons. The viruses may be spread when infected persons touch objects and surfaces that are then touched by others.\n\nThere is no specific treatment. There is no vaccine to protect against the viruses that cause HFMD. Cleanliness and avoidance of close contact with affected persons are the best protection.\n\nA map showing the locations of the States of Malaysia can be accessed at: http://www.mymalaysiabooks.com/malaysia/Malaysia_states.htm. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Mexico: (Mexico City) RFI 20120511.1130367\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA (02): (NC) 20120508.1126671\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore (03) 20120507.1125540\nHand foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (05) 20120408.1093926\nHand-foot & mouth disease - USA: (multistate) Coxsackievirus A6 20120329.1084829\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia: (SK) 20120322.1077794\nHand, foot & mouth disease (03): Taiwan, EV71 20120319.1074955\nHand, foot & mouth disease (02): Viet Nam (southern) 20120313.1069657\nHand foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20120301.1058004\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20120221.1048374\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AL) Coxsackie A6 virus 20120211.1039435\n.................................................sb/cp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1468-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2012-05-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mexico City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the States of Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kuala Lumpur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Selangor", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Penang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1198166", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Worldwide", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1186614", "date": "2012-05-19 16:20:54", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - MALAYSIA (02)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 18 May 2012\nSource: The Star Online [edited]\nhttp://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2012/5/18/nation/20120518150140&sec=nation\n\n\nMild cases of hand, foot and mouth disease on the rise\n------------------------------------------------------\nPETALING JAYA (Selangor): The hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) endemic increased to 1468 new cases between 6 and 12 May 2012, compared to the previous weeks 1147 cases, but most cases are mild. Health Ministry director general Datuk Seri Dr Hasan Abdul Rahman said this week. Selangor had the highest number of HMFD cases (354 cases), followed by Sarawak (343 cases), Johor (195 cases), Penang (128 cases), Kuala Lumpur (100 cases) and Sabah (91 cases). Other states reported less than 60 cases.\n\nMost of the cases reported are mild. This week, 180 cases nationwide have been hospitalised for observation and rehydration treatment and no deaths were reported, the Health Ministry Director said in a statement on Friday [18 May 2012]. The increase in cases had been observed since January this year, and 17 221 cases have been reported since then. Dr Hasan added that the Ministry's measures to curb the spread were to temporarily shut down premises or institutions where HMFD was spreading, and urged medical practitioners to report HFMD cases to the ministry. He also advised the public to take precautionary measures through maintaining cleanliness, taking children with HFMD symptoms for treatment and keeping the infected children away from public places.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HelthMap alerts\n<promed@promemail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease is a common viral illness that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old. However, it can sometimes occur in adults. Symptoms of hand, foot, and mouth disease include fever, mouth sores, and a skin rash. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. Unfortunately this report does not identify the causative agent (or agents) responsible for this outbreak of HFMD. The uniformly mild symptoms observed suggests that this outbreak is not caused by human enterovirus 71, which in the past has been accompanied by cases of severe disease in Malaysia.\n\nHFMD usually starts with a fever, poor appetite, a vague feeling of being unwell (malaise), and sore throat. One or 2 days after fever starts, painful sores usually develop in the mouth (herpangina). They begin as small red spots that blister and that often become ulcers. The sores are often in the back of the mouth. A skin rash develops over 1 to 2 days. The rash has flat or raised red spots, sometimes with blisters. The rash is usually on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet; it may also appear on the knees, elbows, buttocks or genital area. Some people, especially young children, may get dehydrated if they are not able to swallow enough liquids because of painful mouth sores.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is spread from person to person by direct contact with the infectious viruses that cause this disease. These viruses are found in the nose and throat secretions (such as saliva, sputum, or nasal mucus), fluid in blisters, and stool of infected persons. The viruses may be spread when infected persons touch objects and surfaces that are then touched by others.\n\nThere is no specific treatment. There is no vaccine to protect against the viruses that cause HFMD. Cleanliness and avoidance of close contact with affected persons are the best protection.\n\nA map showing the locations of the States of Malaysia can be accessed at: http://www.mymalaysiabooks.com/malaysia/Malaysia_states.htm. - Viet Nam (09): (DN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1168548", "date": "2012-05-19 16:20:54", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - MALAYSIA (02)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 18 May 2012\nSource: The Star Online [edited]\nhttp://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2012/5/18/nation/20120518150140&sec=nation\n\n\nMild cases of hand, foot and mouth disease on the rise\n------------------------------------------------------\nPETALING JAYA (Selangor): The hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) endemic increased to 1468 new cases between 6 and 12 May 2012, compared to the previous weeks 1147 cases, but most cases are mild. Health Ministry director general Datuk Seri Dr Hasan Abdul Rahman said this week. Selangor had the highest number of HMFD cases (354 cases), followed by Sarawak (343 cases), Johor (195 cases), Penang (128 cases), Kuala Lumpur (100 cases) and Sabah (91 cases). Other states reported less than 60 cases.\n\nMost of the cases reported are mild. This week, 180 cases nationwide have been hospitalised for observation and rehydration treatment and no deaths were reported, the Health Ministry Director said in a statement on Friday [18 May 2012]. The increase in cases had been observed since January this year, and 17 221 cases have been reported since then. Dr Hasan added that the Ministry's measures to curb the spread were to temporarily shut down premises or institutions where HMFD was spreading, and urged medical practitioners to report HFMD cases to the ministry. He also advised the public to take precautionary measures through maintaining cleanliness, taking children with HFMD symptoms for treatment and keeping the infected children away from public places.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HelthMap alerts\n<promed@promemail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease is a common viral illness that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old. However, it can sometimes occur in adults. Symptoms of hand, foot, and mouth disease include fever, mouth sores, and a skin rash. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. Unfortunately this report does not identify the causative agent (or agents) responsible for this outbreak of HFMD. The uniformly mild symptoms observed suggests that this outbreak is not caused by human enterovirus 71, which in the past has been accompanied by cases of severe disease in Malaysia.\n\nHFMD usually starts with a fever, poor appetite, a vague feeling of being unwell (malaise), and sore throat. One or 2 days after fever starts, painful sores usually develop in the mouth (herpangina). They begin as small red spots that blister and that often become ulcers. The sores are often in the back of the mouth. A skin rash develops over 1 to 2 days. The rash has flat or raised red spots, sometimes with blisters. The rash is usually on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet; it may also appear on the knees, elbows, buttocks or genital area. Some people, especially young children, may get dehydrated if they are not able to swallow enough liquids because of painful mouth sores.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is spread from person to person by direct contact with the infectious viruses that cause this disease. These viruses are found in the nose and throat secretions (such as saliva, sputum, or nasal mucus), fluid in blisters, and stool of infected persons. The viruses may be spread when infected persons touch objects and surfaces that are then touched by others.\n\nThere is no specific treatment. There is no vaccine to protect against the viruses that cause HFMD. Cleanliness and avoidance of close contact with affected persons are the best protection.\n\nA map showing the locations of the States of Malaysia can be accessed at: http://www.mymalaysiabooks.com/malaysia/Malaysia_states.htm. - Singapore 20120301.1058004\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20120221.1048374\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AL) Coxsackie A6 virus 20120211.1039435\n.................................................sb/cp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1468-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2012-05-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mexico City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the States of Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kuala Lumpur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Selangor", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Penang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1130367", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Mexico: (Mexico City) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1130367", "date": "2012-04-08 13:20:06", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - VIET NAM (05)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Apr 2012\nSource: IRIN Asia [edited]\nhttp://www.irinnews.org/Report/95244/VIETNAM-Mild-disease-turns-deadly-for=\n\nViet nam: Mild disease turns deadly for children\n----------------------------------------\nBANGKOK: A dangerous strain of the typically non-lethal hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) [virus] has affected more than 21 000 persons -- mostly children younger than five -- killing 16 thus far in Viet Nam, according to the Ministry of Health.\n\n\"Despite being a benign viral infection in developed countries, the strain EV71 [Human enterovirus 71] of HFMD is causing multiple deaths of children under five here in Asia. We are especially worried about South Viet Nnam, where lots of children are in informal [hygienically unregulated] cr\u00e8ches while their parents work,\" Bhupinder Tomar, representative of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) in Viet Nam, told IRIN.\n\nHFMD\u2019s symptoms are fever, sores in the mouth and blisters on the hands and feet. The disease spreads by direct contact with fluids from infected persons and there is no specific treatment. Most of the viruses that cause HFMD are benign, but EV71 can be fatal. The new strain appeared in Viet Nam over the past year and since then it has become a serious public health issue for children, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nThe risk of catching HFMD is greatly reduced by improving hygiene, which IFRC is trying to promote through an existing public education campaign.\n\nIn 2011 there were 110 000 reported infections and 169 deaths linked to EV71, mostly in the south of the country. The disease is active year-round and peaks between April-May and then again in September-October. In March 2012 there were twice as many deaths and seven times as many infections as in the same period last year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n\n[HFMD is a common, mild and self-limiting rash-associated illness in most children, with Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) or Enterovirus 71 (EV71) the predominant causative agents. Since first described in California in 1969, EV71 has been reported to be responsible for many large outbreaks all over the world, including outbreaks that occurred in South and East Asia from 1997 onwards. Generally, these outbreaks were accompanied by a small number of cases with severe neurologic disease such as acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema, myocarditis, and fatal encephalitis. The EV71 viruses have been classified into three independent lineages, A, B, and C, based on the structural VP1 gene; each group has at least 15% divergence from the others. Consequently the epidemiology of EV71-associated HFMD in South and East Asia is proving to be very complex. For example a recent study of Enterovirus 71 strains from severe and mild disease patients in North-eastern China identified seven circulating EV71 viruses (see: Xiaomei Wang et al., PLoS ONE 7(3): e32405. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0032405, 29 Mar 2012 http://www.plosone.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pone.0032405). These EV71 viruses contained genetic recombination events between four distinct EV71 strains. Most of the structural protein region (P1) of these viruses resembled that of the prototype EV71 C1 strain. The non-structural protein domains (P2 and P3) showed a high degree of similarity with Coxsackieviruses A4 and A5. The 5\u2032UTR (untranslated region) showed a high degree of similarity to Coxsackievirus A16. However, irrespective of genotype no correlation was observed between genotype and virulence. In the immediate future education and control of hygiene and sanitation may remain the best options for containment of HFMD, rather than vaccine development.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap of Vet Nam can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/008c. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (04): HCM 20110613.1804\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03): HCM 20110607.1739\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02): (QN, HCM) 20110604.1712\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Croatia: (ZG) childcare centre\n20110527.1624\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Hong Kong, nursery school 20110523.1567\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AR) 20110519.1513\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (HCM) 20110409.1119\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India: (MH) 20110101.0009\n.................................................cp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1969-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North - eastern", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1126671", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - USA (02): (NC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1126671", "date": "2012-04-08 13:20:06", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - VIET NAM (05)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Apr 2012\nSource: IRIN Asia [edited]\nhttp://www.irinnews.org/Report/95244/VIETNAM-Mild-disease-turns-deadly-for=\n\nViet nam: Mild disease turns deadly for children\n----------------------------------------\nBANGKOK: A dangerous strain of the typically non-lethal hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) [virus] has affected more than 21 000 persons -- mostly children younger than five -- killing 16 thus far in Viet Nam, according to the Ministry of Health.\n\n\"Despite being a benign viral infection in developed countries, the strain EV71 [Human enterovirus 71] of HFMD is causing multiple deaths of children under five here in Asia. We are especially worried about South Viet Nnam, where lots of children are in informal [hygienically unregulated] cr\u00e8ches while their parents work,\" Bhupinder Tomar, representative of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) in Viet Nam, told IRIN.\n\nHFMD\u2019s symptoms are fever, sores in the mouth and blisters on the hands and feet. The disease spreads by direct contact with fluids from infected persons and there is no specific treatment. Most of the viruses that cause HFMD are benign, but EV71 can be fatal. The new strain appeared in Viet Nam over the past year and since then it has become a serious public health issue for children, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nThe risk of catching HFMD is greatly reduced by improving hygiene, which IFRC is trying to promote through an existing public education campaign.\n\nIn 2011 there were 110 000 reported infections and 169 deaths linked to EV71, mostly in the south of the country. The disease is active year-round and peaks between April-May and then again in September-October. In March 2012 there were twice as many deaths and seven times as many infections as in the same period last year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n\n[HFMD is a common, mild and self-limiting rash-associated illness in most children, with Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) or Enterovirus 71 (EV71) the predominant causative agents. Since first described in California in 1969, EV71 has been reported to be responsible for many large outbreaks all over the world, including outbreaks that occurred in South and East Asia from 1997 onwards. Generally, these outbreaks were accompanied by a small number of cases with severe neurologic disease such as acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema, myocarditis, and fatal encephalitis. The EV71 viruses have been classified into three independent lineages, A, B, and C, based on the structural VP1 gene; each group has at least 15% divergence from the others. Consequently the epidemiology of EV71-associated HFMD in South and East Asia is proving to be very complex. For example a recent study of Enterovirus 71 strains from severe and mild disease patients in North-eastern China identified seven circulating EV71 viruses (see: Xiaomei Wang et al., PLoS ONE 7(3): e32405. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0032405, 29 Mar 2012 http://www.plosone.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pone.0032405). These EV71 viruses contained genetic recombination events between four distinct EV71 strains. Most of the structural protein region (P1) of these viruses resembled that of the prototype EV71 C1 strain. The non-structural protein domains (P2 and P3) showed a high degree of similarity with Coxsackieviruses A4 and A5. The 5\u2032UTR (untranslated region) showed a high degree of similarity to Coxsackievirus A16. However, irrespective of genotype no correlation was observed between genotype and virulence. In the immediate future education and control of hygiene and sanitation may remain the best options for containment of HFMD, rather than vaccine development.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap of Vet Nam can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/008c. - VIET NAM (05)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Apr 2012\nSource: IRIN Asia [edited]\nhttp://www.irinnews.org/Report/95244/VIETNAM-Mild-disease-turns-deadly-for=\n\nViet nam: Mild disease turns deadly for children\n----------------------------------------\nBANGKOK: A dangerous strain of the typically non-lethal hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) [virus] has affected more than 21 000 persons -- mostly children younger than five -- killing 16 thus far in Viet Nam, according to the Ministry of Health.\n\n\"Despite being a benign viral infection in developed countries, the strain EV71 [Human enterovirus 71] of HFMD is causing multiple deaths of children under five here in Asia. We are especially worried about South Viet Nnam, where lots of children are in informal [hygienically unregulated] cr\u00e8ches while their parents work,\" Bhupinder Tomar, representative of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) in Viet Nam, told IRIN.\n\nHFMD\u2019s symptoms are fever, sores in the mouth and blisters on the hands and feet. The disease spreads by direct contact with fluids from infected persons and there is no specific treatment. Most of the viruses that cause HFMD are benign, but EV71 can be fatal. The new strain appeared in Viet Nam over the past year and since then it has become a serious public health issue for children, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nThe risk of catching HFMD is greatly reduced by improving hygiene, which IFRC is trying to promote through an existing public education campaign.\n\nIn 2011 there were 110 000 reported infections and 169 deaths linked to EV71, mostly in the south of the country. The disease is active year-round and peaks between April-May and then again in September-October. In March 2012 there were twice as many deaths and seven times as many infections as in the same period last year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n\n[HFMD is a common, mild and self-limiting rash-associated illness in most children, with Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) or Enterovirus 71 (EV71) the predominant causative agents. Since first described in California in 1969, EV71 has been reported to be responsible for many large outbreaks all over the world, including outbreaks that occurred in South and East Asia from 1997 onwards. Generally, these outbreaks were accompanied by a small number of cases with severe neurologic disease such as acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema, myocarditis, and fatal encephalitis. The EV71 viruses have been classified into three independent lineages, A, B, and C, based on the structural VP1 gene; each group has at least 15% divergence from the others. Consequently the epidemiology of EV71-associated HFMD in South and East Asia is proving to be very complex. For example a recent study of Enterovirus 71 strains from severe and mild disease patients in North-eastern China identified seven circulating EV71 viruses (see: Xiaomei Wang et al., PLoS ONE 7(3): e32405. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0032405, 29 Mar 2012 http://www.plosone.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pone.0032405). These EV71 viruses contained genetic recombination events between four distinct EV71 strains. Most of the structural protein region (P1) of these viruses resembled that of the prototype EV71 C1 strain. The non-structural protein domains (P2 and P3) showed a high degree of similarity with Coxsackieviruses A4 and A5. The 5\u2032UTR (untranslated region) showed a high degree of similarity to Coxsackievirus A16. However, irrespective of genotype no correlation was observed between genotype and virulence. In the immediate future education and control of hygiene and sanitation may remain the best options for containment of HFMD, rather than vaccine development.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap of Vet Nam can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/008c. - We are especially worried about South Viet Nnam, where lots of children are in informal [hygienically unregulated] cr\u00e8ches while their parents work,\" Bhupinder Tomar, representative of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) in Viet Nam, told IRIN.\n\nHFMD\u2019s symptoms are fever, sores in the mouth and blisters on the hands and feet. The disease spreads by direct contact with fluids from infected persons and there is no specific treatment. Most of the viruses that cause HFMD are benign, but EV71 can be fatal. The new strain appeared in Viet Nam over the past year and since then it has become a serious public health issue for children, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nThe risk of catching HFMD is greatly reduced by improving hygiene, which IFRC is trying to promote through an existing public education campaign.\n\nIn 2011 there were 110 000 reported infections and 169 deaths linked to EV71, mostly in the south of the country. In March 2012 there were twice as many deaths and seven times as many infections as in the same period last year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n\n[HFMD is a common, mild and self-limiting rash-associated illness in most children, with Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) or Enterovirus 71 (EV71) the predominant causative agents. Since first described in California in 1969, EV71 has been reported to be responsible for many large outbreaks all over the world, including outbreaks that occurred in South and East Asia from 1997 onwards. Generally, these outbreaks were accompanied by a small number of cases with severe neurologic disease such as acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema, myocarditis, and fatal encephalitis. The EV71 viruses have been classified into three independent lineages, A, B, and C, based on the structural VP1 gene; each group has at least 15% divergence from the others. Consequently the epidemiology of EV71-associated HFMD in South and East Asia is proving to be very complex. For example a recent study of Enterovirus 71 strains from severe and mild disease patients in North-eastern China identified seven circulating EV71 viruses (see: Xiaomei Wang et al., PLoS ONE 7(3): e32405. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0032405, 29 Mar 2012 http://www.plosone.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pone.0032405). These EV71 viruses contained genetic recombination events between four distinct EV71 strains. Most of the structural protein region (P1) of these viruses resembled that of the prototype EV71 C1 strain. The non-structural protein domains (P2 and P3) showed a high degree of similarity with Coxsackieviruses A4 and A5. The 5\u2032UTR (untranslated region) showed a high degree of similarity to Coxsackievirus A16. However, irrespective of genotype no correlation was observed between genotype and virulence. In the immediate future education and control of hygiene and sanitation may remain the best options for containment of HFMD, rather than vaccine development.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap of Vet Nam can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/008c. - Since first described in California in 1969, EV71 has been reported to be responsible for many large outbreaks all over the world, including outbreaks that occurred in South and East Asia from 1997 onwards. Generally, these outbreaks were accompanied by a small number of cases with severe neurologic disease such as acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema, myocarditis, and fatal encephalitis. The EV71 viruses have been classified into three independent lineages, A, B, and C, based on the structural VP1 gene; each group has at least 15% divergence from the others. Consequently the epidemiology of EV71-associated HFMD in South and East Asia is proving to be very complex. For example a recent study of Enterovirus 71 strains from severe and mild disease patients in North-eastern China identified seven circulating EV71 viruses (see: Xiaomei Wang et al., PLoS ONE 7(3): e32405. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0032405, 29 Mar 2012 http://www.plosone.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pone.0032405). Most of the structural protein region (P1) of these viruses resembled that of the prototype EV71 C1 strain. The non-structural protein domains (P2 and P3) showed a high degree of similarity with Coxsackieviruses A4 and A5. The 5\u2032UTR (untranslated region) showed a high degree of similarity to Coxsackievirus A16. However, irrespective of genotype no correlation was observed between genotype and virulence. eastern", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1105864", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (NE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1105864", "date": "2012-04-08 13:20:06", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - VIET NAM (05)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Apr 2012\nSource: IRIN Asia [edited]\nhttp://www.irinnews.org/Report/95244/VIETNAM-Mild-disease-turns-deadly-for=\n\nViet nam: Mild disease turns deadly for children\n----------------------------------------\nBANGKOK: A dangerous strain of the typically non-lethal hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) [virus] has affected more than 21 000 persons -- mostly children younger than five -- killing 16 thus far in Viet Nam, according to the Ministry of Health.\n\n\"Despite being a benign viral infection in developed countries, the strain EV71 [Human enterovirus 71] of HFMD is causing multiple deaths of children under five here in Asia. We are especially worried about South Viet Nnam, where lots of children are in informal [hygienically unregulated] cr\u00e8ches while their parents work,\" Bhupinder Tomar, representative of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) in Viet Nam, told IRIN.\n\nHFMD\u2019s symptoms are fever, sores in the mouth and blisters on the hands and feet. The disease spreads by direct contact with fluids from infected persons and there is no specific treatment. Most of the viruses that cause HFMD are benign, but EV71 can be fatal. The new strain appeared in Viet Nam over the past year and since then it has become a serious public health issue for children, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nThe risk of catching HFMD is greatly reduced by improving hygiene, which IFRC is trying to promote through an existing public education campaign.\n\nIn 2011 there were 110 000 reported infections and 169 deaths linked to EV71, mostly in the south of the country. The disease is active year-round and peaks between April-May and then again in September-October. In March 2012 there were twice as many deaths and seven times as many infections as in the same period last year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n\n[HFMD is a common, mild and self-limiting rash-associated illness in most children, with Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) or Enterovirus 71 (EV71) the predominant causative agents. Since first described in California in 1969, EV71 has been reported to be responsible for many large outbreaks all over the world, including outbreaks that occurred in South and East Asia from 1997 onwards. Generally, these outbreaks were accompanied by a small number of cases with severe neurologic disease such as acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema, myocarditis, and fatal encephalitis. The EV71 viruses have been classified into three independent lineages, A, B, and C, based on the structural VP1 gene; each group has at least 15% divergence from the others. Consequently the epidemiology of EV71-associated HFMD in South and East Asia is proving to be very complex. For example a recent study of Enterovirus 71 strains from severe and mild disease patients in North-eastern China identified seven circulating EV71 viruses (see: Xiaomei Wang et al., PLoS ONE 7(3): e32405. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0032405, 29 Mar 2012 http://www.plosone.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pone.0032405). These EV71 viruses contained genetic recombination events between four distinct EV71 strains. Most of the structural protein region (P1) of these viruses resembled that of the prototype EV71 C1 strain. The non-structural protein domains (P2 and P3) showed a high degree of similarity with Coxsackieviruses A4 and A5. The 5\u2032UTR (untranslated region) showed a high degree of similarity to Coxsackievirus A16. However, irrespective of genotype no correlation was observed between genotype and virulence. In the immediate future education and control of hygiene and sanitation may remain the best options for containment of HFMD, rather than vaccine development.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap of Vet Nam can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/008c. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (04): HCM 20110613.1804\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03): HCM 20110607.1739\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02): (QN, HCM) 20110604.1712\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Croatia: (ZG) childcare centre\n20110527.1624\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Hong Kong, nursery school 20110523.1567\nHand, foot & mouth disease - USA: (AR) 20110519.1513\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (HCM) 20110409.1119\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India: (MH) 20110101.0009\n.................................................cp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1969-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North - eastern", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1104577", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (06), Mekong Delta", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1104577", "date": "2012-04-08 13:20:06", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - VIET NAM (05)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Apr 2012\nSource: IRIN Asia [edited]\nhttp://www.irinnews.org/Report/95244/VIETNAM-Mild-disease-turns-deadly-for=\n\nViet nam: Mild disease turns deadly for children\n----------------------------------------\nBANGKOK: A dangerous strain of the typically non-lethal hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) [virus] has affected more than 21 000 persons -- mostly children younger than five -- killing 16 thus far in Viet Nam, according to the Ministry of Health.\n\n\"Despite being a benign viral infection in developed countries, the strain EV71 [Human enterovirus 71] of HFMD is causing multiple deaths of children under five here in Asia. We are especially worried about South Viet Nnam, where lots of children are in informal [hygienically unregulated] cr\u00e8ches while their parents work,\" Bhupinder Tomar, representative of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) in Viet Nam, told IRIN.\n\nHFMD\u2019s symptoms are fever, sores in the mouth and blisters on the hands and feet. The disease spreads by direct contact with fluids from infected persons and there is no specific treatment. Most of the viruses that cause HFMD are benign, but EV71 can be fatal. The new strain appeared in Viet Nam over the past year and since then it has become a serious public health issue for children, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nThe risk of catching HFMD is greatly reduced by improving hygiene, which IFRC is trying to promote through an existing public education campaign.\n\nIn 2011 there were 110 000 reported infections and 169 deaths linked to EV71, mostly in the south of the country. The disease is active year-round and peaks between April-May and then again in September-October. In March 2012 there were twice as many deaths and seven times as many infections as in the same period last year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n\n[HFMD is a common, mild and self-limiting rash-associated illness in most children, with Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) or Enterovirus 71 (EV71) the predominant causative agents. Since first described in California in 1969, EV71 has been reported to be responsible for many large outbreaks all over the world, including outbreaks that occurred in South and East Asia from 1997 onwards. Generally, these outbreaks were accompanied by a small number of cases with severe neurologic disease such as acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema, myocarditis, and fatal encephalitis. The EV71 viruses have been classified into three independent lineages, A, B, and C, based on the structural VP1 gene; each group has at least 15% divergence from the others. Consequently the epidemiology of EV71-associated HFMD in South and East Asia is proving to be very complex. For example a recent study of Enterovirus 71 strains from severe and mild disease patients in North-eastern China identified seven circulating EV71 viruses (see: Xiaomei Wang et al., PLoS ONE 7(3): e32405. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0032405, 29 Mar 2012 http://www.plosone.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pone.0032405). These EV71 viruses contained genetic recombination events between four distinct EV71 strains. Most of the structural protein region (P1) of these viruses resembled that of the prototype EV71 C1 strain. The non-structural protein domains (P2 and P3) showed a high degree of similarity with Coxsackieviruses A4 and A5. The 5\u2032UTR (untranslated region) showed a high degree of similarity to Coxsackievirus A16. However, irrespective of genotype no correlation was observed between genotype and virulence. In the immediate future education and control of hygiene and sanitation may remain the best options for containment of HFMD, rather than vaccine development.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap of Vet Nam can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/008c. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (04): HCM 20110613.1804\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03): HCM 20110607.1739\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02): (QN, HCM) 20110604.1712\nHand, foot & mouth disease - VIET NAM (05)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Apr 2012\nSource: IRIN Asia [edited]\nhttp://www.irinnews.org/Report/95244/VIETNAM-Mild-disease-turns-deadly-for=\n\nViet nam: Mild disease turns deadly for children\n----------------------------------------\nBANGKOK: A dangerous strain of the typically non-lethal hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) [virus] has affected more than 21 000 persons -- mostly children younger than five -- killing 16 thus far in Viet Nam, according to the Ministry of Health.\n\n\"Despite being a benign viral infection in developed countries, the strain EV71 [Human enterovirus 71] of HFMD is causing multiple deaths of children under five here in Asia. We are especially worried about South Viet Nnam, where lots of children are in informal [hygienically unregulated] cr\u00e8ches while their parents work,\" Bhupinder Tomar, representative of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) in Viet Nam, told IRIN.\n\nHFMD\u2019s symptoms are fever, sores in the mouth and blisters on the hands and feet. The disease spreads by direct contact with fluids from infected persons and there is no specific treatment. Most of the viruses that cause HFMD are benign, but EV71 can be fatal. The new strain appeared in Viet Nam over the past year and since then it has become a serious public health issue for children, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nThe risk of catching HFMD is greatly reduced by improving hygiene, which IFRC is trying to promote through an existing public education campaign.\n\nIn 2011 there were 110 000 reported infections and 169 deaths linked to EV71, mostly in the south of the country. The disease is active year-round and peaks between April-May and then again in September-October. In March 2012 there were twice as many deaths and seven times as many infections as in the same period last year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n\n[HFMD is a common, mild and self-limiting rash-associated illness in most children, with Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) or Enterovirus 71 (EV71) the predominant causative agents. Since first described in California in 1969, EV71 has been reported to be responsible for many large outbreaks all over the world, including outbreaks that occurred in South and East Asia from 1997 onwards. Generally, these outbreaks were accompanied by a small number of cases with severe neurologic disease such as acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema, myocarditis, and fatal encephalitis. The EV71 viruses have been classified into three independent lineages, A, B, and C, based on the structural VP1 gene; each group has at least 15% divergence from the others. Consequently the epidemiology of EV71-associated HFMD in South and East Asia is proving to be very complex. For example a recent study of Enterovirus 71 strains from severe and mild disease patients in North-eastern China identified seven circulating EV71 viruses (see: Xiaomei Wang et al., PLoS ONE 7(3): e32405. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0032405, 29 Mar 2012 http://www.plosone.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pone.0032405). These EV71 viruses contained genetic recombination events between four distinct EV71 strains. Most of the structural protein region (P1) of these viruses resembled that of the prototype EV71 C1 strain. The non-structural protein domains (P2 and P3) showed a high degree of similarity with Coxsackieviruses A4 and A5. The 5\u2032UTR (untranslated region) showed a high degree of similarity to Coxsackievirus A16. However, irrespective of genotype no correlation was observed between genotype and virulence. In the immediate future education and control of hygiene and sanitation may remain the best options for containment of HFMD, rather than vaccine development.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap of Vet Nam can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/008c. - VIET NAM (08)\n********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 16 Dec 2011\nSource: Associated Press report [edited]\nhttp://washingtonexaminer.com/news/2011/12/hand-foot-mouth-disease-kills-156-vietnam/2009531\n\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease kills 156 in Viet Nam\n--------------------------------------------------\nViet Nam authorities say an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease\nhas killed 156 people, mostly children, and sickened more than 96 000\nthrough late November 2011. An official at the Ministry of Health says\nthe average number of weekly cases dropped from about 3000 in\nSeptember to 2460 in November.\n\nThe U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued a travel\nalert on Monday urging people visiting Viet Nam to protect themselves\nfrom the disease by practicing \"healthy personal hygiene.\"\n\nThis year's outbreak is a sharp contrast to recent years. Since 2008,\nabout 10 000 to 15 000 cases were reported per year with about 20 to\n30 children dying annually. This common childhood illness typically\ncauses little more than a fever and rash, and most recover quickly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nGeorge A. Robertson, PhD\nSenior Technical Advisor\nVaccine Development Global Program\nPATH\n455 Massachusetts Ave NW, Suite 1000\nWashington, DC 20001 USA\n<grobertson@path.org>\n\n[Since the end of October 2011 the number of cases of hand, foot and\nmouth disease in Viet Nam has increased from 77 895 to more than 96\n000 and the number of fatalities from 137 to 156. This is in contrast\nto the 10 000 to 15 000 cases and 20-30 deaths reported annually since\n2008. The 2011 outbreak appears to involve all 63 provinces of Viet\nNam. It is unclear from the information released so far whether the\ncurrent outbreak is a consequence of social and environmental factors,\nor enhanced virulence of the causative agent, believed to be human\nenterovirus 71. Are Viet Nam's neighbours similarly afflicted?\n\nA map showing the locations of the 63 provinces of Viet Nam can be\naccessed at\nhttp://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - An official at the Ministry of Health says\nthe average number of weekly cases dropped from about 3000 in\nSeptember to 2460 in November.\n\nThe U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued a travel\nalert on Monday urging people visiting Viet Nam to protect themselves\nfrom the disease by practicing \"healthy personal hygiene.\"\n\nThis year's outbreak is a sharp contrast to recent years. Since 2008,\nabout 10 000 to 15 000 cases were reported per year with about 20 to\n30 children dying annually. This common childhood illness typically\ncauses little more than a fever and rash, and most recover quickly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nGeorge A. Robertson, PhD\nSenior Technical Advisor\nVaccine Development Global Program\nPATH\n455 Massachusetts Ave NW, Suite 1000\nWashington, DC 20001 USA\n<grobertson@path.org>\n\n[Since the end of October 2011 the number of cases of hand, foot and\nmouth disease in Viet Nam has increased from 77 895 to more than 96\n000 and the number of fatalities from 137 to 156. This is in contrast\nto the 10 000 to 15 000 cases and 20-30 deaths reported annually since\n2008. The 2011 outbreak appears to involve all 63 provinces of Viet\nNam. It is unclear from the information released so far whether the\ncurrent outbreak is a consequence of social and environmental factors,\nor enhanced virulence of the causative agent, believed to be human\nenterovirus 71. Are Viet Nam's neighbours similarly afflicted?\n\nA map showing the locations of the 63 provinces of Viet Nam can be\naccessed at\nhttp://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - VIET NAM (08)\n********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 16 Dec 2011\nSource: Associated Press report [edited]\nhttp://washingtonexaminer.com/news/2011/12/hand-foot-mouth-disease-kills-156-vietnam/2009531\n\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease kills 156 in Viet Nam\n--------------------------------------------------\nViet Nam authorities say an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease\nhas killed 156 people, mostly children, and sickened more than 96 000\nthrough late November 2011. An official at the Ministry of Health says\nthe average number of weekly cases dropped from about 3000 in\nSeptember to 2460 in November.\n\nThe U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued a travel\nalert on Monday urging people visiting Viet Nam to protect themselves\nfrom the disease by practicing \"healthy personal hygiene.\"\n\nThis year's outbreak is a sharp contrast to recent years. Since 2008,\nabout 10 000 to 15 000 cases were reported per year with about 20 to\n30 children dying annually. This common childhood illness typically\ncauses little more than a fever and rash, and most recover quickly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nGeorge A. Robertson, PhD\nSenior Technical Advisor\nVaccine Development Global Program\nPATH\n455 Massachusetts Ave NW, Suite 1000\nWashington, DC 20001 USA\n<grobertson@path.org>\n\n[Since the end of October 2011 the number of cases of hand, foot and\nmouth disease in Viet Nam has increased from 77 895 to more than 96\n000 and the number of fatalities from 137 to 156. This is in contrast\nto the 10 000 to 15 000 cases and 20-30 deaths reported annually since\n2008. The 2011 outbreak appears to involve all 63 provinces of Viet\nNam. It is unclear from the information released so far whether the\ncurrent outbreak is a consequence of social and environmental factors,\nor enhanced virulence of the causative agent, believed to be human\nenterovirus 71. Are Viet Nam's neighbours similarly afflicted?\n\nA map showing the locations of the 63 provinces of Viet Nam can be\naccessed at\nhttp://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - An official at the Ministry of Health says\nthe average number of weekly cases dropped from about 3000 in\nSeptember to 2460 in November.\n\nThe U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued a travel\nalert on Monday urging people visiting Viet Nam to protect themselves\nfrom the disease by practicing \"healthy personal hygiene.\"\n\nThis year's outbreak is a sharp contrast to recent years. Since 2008,\nabout 10 000 to 15 000 cases were reported per year with about 20 to\n30 children dying annually. This common childhood illness typically\ncauses little more than a fever and rash, and most recover quickly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nGeorge A. Robertson, PhD\nSenior Technical Advisor\nVaccine Development Global Program\nPATH\n455 Massachusetts Ave NW, Suite 1000\nWashington, DC 20001 USA\n<grobertson@path.org>\n\n[Since the end of October 2011 the number of cases of hand, foot and\nmouth disease in Viet Nam has increased from 77 895 to more than 96\n000 and the number of fatalities from 137 to 156. This is in contrast\nto the 10 000 to 15 000 cases and 20-30 deaths reported annually since\n2008. The 2011 outbreak appears to involve all 63 provinces of Viet\nNam. It is unclear from the information released so far whether the\ncurrent outbreak is a consequence of social and environmental factors,\nor enhanced virulence of the causative agent, believed to be human\nenterovirus 71. Are Viet Nam's neighbours similarly afflicted?\n\nA map showing the locations of the 63 provinces of Viet Nam can be\naccessed at\nhttp://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (07): travel alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=979263", "date": "2011-08-16 18:35:25", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - VIET NAM (07)\n********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 15 Aug 2011\nSource: Thanh Nien News [edited]\nhttp://www.thanhniennews.com/2010/Pages/20110815144904.aspx\n\n\nHFMD death toll climbs to 81 in Viet Nam\n----------------------------------------\nA health official said 96 percent of HFMD [Hand, foot and mouth\ndisease] fatalities in Viet Nam this year have been of children under\n5 years of age. The death toll for HFMD has climbed to 81 among 32 588\ncases reported in 52 cities and provinces, according to the Viet Nam\nAdministration of Preventive Medicine.\n\nTran Thanh Duong, the agency's deputy chief, told the Viet Nam News\nAgency that fatalities have been reported in 17 cities and provinces,\nwith Ho Chi Minh City having the highest toll at 22, followed by the\nprovinces of Dong Nai, Binh Duong, Long An and Ba Ria-Vung Tau. He\nadded 96 percent of fatalities were of children under 5.\n\nDuong's office has warned the disease may continue to spread to more\nprovinces and claim more lives in the coming months. The risks are\nhigher for children attending kindergartens, since the new school year\nhas begun, it said.\n\nThe Ministry of Health has asked the education sector to take active\nmeasures to sterilize [decontaminate] kindergartens, day care centers\nand schools to prevent the spread of the HFMD virus.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Since the end of June 2011 the number of cases of HFMD in Viet Nam\nhas risen from around 23 000 to 32 588, and death toll has risen from\n70 to 81.\n\nIt has been established previously (see ProMED-mail posts referenced\nbelow) that human enterovirus 71 is the dominant HFMD-associated virus\ncirculating in Viet Nam currently. HFMD caused by this virus can\nresult in a more serious form of this common childhood disease leading\nto paralysis, encephalitis or death. This year's outbreak is a sharp\nincrease from recent years. Since 2008, about 10 000 to 15 000 cases\nwere reported annually with about 20 to 30 children dying each year.\n\nA map showing the locations of HCM city (southern area map) and the\nprovinces of Viet Nam can be accessed at:\nhttp://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (06) 20110730.2291\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (05) 20110723.2218\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Viet Nam (04): HCM 20110613.1804\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03): HCM 20110607.1739\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02): (QN, HCM) 20110604.1712\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (HCM) 20110409.1119\n.................................................cp/ejp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Duong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "928058", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=928058", "date": "2011-08-16 18:35:25", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - VIET NAM (07)\n********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 15 Aug 2011\nSource: Thanh Nien News [edited]\nhttp://www.thanhniennews.com/2010/Pages/20110815144904.aspx\n\n\nHFMD death toll climbs to 81 in Viet Nam\n----------------------------------------\nA health official said 96 percent of HFMD [Hand, foot and mouth\ndisease] fatalities in Viet Nam this year have been of children under\n5 years of age. The death toll for HFMD has climbed to 81 among 32 588\ncases reported in 52 cities and provinces, according to the Viet Nam\nAdministration of Preventive Medicine.\n\nTran Thanh Duong, the agency's deputy chief, told the Viet Nam News\nAgency that fatalities have been reported in 17 cities and provinces,\nwith Ho Chi Minh City having the highest toll at 22, followed by the\nprovinces of Dong Nai, Binh Duong, Long An and Ba Ria-Vung Tau. He\nadded 96 percent of fatalities were of children under 5.\n\nDuong's office has warned the disease may continue to spread to more\nprovinces and claim more lives in the coming months. The risks are\nhigher for children attending kindergartens, since the new school year\nhas begun, it said.\n\nThe Ministry of Health has asked the education sector to take active\nmeasures to sterilize [decontaminate] kindergartens, day care centers\nand schools to prevent the spread of the HFMD virus.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Since the end of June 2011 the number of cases of HFMD in Viet Nam\nhas risen from around 23 000 to 32 588, and death toll has risen from\n70 to 81.\n\nIt has been established previously (see ProMED-mail posts referenced\nbelow) that human enterovirus 71 is the dominant HFMD-associated virus\ncirculating in Viet Nam currently. HFMD caused by this virus can\nresult in a more serious form of this common childhood disease leading\nto paralysis, encephalitis or death. This year's outbreak is a sharp\nincrease from recent years. Since 2008, about 10 000 to 15 000 cases\nwere reported annually with about 20 to 30 children dying each year.\n\nA map showing the locations of HCM city (southern area map) and the\nprovinces of Viet Nam can be accessed at:\nhttp://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (06) 20110730.2291\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (05) 20110723.2218\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Viet Nam (04): HCM 20110613.1804\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03): HCM 20110607.1739\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02): (QN, HCM) 20110604.1712\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (HCM) 20110409.1119\n.................................................cp/ejp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Duong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "927079", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - USA (02): (TX), daycare facilities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=927079", "date": "2011-08-16 18:35:25", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - VIET NAM (07)\n********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 15 Aug 2011\nSource: Thanh Nien News [edited]\nhttp://www.thanhniennews.com/2010/Pages/20110815144904.aspx\n\n\nHFMD death toll climbs to 81 in Viet Nam\n----------------------------------------\nA health official said 96 percent of HFMD [Hand, foot and mouth\ndisease] fatalities in Viet Nam this year have been of children under\n5 years of age. The death toll for HFMD has climbed to 81 among 32 588\ncases reported in 52 cities and provinces, according to the Viet Nam\nAdministration of Preventive Medicine.\n\nTran Thanh Duong, the agency's deputy chief, told the Viet Nam News\nAgency that fatalities have been reported in 17 cities and provinces,\nwith Ho Chi Minh City having the highest toll at 22, followed by the\nprovinces of Dong Nai, Binh Duong, Long An and Ba Ria-Vung Tau. He\nadded 96 percent of fatalities were of children under 5.\n\nDuong's office has warned the disease may continue to spread to more\nprovinces and claim more lives in the coming months. The risks are\nhigher for children attending kindergartens, since the new school year\nhas begun, it said.\n\nThe Ministry of Health has asked the education sector to take active\nmeasures to sterilize [decontaminate] kindergartens, day care centers\nand schools to prevent the spread of the HFMD virus.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Since the end of June 2011 the number of cases of HFMD in Viet Nam\nhas risen from around 23 000 to 32 588, and death toll has risen from\n70 to 81.\n\nIt has been established previously (see ProMED-mail posts referenced\nbelow) that human enterovirus 71 is the dominant HFMD-associated virus\ncirculating in Viet Nam currently. HFMD caused by this virus can\nresult in a more serious form of this common childhood disease leading\nto paralysis, encephalitis or death. This year's outbreak is a sharp\nincrease from recent years. Since 2008, about 10 000 to 15 000 cases\nwere reported annually with about 20 to 30 children dying each year.\n\nA map showing the locations of HCM city (southern area map) and the\nprovinces of Viet Nam can be accessed at:\nhttp://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (06) 20110730.2291\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (05) 20110723.2218\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Viet Nam (04): HCM 20110613.1804\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03): HCM 20110607.1739\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02): (QN, HCM) 20110604.1712\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (HCM) 20110409.1119\n.................................................cp/ejp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Duong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "922857", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (02): (SK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=922857", "date": "2011-08-16 18:35:25", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - VIET NAM (07)\n********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 15 Aug 2011\nSource: Thanh Nien News [edited]\nhttp://www.thanhniennews.com/2010/Pages/20110815144904.aspx\n\n\nHFMD death toll climbs to 81 in Viet Nam\n----------------------------------------\nA health official said 96 percent of HFMD [Hand, foot and mouth\ndisease] fatalities in Viet Nam this year have been of children under\n5 years of age. The death toll for HFMD has climbed to 81 among 32 588\ncases reported in 52 cities and provinces, according to the Viet Nam\nAdministration of Preventive Medicine.\n\nTran Thanh Duong, the agency's deputy chief, told the Viet Nam News\nAgency that fatalities have been reported in 17 cities and provinces,\nwith Ho Chi Minh City having the highest toll at 22, followed by the\nprovinces of Dong Nai, Binh Duong, Long An and Ba Ria-Vung Tau. He\nadded 96 percent of fatalities were of children under 5.\n\nDuong's office has warned the disease may continue to spread to more\nprovinces and claim more lives in the coming months. The risks are\nhigher for children attending kindergartens, since the new school year\nhas begun, it said.\n\nThe Ministry of Health has asked the education sector to take active\nmeasures to sterilize [decontaminate] kindergartens, day care centers\nand schools to prevent the spread of the HFMD virus.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Since the end of June 2011 the number of cases of HFMD in Viet Nam\nhas risen from around 23 000 to 32 588, and death toll has risen from\n70 to 81.\n\nIt has been established previously (see ProMED-mail posts referenced\nbelow) that human enterovirus 71 is the dominant HFMD-associated virus\ncirculating in Viet Nam currently. HFMD caused by this virus can\nresult in a more serious form of this common childhood disease leading\nto paralysis, encephalitis or death. This year's outbreak is a sharp\nincrease from recent years. The risks are\nhigher for children attending kindergartens, since the new school year\nhas begun, it said.\n\nThe Ministry of Health has asked the education sector to take active\nmeasures to sterilize [decontaminate] kindergartens, day care centers\nand schools to prevent the spread of the HFMD virus.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Since the end of June 2011 the number of cases of HFMD in Viet Nam\nhas risen from around 23 000 to 32 588, and death toll has risen from\n70 to 81.\n\nIt has been established previously (see ProMED-mail posts referenced\nbelow) that human enterovirus 71 is the dominant HFMD-associated virus\ncirculating in Viet Nam currently. HFMD caused by this virus can\nresult in a more serious form of this common childhood disease leading\nto paralysis, encephalitis or death. This year's outbreak is a sharp\nincrease from recent years.
