We're seeing an increase in the area currently,\" Ranata\nHatcher, a pediatric nurse practitioner, said.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the illness\nusually starts after a fever, then rashes can appear on arms and legs,\neven ulcers can appear in your child's mouth, causing him or her pain\nwhen eating or drinking foods. Hatcher said, \"It's spread through\nsaliva, eating, and drinking after each other. That's why it's so\nprevalent in preschools and day cares.\"\n\nAnd preventing it is as easy as cleaning toys with bleach and washing\nyour hands. \"We recommend you rub your hands together, cleaning under\nyour fingernails, between your fingers, backs of the hands. If you\nteach them the ABC's while they're washing their hands, that's about\nthe time frame you need to efficiently kill all the germs,\" Hatcher\nsaid.\n\nParents shouldn't be afraid; the disease has nothing to do with\nanimals. \"HFMD is specific to humans. Foot-and-mouth disease is\nsomething that you see in animals, you cannot catch hand-foot-mouth\ndisease from an animal,\" Hatcher said.\n\nHatcher said not being clean is the no. 1 cause for the spread of\nhand- foot-mouth disease. If your child is showing signs of\ndehydration, a symptom of the illness, you might want to call your\ndoctor.\n\n[Byline: Tony Russell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_.\nThis genus of viruses includes the polioviruses, coxsackieviruses,\nechoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most\ncommon cause of HFMD in the United States in recent years, but other\ncoxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness. Other\nenteroviruses, such as enterovirus 71, have also been associated with\noutbreaks of HFMD, principally in Asia.\n\nIndividual cases and outbreaks of HFMD occur worldwide. In temperate\nclimates cases occur more often in summer and early autumn. HFMD\ncaused by coxsackievirus A16 infection is generally a mild disease,\nwith nearly all patients recovering in 7 to 10 days without medical\ntreatment. Since 1997, however, outbreaks of HFMD caused by\nenterovirus 71 have been reported in Asia and Australia. HFMD caused\nby enterovirus 71 has shown a higher incidence of neurologic\ninvolvement and fatal cases of encephalitis have occurred during\noutbreaks. However, such serious outcomes are still very rare.\n\nHFMD infection is spread from person to person by direct contact.\nInfectious virus is found in the nose and throat secretions, saliva,\nblister fluid and stool of infected persons. The virus is most often\nspread by persons with unwashed, virus-contaminated hands and by\ncontact with virus-contaminated surfaces. Infected persons are most\ncontagious during the 1st week of the illness, but may remain a source\nof infection for others after symptoms have resolved.\n\nComplications from virus infections that cause HFMD are uncommon;\n\"aseptic\" meningitis can occur rarely with HFMD causing fever,\nheadache, stiff neck, or back pain. Some patients may require\nhospitalization for a short time. Other more serious conditions, such\nas encephalitis, are very rare although encephalitis can be fatal.\nThere have been reports of fingernail and toenail loss occurring\nmostly in children within 4 weeks of having HFMD (see: ProMED-mail\npostings Onychomadesis, coxsackievirus - USA: (MI), RFI 20080729.2317;\nOnychomadesis - Spain: (Valencia), coxsackievirus 20080709.2099; and\nOnychomadesis - Spain: (Valencia), coxsackievirus (02) 20080711.2120).\nAt this time, it is not known whether the reported nail loss is or is\nnot a result of the infection. However, nail loss has been temporary\nand nail growth has resumed without medical treatment.\n\nFurther information about HFMD can be obtained from the CDC website\nat http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/revb/enterovirus/hfhf.htm.\n\nIt is difficult to assess the seriousness of the outbreak of HFMD at\nFort Smith in the absence of information on the number of children\n(and adults) affected and without identification of the causative\nagent. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Fort Smith can be located via the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap at http://healthmap.org/r/0Rit. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (HCM) 20110409.1119\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India: (MH) 20110101.0009\n2010\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease (07): Viet Nam 20100801.2586\nHand foot & mouth disease (06): Thailand 20100721.2451\nHand, foot & mouth disease (05): China, rural areas 20100625.2121\nHand, foot & mouth disease (04): China (GI) 20100507.1489\nHand, foot & mouth disease (03): China (Beijing) 20100416.1235\nHand, foot & mouth disease (02): China 20100412.1184\nHand foot & mouth disease: Singapore, China (HN), Viet Nam\n20100329.0985\n.................................................sb/cp/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1971-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fort Smith", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "795900", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=795900", "date": "2011-05-19 17:24:09", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA: (ARKANSAS)\n**********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 May 2011\nSource: 4029tv.com [edited]\nhttp://www.4029tv.com/news/27918437/detail.html\n\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) can easily be prevented by just\nwashing your hands, and doctors [in Fort Smith , Arkansas] said\nthey've been seeing more cases this season. \"It's easily spread in\nyounger children, preschool children, school-aged children, and in day\ncares. We're seeing an increase in the area currently,\" Ranata\nHatcher, a pediatric nurse practitioner, said.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the illness\nusually starts after a fever, then rashes can appear on arms and legs,\neven ulcers can appear in your child's mouth, causing him or her pain\nwhen eating or drinking foods. Hatcher said, \"It's spread through\nsaliva, eating, and drinking after each other. That's why it's so\nprevalent in preschools and day cares.\"\n\nAnd preventing it is as easy as cleaning toys with bleach and washing\nyour hands. \"We recommend you rub your hands together, cleaning under\nyour fingernails, between your fingers, backs of the hands. If you\nteach them the ABC's while they're washing their hands, that's about\nthe time frame you need to efficiently kill all the germs,\" Hatcher\nsaid.\n\nParents shouldn't be afraid; the disease has nothing to do with\nanimals. \"HFMD is specific to humans. Foot-and-mouth disease is\nsomething that you see in animals, you cannot catch hand-foot-mouth\ndisease from an animal,\" Hatcher said.\n\nHatcher said not being clean is the no. 1 cause for the spread of\nhand- foot-mouth disease. If your child is showing signs of\ndehydration, a symptom of the illness, you might want to call your\ndoctor.\n\n[Byline: Tony Russell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_.\nThis genus of viruses includes the polioviruses, coxsackieviruses,\nechoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most\ncommon cause of HFMD in the United States in recent years, but other\ncoxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness. Other\nenteroviruses, such as enterovirus 71, have also been associated with\noutbreaks of HFMD, principally in Asia.\n\nIndividual cases and outbreaks of HFMD occur worldwide. In temperate\nclimates cases occur more often in summer and early autumn. HFMD\ncaused by coxsackievirus A16 infection is generally a mild disease,\nwith nearly all patients recovering in 7 to 10 days without medical\ntreatment. Since 1997, however, outbreaks of HFMD caused by\nenterovirus 71 have been reported in Asia and Australia. HFMD caused\nby enterovirus 71 has shown a higher incidence of neurologic\ninvolvement and fatal cases of encephalitis have occurred during\noutbreaks. However, such serious outcomes are still very rare.\n\nHFMD infection is spread from person to person by direct contact.\nInfectious virus is found in the nose and throat secretions, saliva,\nblister fluid and stool of infected persons. The virus is most often\nspread by persons with unwashed, virus-contaminated hands and by\ncontact with virus-contaminated surfaces. Infected persons are most\ncontagious during the 1st week of the illness, but may remain a source\nof infection for others after symptoms have resolved.\n\nComplications from virus infections that cause HFMD are uncommon;\n\"aseptic\" meningitis can occur rarely with HFMD causing fever,\nheadache, stiff neck, or back pain. Some patients may require\nhospitalization for a short time. Other more serious conditions, such\nas encephalitis, are very rare although encephalitis can be fatal.\nThere have been reports of fingernail and toenail loss occurring\nmostly in children within 4 weeks of having HFMD (see: ProMED-mail\npostings Onychomadesis, coxsackievirus - USA: (MI), RFI 20080729.2317;\nOnychomadesis - Spain: (Valencia), coxsackievirus 20080709.2099; and\nOnychomadesis - Spain: (Valencia), coxsackievirus (02) 20080711.2120).\nAt this time, it is not known whether the reported nail loss is or is\nnot a result of the infection. However, nail loss has been temporary\nand nail growth has resumed without medical treatment.\n\nFurther information about HFMD can be obtained from the CDC website\nat http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/revb/enterovirus/hfhf.htm.\n\nIt is difficult to assess the seriousness of the outbreak of HFMD at\nFort Smith in the absence of information on the number of children\n(and adults) affected and without identification of the causative\nagent. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Fort Smith can be located via the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap at http://healthmap.org/r/0Rit. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (HCM) 20110409.1119\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India: (MH) 20110101.0009\n2010\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease (07): Viet Nam 20100801.2586\nHand foot & mouth disease (06): Thailand 20100721.2451\nHand, foot & mouth disease (05): China, rural areas 20100625.2121\nHand, foot & mouth disease (04): China (GI) 20100507.1489\nHand, foot & mouth disease (03): China (Beijing) 20100416.1235\nHand, foot & mouth disease (02): China 20100412.1184\nHand foot & mouth disease: Singapore, China (HN), Viet Nam\n20100329.0985\n.................................................sb/cp/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1971-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fort Smith", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "753817", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot and mouth disease - Viet Nam (04): HCM", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=753817", "date": "2011-05-19 17:24:09", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA: (ARKANSAS)\n**********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 May 2011\nSource: 4029tv.com [edited]\nhttp://www.4029tv.com/news/27918437/detail.html\n\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) can easily be prevented by just\nwashing your hands, and doctors [in Fort Smith , Arkansas] said\nthey've been seeing more cases this season. \"It's easily spread in\nyounger children, preschool children, school-aged children, and in day\ncares. We're seeing an increase in the area currently,\" Ranata\nHatcher, a pediatric nurse practitioner, said.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the illness\nusually starts after a fever, then rashes can appear on arms and legs,\neven ulcers can appear in your child's mouth, causing him or her pain\nwhen eating or drinking foods. Hatcher said, \"It's spread through\nsaliva, eating, and drinking after each other. That's why it's so\nprevalent in preschools and day cares.\"\n\nAnd preventing it is as easy as cleaning toys with bleach and washing\nyour hands. \"We recommend you rub your hands together, cleaning under\nyour fingernails, between your fingers, backs of the hands. If you\nteach them the ABC's while they're washing their hands, that's about\nthe time frame you need to efficiently kill all the germs,\" Hatcher\nsaid.\n\nParents shouldn't be afraid; the disease has nothing to do with\nanimals. \"HFMD is specific to humans. Foot-and-mouth disease is\nsomething that you see in animals, you cannot catch hand-foot-mouth\ndisease from an animal,\" Hatcher said.\n\nHatcher said not being clean is the no. 1 cause for the spread of\nhand- foot-mouth disease. If your child is showing signs of\ndehydration, a symptom of the illness, you might want to call your\ndoctor.\n\n[Byline: Tony Russell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_.\nThis genus of viruses includes the polioviruses, coxsackieviruses,\nechoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most\ncommon cause of HFMD in the United States in recent years, but other\ncoxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness. Other\nenteroviruses, such as enterovirus 71, have also been associated with\noutbreaks of HFMD, principally in Asia.\n\nIndividual cases and outbreaks of HFMD occur worldwide. In temperate\nclimates cases occur more often in summer and early autumn. HFMD\ncaused by coxsackievirus A16 infection is generally a mild disease,\nwith nearly all patients recovering in 7 to 10 days without medical\ntreatment. Since 1997, however, outbreaks of HFMD caused by\nenterovirus 71 have been reported in Asia and Australia. HFMD caused\nby enterovirus 71 has shown a higher incidence of neurologic\ninvolvement and fatal cases of encephalitis have occurred during\noutbreaks. However, such serious outcomes are still very rare.\n\nHFMD infection is spread from person to person by direct contact.\nInfectious virus is found in the nose and throat secretions, saliva,\nblister fluid and stool of infected persons. The virus is most often\nspread by persons with unwashed, virus-contaminated hands and by\ncontact with virus-contaminated surfaces. Infected persons are most\ncontagious during the 1st week of the illness, but may remain a source\nof infection for others after symptoms have resolved.\n\nComplications from virus infections that cause HFMD are uncommon;\n\"aseptic\" meningitis can occur rarely with HFMD causing fever,\nheadache, stiff neck, or back pain. Some patients may require\nhospitalization for a short time. Other more serious conditions, such\nas encephalitis, are very rare although encephalitis can be fatal.\nThere have been reports of fingernail and toenail loss occurring\nmostly in children within 4 weeks of having HFMD (see: ProMED-mail\npostings Onychomadesis, coxsackievirus - USA: (MI), RFI 20080729.2317;\nOnychomadesis - Spain: (Valencia), coxsackievirus 20080709.2099; and\nOnychomadesis - Spain: (Valencia), coxsackievirus (02) 20080711.2120).\nAt this time, it is not known whether the reported nail loss is or is\nnot a result of the infection. However, nail loss has been temporary\nand nail growth has resumed without medical treatment.\n\nFurther information about HFMD can be obtained from the CDC website\nat http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/revb/enterovirus/hfhf.htm.\n\nIt is difficult to assess the seriousness of the outbreak of HFMD at\nFort Smith in the absence of information on the number of children\n(and adults) affected and without identification of the causative\nagent. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Fort Smith can be located via the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap at http://healthmap.org/r/0Rit. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (HCM) 20110409.1119\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03): HCM", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=746211", "date": "2011-05-19 17:24:09", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA: (ARKANSAS)\n**********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 May 2011\nSource: 4029tv.com [edited]\nhttp://www.4029tv.com/news/27918437/detail.html\n\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) can easily be prevented by just\nwashing your hands, and doctors [in Fort Smith , Arkansas] said\nthey've been seeing more cases this season. \"It's easily spread in\nyounger children, preschool children, school-aged children, and in day\ncares. We're seeing an increase in the area currently,\" Ranata\nHatcher, a pediatric nurse practitioner, said.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the illness\nusually starts after a fever, then rashes can appear on arms and legs,\neven ulcers can appear in your child's mouth, causing him or her pain\nwhen eating or drinking foods. Hatcher said, \"It's spread through\nsaliva, eating, and drinking after each other. That's why it's so\nprevalent in preschools and day cares.\"\n\nAnd preventing it is as easy as cleaning toys with bleach and washing\nyour hands. \"We recommend you rub your hands together, cleaning under\nyour fingernails, between your fingers, backs of the hands. If you\nteach them the ABC's while they're washing their hands, that's about\nthe time frame you need to efficiently kill all the germs,\" Hatcher\nsaid.\n\nParents shouldn't be afraid; the disease has nothing to do with\nanimals. \"HFMD is specific to humans. Foot-and-mouth disease is\nsomething that you see in animals, you cannot catch hand-foot-mouth\ndisease from an animal,\" Hatcher said.\n\nHatcher said not being clean is the no. 1 cause for the spread of\nhand- foot-mouth disease. If your child is showing signs of\ndehydration, a symptom of the illness, you might want to call your\ndoctor.\n\n[Byline: Tony Russell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_.\nThis genus of viruses includes the polioviruses, coxsackieviruses,\nechoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most\ncommon cause of HFMD in the United States in recent years, but other\ncoxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness. Other\nenteroviruses, such as enterovirus 71, have also been associated with\noutbreaks of HFMD, principally in Asia.\n\nIndividual cases and outbreaks of HFMD occur worldwide. In temperate\nclimates cases occur more often in summer and early autumn. HFMD\ncaused by coxsackievirus A16 infection is generally a mild disease,\nwith nearly all patients recovering in 7 to 10 days without medical\ntreatment. Since 1997, however, outbreaks of HFMD caused by\nenterovirus 71 have been reported in Asia and Australia. HFMD caused\nby enterovirus 71 has shown a higher incidence of neurologic\ninvolvement and fatal cases of encephalitis have occurred during\noutbreaks. However, such serious outcomes are still very rare.\n\nHFMD infection is spread from person to person by direct contact.\nInfectious virus is found in the nose and throat secretions, saliva,\nblister fluid and stool of infected persons. The virus is most often\nspread by persons with unwashed, virus-contaminated hands and by\ncontact with virus-contaminated surfaces. Infected persons are most\ncontagious during the 1st week of the illness, but may remain a source\nof infection for others after symptoms have resolved.\n\nComplications from virus infections that cause HFMD are uncommon;\n\"aseptic\" meningitis can occur rarely with HFMD causing fever,\nheadache, stiff neck, or back pain. Some patients may require\nhospitalization for a short time. Other more serious conditions, such\nas encephalitis, are very rare although encephalitis can be fatal.\nThere have been reports of fingernail and toenail loss occurring\nmostly in children within 4 weeks of having HFMD (see: ProMED-mail\npostings Onychomadesis, coxsackievirus - USA: (MI), RFI 20080729.2317;\nOnychomadesis - Spain: (Valencia), coxsackievirus 20080709.2099; and\nOnychomadesis - Spain: (Valencia), coxsackievirus (02) 20080711.2120).\nAt this time, it is not known whether the reported nail loss is or is\nnot a result of the infection. However, nail loss has been temporary\nand nail growth has resumed without medical treatment.\n\nFurther information about HFMD can be obtained from the CDC website\nat http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/revb/enterovirus/hfhf.htm.\n\nIt is difficult to assess the seriousness of the outbreak of HFMD at\nFort Smith in the absence of information on the number of children\n(and adults) affected and without identification of the causative\nagent. - Croatia: (ZG) childcare centre", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=731679", "date": "2011-05-19 17:24:09", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA: (ARKANSAS)\n**********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 May 2011\nSource: 4029tv.com [edited]\nhttp://www.4029tv.com/news/27918437/detail.html\n\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) can easily be prevented by just\nwashing your hands, and doctors [in Fort Smith , Arkansas] said\nthey've been seeing more cases this season. \"It's easily spread in\nyounger children, preschool children, school-aged children, and in day\ncares. We're seeing an increase in the area currently,\" Ranata\nHatcher, a pediatric nurse practitioner, said.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the illness\nusually starts after a fever, then rashes can appear on arms and legs,\neven ulcers can appear in your child's mouth, causing him or her pain\nwhen eating or drinking foods. Hatcher said, \"It's spread through\nsaliva, eating, and drinking after each other. That's why it's so\nprevalent in preschools and day cares.\"\n\nAnd preventing it is as easy as cleaning toys with bleach and washing\nyour hands. \"We recommend you rub your hands together, cleaning under\nyour fingernails, between your fingers, backs of the hands. If you\nteach them the ABC's while they're washing their hands, that's about\nthe time frame you need to efficiently kill all the germs,\" Hatcher\nsaid.\n\nParents shouldn't be afraid; the disease has nothing to do with\nanimals. \"HFMD is specific to humans. Foot-and-mouth disease is\nsomething that you see in animals, you cannot catch hand-foot-mouth\ndisease from an animal,\" Hatcher said.\n\nHatcher said not being clean is the no. 1 cause for the spread of\nhand- foot-mouth disease. If your child is showing signs of\ndehydration, a symptom of the illness, you might want to call your\ndoctor.\n\n[Byline: Tony Russell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_.\nThis genus of viruses includes the polioviruses, coxsackieviruses,\nechoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most\ncommon cause of HFMD in the United States in recent years, but other\ncoxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness. Other\nenteroviruses, such as enterovirus 71, have also been associated with\noutbreaks of HFMD, principally in Asia.\n\nIndividual cases and outbreaks of HFMD occur worldwide. In temperate\nclimates cases occur more often in summer and early autumn. HFMD\ncaused by coxsackievirus A16 infection is generally a mild disease,\nwith nearly all patients recovering in 7 to 10 days without medical\ntreatment. Since 1997, however, outbreaks of HFMD caused by\nenterovirus 71 have been reported in Asia and Australia. HFMD caused\nby enterovirus 71 has shown a higher incidence of neurologic\ninvolvement and fatal cases of encephalitis have occurred during\noutbreaks. However, such serious outcomes are still very rare.\n\nHFMD infection is spread from person to person by direct contact.\nInfectious virus is found in the nose and throat secretions, saliva,\nblister fluid and stool of infected persons. The virus is most often\nspread by persons with unwashed, virus-contaminated hands and by\ncontact with virus-contaminated surfaces. Infected persons are most\ncontagious during the 1st week of the illness, but may remain a source\nof infection for others after symptoms have resolved.\n\nComplications from virus infections that cause HFMD are uncommon;\n\"aseptic\" meningitis can occur rarely with HFMD causing fever,\nheadache, stiff neck, or back pain. Some patients may require\nhospitalization for a short time. Other more serious conditions, such\nas encephalitis, are very rare although encephalitis can be fatal.\nThere have been reports of fingernail and toenail loss occurring\nmostly in children within 4 weeks of having HFMD (see: ProMED-mail\npostings Onychomadesis, coxsackievirus - USA: (MI), RFI 20080729.2317;\nOnychomadesis - Spain: (Valencia), coxsackievirus 20080709.2099; and\nOnychomadesis - Spain: (Valencia), coxsackievirus (02) 20080711.2120).\nAt this time, it is not known whether the reported nail loss is or is\nnot a result of the infection. However, nail loss has been temporary\nand nail growth has resumed without medical treatment.\n\nFurther information about HFMD can be obtained from the CDC website\nat http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/revb/enterovirus/hfhf.htm.\n\nIt is difficult to assess the seriousness of the outbreak of HFMD at\nFort Smith in the absence of information on the number of children\n(and adults) affected and without identification of the causative\nagent. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Fort Smith can be located via the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap at http://healthmap.org/r/0Rit. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (HCM) 20110409.1119\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India: (MH) 20110101.0009\n2010\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease (07): Viet Nam 20100801.2586\nHand foot & mouth disease (06): Thailand 20100721.2451\nHand, foot & mouth disease (05): China, rural areas 20100625.2121\nHand, foot & mouth disease (04): China (GI) 20100507.1489\nHand, foot & mouth disease (03): China (Beijing) 20100416.1235\nHand, foot & mouth disease (02): China 20100412.1184\nHand foot & mouth disease: Singapore, China (HN), Viet Nam\n20100329.0985\n.................................................sb/cp/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1971-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fort Smith", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "727705", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Hong Kong, nursery school", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=727705", "date": "2011-05-19 17:24:09", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA: (ARKANSAS)\n**********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 May 2011\nSource: 4029tv.com [edited]\nhttp://www.4029tv.com/news/27918437/detail.html\n\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) can easily be prevented by just\nwashing your hands, and doctors [in Fort Smith , Arkansas] said\nthey've been seeing more cases this season. \"It's easily spread in\nyounger children, preschool children, school-aged children, and in day\ncares. We're seeing an increase in the area currently,\" Ranata\nHatcher, a pediatric nurse practitioner, said.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the illness\nusually starts after a fever, then rashes can appear on arms and legs,\neven ulcers can appear in your child's mouth, causing him or her pain\nwhen eating or drinking foods. Hatcher said, \"It's spread through\nsaliva, eating, and drinking after each other. That's why it's so\nprevalent in preschools and day cares.\"\n\nAnd preventing it is as easy as cleaning toys with bleach and washing\nyour hands. \"We recommend you rub your hands together, cleaning under\nyour fingernails, between your fingers, backs of the hands. If you\nteach them the ABC's while they're washing their hands, that's about\nthe time frame you need to efficiently kill all the germs,\" Hatcher\nsaid.\n\nParents shouldn't be afraid; the disease has nothing to do with\nanimals. \"HFMD is specific to humans. Foot-and-mouth disease is\nsomething that you see in animals, you cannot catch hand-foot-mouth\ndisease from an animal,\" Hatcher said.\n\nHatcher said not being clean is the no. 1 cause for the spread of\nhand- foot-mouth disease. If your child is showing signs of\ndehydration, a symptom of the illness, you might want to call your\ndoctor.\n\n[Byline: Tony Russell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_.\nThis genus of viruses includes the polioviruses, coxsackieviruses,\nechoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most\ncommon cause of HFMD in the United States in recent years, but other\ncoxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness. Other\nenteroviruses, such as enterovirus 71, have also been associated with\noutbreaks of HFMD, principally in Asia.\n\nIndividual cases and outbreaks of HFMD occur worldwide. In temperate\nclimates cases occur more often in summer and early autumn. HFMD\ncaused by coxsackievirus A16 infection is generally a mild disease,\nwith nearly all patients recovering in 7 to 10 days without medical\ntreatment. Since 1997, however, outbreaks of HFMD caused by\nenterovirus 71 have been reported in Asia and Australia. HFMD caused\nby enterovirus 71 has shown a higher incidence of neurologic\ninvolvement and fatal cases of encephalitis have occurred during\noutbreaks. However, such serious outcomes are still very rare.\n\nHFMD infection is spread from person to person by direct contact.\nInfectious virus is found in the nose and throat secretions, saliva,\nblister fluid and stool of infected persons. The virus is most often\nspread by persons with unwashed, virus-contaminated hands and by\ncontact with virus-contaminated surfaces. Infected persons are most\ncontagious during the 1st week of the illness, but may remain a source\nof infection for others after symptoms have resolved.\n\nComplications from virus infections that cause HFMD are uncommon;\n\"aseptic\" meningitis can occur rarely with HFMD causing fever,\nheadache, stiff neck, or back pain. Some patients may require\nhospitalization for a short time. Other more serious conditions, such\nas encephalitis, are very rare although encephalitis can be fatal.\nThere have been reports of fingernail and toenail loss occurring\nmostly in children within 4 weeks of having HFMD (see: ProMED-mail\npostings Onychomadesis, coxsackievirus - USA: (MI), RFI 20080729.2317;\nOnychomadesis - Spain: (Valencia), coxsackievirus 20080709.2099; and\nOnychomadesis - Spain: (Valencia), coxsackievirus (02) 20080711.2120).\nAt this time, it is not known whether the reported nail loss is or is\nnot a result of the infection. However, nail loss has been temporary\nand nail growth has resumed without medical treatment.\n\nFurther information about HFMD can be obtained from the CDC website\nat http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/revb/enterovirus/hfhf.htm.\n\nIt is difficult to assess the seriousness of the outbreak of HFMD at\nFort Smith in the absence of information on the number of children\n(and adults) affected and without identification of the causative\nagent. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Fort Smith can be located via the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap at http://healthmap.org/r/0Rit. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (HCM) 20110409.1119\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Foot-and-mouth disease is\nsomething that you see in animals, you cannot catch hand-foot-mouth\ndisease from an animal,\" Hatcher said.\n\nHatcher said not being clean is the no. 1 cause for the spread of\nhand- foot-mouth disease. If your child is showing signs of\ndehydration, a symptom of the illness, you might want to call your\ndoctor.\n\n[Byline: Tony Russell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_.\nThis genus of viruses includes the polioviruses, coxsackieviruses,\nechoviruses, and enteroviruses. Other\nenteroviruses, such as enterovirus 71, have also been associated with\noutbreaks of HFMD, principally in Asia.\n\nIndividual cases and outbreaks of HFMD occur worldwide. In temperate\nclimates cases occur more often in summer and early autumn. Since 1997, however, outbreaks of HFMD caused by\nenterovirus 71 have been reported in Asia and Australia. HFMD caused\nby enterovirus 71 has shown a higher incidence of neurologic\ninvolvement and fatal cases of encephalitis have occurred during\noutbreaks. However, such serious outcomes are still very rare.\n\nHFMD infection is spread from person to person by direct contact.\nInfectious virus is found in the nose and throat secretions, saliva,\nblister fluid and stool of infected persons. The virus is most often\nspread by persons with unwashed, virus-contaminated hands and by\ncontact with virus-contaminated surfaces. Infected persons are most\ncontagious during the 1st week of the illness, but may remain a source\nof infection for others after symptoms have resolved.\n\nComplications from virus infections that cause HFMD are uncommon;\n\"aseptic\" meningitis can occur rarely with HFMD causing fever,\nheadache, stiff neck, or back pain. Some patients may require\nhospitalization for a short time. India: (MH) 20110101.0009\n2010\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease (07): Viet Nam 20100801.2586\nHand foot & mouth disease (06): Thailand 20100721.2451\nHand, foot & mouth disease (05): China, rural areas 20100625.2121\nHand, foot & mouth disease (04): China (GI) 20100507.1489\nHand, foot & mouth disease (03): China (Beijing) 20100416.1235\nHand, foot & mouth disease (02): China 20100412.1184\nHand foot & mouth disease: Singapore, China (HN), Viet Nam\n20100329.0985\n.................................................sb/cp/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1971-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fort Smith", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "695546", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: (HCM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=695546", "date": "2010-07-21 17:00:09", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE (06): THAILAND\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 20 Jul 2010\nSource: Phuket Gazette, Daily News [edited]\n<http://www.phuketgazette.net/archives/articles/2010/article8979.html>\n\n\nWith more than 70 children in Phuket having contracted Hand, Foot and\nMouth Disease (HFMD) already this year [2010], Phuket City\nMunicipality has issued an advisory urging parents to be aware of the\nhighly contagious disease.\n\nNittaya Panchamedithee, an officer at the municipality's health\nsection, said: \"There is more chance of an outbreak in the rainy\nseason as the virus can live longer when the weather is cool and\nhumid.\" The onset of the rainy season also coincides with the start\nof the 1st school semester, which also makes it easy for the virus to\nspread, she said.\n\nMs Nittaya urged parents to keep an eye on all children, especially\nthose under 3 years old and infants. Indications of the disease\ninclude fever, loss of appetite, lethargy, coughing, a sore throat,\nvomiting and diarrhea. The disease is most often identified by mouth\nulcers and rashes on the hands and feet.\n\nParents whose children exhibit any of these conditions are urged to\nseek medical treatment as soon as possible and not to allow their\nchildren to go to school, said the release. Teachers were also urged\nto be vigilant against an outbreak. School administrators should\nsuspend any classes with 2 or more children found to have HFMD, and\nany schools with 5 or more children diagnosed with the disease should\nbe closed temporarily.\n\n[Byline: Sitthipong Nongkaew]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This newspaper article reproduces a poster used to raise awareness\nof hand, foot and mouth disease in a rather oblique manner.\n\nOwing to the ubiquity and regularity of outbreaks of HFMD in\nSoutheast Asia at this time of year, ProMED-mail does not routinely\nreport individual outbreaks of HFMD. Currently, HFMD is widespread\nthroughout most provinces of China. The onset of milder weather\nfacilitates transmission of the infection, and strict attention to\npersonal hygiene is the only protection against infection.\n\nHFMD is a common illness of infants and children caused by viruses\nthat belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. This genus of viruses\nincludes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and\nenteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most common cause of\nHFMD, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with this\nillness. In recent outbreaks in Asia and Australasia, enterovirus 71\nhas more often been associated with HFMD and linked with rare\nneurological complications of infection. In the outbreak of HFMD in\nViet Nam (Ho Chi Minh City) in March 2010 (see the 1st of the\nProMED-mail archived references below), several children suffered\nserious neurological complications, so it is probable that\nenterovirus 71 is the etiologic agent circulating in Thailand at\npresent.\n\nPhuket is an island in the south of Thailand, and Phuket city is the\nmain population centre in the southeast of the island. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Thailand can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00cC>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand foot & mouth disease: Singapore, China (HN), Viet Nam 20100329.0985\n2009\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20090920.3306\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20090920.3305\n2008\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: HCM, RFI 20080423.1435\n2007\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (HCM city) 20070926.3193\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (05): Viet Nam 20060910.2573\n.........................................................sb/cp/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. India: (MH)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=617140", "date": "2010-07-21 17:00:09", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE (06): THAILAND\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 20 Jul 2010\nSource: Phuket Gazette, Daily News [edited]\n<http://www.phuketgazette.net/archives/articles/2010/article8979.html>\n\n\nWith more than 70 children in Phuket having contracted Hand, Foot and\nMouth Disease (HFMD) already this year [2010], Phuket City\nMunicipality has issued an advisory urging parents to be aware of the\nhighly contagious disease.\n\nNittaya Panchamedithee, an officer at the municipality's health\nsection, said: \"There is more chance of an outbreak in the rainy\nseason as the virus can live longer when the weather is cool and\nhumid.\" The onset of the rainy season also coincides with the start\nof the 1st school semester, which also makes it easy for the virus to\nspread, she said.\n\nMs Nittaya urged parents to keep an eye on all children, especially\nthose under 3 years old and infants. Indications of the disease\ninclude fever, loss of appetite, lethargy, coughing, a sore throat,\nvomiting and diarrhea. The disease is most often identified by mouth\nulcers and rashes on the hands and feet.\n\nParents whose children exhibit any of these conditions are urged to\nseek medical treatment as soon as possible and not to allow their\nchildren to go to school, said the release. Teachers were also urged\nto be vigilant against an outbreak. School administrators should\nsuspend any classes with 2 or more children found to have HFMD, and\nany schools with 5 or more children diagnosed with the disease should\nbe closed temporarily.\n\n[Byline: Sitthipong Nongkaew]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This newspaper article reproduces a poster used to raise awareness\nof hand, foot and mouth disease in a rather oblique manner.\n\nOwing to the ubiquity and regularity of outbreaks of HFMD in\nSoutheast Asia at this time of year, ProMED-mail does not routinely\nreport individual outbreaks of HFMD. Currently, HFMD is widespread\nthroughout most provinces of China. The onset of milder weather\nfacilitates transmission of the infection, and strict attention to\npersonal hygiene is the only protection against infection.\n\nHFMD is a common illness of infants and children caused by viruses\nthat belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. This genus of viruses\nincludes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and\nenteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most common cause of\nHFMD, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with this\nillness. In recent outbreaks in Asia and Australasia, enterovirus 71\nhas more often been associated with HFMD and linked with rare\nneurological complications of infection. In the outbreak of HFMD in\nViet Nam (Ho Chi Minh City) in March 2010 (see the 1st of the\nProMED-mail archived references below), several children suffered\nserious neurological complications, so it is probable that\nenterovirus 71 is the etiologic agent circulating in Thailand at\npresent.\n\nPhuket is an island in the south of Thailand, and Phuket city is the\nmain population centre in the southeast of the island. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Thailand can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00cC>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand foot & mouth disease: Singapore, China (HN), Viet Nam 20100329.0985\n2009\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20090920.3306\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20090920.3305\n2008\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: HCM, RFI 20080423.1435\n2007\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (HCM city) 20070926.3193\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (05): Viet Nam 20060910.2573\n.........................................................sb/cp/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Phuket", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "540636", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease (08): Thailand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=540636", "date": "2010-07-21 17:00:09", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE (06): THAILAND\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 20 Jul 2010\nSource: Phuket Gazette, Daily News [edited]\n<http://www.phuketgazette.net/archives/articles/2010/article8979.html>\n\n\nWith more than 70 children in Phuket having contracted Hand, Foot and\nMouth Disease (HFMD) already this year [2010], Phuket City\nMunicipality has issued an advisory urging parents to be aware of the\nhighly contagious disease.\n\nNittaya Panchamedithee, an officer at the municipality's health\nsection, said: \"There is more chance of an outbreak in the rainy\nseason as the virus can live longer when the weather is cool and\nhumid.\" The onset of the rainy season also coincides with the start\nof the 1st school semester, which also makes it easy for the virus to\nspread, she said.\n\nMs Nittaya urged parents to keep an eye on all children, especially\nthose under 3 years old and infants. Indications of the disease\ninclude fever, loss of appetite, lethargy, coughing, a sore throat,\nvomiting and diarrhea. The disease is most often identified by mouth\nulcers and rashes on the hands and feet.\n\nParents whose children exhibit any of these conditions are urged to\nseek medical treatment as soon as possible and not to allow their\nchildren to go to school, said the release. Teachers were also urged\nto be vigilant against an outbreak. School administrators should\nsuspend any classes with 2 or more children found to have HFMD, and\nany schools with 5 or more children diagnosed with the disease should\nbe closed temporarily.\n\n[Byline: Sitthipong Nongkaew]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This newspaper article reproduces a poster used to raise awareness\nof hand, foot and mouth disease in a rather oblique manner.\n\nOwing to the ubiquity and regularity of outbreaks of HFMD in\nSoutheast Asia at this time of year, ProMED-mail does not routinely\nreport individual outbreaks of HFMD. Currently, HFMD is widespread\nthroughout most provinces of China. The onset of milder weather\nfacilitates transmission of the infection, and strict attention to\npersonal hygiene is the only protection against infection.\n\nHFMD is a common illness of infants and children caused by viruses\nthat belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. This genus of viruses\nincludes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and\nenteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most common cause of\nHFMD, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with this\nillness. In recent outbreaks in Asia and Australasia, enterovirus 71\nhas more often been associated with HFMD and linked with rare\nneurological complications of infection. In the outbreak of HFMD in\nViet Nam (Ho Chi Minh City) in March 2010 (see the 1st of the\nProMED-mail archived references below), several children suffered\nserious neurological complications, so it is probable that\nenterovirus 71 is the etiologic agent circulating in Thailand at\npresent.\n\nPhuket is an island in the south of Thailand, and Phuket city is the\nmain population centre in the southeast of the island. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Thailand can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00cC>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand foot & mouth disease: Singapore, China (HN), Viet Nam 20100329.0985\n2009\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20090920.3306\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20090920.3305\n2008\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: HCM, RFI 20080423.1435\n2007\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (HCM city) 20070926.3193\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (05): Viet Nam 20060910.2573\n.........................................................sb/cp/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 20 Jul 2010\nSource: Phuket Gazette, Daily News [edited]\n<http://www.phuketgazette.net/archives/articles/2010/article8979.html>\n\n\nWith more than 70 children in Phuket having contracted Hand, Foot and\nMouth Disease (HFMD) already this year [2010], Phuket City\nMunicipality has issued an advisory urging parents to be aware of the\nhighly contagious disease.\n\nNittaya Panchamedithee, an officer at the municipality's health\nsection, said: \"There is more chance of an outbreak in the rainy\nseason as the virus can live longer when the weather is cool and\nhumid.\" The onset of the rainy season also coincides with the start\nof the 1st school semester, which also makes it easy for the virus to\nspread, she said.\n\nMs Nittaya urged parents to keep an eye on all children, especially\nthose under 3 years old and infants. Indications of the disease\ninclude fever, loss of appetite, lethargy, coughing, a sore throat,\nvomiting and diarrhea. The disease is most often identified by mouth\nulcers and rashes on the hands and feet.\n\nParents whose children exhibit any of these conditions are urged to\nseek medical treatment as soon as possible and not to allow their\nchildren to go to school, said the release. Teachers were also urged\nto be vigilant against an outbreak. School administrators should\nsuspend any classes with 2 or more children found to have HFMD, and\nany schools with 5 or more children diagnosed with the disease should\nbe closed temporarily.\n\n[Byline: Sitthipong Nongkaew]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This newspaper article reproduces a poster used to raise awareness\nof hand, foot and mouth disease in a rather oblique manner.\n\nOwing to the ubiquity and regularity of outbreaks of HFMD in\nSoutheast Asia at this time of year, ProMED-mail does not routinely\nreport individual outbreaks of HFMD. Currently, HFMD is widespread\nthroughout most provinces of China. The onset of milder weather\nfacilitates transmission of the infection, and strict attention to\npersonal hygiene is the only protection against infection.\n\nHFMD is a common illness of infants and children caused by viruses\nthat belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. This genus of viruses\nincludes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and\nenteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most common cause of\nHFMD, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with this\nillness. In recent outbreaks in Asia and Australasia, enterovirus 71\nhas more often been associated with HFMD and linked with rare\nneurological complications of infection. In the outbreak of HFMD in\nViet Nam (Ho Chi Minh City) in March 2010 (see the 1st of the\nProMED-mail archived references below), several children suffered\nserious neurological complications, so it is probable that\nenterovirus 71 is the etiologic agent circulating in Thailand at\npresent.\n\nPhuket is an island in the south of Thailand, and Phuket city is the\nmain population centre in the southeast of the island. [edited]\n<http://www.phuketgazette.net/archives/articles/2010/article8979.html>\n\n\nWith more than 70 children in Phuket having contracted Hand, Foot and\nMouth Disease (HFMD) already this year [2010], Phuket City\nMunicipality has issued an advisory urging parents to be aware of the\nhighly contagious disease.\n\nNittaya Panchamedithee, an officer at the municipality's health\nsection, said: \"There is more chance of an outbreak in the rainy\nseason as the virus can live longer when the weather is cool and\nhumid.\" The onset of the rainy season also coincides with the start\nof the 1st school semester, which also makes it easy for the virus to\nspread, she said.\n\nMs Nittaya urged parents to keep an eye on all children, especially\nthose under 3 years old and infants. Indications of the disease\ninclude fever, loss of appetite, lethargy, coughing, a sore throat,\nvomiting and diarrhea. Currently, HFMD is widespread\nthroughout most provinces of China. The onset of milder weather\nfacilitates transmission of the infection, and strict attention to\npersonal hygiene is the only protection against infection.\n\nHFMD is a common illness of infants and children caused by viruses\nthat belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. This genus of viruses\nincludes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and\nenteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most common cause of\nHFMD, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with this\nillness. In the outbreak of HFMD in\nViet Nam (Ho Chi Minh City) in March 2010 (see the 1st of the\nProMED-mail archived references below), several children suffered\nserious neurological complications, so it is probable that\nenterovirus 71 is the etiologic agent circulating in Thailand at\npresent.\n\nPhuket is an island in the south of Thailand, and Phuket city is the\nmain population centre in the southeast of the island. [2010], Phuket City\nMunicipality has issued an advisory urging parents to be aware of the\nhighly contagious disease.\n\nNittaya Panchamedithee, an officer at the municipality's health\nsection, 1st school semester, which also makes it easy for the virus to\nspread, she said.\n\nMs Nittaya urged parents to keep an eye on all children, especially\nthose under 3 years old and infants. Currently, HFMD is widespread\nthroughout most provinces of China. The onset of milder weather\nfacilitates transmission of the infection, and strict attention to\npersonal hygiene is the only protection against infection.\n\nHFMD is a common illness of infants and children caused by viruses\nthat belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. This genus of viruses\nincludes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and\nenteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most common cause of\nHFMD, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with this\nillness. In recent outbreaks in Asia and Australasia, enterovirus 71\nhas more often been associated with HFMD and linked with rare\nneurological complications of infection. In the outbreak of HFMD in\nViet Nam (Ho Chi Minh City) in March 2010 (see the 1st of the\nProMED-mail archived references below), several children suffered\nserious neurological complications, so it is probable that\nenterovirus 71 is the etiologic agent circulating in Thailand at\npresent.\n\nPhuket is an island in the south of Thailand, and Phuket city is the\nmain population centre in the southeast of the island. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Thailand can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00cC>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand foot & mouth disease: Singapore, China (HN), Viet Nam 20100329.0985\n2009\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20090920.3306\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20090920.3305\n2008\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: HCM, RFI 20080423.1435\n2007\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (HCM city) 20070926.3193\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (05): Viet Nam 20060910.2573\n.........................................................sb/cp/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Phuket", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "472242", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand foot & mouth disease (06): Thailand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=472242", "date": "2010-07-21 17:00:09", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE (06): THAILAND\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 20 Jul 2010\nSource: Phuket Gazette, Daily News [edited]\n<http://www.phuketgazette.net/archives/articles/2010/article8979.html>\n\n\nWith more than 70 children in Phuket having contracted Hand, Foot and\nMouth Disease (HFMD) already this year [2010], Phuket City\nMunicipality has issued an advisory urging parents to be aware of the\nhighly contagious disease.\n\nNittaya Panchamedithee, an officer at the municipality's health\nsection, said: \"There is more chance of an outbreak in the rainy\nseason as the virus can live longer when the weather is cool and\nhumid.\" The onset of the rainy season also coincides with the start\nof the 1st school semester, which also makes it easy for the virus to\nspread, she said.\n\nMs Nittaya urged parents to keep an eye on all children, especially\nthose under 3 years old and infants. Indications of the disease\ninclude fever, loss of appetite, lethargy, coughing, a sore throat,\nvomiting and diarrhea. The disease is most often identified by mouth\nulcers and rashes on the hands and feet.\n\nParents whose children exhibit any of these conditions are urged to\nseek medical treatment as soon as possible and not to allow their\nchildren to go to school, said the release. Teachers were also urged\nto be vigilant against an outbreak. School administrators should\nsuspend any classes with 2 or more children found to have HFMD, and\nany schools with 5 or more children diagnosed with the disease should\nbe closed temporarily.\n\n[Byline: Sitthipong Nongkaew]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This newspaper article reproduces a poster used to raise awareness\nof hand, foot and mouth disease in a rather oblique manner.\n\nOwing to the ubiquity and regularity of outbreaks of HFMD in\nSoutheast Asia at this time of year, ProMED-mail does not routinely\nreport individual outbreaks of HFMD. Currently, HFMD is widespread\nthroughout most provinces of China. The onset of milder weather\nfacilitates transmission of the infection, and strict attention to\npersonal hygiene is the only protection against infection.\n\nHFMD is a common illness of infants and children caused by viruses\nthat belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. This genus of viruses\nincludes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and\nenteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most common cause of\nHFMD, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with this\nillness. In recent outbreaks in Asia and Australasia, enterovirus 71\nhas more often been associated with HFMD and linked with rare\nneurological complications of infection. In the outbreak of HFMD in\nViet Nam (Ho Chi Minh City) in March 2010 (see the 1st of the\nProMED-mail archived references below), several children suffered\nserious neurological complications, so it is probable that\nenterovirus 71 is the etiologic agent circulating in Thailand at\npresent.\n\nPhuket is an island in the south of Thailand, and Phuket city is the\nmain population centre in the southeast of the island. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Thailand can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00cC>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand foot & mouth disease: Singapore, China (HN), Viet Nam 20100329.0985\n2009\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20090920.3306\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20090920.3305\n2008\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: HCM, RFI 20080423.1435\n2007\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (HCM city) 20070926.3193\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (05): Viet Nam 20060910.2573\n.........................................................sb/cp/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Some 3000 children in Viet Nam caught the\ndisease last year [2008] and at least 10 died.\n\nChildren's Hospital No. 1, for example, reported on Friday [11 Sep\n2009] that 60 patients were under treatment for the disease, which is\ncaused by the enterovirus 71, with fever, blisters, mouth ulcers, and rashes.\n\nDr Truong Huu Khanh from the hospital said nearly 90 percent of the\nchildren, mainly from other provinces, were admitted to the hospital\nin already serious condition.\n\n[Byline: Lien Chau, Thanh Tung]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPRO/MBDS\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness of\ninfants and children. The disease causes fever and blister-like\neruptions in the mouth and/or a skin rash. HFMD is caused by viruses\nthat belong to the enterovirus genus. This group of viruses includes\npolioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\nEnteroviruses, including enterovirus 71, have also been associated\nwith HFMD and with outbreaks of the disease. Enterovirus 71 may be\nassociated with fatalities due to viral meningitis or encephalitis\n(see <https://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/index.html>).\n\nDuring 2009, HFMD outbreak in Viet Nam started in April 2009, with\nincreasing numbers of patients reported in hospitals from Ho Chi Minh\nCity, Dong Nai, Binh Duong, Binh Phuoc, Tay Ninh and An Giang\nprovinces (see prior PRO/MBDS posting Hand, foot & mouth disease -\nViet Nam: RFI 20090411.1387).\n\nPeaks of HFMD were usually during the dry seasons from March to May\nand September to December. As of 22 May 2009, there were 50 children\ninfected with HFMD and 3 of them were in a serious condition (see\nprior PRO/MBDS posting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02)\n20090524.1942). As of 12 May 2008, 2300 cases of HFMD had been\nreported in Viet Nam with 10 fatalities during 2008 and most of the\nreported cases were from the southern regions (see prior PRO/MBDS\nposting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03) 20080516.1634).\n\nSince the beginning of 2009 to 11 Sep 2009, there had been 60\npatients under treatment for HFMD. Approximately 54 out of 60\nchildren (90 percent) were in serious condition. The disease is\ncaused by enterovirus 71. There is no specific vaccine for the disease.\n\nFor a map of Viet Nam with provinces, see\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:VietnameseProvincesMap.png>. The\ninteractive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map with direct links to other\noutbreaks in Viet Nam and surrounding countries reported on\nProMED-mail and PRO/MBDS can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/008c> - Mod.SCM]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (10): (SD) 20090710.2478\n2008\n----\nHand, foot & mouth - Asia (02): China, Singapore, Viet Nam 20080504.1528\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: HCM, RFI 20080423.1435\n\nand PRO/MBDS archives:\n\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02) 20090524.1942\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: RFI 20090411.1387\n2008\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (04): Ben Tre 20081110.3531\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03) 20080516.1634\nHand, foot & Mouth Disease - Viet Nam "main_text": "************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Sep 2009\nSource: Thanh Nien News [edited]\n<http://www.thanhniennews.com/healthy/?catid=8&newsid=52495>\n\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease is spreading in Ho Chi Minh City [HCMC],\nlocal authorities said. Some 3000 children in Viet Nam caught the\ndisease last year [2008] and at least 10 died.\n\nChildren's Hospital No. 1, for example, reported on Friday [11 Sep\n2009] that 60 patients were under treatment for the disease, which is\ncaused by the enterovirus 71, with fever, blisters, mouth ulcers, and rashes.\n\nDr Truong Huu Khanh from the hospital said nearly 90 percent of the\nchildren, mainly from other provinces, were admitted to the hospital\nin already serious condition.\n\n[Byline: Lien Chau, Thanh Tung]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPRO/MBDS\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness of\ninfants and children. The disease causes fever and blister-like\neruptions in the mouth and/or a skin rash. HFMD is caused by viruses\nthat belong to the enterovirus genus. This group of viruses includes\npolioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\nEnteroviruses, including enterovirus 71, have also been associated\nwith HFMD and with outbreaks of the disease. As of 22 May 2009, there were 50 children\ninfected with HFMD and 3 of them were in a serious condition (see\nprior PRO/MBDS posting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02)\n20090524.1942). As of 12 May 2008, 2300 cases of HFMD had been\nreported in Viet Nam with 10 fatalities during 2008 and most of the\nreported cases were from the southern regions (see prior PRO/MBDS\nposting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03) 20080516.1634).\n\nSince the beginning of 2009 to 11 Sep 2009, there had been 60\npatients under treatment for HFMD. Approximately 54 out of 60\nchildren (90 percent) were in serious condition. The disease is\ncaused by enterovirus 71. There is no specific vaccine for the disease.\n\nFor a map of Viet Nam with provinces, see\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:VietnameseProvincesMap.png>. 2009\nSource: Thanh Nien News [edited]\n<http://www.thanhniennews.com/healthy/?catid=8&newsid=52495>\n\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease is spreading in Ho Chi Minh City [HCMC],\nlocal authorities said. Some 3000 children in Viet Nam caught the\ndisease last year [2008] and at least 10 died.\n\nChildren's Hospital No. 1, for example, reported on Friday [11 Sep\n2009] that 60 patients were under treatment for the disease, which is\ncaused by the enterovirus 71, with fever, blisters, mouth ulcers, and rashes.\n\nDr Truong Huu Khanh from the hospital said nearly 90 percent of the\nchildren, mainly from other provinces, were admitted to the hospital\nin already serious condition.\n\n[Byline: Lien Chau, Thanh Tung]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPRO/MBDS\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness of\ninfants and children. The disease causes fever and blister-like\neruptions in the mouth and/or a skin rash. HFMD is caused by viruses\nthat belong to the enterovirus genus. This group of viruses includes\npolioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\nEnteroviruses, including enterovirus 71, have also been associated\nwith HFMD and with outbreaks of the disease. Enterovirus 71 may be\nassociated with fatalities due to viral meningitis or encephalitis\n(see <https://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/index.html>).\n\nDuring 2009, HFMD outbreak in Viet Nam started in April 2009, with\nincreasing numbers of patients reported in hospitals from Ho Chi Minh\nCity, Dong Nai, Binh Duong, Binh Phuoc, Tay Ninh and An Giang\nprovinces (see prior PRO/MBDS posting Hand, foot & mouth disease -\nViet Nam: RFI 20090411.1387).\n\nPeaks of HFMD were usually during the dry seasons from March to May\nand September to December. As of 22 May 2009, there were 50 children\ninfected with HFMD and 3 of them were in a serious condition (see\nprior PRO/MBDS posting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02)\n20090524.1942). As of 12 May 2008, 2300 cases of HFMD had been\nreported in Viet Nam with 10 fatalities during 2008 and most of the\nreported cases were from the southern regions (see prior PRO/MBDS\nposting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03) 20080516.1634).\n\nSince the beginning of 2009 to 11 Sep 2009, there had been 60\npatients under treatment for HFMD. Approximately 54 out of 60\nchildren (90 percent) were in serious condition. The disease is\ncaused by enterovirus 71. There is no specific vaccine for the disease.\n\nFor a map of Viet Nam with provinces, see\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:VietnameseProvincesMap.png>. Some 3000 children in Viet Nam caught the\ndisease last year [2008] and at least 10 died.\n\nChildren's Hospital No. 1, for example, reported on Friday [11 Sep\n2009] that 60 patients were under treatment for the disease, which is\ncaused by the enterovirus 71, with fever, blisters, mouth ulcers, and rashes.\n\nDr Truong Huu Khanh from the hospital said nearly 90 percent of the\nchildren, mainly from other provinces, were admitted to the hospital\nin already serious condition.\n\n[Byline: Lien Chau, Thanh Tung]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPRO/MBDS\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness of\ninfants and children. The disease causes fever and blister-like\neruptions in the mouth and/or a skin rash. HFMD is caused by viruses\nthat belong to the enterovirus genus. This group of viruses includes\npolioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\nEnteroviruses, including enterovirus 71, have also been associated\nwith HFMD and with outbreaks of the disease. Enterovirus 71 may be\nassociated with fatalities due to viral meningitis or encephalitis\n(see <https://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/index.html>).\n\nDuring 2009, HFMD outbreak in Viet Nam started in April 2009, with\nincreasing numbers of patients reported in hospitals from Ho Chi Minh\nCity, Dong Nai, Binh Duong, Binh Phuoc, Tay Ninh and An Giang\nprovinces (see prior PRO/MBDS posting Hand, foot & mouth disease -\nViet Nam: RFI 20090411.1387).\n\nPeaks of HFMD were usually during the dry seasons from March to May\nand September to December. As of 22 May 2009, there were 50 children\ninfected with HFMD and 3 of them were in a serious condition (see\nprior PRO/MBDS posting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02)\n20090524.1942). As of 12 May 2008, 2300 cases of HFMD had been\nreported in Viet Nam with 10 fatalities during 2008 and most of the\nreported cases were from the southern regions (see prior PRO/MBDS\nposting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03) 20080516.1634).\n\nSince the beginning of 2009 to 11 Sep 2009, there had been 60\npatients under treatment for HFMD. Approximately 54 out of 60\nchildren (90 percent) were in serious condition. The disease is\ncaused by enterovirus 71. There is no specific vaccine for the disease.\n\nFor a map of Viet Nam with provinces, see\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:VietnameseProvincesMap.png>. The\ninteractive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map with direct links to other\noutbreaks in Viet Nam and surrounding countries reported on\nProMED-mail and PRO/MBDS can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/008c> - Mod.SCM]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (10): (SD) 20090710.2478\n2008\n----\nHand, foot & mouth - Asia (02): China, Singapore, Viet Nam 20080504.1528\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: HCM, RFI 20080423.1435\n\nand PRO/MBDS archives:\n\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02) 20090524.1942\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: RFI 20090411.1387\n2008\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (04): Ben Tre 20081110.3531\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03) 20080516.1634\nHand, foot & Mouth Disease - Viet Nam "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "402685", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand foot & mouth disease: Singapore, China (HN), Viet Nam", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=402685", "date": "2009-09-20 22:00:02", "main_text": "************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Sep 2009\nSource: Thanh Nien News [edited]\n<http://www.thanhniennews.com/healthy/?catid=8&newsid=52495>\n\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease is spreading in Ho Chi Minh City [HCMC],\nlocal authorities said. Some 3000 children in Viet Nam caught the\ndisease last year [2008] and at least 10 died.\n\nChildren's Hospital No. 1, for example, reported on Friday [11 Sep\n2009] that 60 patients were under treatment for the disease, which is\ncaused by the enterovirus 71, with fever, blisters, mouth ulcers, and rashes.\n\nDr Truong Huu Khanh from the hospital said nearly 90 percent of the\nchildren, mainly from other provinces, were admitted to the hospital\nin already serious condition.\n\n[Byline: Lien Chau, Thanh Tung]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPRO/MBDS\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness of\ninfants and children. The disease causes fever and blister-like\neruptions in the mouth and/or a skin rash. HFMD is caused by viruses\nthat belong to the enterovirus genus. This group of viruses includes\npolioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\nEnteroviruses, including enterovirus 71, have also been associated\nwith HFMD and with outbreaks of the disease. Enterovirus 71 may be\nassociated with fatalities due to viral meningitis or encephalitis\n(see <https://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/index.html>).\n\nDuring 2009, HFMD outbreak in Viet Nam started in April 2009, with\nincreasing numbers of patients reported in hospitals from Ho Chi Minh\nCity, Dong Nai, Binh Duong, Binh Phuoc, Tay Ninh and An Giang\nprovinces (see prior PRO/MBDS posting Hand, foot & mouth disease -\nViet Nam: RFI 20090411.1387).\n\nPeaks of HFMD were usually during the dry seasons from March to May\nand September to December. As of 22 May 2009, there were 50 children\ninfected with HFMD and 3 of them were in a serious condition (see\nprior PRO/MBDS posting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02)\n20090524.1942). As of 12 May 2008, 2300 cases of HFMD had been\nreported in Viet Nam with 10 fatalities during 2008 and most of the\nreported cases were from the southern regions (see prior PRO/MBDS\nposting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03) 20080516.1634).\n\nSince the beginning of 2009 to 11 Sep 2009, there had been 60\npatients under treatment for HFMD. Approximately 54 out of 60\nchildren (90 percent) were in serious condition. The disease is\ncaused by enterovirus 71. There is no specific vaccine for the disease.\n\nFor a map of Viet Nam with provinces, see\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:VietnameseProvincesMap.png>. The\ninteractive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map with direct links to other\noutbreaks in Viet Nam and surrounding countries reported on\nProMED-mail and PRO/MBDS can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/008c> - Some 3000 children in Viet Nam caught the\ndisease last year [2008] and at least 10 died.\n\nChildren's Hospital No. 1, for example, reported on Friday [11 Sep\n2009] that 60 patients were under treatment for the disease, which is\ncaused by the enterovirus 71, with fever, blisters, mouth ulcers, and rashes.\n\nDr Truong Huu Khanh from the hospital said nearly 90 percent of the\nchildren, mainly from other provinces, were admitted to the hospital\nin already serious condition.\n\n[Byline: Lien Chau, Thanh Tung]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPRO/MBDS\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness of\ninfants and children. The disease causes fever and blister-like\neruptions in the mouth and/or a skin rash. HFMD is caused by viruses\nthat belong to the enterovirus genus. This group of viruses includes\npolioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\nEnteroviruses, including enterovirus 71, have also been associated\nwith HFMD and with outbreaks of the disease. As of 22 May 2009, there were 50 children\ninfected with HFMD and 3 of them were in a serious condition (see\nprior PRO/MBDS posting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02)\n20090524.1942). As of 12 May 2008, 2300 cases of HFMD had been\nreported in Viet Nam with 10 fatalities during 2008 and most of the\nreported cases were from the southern regions (see prior PRO/MBDS\nposting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03) 20080516.1634).\n\nSince the beginning of 2009 to 11 Sep 2009, there had been 60\npatients under treatment for HFMD. Approximately 54 out of 60\nchildren (90 percent) were in serious condition. The disease is\ncaused by enterovirus 71. There is no specific vaccine for the disease.\n\nFor a map of Viet Nam with provinces, see\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:VietnameseProvincesMap.png>.
