Jamaica", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=307897", "date": "2009-09-20 22:00:02", "main_text": "************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Sep 2009\nSource: Thanh Nien News [edited]\n<http://www.thanhniennews.com/healthy/?catid=8&newsid=52495>\n\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease is spreading in Ho Chi Minh City [HCMC],\nlocal authorities said. Some 3000 children in Viet Nam caught the\ndisease last year [2008] and at least 10 died.\n\nChildren's Hospital No. 1, for example, reported on Friday [11 Sep\n2009] that 60 patients were under treatment for the disease, which is\ncaused by the enterovirus 71, with fever, blisters, mouth ulcers, and rashes.\n\nDr Truong Huu Khanh from the hospital said nearly 90 percent of the\nchildren, mainly from other provinces, were admitted to the hospital\nin already serious condition.\n\n[Byline: Lien Chau, Thanh Tung]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPRO/MBDS\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness of\ninfants and children. The disease causes fever and blister-like\neruptions in the mouth and/or a skin rash. HFMD is caused by viruses\nthat belong to the enterovirus genus. This group of viruses includes\npolioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\nEnteroviruses, including enterovirus 71, have also been associated\nwith HFMD and with outbreaks of the disease. As of 22 May 2009, there were 50 children\ninfected with HFMD and 3 of them were in a serious condition (see\nprior PRO/MBDS posting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02)\n20090524.1942). As of 12 May 2008, 2300 cases of HFMD had been\nreported in Viet Nam with 10 fatalities during 2008 and most of the\nreported cases were from the southern regions (see prior PRO/MBDS\nposting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03) 20080516.1634).\n\nSince the beginning of 2009 to 11 Sep 2009, there had been 60\npatients under treatment for HFMD. Approximately 54 out of 60\nchildren (90 percent) were in serious condition. The disease is\ncaused by enterovirus 71. There is no specific vaccine for the disease.\n\nFor a map of Viet Nam with provinces, see\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:VietnameseProvincesMap.png>. Some 3000 children in Viet Nam caught the\ndisease last year [2008] and at least 10 died.\n\nChildren's Hospital No. 1, for example, reported on Friday [11 Sep\n2009] that 60 patients were under treatment for the disease, which is\ncaused by the enterovirus 71, with fever, blisters, mouth ulcers, and rashes.\n\nDr Truong Huu Khanh from the hospital said nearly 90 percent of the\nchildren, mainly from other provinces, were admitted to the hospital\nin already serious condition.\n\n[Byline: Lien Chau, Thanh Tung]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPRO/MBDS\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness of\ninfants and children. The disease causes fever and blister-like\neruptions in the mouth and/or a skin rash. HFMD is caused by viruses\nthat belong to the enterovirus genus. This group of viruses includes\npolioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\nEnteroviruses, including enterovirus 71, have also been associated\nwith HFMD and with outbreaks of the disease. As of 22 May 2009, there were 50 children\ninfected with HFMD and 3 of them were in a serious condition (see\nprior PRO/MBDS posting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (02)\n20090524.1942). As of 12 May 2008, 2300 cases of HFMD had been\nreported in Viet Nam with 10 fatalities during 2008 and most of the\nreported cases were from the southern regions (see prior PRO/MBDS\nposting Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (03) 20080516.1634).\n\nSince the beginning of 2009 to 11 Sep 2009, there had been 60\npatients under treatment for HFMD. Approximately 54 out of 60\nchildren (90 percent) were in serious condition. The disease is\ncaused by enterovirus 71. There is no specific vaccine for the disease.\n\nFor a map of Viet Nam with provinces, see\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:VietnameseProvincesMap.png>. China (10): (SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=238647", "date": "2009-04-01 22:00:52", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (05)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 1 Apr 2009\nSource: Nature News, Nature 458, 554-555 (2009) [edited]\n<http://www.nature.com/news/2009/090401/full/458554a.html>\n\n\nViral outbreak in China tests government efforts\n------------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in\nChina, which since January [2009] has killed 19\nchildren and made nearly 42 000 ill, has\nresearchers calling for a better surveillance\nsystem to detect the disease and for action to\nspeed up vaccine development. \"The situation of\npreventing and containing hand, foot and mouth\ndisease is very serious at the moment,\" Deng\nHaihua, spokesman for China's health ministry,\nsaid last week. More cases are expected, as the\ndisease normally peaks between May and July. In\nthe absence of a drug treatment, the ministry is\nfocusing on prevention and containment.\n\nThe outbreak is the latest in a series to have\nhit China in recent years, caused by a\nfast-spreading virus called enterovirus 71. \"The\npersistence of enterovirus 71 outbreaks in China\nis a wake-up call,\" says Jane Cardosa, a\nvirologist at the University Malaysia Sarawak in\nKota Samarahan. In 1997, Sarawak saw the 1st\noutbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in the\nAsia-Pacific region. The disease causes flu-like\nsymptoms, along with rashes on the hands and\nfeet, and mouth ulcers. It can be caused by many\ntypes of human enterovirus belonging to the\nfamily _Picornaviridae_, which are mainly\ntransmitted through fecal or oral routes.\nAlthough normally mild, the disease can be\nlife-threatening: some viruses, particularly\nenterovirus 71, can cause inflammation of the\nbrain stem, resulting in heart failure and fluid accumulation in the lungs.\n\nIn 1997 in Sarawak, more than 2600 cases of the\ndisease were reported and 29 people died. The\nnext year in Taiwan, there were 129 000 reported\ncases and 78 deaths. In mainland China, the 1st\nreported case was in Shenzhen, Guangdong\nprovince, in 1999. At 1st, outbreaks were local\nand there were no reported fatalities. But since\n2004, the outbreaks have become more severe and\nwidespread, says Xu Wenbo, an infectious-disease\nexpert at the Beijing-based China Center for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nIn May 2008, the country's health ministry added\nhand, foot and mouth to its category 'C' of\nnotifiable diseases, meaning that all diagnosed\ncases must be reported through a national\nWeb-based system for disease surveillance, and\ntook measures to streamline reporting\nrequirements. The Ministry also vowed to take a\ntough stance against cover-ups and last month\n[fired] 4 health officials in Henan province for\nconcealing the number of infections and deaths.\n\nThis year, enterovirus 71 has caused nearly all\nof the laboratory-confirmed cases in 2 hot-spots,\nthe provinces of Henan and Shandong.\n\nXu suspects that the disease's increasing\nvirulence may be due to a genetic change in the\ncirculating virus strain. Before 2004 the\npredominant strain was called C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common (see:\nY. Zhang et al. J. Clin. Virol. 44, 262\u00ad267;\n2009). What caused this switch isn't clear, says\nXu, as little is known about the genetics and\ntransmission trends of the fast-mutating virus.\nMost studies have been clinical, aimed at, for\nexample, identifying the strains behind a given\noutbreak and the disease's clinical features,\nespecially when there are neurological\ncomplications. Many researchers say it is time to\nstep up efforts to understand the basic biology\nof enterovirus 71 to speed vaccine development.\n\nIn a major push financed by the Chinese Health\nMinistry and the Center for Disease Control and\nPrevention, Xu and his colleagues measured the\ninfection rate in adults and children during last\nyear's outbreak and analysed stool samples and\nthroat swabs taken from more than 18 000\npatients. Preliminary results suggest that the\ninfection rate is alarmingly high, meaning that\nthere are large populations of virus carriers who\ndo not show any symptoms of the disease.\n\nExperts are divided as to how worried the world\nshould be about the virus. Tom Solomon, a\nneurologist at the University of Liverpool, UK,\nargues that enterovirus 71 infection is\nunderappreciated on a global scale and may pose a\nbigger risk to public health than is currently\nthought. But Hans Troedsson, the World Health\nOrganization's representative in China, says\n\"there is no cause for alarm.\" The public-health\nimpact of hand, foot and mouth disease, including\ncases caused by enterovirus 71, is no more\nserious than other common childhood diseases, he\nsays. Troedsson thinks that the recent apparent\nincrease in enterovirus 71 infection might be due\nto higher reporting rates rather than an increase\nin disease prevalence. \"We will closely monitor\nthe situation and decide policies accordingly,\" he says.\n\n[Byline: Jane Qiu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This article provides a useful statement of the current situation and\nan indication of the extent of the epidemic. The strain of\nenterovirus 71 associated with this outbreak differs from that\nprevalent in earlier outbreaks when the disease was less prevalent.\nBefore 2004, the predominant strain was designated C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common. Whether this is related\nto the apparently greater severity of the disease since 2004 has still\nto be established. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (04): (HE, SD) 20090327.1194\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (SD) 20090324.1154\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HE), RFI 20090318.1099\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong S.A.R.) 20090312.1023\n..............................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "enterovirus 71 infection", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2008-05-16 00:00:00", "1971-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1971-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shandong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong S.A.R.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Henan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Henan province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sarawak", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shenzhen", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "211898", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=211898", "date": "2009-04-01 22:00:52", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (05)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 1 Apr 2009\nSource: Nature News, Nature 458, 554-555 (2009) [edited]\n<http://www.nature.com/news/2009/090401/full/458554a.html>\n\n\nViral outbreak in China tests government efforts\n------------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in\nChina, which since January [2009] has killed 19\nchildren and made nearly 42 000 ill, has\nresearchers calling for a better surveillance\nsystem to detect the disease and for action to\nspeed up vaccine development. \"The situation of\npreventing and containing hand, foot and mouth\ndisease is very serious at the moment,\" Deng\nHaihua, spokesman for China's health ministry,\nsaid last week. More cases are expected, as the\ndisease normally peaks between May and July. In\nthe absence of a drug treatment, the ministry is\nfocusing on prevention and containment.\n\nThe outbreak is the latest in a series to have\nhit China in recent years, caused by a\nfast-spreading virus called enterovirus 71. \"The\npersistence of enterovirus 71 outbreaks in China\nis a wake-up call,\" says Jane Cardosa, a\nvirologist at the University Malaysia Sarawak in\nKota Samarahan. In 1997, Sarawak saw the 1st\noutbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in the\nAsia-Pacific region. The disease causes flu-like\nsymptoms, along with rashes on the hands and\nfeet, and mouth ulcers. It can be caused by many\ntypes of human enterovirus belonging to the\nfamily _Picornaviridae_, which are mainly\ntransmitted through fecal or oral routes.\nAlthough normally mild, the disease can be\nlife-threatening: some viruses, particularly\nenterovirus 71, can cause inflammation of the\nbrain stem, resulting in heart failure and fluid accumulation in the lungs.\n\nIn 1997 in Sarawak, more than 2600 cases of the\ndisease were reported and 29 people died. The\nnext year in Taiwan, there were 129 000 reported\ncases and 78 deaths. In mainland China, the 1st\nreported case was in Shenzhen, Guangdong\nprovince, in 1999. At 1st, outbreaks were local\nand there were no reported fatalities. But since\n2004, the outbreaks have become more severe and\nwidespread, says Xu Wenbo, an infectious-disease\nexpert at the Beijing-based China Center for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nIn May 2008, the country's health ministry added\nhand, foot and mouth to its category 'C' of\nnotifiable diseases, meaning that all diagnosed\ncases must be reported through a national\nWeb-based system for disease surveillance, and\ntook measures to streamline reporting\nrequirements. The Ministry also vowed to take a\ntough stance against cover-ups and last month\n[fired] 4 health officials in Henan province for\nconcealing the number of infections and deaths.\n\nThis year, enterovirus 71 has caused nearly all\nof the laboratory-confirmed cases in 2 hot-spots,\nthe provinces of Henan and Shandong.\n\nXu suspects that the disease's increasing\nvirulence may be due to a genetic change in the\ncirculating virus strain. Before 2004 the\npredominant strain was called C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common (see:\nY. Zhang et al. J. Clin. Virol. 44, 262\u00ad267;\n2009). What caused this switch isn't clear, says\nXu, as little is known about the genetics and\ntransmission trends of the fast-mutating virus.\nMost studies have been clinical, aimed at, for\nexample, identifying the strains behind a given\noutbreak and the disease's clinical features,\nespecially when there are neurological\ncomplications. Many researchers say it is time to\nstep up efforts to understand the basic biology\nof enterovirus 71 to speed vaccine development.\n\nIn a major push financed by the Chinese Health\nMinistry and the Center for Disease Control and\nPrevention, Xu and his colleagues measured the\ninfection rate in adults and children during last\nyear's outbreak and analysed stool samples and\nthroat swabs taken from more than 18 000\npatients. Preliminary results suggest that the\ninfection rate is alarmingly high, meaning that\nthere are large populations of virus carriers who\ndo not show any symptoms of the disease.\n\nExperts are divided as to how worried the world\nshould be about the virus. Tom Solomon, a\nneurologist at the University of Liverpool, UK,\nargues that enterovirus 71 infection is\nunderappreciated on a global scale and may pose a\nbigger risk to public health than is currently\nthought. But Hans Troedsson, the World Health\nOrganization's representative in China, says\n\"there is no cause for alarm.\" The public-health\nimpact of hand, foot and mouth disease, including\ncases caused by enterovirus 71, is no more\nserious than other common childhood diseases, he\nsays. Troedsson thinks that the recent apparent\nincrease in enterovirus 71 infection might be due\nto higher reporting rates rather than an increase\nin disease prevalence. \"We will closely monitor\nthe situation and decide policies accordingly,\" he says.\n\n[Byline: Jane Qiu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This article provides a useful statement of the current situation and\nan indication of the extent of the epidemic. The strain of\nenterovirus 71 associated with this outbreak differs from that\nprevalent in earlier outbreaks when the disease was less prevalent.\nBefore 2004, the predominant strain was designated C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common. Whether this is related\nto the apparently greater severity of the disease since 2004 has still\nto be established. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (04): (HE, SD) 20090327.1194\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (SD) 20090324.1154\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HE), RFI 20090318.1099\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong S.A.R.) 20090312.1023\n..............................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. More cases are expected, as the\ndisease normally peaks between May and July. In\nthe absence of a drug treatment, the ministry is\nfocusing on prevention and containment.\n\nThe outbreak is the latest in a series to have\nhit China in recent years, caused by a\nfast-spreading virus called enterovirus 71. \"The\npersistence of enterovirus 71 outbreaks in China\nis a wake-up call,\" says Jane Cardosa, a\nvirologist at the University Malaysia Sarawak in\nKota Samarahan. It can be caused by many\ntypes of human enterovirus belonging to the\nfamily _Picornaviridae_, which are mainly\ntransmitted through fecal or oral routes.\nAlthough normally mild, the disease can be\nlife-threatening: some viruses, particularly\nenterovirus 71, can cause inflammation of the\nbrain stem, resulting in heart failure and fluid accumulation in the lungs.\n\nIn 1997 in Sarawak, more than 2600 cases of the\ndisease were reported and 29 people died. The\nnext year in Taiwan, there were 129 000 reported\ncases and 78 deaths. In mainland China, the 1st\nreported case was in Shenzhen, Guangdong\nprovince, in 1999. At 1st, outbreaks were local\nand there were no reported fatalities. But since\n2004, the outbreaks have become more severe and\nwidespread, says Xu Wenbo, an infectious-disease\nexpert at the Beijing-based China Center for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nIn May 2008, the country's health ministry added\nhand, foot and mouth to its category 'C' of\nnotifiable diseases, meaning that all diagnosed\ncases must be reported through a national\nWeb-based system for disease surveillance, and\ntook measures to streamline reporting\nrequirements. The Ministry also vowed to take a\ntough stance against cover-ups and last month\n[fired] 4 health officials in Henan province for\nconcealing the number of infections and deaths.\n\nThis year, enterovirus 71 has caused nearly all\nof the laboratory-confirmed cases in 2 hot-spots,\nthe provinces of Henan and Shandong.\n\nXu suspects that the disease's increasing\nvirulence may be due to a genetic change in the\ncirculating virus strain. Before 2004 the\npredominant strain was called C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common (see:\nY. Zhang et al. J. Clin. Virol. 44, 262\u00ad267;\n2009). What caused this switch isn't clear, says\nXu, as little is known about the genetics and\ntransmission trends of the fast-mutating virus.\nMost studies have been clinical, aimed at, for\nexample, identifying the strains behind a given\noutbreak and the disease's clinical features,\nespecially when there are neurological\ncomplications. Many researchers say it is time to\nstep up efforts to understand the basic biology\nof enterovirus 71 to speed vaccine development.\n\nIn a major push financed by the Chinese Health\nMinistry and the Center for Disease Control and\nPrevention, Xu and his colleagues measured the\ninfection rate in adults and children during last\nyear's outbreak and analysed stool samples and\nthroat swabs taken from more than 18 000\npatients. Preliminary results suggest that the\ninfection rate is alarmingly high, meaning that\nthere are large populations of virus carriers who\ndo not show any symptoms of the disease.\n\nExperts are divided as to how worried the world\nshould be about the virus. Tom Solomon, a\nneurologist at the University of Liverpool, UK,\nargues that enterovirus 71 infection is\nunderappreciated on a global scale and may pose a\nbigger risk to public health than is currently\nthought. But Hans Troedsson, the World Health\nOrganization's representative in China, says\n\"there is no cause for alarm.\" The public-health\nimpact of hand, foot and mouth disease, including\ncases caused by enterovirus 71, is no more\nserious than other common childhood diseases, he\nsays. Troedsson thinks that the recent apparent\nincrease in enterovirus 71 infection might be due\nto higher reporting rates rather than an increase\nin disease prevalence. \"We will closely monitor\nthe situation and decide policies accordingly,\" he says.\n\n[Byline: Jane Qiu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This article provides a useful statement of the current situation and\nan indication of the extent of the epidemic. China (09): (SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=189578", "date": "2009-04-01 22:00:52", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (05)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 1 Apr 2009\nSource: Nature News, Nature 458, 554-555 (2009) [edited]\n<http://www.nature.com/news/2009/090401/full/458554a.html>\n\n\nViral outbreak in China tests government efforts\n------------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in\nChina, which since January [2009] has killed 19\nchildren and made nearly 42 000 ill, has\nresearchers calling for a better surveillance\nsystem to detect the disease and for action to\nspeed up vaccine development. \"The situation of\npreventing and containing hand, foot and mouth\ndisease is very serious at the moment,\" Deng\nHaihua, spokesman for China's health ministry,\nsaid last week. More cases are expected, as the\ndisease normally peaks between May and July. In\nthe absence of a drug treatment, the ministry is\nfocusing on prevention and containment.\n\nThe outbreak is the latest in a series to have\nhit China in recent years, caused by a\nfast-spreading virus called enterovirus 71. \"The\npersistence of enterovirus 71 outbreaks in China\nis a wake-up call,\" says Jane Cardosa, a\nvirologist at the University Malaysia Sarawak in\nKota Samarahan. In 1997, Sarawak saw the 1st\noutbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in the\nAsia-Pacific region. The disease causes flu-like\nsymptoms, along with rashes on the hands and\nfeet, and mouth ulcers. It can be caused by many\ntypes of human enterovirus belonging to the\nfamily _Picornaviridae_, which are mainly\ntransmitted through fecal or oral routes.\nAlthough normally mild, the disease can be\nlife-threatening: some viruses, particularly\nenterovirus 71, can cause inflammation of the\nbrain stem, resulting in heart failure and fluid accumulation in the lungs.\n\nIn 1997 in Sarawak, more than 2600 cases of the\ndisease were reported and 29 people died. The\nnext year in Taiwan, there were 129 000 reported\ncases and 78 deaths. In mainland China, the 1st\nreported case was in Shenzhen, Guangdong\nprovince, in 1999. At 1st, outbreaks were local\nand there were no reported fatalities. But since\n2004, the outbreaks have become more severe and\nwidespread, says Xu Wenbo, an infectious-disease\nexpert at the Beijing-based China Center for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nIn May 2008, the country's health ministry added\nhand, foot and mouth to its category 'C' of\nnotifiable diseases, meaning that all diagnosed\ncases must be reported through a national\nWeb-based system for disease surveillance, and\ntook measures to streamline reporting\nrequirements. The Ministry also vowed to take a\ntough stance against cover-ups and last month\n[fired] 4 health officials in Henan province for\nconcealing the number of infections and deaths.\n\nThis year, enterovirus 71 has caused nearly all\nof the laboratory-confirmed cases in 2 hot-spots,\nthe provinces of Henan and Shandong.\n\nXu suspects that the disease's increasing\nvirulence may be due to a genetic change in the\ncirculating virus strain. Before 2004 the\npredominant strain was called C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common (see:\nY. Zhang et al. J. Clin. Virol. 44, 262\u00ad267;\n2009). What caused this switch isn't clear, says\nXu, as little is known about the genetics and\ntransmission trends of the fast-mutating virus.\nMost studies have been clinical, aimed at, for\nexample, identifying the strains behind a given\noutbreak and the disease's clinical features,\nespecially when there are neurological\ncomplications. Many researchers say it is time to\nstep up efforts to understand the basic biology\nof enterovirus 71 to speed vaccine development.\n\nIn a major push financed by the Chinese Health\nMinistry and the Center for Disease Control and\nPrevention, Xu and his colleagues measured the\ninfection rate in adults and children during last\nyear's outbreak and analysed stool samples and\nthroat swabs taken from more than 18 000\npatients. Preliminary results suggest that the\ninfection rate is alarmingly high, meaning that\nthere are large populations of virus carriers who\ndo not show any symptoms of the disease.\n\nExperts are divided as to how worried the world\nshould be about the virus. Tom Solomon, a\nneurologist at the University of Liverpool, UK,\nargues that enterovirus 71 infection is\nunderappreciated on a global scale and may pose a\nbigger risk to public health than is currently\nthought. But Hans Troedsson, the World Health\nOrganization's representative in China, says\n\"there is no cause for alarm.\" The public-health\nimpact of hand, foot and mouth disease, including\ncases caused by enterovirus 71, is no more\nserious than other common childhood diseases, he\nsays. Troedsson thinks that the recent apparent\nincrease in enterovirus 71 infection might be due\nto higher reporting rates rather than an increase\nin disease prevalence. \"We will closely monitor\nthe situation and decide policies accordingly,\" he says.\n\n[Byline: Jane Qiu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This article provides a useful statement of the current situation and\nan indication of the extent of the epidemic. The strain of\nenterovirus 71 associated with this outbreak differs from that\nprevalent in earlier outbreaks when the disease was less prevalent.\nBefore 2004, the predominant strain was designated C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common. Whether this is related\nto the apparently greater severity of the disease since 2004 has still\nto be established. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (04): (HE, SD) 20090327.1194\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (SD) 20090324.1154\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HE), RFI 20090318.1099\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong S.A.R.) 20090312.1023\n..............................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "enterovirus 71 infection", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2008-05-16 00:00:00", "1971-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1971-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shandong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong S.A.R.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Henan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Henan province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sarawak", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shenzhen", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "173424", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - China (08): (ZJ) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=173424", "date": "2009-04-01 22:00:52", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (05)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 1 Apr 2009\nSource: Nature News, Nature 458, 554-555 (2009) [edited]\n<http://www.nature.com/news/2009/090401/full/458554a.html>\n\n\nViral outbreak in China tests government efforts\n------------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in\nChina, which since January [2009] has killed 19\nchildren and made nearly 42 000 ill, has\nresearchers calling for a better surveillance\nsystem to detect the disease and for action to\nspeed up vaccine development. \"The situation of\npreventing and containing hand, foot and mouth\ndisease is very serious at the moment,\" Deng\nHaihua, spokesman for China's health ministry,\nsaid last week. More cases are expected, as the\ndisease normally peaks between May and July. In\nthe absence of a drug treatment, the ministry is\nfocusing on prevention and containment.\n\nThe outbreak is the latest in a series to have\nhit China in recent years, caused by a\nfast-spreading virus called enterovirus 71. \"The\npersistence of enterovirus 71 outbreaks in China\nis a wake-up call,\" says Jane Cardosa, a\nvirologist at the University Malaysia Sarawak in\nKota Samarahan. In 1997, Sarawak saw the 1st\noutbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in the\nAsia-Pacific region. The disease causes flu-like\nsymptoms, along with rashes on the hands and\nfeet, and mouth ulcers. It can be caused by many\ntypes of human enterovirus belonging to the\nfamily _Picornaviridae_, which are mainly\ntransmitted through fecal or oral routes.\nAlthough normally mild, the disease can be\nlife-threatening: some viruses, particularly\nenterovirus 71, can cause inflammation of the\nbrain stem, resulting in heart failure and fluid accumulation in the lungs.\n\nIn 1997 in Sarawak, more than 2600 cases of the\ndisease were reported and 29 people died. The\nnext year in Taiwan, there were 129 000 reported\ncases and 78 deaths. In mainland China, the 1st\nreported case was in Shenzhen, Guangdong\nprovince, in 1999. At 1st, outbreaks were local\nand there were no reported fatalities. But since\n2004, the outbreaks have become more severe and\nwidespread, says Xu Wenbo, an infectious-disease\nexpert at the Beijing-based China Center for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nIn May 2008, the country's health ministry added\nhand, foot and mouth to its category 'C' of\nnotifiable diseases, meaning that all diagnosed\ncases must be reported through a national\nWeb-based system for disease surveillance, and\ntook measures to streamline reporting\nrequirements. The Ministry also vowed to take a\ntough stance against cover-ups and last month\n[fired] 4 health officials in Henan province for\nconcealing the number of infections and deaths.\n\nThis year, enterovirus 71 has caused nearly all\nof the laboratory-confirmed cases in 2 hot-spots,\nthe provinces of Henan and Shandong.\n\nXu suspects that the disease's increasing\nvirulence may be due to a genetic change in the\ncirculating virus strain. Before 2004 the\npredominant strain was called C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common (see:\nY. Zhang et al. J. Clin. Virol. 44, 262\u00ad267;\n2009). What caused this switch isn't clear, says\nXu, as little is known about the genetics and\ntransmission trends of the fast-mutating virus.\nMost studies have been clinical, aimed at, for\nexample, identifying the strains behind a given\noutbreak and the disease's clinical features,\nespecially when there are neurological\ncomplications. Many researchers say it is time to\nstep up efforts to understand the basic biology\nof enterovirus 71 to speed vaccine development.\n\nIn a major push financed by the Chinese Health\nMinistry and the Center for Disease Control and\nPrevention, Xu and his colleagues measured the\ninfection rate in adults and children during last\nyear's outbreak and analysed stool samples and\nthroat swabs taken from more than 18 000\npatients. Preliminary results suggest that the\ninfection rate is alarmingly high, meaning that\nthere are large populations of virus carriers who\ndo not show any symptoms of the disease.\n\nExperts are divided as to how worried the world\nshould be about the virus. Tom Solomon, a\nneurologist at the University of Liverpool, UK,\nargues that enterovirus 71 infection is\nunderappreciated on a global scale and may pose a\nbigger risk to public health than is currently\nthought. But Hans Troedsson, the World Health\nOrganization's representative in China, says\n\"there is no cause for alarm.\" The public-health\nimpact of hand, foot and mouth disease, including\ncases caused by enterovirus 71, is no more\nserious than other common childhood diseases, he\nsays. Troedsson thinks that the recent apparent\nincrease in enterovirus 71 infection might be due\nto higher reporting rates rather than an increase\nin disease prevalence. \"We will closely monitor\nthe situation and decide policies accordingly,\" he says.\n\n[Byline: Jane Qiu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This article provides a useful statement of the current situation and\nan indication of the extent of the epidemic. The strain of\nenterovirus 71 associated with this outbreak differs from that\nprevalent in earlier outbreaks when the disease was less prevalent.\nBefore 2004, the predominant strain was designated C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common. Whether this is related\nto the apparently greater severity of the disease since 2004 has still\nto be established. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (04): (HE, SD) 20090327.1194\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (SD) 20090324.1154\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HE), RFI 20090318.1099\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong S.A.R.) 20090312.1023\n..............................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. More cases are expected, as the\ndisease normally peaks between May and July. In\nthe absence of a drug treatment, the ministry is\nfocusing on prevention and containment.\n\nThe outbreak is the latest in a series to have\nhit China in recent years, caused by a\nfast-spreading virus called enterovirus 71. \"The\npersistence of enterovirus 71 outbreaks in China\nis a wake-up call,\" says Jane Cardosa, a\nvirologist at the University Malaysia Sarawak in\nKota Samarahan. In 1997, Sarawak saw the 1st\noutbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in the\nAsia-Pacific region. The disease causes flu-like\nsymptoms, along with rashes on the hands and\nfeet, and mouth ulcers. It can be caused by many\ntypes of human enterovirus belonging to the\nfamily _Picornaviridae_, which are mainly\ntransmitted through fecal or oral routes.\nAlthough normally mild, the disease can be\nlife-threatening: some viruses, particularly\nenterovirus 71, can cause inflammation of the\nbrain stem, resulting in heart failure and fluid accumulation in the lungs.\n\nIn 1997 in Sarawak, more than 2600 cases of the\ndisease were reported and 29 people died. The\nnext year in Taiwan, there were 129 000 reported\ncases and 78 deaths. In mainland China, the 1st\nreported case was in Shenzhen, Guangdong\nprovince, in 1999. At 1st, outbreaks were local\nand there were no reported fatalities. But since\n2004, the outbreaks have become more severe and\nwidespread, says Xu Wenbo, an infectious-disease\nexpert at the Beijing-based China Center for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nIn May 2008, the country's health ministry added\nhand, foot and mouth to its category 'C' of\nnotifiable diseases, meaning that all diagnosed\ncases must be reported through a national\nWeb-based system for disease surveillance, and\ntook measures to streamline reporting\nrequirements. The Ministry also vowed to take a\ntough stance against cover-ups and last month\n[fired] 4 health officials in Henan province for\nconcealing the number of infections and deaths.\n\nThis year, enterovirus 71 has caused nearly all\nof the laboratory-confirmed cases in 2 hot-spots,\nthe provinces of Henan and Shandong.\n\nXu suspects that the disease's increasing\nvirulence may be due to a genetic change in the\ncirculating virus strain. Before 2004 the\npredominant strain was called C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common (see:\nY. Zhang et al. J. Clin. Virol. 44, 262\u00ad267;\n2009). What caused this switch isn't clear, says\nXu, as little is known about the genetics and\ntransmission trends of the fast-mutating virus.\nMost studies have been clinical, aimed at, for\nexample, identifying the strains behind a given\noutbreak and the disease's clinical features,\nespecially when there are neurological\ncomplications. Many researchers say it is time to\nstep up efforts to understand the basic biology\nof enterovirus 71 to speed vaccine development.\n\nIn a major push financed by the Chinese Health\nMinistry and the Center for Disease Control and\nPrevention, Xu and his colleagues measured the\ninfection rate in adults and children during last\nyear's outbreak and analysed stool samples and\nthroat swabs taken from more than 18 000\npatients. Preliminary results suggest that the\ninfection rate is alarmingly high, meaning that\nthere are large populations of virus carriers who\ndo not show any symptoms of the disease.\n\nExperts are divided as to how worried the world\nshould be about the virus. Tom Solomon, a\nneurologist at the University of Liverpool, UK,\nargues that enterovirus 71 infection is\nunderappreciated on a global scale and may pose a\nbigger risk to public health than is currently\nthought. But Hans Troedsson, the World Health\nOrganization's representative in China, says\n\"there is no cause for alarm.\" The public-health\nimpact of hand, foot and mouth disease, including\ncases caused by enterovirus 71, is no more\nserious than other common childhood diseases, he\nsays. Troedsson thinks that the recent apparent\nincrease in enterovirus 71 infection might be due\nto higher reporting rates rather than an increase\nin disease prevalence. \"We will closely monitor\nthe situation and decide policies accordingly,\" he says.\n\n[Byline: Jane Qiu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This article provides a useful statement of the current situation and\nan indication of the extent of the epidemic. China (06): (SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=171371", "date": "2009-04-01 22:00:52", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (05)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 1 Apr 2009\nSource: Nature News, Nature 458, 554-555 (2009) [edited]\n<http://www.nature.com/news/2009/090401/full/458554a.html>\n\n\nViral outbreak in China tests government efforts\n------------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in\nChina, which since January [2009] has killed 19\nchildren and made nearly 42 000 ill, has\nresearchers calling for a better surveillance\nsystem to detect the disease and for action to\nspeed up vaccine development. \"The situation of\npreventing and containing hand, foot and mouth\ndisease is very serious at the moment,\" Deng\nHaihua, spokesman for China's health ministry,\nsaid last week. More cases are expected, as the\ndisease normally peaks between May and July. In\nthe absence of a drug treatment, the ministry is\nfocusing on prevention and containment.\n\nThe outbreak is the latest in a series to have\nhit China in recent years, caused by a\nfast-spreading virus called enterovirus 71. \"The\npersistence of enterovirus 71 outbreaks in China\nis a wake-up call,\" says Jane Cardosa, a\nvirologist at the University Malaysia Sarawak in\nKota Samarahan. In 1997, Sarawak saw the 1st\noutbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in the\nAsia-Pacific region. The disease causes flu-like\nsymptoms, along with rashes on the hands and\nfeet, and mouth ulcers. It can be caused by many\ntypes of human enterovirus belonging to the\nfamily _Picornaviridae_, which are mainly\ntransmitted through fecal or oral routes.\nAlthough normally mild, the disease can be\nlife-threatening: some viruses, particularly\nenterovirus 71, can cause inflammation of the\nbrain stem, resulting in heart failure and fluid accumulation in the lungs.\n\nIn 1997 in Sarawak, more than 2600 cases of the\ndisease were reported and 29 people died. The\nnext year in Taiwan, there were 129 000 reported\ncases and 78 deaths. In mainland China, the 1st\nreported case was in Shenzhen, Guangdong\nprovince, in 1999. At 1st, outbreaks were local\nand there were no reported fatalities. But since\n2004, the outbreaks have become more severe and\nwidespread, says Xu Wenbo, an infectious-disease\nexpert at the Beijing-based China Center for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nIn May 2008, the country's health ministry added\nhand, foot and mouth to its category 'C' of\nnotifiable diseases, meaning that all diagnosed\ncases must be reported through a national\nWeb-based system for disease surveillance, and\ntook measures to streamline reporting\nrequirements. The Ministry also vowed to take a\ntough stance against cover-ups and last month\n[fired] 4 health officials in Henan province for\nconcealing the number of infections and deaths.\n\nThis year, enterovirus 71 has caused nearly all\nof the laboratory-confirmed cases in 2 hot-spots,\nthe provinces of Henan and Shandong.\n\nXu suspects that the disease's increasing\nvirulence may be due to a genetic change in the\ncirculating virus strain. Before 2004 the\npredominant strain was called C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common (see:\nY. Zhang et al. J. Clin. Virol. 44, 262\u00ad267;\n2009). What caused this switch isn't clear, says\nXu, as little is known about the genetics and\ntransmission trends of the fast-mutating virus.\nMost studies have been clinical, aimed at, for\nexample, identifying the strains behind a given\noutbreak and the disease's clinical features,\nespecially when there are neurological\ncomplications. Many researchers say it is time to\nstep up efforts to understand the basic biology\nof enterovirus 71 to speed vaccine development.\n\nIn a major push financed by the Chinese Health\nMinistry and the Center for Disease Control and\nPrevention, Xu and his colleagues measured the\ninfection rate in adults and children during last\nyear's outbreak and analysed stool samples and\nthroat swabs taken from more than 18 000\npatients. Preliminary results suggest that the\ninfection rate is alarmingly high, meaning that\nthere are large populations of virus carriers who\ndo not show any symptoms of the disease.\n\nExperts are divided as to how worried the world\nshould be about the virus. Tom Solomon, a\nneurologist at the University of Liverpool, UK,\nargues that enterovirus 71 infection is\nunderappreciated on a global scale and may pose a\nbigger risk to public health than is currently\nthought. But Hans Troedsson, the World Health\nOrganization's representative in China, says\n\"there is no cause for alarm.\" The public-health\nimpact of hand, foot and mouth disease, including\ncases caused by enterovirus 71, is no more\nserious than other common childhood diseases, he\nsays. Troedsson thinks that the recent apparent\nincrease in enterovirus 71 infection might be due\nto higher reporting rates rather than an increase\nin disease prevalence. \"We will closely monitor\nthe situation and decide policies accordingly,\" he says.\n\n[Byline: Jane Qiu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This article provides a useful statement of the current situation and\nan indication of the extent of the epidemic. The strain of\nenterovirus 71 associated with this outbreak differs from that\nprevalent in earlier outbreaks when the disease was less prevalent.\nBefore 2004, the predominant strain was designated C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common. Whether this is related\nto the apparently greater severity of the disease since 2004 has still\nto be established. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (04): (HE, SD) 20090327.1194\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (SD) 20090324.1154\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HE), RFI 20090318.1099\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong S.A.R.) 20090312.1023\n..............................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "enterovirus 71 infection", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2008-05-16 00:00:00", "1971-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1971-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shandong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong S.A.R.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Henan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Henan province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sarawak", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shenzhen", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "170269", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - China (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=170269", "date": "2009-04-01 22:00:52", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (05)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 1 Apr 2009\nSource: Nature News, Nature 458, 554-555 (2009) [edited]\n<http://www.nature.com/news/2009/090401/full/458554a.html>\n\n\nViral outbreak in China tests government efforts\n------------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in\nChina, which since January [2009] has killed 19\nchildren and made nearly 42 000 ill, has\nresearchers calling for a better surveillance\nsystem to detect the disease and for action to\nspeed up vaccine development. \"The situation of\npreventing and containing hand, foot and mouth\ndisease is very serious at the moment,\" Deng\nHaihua, spokesman for China's health ministry,\nsaid last week. More cases are expected, as the\ndisease normally peaks between May and July. In\nthe absence of a drug treatment, the ministry is\nfocusing on prevention and containment.\n\nThe outbreak is the latest in a series to have\nhit China in recent years, caused by a\nfast-spreading virus called enterovirus 71. \"The\npersistence of enterovirus 71 outbreaks in China\nis a wake-up call,\" says Jane Cardosa, a\nvirologist at the University Malaysia Sarawak in\nKota Samarahan. In 1997, Sarawak saw the 1st\noutbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in the\nAsia-Pacific region. The disease causes flu-like\nsymptoms, along with rashes on the hands and\nfeet, and mouth ulcers. It can be caused by many\ntypes of human enterovirus belonging to the\nfamily _Picornaviridae_, which are mainly\ntransmitted through fecal or oral routes.\nAlthough normally mild, the disease can be\nlife-threatening: some viruses, particularly\nenterovirus 71, can cause inflammation of the\nbrain stem, resulting in heart failure and fluid accumulation in the lungs.\n\nIn 1997 in Sarawak, more than 2600 cases of the\ndisease were reported and 29 people died. The\nnext year in Taiwan, there were 129 000 reported\ncases and 78 deaths. In mainland China, the 1st\nreported case was in Shenzhen, Guangdong\nprovince, in 1999. At 1st, outbreaks were local\nand there were no reported fatalities. But since\n2004, the outbreaks have become more severe and\nwidespread, says Xu Wenbo, an infectious-disease\nexpert at the Beijing-based China Center for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nIn May 2008, the country's health ministry added\nhand, foot and mouth to its category 'C' of\nnotifiable diseases, meaning that all diagnosed\ncases must be reported through a national\nWeb-based system for disease surveillance, and\ntook measures to streamline reporting\nrequirements. The Ministry also vowed to take a\ntough stance against cover-ups and last month\n[fired] 4 health officials in Henan province for\nconcealing the number of infections and deaths.\n\nThis year, enterovirus 71 has caused nearly all\nof the laboratory-confirmed cases in 2 hot-spots,\nthe provinces of Henan and Shandong.\n\nXu suspects that the disease's increasing\nvirulence may be due to a genetic change in the\ncirculating virus strain. Before 2004 the\npredominant strain was called C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common (see:\nY. Zhang et al. J. Clin. Virol. 44, 262\u00ad267;\n2009). What caused this switch isn't clear, says\nXu, as little is known about the genetics and\ntransmission trends of the fast-mutating virus.\nMost studies have been clinical, aimed at, for\nexample, identifying the strains behind a given\noutbreak and the disease's clinical features,\nespecially when there are neurological\ncomplications. Many researchers say it is time to\nstep up efforts to understand the basic biology\nof enterovirus 71 to speed vaccine development.\n\nIn a major push financed by the Chinese Health\nMinistry and the Center for Disease Control and\nPrevention, Xu and his colleagues measured the\ninfection rate in adults and children during last\nyear's outbreak and analysed stool samples and\nthroat swabs taken from more than 18 000\npatients. Preliminary results suggest that the\ninfection rate is alarmingly high, meaning that\nthere are large populations of virus carriers who\ndo not show any symptoms of the disease.\n\nExperts are divided as to how worried the world\nshould be about the virus. Tom Solomon, a\nneurologist at the University of Liverpool, UK,\nargues that enterovirus 71 infection is\nunderappreciated on a global scale and may pose a\nbigger risk to public health than is currently\nthought. But Hans Troedsson, the World Health\nOrganization's representative in China, says\n\"there is no cause for alarm.\" The public-health\nimpact of hand, foot and mouth disease, including\ncases caused by enterovirus 71, is no more\nserious than other common childhood diseases, he\nsays. Troedsson thinks that the recent apparent\nincrease in enterovirus 71 infection might be due\nto higher reporting rates rather than an increase\nin disease prevalence. \"We will closely monitor\nthe situation and decide policies accordingly,\" he says.\n\n[Byline: Jane Qiu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This article provides a useful statement of the current situation and\nan indication of the extent of the epidemic. The strain of\nenterovirus 71 associated with this outbreak differs from that\nprevalent in earlier outbreaks when the disease was less prevalent.\nBefore 2004, the predominant strain was designated C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common. Whether this is related\nto the apparently greater severity of the disease since 2004 has still\nto be established. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (04): (HE, SD) 20090327.1194\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (SD) 20090324.1154\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HE), RFI 20090318.1099\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong S.A.R.) 20090312.1023\n..............................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "enterovirus 71 infection", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2008-05-16 00:00:00", "1971-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1971-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shandong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong S.A.R.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Henan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Henan province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sarawak", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shenzhen", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "168759", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - China (04): (HE, SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=168759", "date": "2008-08-26 23:00:41", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - ASIA (24): SINGAPORE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 26 Aug 2008\nSource: The Straits Times, Breaking News, online [edited]\n<http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/Singapore/Story/STIStory_271073.html>\n\n\nNew outbreak looming\n--------------------\nSingapore is on the verge of a hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD)\noutbreak, health officials revealed yesterday [Mon 25 Aug 2008]. Last\nweek, 553 people came down with the normally mild childhood disease\nthat usually causes fever and rashes on the hands, feet and buttocks.\nThat is just 12 fewer than the Health Ministry's official 'epidemic level.'\n\nThe tally last week was up from 415 over the previous 7 days, and\nhealth officials warn the numbers are likely to rise between now and\nOctober, traditionally a peak period for HFMD. This peak, though,\nusually affects fewer people than the 1st one from March to May, said\nDr. Lyn James, director of the Health Ministry's communicable\ndiseases division. The reasons for the peaks are not known.\n\nStill, the latest surge has already proven deadly. On 6 Aug 2008,\nSingapore registered its 1st death from HFMD [see: Hand, foot & mouth\ndisease - Asia (23): Singapore 20080808.2447] since a severe\noutbreak from 2000 to 2001 killed 7 children. Like most of those\nvictims, the 3-year-old child died from a severe form of HFMD caused by\na virus called EV71 [human enterovirus 71]. This virus has been of\nparticular concern to countries in Asia, which have been battling\noutbreaks of HFMD in recent years. This year, it has killed 44 in\nChina, 10 in Taiwan and 11 in Viet Nam.\n\nThe Health Ministry and the Regional Emerging Disease Intervention\n(Redi) Centre organised a 2-day regional forum on HFMD, which was\nattended by more than 80 scientists and public health officers from\n12 countries. At the forum's last day yesterday [25 Aug 2008], local\nvaccine company SingVax, Chinese vaccine company Sinovac Biotech and\nTaiwan's Centres for Disease Control gave updates on their progress\nin developing the world's first HFMD vaccine. Both SingVax and\nTaiwan's CDC said they have seen good results in the laboratories and\nhope to start clinical trials next year [2009].\n\nIn the absence of a vaccine, parents should ensure their children\nwash their hands, because the disease is often spread through saliva\nand faecal matter. They should also take their children to the doctor\nat the 1st sign of symptoms, and keep them away from schools and\ncrowded places, Dr. James said.\n\nMeanwhile, the school that the deceased child attended, Elias\nKindergarten in Woodlands, reopened earlier this week after a 10-day\nclosure to clean up. When The Straits Times visited yesterday, about\n20 to 30 children were in a queue waiting to have their teachers\ncheck their temperatures as well as hands and mouths to look for signs\nof HFMD.\n\n[Byline: Lee Hui Chieh and Ang Yiying]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As elsewhere in Asia the current outbreak of HFMD is predominantly a\nconsequence of enterovirus 71 infection. The preceding report from\nSingapore suggested that the small HFMD outbreak in the country was\nwaning, but that inference may be premature.\n\nEnterovirus 71 (EV71) was initially identified in Calfornia in 1969\nand outbreaks of EV71 infection have been recorded throughout the\nworld since then. EV71 has been associated with acute febrile\nillness, myocarditis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis,\nand encephalitis as well as with HFMD. Children under 5 years of age\nare particulalry susceptible to these conditions and may develop\npermanent neurological damage or, rarely, may succumb to these\ndisorders. The largest EV71 epidemic to date occurred in Taiwan in\n1998 with nearly 130 000 cases. Since then there have been recurrent\nHFMD epidemics of varying severity and intensity throughout the\nAsia-Pacific region. This year (2008) until recently Singapore has\nescaped the worst effects of the current outbreak, but this pattern\nmay be changing. Whether this is due to environmental factors or to a\nchange in virulence of the virus is an open question.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Singapore can be found at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=1.4,103.8,6>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (23): Singapore 20080808.2447\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (22): China (JIN) 20080726.2281\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (21): Mongolia 20080715.2147\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (20): Taiwan 20080708.2078\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (15): China (Anhui, Macao) 20080530.1748\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (10): China (Beijing) 20080514.1622\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (05): China 20080508.1577\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (04): China, Macao S.A.R. 20080507.1561\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (03): China, Taiwan 20080506.1553\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia: China (Hubei), Malaysia\n(Sarawak) 20080502.1511\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (05): Viet Nam 20060910.2573\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (04) 20060628.1794\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (03) 20060606.1573\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Southeast Asia (02) 20060406.1035\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia 20060330.0960\n..........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["enterovirus 71 infection", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2008-08-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "1969-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Macao", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anhui", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Calfornia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Centre", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hubei", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "168072", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=168072", "date": "2008-08-26 23:00:41", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - ASIA (24): SINGAPORE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 26 Aug 2008\nSource: The Straits Times, Breaking News, online [edited]\n<http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/Singapore/Story/STIStory_271073.html>\n\n\nNew outbreak looming\n--------------------\nSingapore is on the verge of a hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD)\noutbreak, health officials revealed yesterday [Mon 25 Aug 2008]. Last\nweek, 553 people came down with the normally mild childhood disease\nthat usually causes fever and rashes on the hands, feet and buttocks.\nThat is just 12 fewer than the Health Ministry's official 'epidemic level.'\n\nThe tally last week was up from 415 over the previous 7 days, and\nhealth officials warn the numbers are likely to rise between now and\nOctober, traditionally a peak period for HFMD. This peak, though,\nusually affects fewer people than the 1st one from March to May, said\nDr. Lyn James, director of the Health Ministry's communicable\ndiseases division. The reasons for the peaks are not known.\n\nStill, the latest surge has already proven deadly. On 6 Aug 2008,\nSingapore registered its 1st death from HFMD [see: Hand, foot & mouth\ndisease - Asia (23): Singapore 20080808.2447] since a severe\noutbreak from 2000 to 2001 killed 7 children. Like most of those\nvictims, the 3-year-old child died from a severe form of HFMD caused by\na virus called EV71 [human enterovirus 71]. This virus has been of\nparticular concern to countries in Asia, which have been battling\noutbreaks of HFMD in recent years. This year, it has killed 44 in\nChina, 10 in Taiwan and 11 in Viet Nam.\n\nThe Health Ministry and the Regional Emerging Disease Intervention\n(Redi) Centre organised a 2-day regional forum on HFMD, which was\nattended by more than 80 scientists and public health officers from\n12 countries. At the forum's last day yesterday [25 Aug 2008], local\nvaccine company SingVax, Chinese vaccine company Sinovac Biotech and\nTaiwan's Centres for Disease Control gave updates on their progress\nin developing the world's first HFMD vaccine. Both SingVax and\nTaiwan's CDC said they have seen good results in the laboratories and\nhope to start clinical trials next year [2009].\n\nIn the absence of a vaccine, parents should ensure their children\nwash their hands, because the disease is often spread through saliva\nand faecal matter. They should also take their children to the doctor\nat the 1st sign of symptoms, and keep them away from schools and\ncrowded places, Dr. James said.\n\nMeanwhile, the school that the deceased child attended, Elias\nKindergarten in Woodlands, reopened earlier this week after a 10-day\nclosure to clean up. When The Straits Times visited yesterday, about\n20 to 30 children were in a queue waiting to have their teachers\ncheck their temperatures as well as hands and mouths to look for signs\nof HFMD.\n\n[Byline: Lee Hui Chieh and Ang Yiying]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As elsewhere in Asia the current outbreak of HFMD is predominantly a\nconsequence of enterovirus 71 infection. The preceding report from\nSingapore suggested that the small HFMD outbreak in the country was\nwaning, but that inference may be premature.\n\nEnterovirus 71 (EV71) was initially identified in Calfornia in 1969\nand outbreaks of EV71 infection have been recorded throughout the\nworld since then. EV71 has been associated with acute febrile\nillness, myocarditis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis,\nand encephalitis as well as with HFMD. Children under 5 years of age\nare particulalry susceptible to these conditions and may develop\npermanent neurological damage or, rarely, may succumb to these\ndisorders. The largest EV71 epidemic to date occurred in Taiwan in\n1998 with nearly 130 000 cases. Since then there have been recurrent\nHFMD epidemics of varying severity and intensity throughout the\nAsia-Pacific region. This year (2008) until recently Singapore has\nescaped the worst effects of the current outbreak, but this pattern\nmay be changing. Whether this is due to environmental factors or to a\nchange in virulence of the virus is an open question.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Singapore can be found at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=1.4,103.8,6>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (23): Singapore 20080808.2447\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (22): China (JIN) 20080726.2281\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (21): Mongolia 20080715.2147\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (20): Taiwan 20080708.2078\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (15): China (Anhui, Macao) 20080530.1748\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (10): China (Beijing) 20080514.1622\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (05): China 20080508.1577\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (04): China, Macao S.A.R. 20080507.1561\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (03): China, Taiwan 20080506.1553\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia: China (Hubei), Malaysia\n(Sarawak) 20080502.1511\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (05): Viet Nam 20060910.2573\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (04) 20060628.1794\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (03) 20060606.1573\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Southeast Asia (02) 20060406.1035\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia 20060330.0960\n..........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["enterovirus 71 infection", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2008-08-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "1969-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Macao", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anhui", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Calfornia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Centre", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hubei", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "166143", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (HE), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=166143", "date": "2008-08-26 23:00:41", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - ASIA (24): SINGAPORE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 26 Aug 2008\nSource: The Straits Times, Breaking News, online [edited]\n<http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/Singapore/Story/STIStory_271073.html>\n\n\nNew outbreak looming\n--------------------\nSingapore is on the verge of a hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD)\noutbreak, health officials revealed yesterday [Mon 25 Aug 2008]. Last\nweek, 553 people came down with the normally mild childhood disease\nthat usually causes fever and rashes on the hands, feet and buttocks.\nThat is just 12 fewer than the Health Ministry's official 'epidemic level.'\n\nThe tally last week was up from 415 over the previous 7 days, and\nhealth officials warn the numbers are likely to rise between now and\nOctober, traditionally a peak period for HFMD. This peak, though,\nusually affects fewer people than the 1st one from March to May, said\nDr. Lyn James, director of the Health Ministry's communicable\ndiseases division. The reasons for the peaks are not known.\n\nStill, the latest surge has already proven deadly. On 6 Aug 2008,\nSingapore registered its 1st death from HFMD [see: Hand, foot & mouth\ndisease - Asia (23): Singapore 20080808.2447] since a severe\noutbreak from 2000 to 2001 killed 7 children. Like most of those\nvictims, the 3-year-old child died from a severe form of HFMD caused by\na virus called EV71 [human enterovirus 71]. This virus has been of\nparticular concern to countries in Asia, which have been battling\noutbreaks of HFMD in recent years. This year, it has killed 44 in\nChina, 10 in Taiwan and 11 in Viet Nam.\n\nThe Health Ministry and the Regional Emerging Disease Intervention\n(Redi) Centre organised a 2-day regional forum on HFMD, which was\nattended by more than 80 scientists and public health officers from\n12 countries. At the forum's last day yesterday [25 Aug 2008], local\nvaccine company SingVax, Chinese vaccine company Sinovac Biotech and\nTaiwan's Centres for Disease Control gave updates on their progress\nin developing the world's first HFMD vaccine. Both SingVax and\nTaiwan's CDC said they have seen good results in the laboratories and\nhope to start clinical trials next year [2009].\n\nIn the absence of a vaccine, parents should ensure their children\nwash their hands, because the disease is often spread through saliva\nand faecal matter. They should also take their children to the doctor\nat the 1st sign of symptoms, and keep them away from schools and\ncrowded places, Dr. James said.\n\nMeanwhile, the school that the deceased child attended, Elias\nKindergarten in Woodlands, reopened earlier this week after a 10-day\nclosure to clean up. When The Straits Times visited yesterday, about\n20 to 30 children were in a queue waiting to have their teachers\ncheck their temperatures as well as hands and mouths to look for signs\nof HFMD.\n\n[Byline: Lee Hui Chieh and Ang Yiying]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As elsewhere in Asia the current outbreak of HFMD is predominantly a\nconsequence of enterovirus 71 infection. The preceding report from\nSingapore suggested that the small HFMD outbreak in the country was\nwaning, but that inference may be premature.\n\nEnterovirus 71 (EV71) was initially identified in Calfornia in 1969\nand outbreaks of EV71 infection have been recorded throughout the\nworld since then. EV71 has been associated with acute febrile\nillness, myocarditis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis,\nand encephalitis as well as with HFMD. Children under 5 years of age\nare particulalry susceptible to these conditions and may develop\npermanent neurological damage or, rarely, may succumb to these\ndisorders. The largest EV71 epidemic to date occurred in Taiwan in\n1998 with nearly 130 000 cases. Since then there have been recurrent\nHFMD epidemics of varying severity and intensity throughout the\nAsia-Pacific region. This year (2008) until recently Singapore has\nescaped the worst effects of the current outbreak, but this pattern\nmay be changing. Whether this is due to environmental factors or to a\nchange in virulence of the virus is an open question.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Singapore can be found at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=1.4,103.8,6>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (23): Singapore 20080808.2447\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (22): China (JIN) 20080726.2281\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (21): Mongolia 20080715.2147\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (20): Taiwan 20080708.2078\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (15): China (Anhui, Macao) 20080530.1748\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (10): China (Beijing) 20080514.1622\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (05): China 20080508.1577\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (04): China, Macao S.A.R. 20080507.1561\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (03): China, Taiwan 20080506.1553\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia: China (Hubei), Malaysia\n(Sarawak) 20080502.1511\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (05): Viet Nam 20060910.2573\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (04) 20060628.1794\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (03) 20060606.1573\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Southeast Asia (02) 20060406.1035\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia 20060330.0960\n..........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
