China (Hong Kong S.A.R.)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=164471", "date": "2008-08-26 23:00:41", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - ASIA (24): SINGAPORE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 26 Aug 2008\nSource: The Straits Times, Breaking News, online [edited]\n<http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/Singapore/Story/STIStory_271073.html>\n\n\nNew outbreak looming\n--------------------\nSingapore is on the verge of a hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD)\noutbreak, health officials revealed yesterday [Mon 25 Aug 2008]. Last\nweek, 553 people came down with the normally mild childhood disease\nthat usually causes fever and rashes on the hands, feet and buttocks.\nThat is just 12 fewer than the Health Ministry's official 'epidemic level.'\n\nThe tally last week was up from 415 over the previous 7 days, and\nhealth officials warn the numbers are likely to rise between now and\nOctober, traditionally a peak period for HFMD. This peak, though,\nusually affects fewer people than the 1st one from March to May, said\nDr. Lyn James, director of the Health Ministry's communicable\ndiseases division. The reasons for the peaks are not known.\n\nStill, the latest surge has already proven deadly. On 6 Aug 2008,\nSingapore registered its 1st death from HFMD [see: Hand, foot & mouth\ndisease - Asia (23): Singapore 20080808.2447] since a severe\noutbreak from 2000 to 2001 killed 7 children. Like most of those\nvictims, the 3-year-old child died from a severe form of HFMD caused by\na virus called EV71 [human enterovirus 71]. This virus has been of\nparticular concern to countries in Asia, which have been battling\noutbreaks of HFMD in recent years. This year, it has killed 44 in\nChina, 10 in Taiwan and 11 in Viet Nam.\n\nThe Health Ministry and the Regional Emerging Disease Intervention\n(Redi) Centre organised a 2-day regional forum on HFMD, which was\nattended by more than 80 scientists and public health officers from\n12 countries. At the forum's last day yesterday [25 Aug 2008], local\nvaccine company SingVax, Chinese vaccine company Sinovac Biotech and\nTaiwan's Centres for Disease Control gave updates on their progress\nin developing the world's first HFMD vaccine. Both SingVax and\nTaiwan's CDC said they have seen good results in the laboratories and\nhope to start clinical trials next year [2009].\n\nIn the absence of a vaccine, parents should ensure their children\nwash their hands, because the disease is often spread through saliva\nand faecal matter. They should also take their children to the doctor\nat the 1st sign of symptoms, and keep them away from schools and\ncrowded places, Dr. James said.\n\nMeanwhile, the school that the deceased child attended, Elias\nKindergarten in Woodlands, reopened earlier this week after a 10-day\nclosure to clean up. When The Straits Times visited yesterday, about\n20 to 30 children were in a queue waiting to have their teachers\ncheck their temperatures as well as hands and mouths to look for signs\nof HFMD.\n\n[Byline: Lee Hui Chieh and Ang Yiying]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As elsewhere in Asia the current outbreak of HFMD is predominantly a\nconsequence of enterovirus 71 infection. The preceding report from\nSingapore suggested that the small HFMD outbreak in the country was\nwaning, but that inference may be premature.\n\nEnterovirus 71 (EV71) was initially identified in Calfornia in 1969\nand outbreaks of EV71 infection have been recorded throughout the\nworld since then. EV71 has been associated with acute febrile\nillness, myocarditis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis,\nand encephalitis as well as with HFMD. Children under 5 years of age\nare particulalry susceptible to these conditions and may develop\npermanent neurological damage or, rarely, may succumb to these\ndisorders. The largest EV71 epidemic to date occurred in Taiwan in\n1998 with nearly 130 000 cases. Since then there have been recurrent\nHFMD epidemics of varying severity and intensity throughout the\nAsia-Pacific region. This year (2008) until recently Singapore has\nescaped the worst effects of the current outbreak, but this pattern\nmay be changing. Whether this is due to environmental factors or to a\nchange in virulence of the virus is an open question.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Singapore can be found at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=1.4,103.8,6>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (23): Singapore 20080808.2447\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (22): China (JIN) 20080726.2281\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (21): Mongolia 20080715.2147\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (20): Taiwan 20080708.2078\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (15): China (Anhui, Macao) 20080530.1748\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (10): China (Beijing) 20080514.1622\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (05): China 20080508.1577\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (04): China, Macao S.A.R. 20080507.1561\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (03): China, Taiwan 20080506.1553\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia: China (Hubei), Malaysia\n(Sarawak) 20080502.1511\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (05): Viet Nam 20060910.2573\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (04) 20060628.1794\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (03) 20060606.1573\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Southeast Asia (02) 20060406.1035\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia 20060330.0960\n..........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Last\nweek, 553 people came down with the normally mild childhood disease\nthat usually causes fever and rashes on the hands, feet and buttocks.\nThat is just 12 fewer than the Health Ministry's official 'epidemic level.'\n\nThe tally last week was up from 415 over the previous 7 days, and\nhealth officials warn the numbers are likely to rise between now and\nOctober, traditionally a peak period for HFMD. This peak, though,\nusually affects fewer people than the 1st one from March to May, said\nDr. Lyn James, director of the Health Ministry's communicable\ndiseases division. The reasons for the peaks are not known.\n\nStill, the latest surge has already proven deadly. On 6 Aug 2008,\nSingapore registered its 1st death from HFMD [see: Hand, foot & mouth\ndisease - Asia (23): Singapore 20080808.2447] since a severe\noutbreak from 2000 to 2001 killed 7 children. Like most of those\nvictims, the 3-year-old child died from a severe form of HFMD caused by\na virus called EV71 [human enterovirus 71]. This virus has been of\nparticular concern to countries in Asia, which have been battling\noutbreaks of HFMD in recent years. This year, it has killed 44 in\nChina, 10 in Taiwan and 11 in Viet Nam.\n\nThe Health Ministry and the Regional Emerging Disease Intervention\n(Redi) Centre organised a 2-day regional forum on HFMD, which was\nattended by more than 80 scientists and public health officers from\n12 countries. At the forum's last day yesterday [25 Aug 2008], local\nvaccine company SingVax, Chinese vaccine company Sinovac Biotech and\nTaiwan's Centres for Disease Control gave updates on their progress\nin developing the world's first HFMD vaccine. Both SingVax and\nTaiwan's CDC said they have seen good results in the laboratories and\nhope to start clinical trials next year [2009].\n\nIn the absence of a vaccine, parents should ensure their children\nwash their hands, because the disease is often spread through saliva\nand faecal matter. They should also take their children to the doctor\nat the 1st sign of symptoms, and keep them away from schools and\ncrowded places, Dr. James said.\n\nMeanwhile, the school that the deceased child attended, Elias\nKindergarten in Woodlands, reopened earlier this week after a 10-day\nclosure to clean up. When The Straits Times visited yesterday, about\n20 to 30 children were in a queue waiting to have their teachers\ncheck their temperatures as well as hands and mouths to look for signs\nof HFMD.\n\n[Byline: Lee Hui Chieh and Ang Yiying]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As elsewhere in Asia the current outbreak of HFMD is predominantly a\nconsequence of enterovirus 71 infection. The preceding report from\nSingapore suggested that the small HFMD outbreak in the country was\nwaning, but that inference may be premature.\n\nEnterovirus 71 (EV71) was initially identified in Calfornia in 1969\nand outbreaks of EV71 infection have been recorded throughout the\nworld since then. EV71 has been associated with acute febrile\nillness, myocarditis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis,\nand encephalitis as well as with HFMD. Children under 5 years of age\nare particulalry susceptible to these conditions and may develop\npermanent neurological damage or, rarely, may succumb to these\ndisorders. The largest EV71 epidemic to date occurred in Taiwan in\n1998 with nearly 130 000 cases. Since then there have been recurrent\nHFMD epidemics of varying severity and intensity throughout the\nAsia-Pacific region. This year (2008) until recently Singapore has\nescaped the worst effects of the current outbreak, but this pattern\nmay be changing. Whether this is due to environmental factors or to a\nchange in virulence of the virus is an open question.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Singapore can be found at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=1.4,103.8,6>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (23): Singapore 20080808.2447\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (22): China (JIN) 20080726.2281\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (21): Mongolia 20080715.2147\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (20): Taiwan 20080708.2078\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (15): China (Anhui, Macao) 20080530.1748\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (10): China (Beijing) 20080514.1622\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (05): China 20080508.1577\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (04): China, Macao S.A.R. 20080507.1561\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (03): China, Taiwan 20080506.1553\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia: China (Hubei), Malaysia\n(Sarawak) 20080502.1511\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (05): Viet Nam 20060910.2573\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (04) 20060628.1794\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (03) 20060606.1573\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Southeast Asia (02) 20060406.1035\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia 20060330.0960\n..........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Asia (25): Taiwan", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=111651", "date": "2008-08-26 23:00:41", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - ASIA (24): SINGAPORE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 26 Aug 2008\nSource: The Straits Times, Breaking News, online [edited]\n<http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/Singapore/Story/STIStory_271073.html>\n\n\nNew outbreak looming\n--------------------\nSingapore is on the verge of a hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD)\noutbreak, health officials revealed yesterday [Mon 25 Aug 2008]. Last\nweek, 553 people came down with the normally mild childhood disease\nthat usually causes fever and rashes on the hands, feet and buttocks.\nThat is just 12 fewer than the Health Ministry's official 'epidemic level.'\n\nThe tally last week was up from 415 over the previous 7 days, and\nhealth officials warn the numbers are likely to rise between now and\nOctober, traditionally a peak period for HFMD. This peak, though,\nusually affects fewer people than the 1st one from March to May, said\nDr. Lyn James, director of the Health Ministry's communicable\ndiseases division. The reasons for the peaks are not known.\n\nStill, the latest surge has already proven deadly. On 6 Aug 2008,\nSingapore registered its 1st death from HFMD [see: Hand, foot & mouth\ndisease - Asia (23): Singapore 20080808.2447] since a severe\noutbreak from 2000 to 2001 killed 7 children. Like most of those\nvictims, the 3-year-old child died from a severe form of HFMD caused by\na virus called EV71 [human enterovirus 71]. This virus has been of\nparticular concern to countries in Asia, which have been battling\noutbreaks of HFMD in recent years. This year, it has killed 44 in\nChina, 10 in Taiwan and 11 in Viet Nam.\n\nThe Health Ministry and the Regional Emerging Disease Intervention\n(Redi) Centre organised a 2-day regional forum on HFMD, which was\nattended by more than 80 scientists and public health officers from\n12 countries. At the forum's last day yesterday [25 Aug 2008], local\nvaccine company SingVax, Chinese vaccine company Sinovac Biotech and\nTaiwan's Centres for Disease Control gave updates on their progress\nin developing the world's first HFMD vaccine. Both SingVax and\nTaiwan's CDC said they have seen good results in the laboratories and\nhope to start clinical trials next year [2009].\n\nIn the absence of a vaccine, parents should ensure their children\nwash their hands, because the disease is often spread through saliva\nand faecal matter. They should also take their children to the doctor\nat the 1st sign of symptoms, and keep them away from schools and\ncrowded places, Dr. James said.\n\nMeanwhile, the school that the deceased child attended, Elias\nKindergarten in Woodlands, reopened earlier this week after a 10-day\nclosure to clean up. When The Straits Times visited yesterday, about\n20 to 30 children were in a queue waiting to have their teachers\ncheck their temperatures as well as hands and mouths to look for signs\nof HFMD.\n\n[Byline: Lee Hui Chieh and Ang Yiying]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As elsewhere in Asia the current outbreak of HFMD is predominantly a\nconsequence of enterovirus 71 infection. The preceding report from\nSingapore suggested that the small HFMD outbreak in the country was\nwaning, but that inference may be premature.\n\nEnterovirus 71 (EV71) was initially identified in Calfornia in 1969\nand outbreaks of EV71 infection have been recorded throughout the\nworld since then. EV71 has been associated with acute febrile\nillness, myocarditis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis,\nand encephalitis as well as with HFMD. Children under 5 years of age\nare particulalry susceptible to these conditions and may develop\npermanent neurological damage or, rarely, may succumb to these\ndisorders. The largest EV71 epidemic to date occurred in Taiwan in\n1998 with nearly 130 000 cases. Since then there have been recurrent\nHFMD epidemics of varying severity and intensity throughout the\nAsia-Pacific region. This year (2008) until recently Singapore has\nescaped the worst effects of the current outbreak, but this pattern\nmay be changing. Whether this is due to environmental factors or to a\nchange in virulence of the virus is an open question.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Singapore can be found at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=1.4,103.8,6>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (23): Singapore 20080808.2447\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (22): China (JIN) 20080726.2281\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (21): Mongolia 20080715.2147\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (20): Taiwan 20080708.2078\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (15): China (Anhui, Macao) 20080530.1748\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (10): China (Beijing) 20080514.1622\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (05): China 20080508.1577\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (04): China, Macao S.A.R. 20080507.1561\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (03): China, Taiwan 20080506.1553\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia: China (Hubei), Malaysia\n(Sarawak) 20080502.1511\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (05): Viet Nam 20060910.2573\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (04) 20060628.1794\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia (03) 20060606.1573\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Southeast Asia (02) 20060406.1035\nHand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia 20060330.0960\n..........................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Last\nweek, 553 people came down with the normally mild childhood disease\nthat usually causes fever and rashes on the hands, feet and buttocks.\nThat is just 12 fewer than the Health Ministry's official 'epidemic level.'\n\nThe tally last week was up from 415 over the previous 7 days, and\nhealth officials warn the numbers are likely to rise between now and\nOctober, traditionally a peak period for HFMD. This peak, though,\nusually affects fewer people than the 1st one from March to May, said\nDr. Lyn James, director of the Health Ministry's communicable\ndiseases division. On 6 Aug 2008,\nSingapore registered its 1st death from HFMD [see: Hand, foot & mouth\ndisease - Asia (23): Singapore 20080808.2447] since a severe\noutbreak from 2000 to 2001 killed 7 children. Like most of those\nvictims, the 3-year-old child died from a severe form of HFMD caused by\na virus called EV71 [human enterovirus 71]. This virus has been of\nparticular concern to countries in Asia, which have been battling\noutbreaks of HFMD in recent years. This year, it has killed 44 in\nChina, 10 in Taiwan and 11 in Viet Nam.\n\nThe Health Ministry and the Regional Emerging Disease Intervention\n(Redi) Centre organised a 2-day regional forum on HFMD, which was\nattended by more than 80 scientists and public health officers from\n12 countries. At the forum's last day yesterday [25 Aug 2008], local\nvaccine company SingVax, Chinese vaccine company Sinovac Biotech and\nTaiwan's Centres for Disease Control gave updates on their progress\nin developing the world's first HFMD vaccine. Both SingVax and\nTaiwan's CDC said they have seen good results in the laboratories and\nhope to start clinical trials next year [2009].\n\nIn the absence of a vaccine, parents should ensure their children\nwash their hands, because the disease is often spread through saliva\nand faecal matter. When The Straits Times visited yesterday, about\n20 to 30 children were in a queue waiting to have their teachers\ncheck their temperatures as well as hands and mouths to look for signs\nof HFMD.\n\n[Byline: Lee Hui Chieh and Ang Yiying]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As elsewhere in Asia the current outbreak of HFMD is predominantly a\nconsequence of enterovirus 71 infection. Asia (23): Singapore", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=101733", "date": "2008-06-04 20:00:23", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - ASIA (16): CHINA (GUANGDONG)\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 4 Jun 2008\nSource: People's Daily online [edited]\n<http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90782/90880/6424004.html>\n\n\nThe Hong Kong Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of\nHealth urged people to be vigilant against enterovirus-71 (EV71)\ninfection following the confirmation of a case by laboratory test on\nTuesday [3 Jun 2008].\n\nA spokesman for the CHP said the case involved a 2-year-old boy.\nLaboratory tests on his throat samples collected earlier showed a\npositive result for EV71. The boy lives in Shenzhen in Guangdong\nProvince. He developed a fever, hand and foot rashes and oral ulcers\non 26 May 2008. He came to Hong Kong on 29 May 2008 and was admitted\nto Princess Margaret Hospital on 31 May 2008. He was discharged on 1\nJun 2008. The spokesman said CHP's investigation is on-going.\n\nThere have been 43 cases of EV71 infection reported to CHP so far in\n2008. There were 35, 8, 16 and 12 cases in 2004, 2005, 2006 and 2007\nrespectively. The spokesman said EV71 is a viral infection usually\nfound among young children. It is also one of the causative agents of\nhand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD). He added that May to August is\nthe usual peak season for HFMD and EV71. The infection is transmitted\nby direct contact with nose and throat discharges. Children suffering\nfrom the infection should stay at home and avoid contacting other\nchildren until they have recovered.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of China can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=36.5,103.9,4>\nand shows the proximity of Hong Kong S.A.R. and Guangdong province. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed fatal disease: North Korea 20080604.1791\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (15): China (Anhui, Macao) 20080530.1748\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (14): Mongolia 20080523.1700\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (22): China (JIN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=98042", "date": "2008-06-04 20:00:23", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - ASIA (16): CHINA (GUANGDONG)\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 4 Jun 2008\nSource: People's Daily online [edited]\n<http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90782/90880/6424004.html>\n\n\nThe Hong Kong Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of\nHealth urged people to be vigilant against enterovirus-71 (EV71)\ninfection following the confirmation of a case by laboratory test on\nTuesday [3 Jun 2008].\n\nA spokesman for the CHP said the case involved a 2-year-old boy.\nLaboratory tests on his throat samples collected earlier showed a\npositive result for EV71. The boy lives in Shenzhen in Guangdong\nProvince. He developed a fever, hand and foot rashes and oral ulcers\non 26 May 2008. He came to Hong Kong on 29 May 2008 and was admitted\nto Princess Margaret Hospital on 31 May 2008. He was discharged on 1\nJun 2008. The spokesman said CHP's investigation is on-going.\n\nThere have been 43 cases of EV71 infection reported to CHP so far in\n2008. There were 35, 8, 16 and 12 cases in 2004, 2005, 2006 and 2007\nrespectively. The spokesman said EV71 is a viral infection usually\nfound among young children. It is also one of the causative agents of\nhand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD). He added that May to August is\nthe usual peak season for HFMD and EV71. The infection is transmitted\nby direct contact with nose and throat discharges. Children suffering\nfrom the infection should stay at home and avoid contacting other\nchildren until they have recovered.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of China can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=36.5,103.9,4>\nand shows the proximity of Hong Kong S.A.R. and Guangdong province. - Asia (18): China (Shanghai)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=88259", "date": "2008-06-04 20:00:23", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - ASIA (16): CHINA (GUANGDONG)\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 4 Jun 2008\nSource: People's Daily online [edited]\n<http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90782/90880/6424004.html>\n\n\nThe Hong Kong Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of\nHealth urged people to be vigilant against enterovirus-71 (EV71)\ninfection following the confirmation of a case by laboratory test on\nTuesday [3 Jun 2008].\n\nA spokesman for the CHP said the case involved a 2-year-old boy.\nLaboratory tests on his throat samples collected earlier showed a\npositive result for EV71. The boy lives in Shenzhen in Guangdong\nProvince. He developed a fever, hand and foot rashes and oral ulcers\non 26 May 2008. He came to Hong Kong on 29 May 2008 and was admitted\nto Princess Margaret Hospital on 31 May 2008. He was discharged on 1\nJun 2008. The spokesman said CHP's investigation is on-going.\n\nThere have been 43 cases of EV71 infection reported to CHP so far in\n2008. There were 35, 8, 16 and 12 cases in 2004, 2005, 2006 and 2007\nrespectively. The spokesman said EV71 is a viral infection usually\nfound among young children. It is also one of the causative agents of\nhand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD). He added that May to August is\nthe usual peak season for HFMD and EV71. The infection is transmitted\nby direct contact with nose and throat discharges. Children suffering\nfrom the infection should stay at home and avoid contacting other\nchildren until they have recovered.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of China can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=36.5,103.9,4>\nand shows the proximity of Hong Kong S.A.R. and Guangdong province. - Asia (15): China (Anhui, Macao)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=83147", "date": "2008-05-12 18:00:21", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - ASIA (08): MONGOLIA\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 12 May 2008\nSource: Soni.mn [trans. Enkhtuvshin Shiilegdamba, edited]\n<http://www.sonin.mn/2008/05/11/2089/>\n\n\nThe enterovirus 71 outbreak with signs of hand, foot and mouth disease\nwhich occurred in China has spread to Mongolia and is infecting more and\nmore children each day. A report from Sun 11 May 2008 shows that, in total,\n183 children from the capital city [Ulaanbataar] and provincal levels have\nbeen infected and have been admitted to hospitals for treatment. Also,\nthere is a suspicion of adults being infected with the virus. A 22 year old\nand a 43 year old have been referred to hospital for a possible infection.\nA presidential order to close (quarantine) schools from 1st to 5th grades\nand kindergartens for an unlimited time was made on 12 May 2008.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nEnkhtuvshin Shiilegdamba\nWildlife Conservation Society Mongolia Country Program\n<enkee.sh@gmail.com>\n\n[A previous report of 7 May 2008 recorded that a small number of cases of\nhand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) had been diagnosed in the Mongolian\nAutonomous Region of China (formerly Inner Mongolia). Now HFMD has spread\nnorthwards into Mongolia (formerly Outer Mongolia). As in China, and some\nother parts of Asia, the etiologic agent is human enterovirus 71. So far,\nno deaths have been recorded. However, unusually, a small number of adults\nmay be cases of HFMDV infection.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Mongolia can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=46.8,103.1,5>. Enkhtuvshin Shiilegdamba, edited]\n<http://www.sonin.mn/2008/05/11/2089/>\n\n\nThe enterovirus 71 outbreak with signs of hand, foot and mouth disease\nwhich occurred in China has spread to Mongolia and is infecting more and\nmore children each day. A report from Sun 11 May 2008 shows that, in total,\n183 children from the capital city [Ulaanbataar] and provincal levels have\nbeen infected and have been admitted to hospitals for treatment. Also,\nthere is a suspicion of adults being infected with the virus. A 22 year old\nand a 43 year old have been referred to hospital for a possible infection.\nA presidential order to close (quarantine) schools from 1st to 5th grades\nand kindergartens for an unlimited time was made on 12 May 2008.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nEnkhtuvshin Shiilegdamba\nWildlife Conservation Society Mongolia Country Program\n<enkee.sh@gmail.com>\n\n[A previous report of 7 May 2008 recorded that a small number of cases of\nhand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) had been diagnosed in the Mongolian\nAutonomous Region of China (formerly Inner Mongolia). Now HFMD has spread\nnorthwards into Mongolia (formerly Outer Mongolia). As in China, and some\nother parts of Asia, the etiologic agent is human enterovirus 71. So far,\nno deaths have been recorded. However, unusually, a small number of adults\nmay be cases of HFMDV infection.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Mongolia can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=46.8,103.1,5>. A map of the provinces of\nChina can be accessed at <http://www.chinamapxl.com/political-map.html>\nshowing the location of the Mongolian autonomous Region of China. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (07): China 20080510.1597\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (06): China 20080509.1583\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (05): China 20080508.1577\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (04): China, Macao S.A.R. 20080507.1561\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (03): China, Taiwan 20080506.1553\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (05): Beijing, provinces 20080505.1537\nHand, foot & mouth - Asia (02): China, Singapore, Viet Nam 20080504.1528\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (04): eastern & HK 20080503.1521\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia: China (Hubei), Malaysia (Sarawak)\n20080502.1511\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (Anhui), WHO 20080501.1504\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (Anhui) 20080429.1481\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Anhui), Singapore 20080429.1472\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore, Brunei 20080427.1456\n\n..................cp/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Enkhtuvshin Shiilegdamba, edited]\n<http://www.sonin.mn/2008/05/11/2089/>\n\n\nThe enterovirus 71 outbreak with signs of hand, foot and mouth disease\nwhich occurred in China has spread to Mongolia and is infecting more and\nmore children each day. A report from Sun 11 May 2008 shows that, in total,\n183 children from the capital city [Ulaanbataar] and provincal levels have\nbeen infected and have been admitted to hospitals for treatment. Also,\nthere is a suspicion of adults being infected with the virus. A 22 year old\nand a 43 year old have been referred to hospital for a possible infection.\nA presidential order to close (quarantine) schools from 1st to 5th grades\nand kindergartens for an unlimited time was made on 12 May 2008.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nEnkhtuvshin Shiilegdamba\nWildlife Conservation Society Mongolia Country Program\n<enkee.sh@gmail.com>\n\n[A previous report of 7 May 2008 recorded that a small number of cases of\nhand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) had been diagnosed in the Mongolian\nAutonomous Region of China (formerly Inner Mongolia). Now HFMD has spread\nnorthwards into Mongolia (formerly Outer Mongolia). As in China, and some\nother parts of Asia, the etiologic agent is human enterovirus 71. So far,\nno deaths have been recorded. However, unusually, a small number of adults\nmay be cases of HFMDV infection.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Mongolia can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=46.8,103.1,5>. Now HFMD has spread\nnorthwards into Mongolia (formerly Outer Mongolia). As in China, and some\nother parts of Asia, the etiologic agent is human enterovirus 71. So far,\nno deaths have been recorded. However, unusually, a small number of adults\nmay be cases of HFMDV infection.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Mongolia can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=46.8,103.1,5>. A map of the provinces of\nChina can be accessed at <http://www.chinamapxl.com/political-map.html>\nshowing the location of the Mongolian autonomous Region of China. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (07): China 20080510.1597\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (06): China 20080509.1583\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (05): China 20080508.1577\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (04): China, Macao S.A.R. 20080507.1561\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (03): China, Taiwan 20080506.1553\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (05): Beijing, provinces 20080505.1537\nHand, foot & mouth - Asia (02): China, Singapore, Viet Nam 20080504.1528\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (04): eastern & HK 20080503.1521\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia: China (Hubei), Malaysia (Sarawak)\n20080502.1511\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (Anhui), WHO 20080501.1504\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (Anhui) 20080429.1481\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Anhui), Singapore 20080429.1472\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore, Brunei 20080427.1456\n\n..................cp/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Enkhtuvshin Shiilegdamba, edited]\n<http://www.sonin.mn/2008/05/11/2089/>\n\n\nThe enterovirus 71 outbreak with signs of hand, foot and mouth disease\nwhich occurred in China has spread to Mongolia and is infecting more and\nmore children each day. A report from Sun 11 May 2008 shows that, in total,\n183 children from the capital city [Ulaanbataar] and provincal levels have\nbeen infected and have been admitted to hospitals for treatment. Also,\nthere is a suspicion of adults being infected with the virus. A 22 year old\nand a 43 year old have been referred to hospital for a possible infection.\nA presidential order to close (quarantine) schools from 1st to 5th grades\nand kindergartens for an unlimited time was made on 12 May 2008.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nEnkhtuvshin Shiilegdamba\nWildlife Conservation Society Mongolia Country Program\n<enkee.sh@gmail.com>\n\n[A previous report of 7 May 2008 recorded that a small number of cases of\nhand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) had been diagnosed in the Mongolian\nAutonomous Region of China (formerly Inner Mongolia). Now HFMD has spread\nnorthwards into Mongolia (formerly Outer Mongolia). As in China, and some\nother parts of Asia, the etiologic agent is human enterovirus 71. So far,\nno deaths have been recorded. However, unusually, a small number of adults\nmay be cases of HFMDV infection.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Mongolia can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=46.8,103.1,5>. A map of the provinces of\nChina can be accessed at <http://www.chinamapxl.com/political-map.html>\nshowing the location of the Mongolian autonomous Region of China. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (07): China 20080510.1597\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (06): China 20080509.1583\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (05): China 20080508.1577\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (04): China, Macao S.A.R. 20080507.1561\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (03): China, Taiwan 20080506.1553\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (05): Beijing, provinces 20080505.1537\nHand, foot & mouth - Asia (02): China, Singapore, Viet Nam 20080504.1528\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (04): eastern & HK 20080503.1521\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia: China (Hubei), Malaysia (Sarawak)\n20080502.1511\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (Anhui), WHO 20080501.1504\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (Anhui) 20080429.1481\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Anhui), Singapore 20080429.1472\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore, Brunei 20080427.1456\n\n..................cp/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Also,\nthere is a suspicion of adults being infected with the virus. Now HFMD has spread\nnorthwards into Mongolia (formerly Outer Mongolia). As in China, and some\nother parts of Asia, the etiologic agent is human enterovirus 71. So far,\nno deaths have been recorded. However, unusually, a small number of adults\nmay be cases of HFMDV infection.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Mongolia can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=46.8,103.1,5>. The situation is so serious that the\ncity now faces quarantine.\n\nEnterovirus 71 (EV71) began spreading in Fuyang, Anhui Province, in\nearly March 2008 and by the early hours of yesterday [2 May 2008],\n3321 children had been infected by the virus, up from 2946 registered\na day earlier, said Wang Yan, a government spokesman. A total of 978\nchildren remain in hospital, 48 of them in a critical condition, Wang\nsaid.\n\nA total of 32 medical specialists sent by the Ministry of Health and\nthe provincial health department have arrived in Fuyang to direct\nproceedings. The province has upgraded its response plan for public\nhealth emergencies from class 3 to 2, which means the provincial\ngovernment has the power to quarantine patients and control traffic in\nand out of Fuyang, Xinhua news agency reported. Another 3 cities in\nother parts of the country have also reported cases of enterovirus 71.\n[See ProMED archives listed below].\n\nEnteroviruses are spread mostly through contact with infected\nblisters or feces and can cause high fever, paralysis and swelling of\nthe brain or its lining. Infection can lead to high mortality rates\nin more serious cases and no vaccine is available.\n\nEV71 cases usually peak from March to July. It began spreading in\nFuyang in early March 2008 as hospitals in the city started to take\nin children with fever, blisters, mouth ulcers and rashes on the\nhands and feet. Some were diagnosed with brain, heart and lung damage.\n\nAll cases in Fuyang were children aged below 6, most of them under 2\nyears of age. There are about 400 000 children below the age of 5 in\nFuyang. In a bid to stop the virus spreading, all kindergartens in\nFuyang began the 3-day May Day holiday 2 days early. More than 700\nbeds have been put into use in Fuyang's hospitals to treat the sick\nchildren. Another 1200 beds have been prepared for future patients.\n\nZhejiang, Hong Kong\n-------------------\nMeanwhile, 5 children were confirmed with EV 71 in Hangzhou City,\nZhejiang Province, as of Wednesday night [30 Apr 2008], and 10 people\nin Hong Kong have also been stricken by the virus as of yesterday.\nHong Kong last year had a total of 12 EV 71 cases. One of the Hong\nKong victims is a woman, who caught the virus from her 4-year-old\ndaughter on 24 Apr 2008. Both have recovered and been released from hospital.\n\nHubei\n-----\nThe Hubei Province Health Department said EV 71 hit 340 young\nchildren by 5pm on Thursday [1 May 2008]. No deaths were reported and\nno new cases have been detected since Wednesday [30 Apr 2008].\n\n[Byline: Lydia Chen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The current outbreak of human enterovirus 71-associated HFMD in\nChina appears to be most severe in the city of Fuyang in the province\nof Anhui. Since the the previous report from Anhui dated 2 May 2008\n(see: \"Hand, foot & mouth disease - Asia: China (Hubei), Malaysia\n(Sarawak) 20080502.1511\"), the number of cases in Fuyang city has\nrisen from 2946 to 3321 and the number of deaths from 21 to 22. It is\nnot immediately clear why Fuyang city should be at greater risk.\n\nA map of the provinces of China showing the affected eastern provinces\n& Hong Kong is available at\n<http://www.chinamapxl.com/political-map.html>.\nA map of Anhui province showing the location of the city of Fuyang in\nthe northwest of the province is available at\n<http://www.mapsofworld.com/china/provinces/anhui/map-of-anhui.html>.\n- Mod.CP/JW]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia: China (Hubei), Malaysia\n(Sarawak) 20080502.1511\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (Anhui), WHO 20080501.1504\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (Anhui) 20080429.1481\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Anhui), Singapore 20080429.1472\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore, Brunei 20080427.1456\n....................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2008-05-02 00:00:00", "2008-05-02 00:00:00", "2946-03-16 00:00:00", "1200-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-04-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2008-05-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2008-05-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fuyang City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zhejiang Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anhui", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fuyang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hubei", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zhejiang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hangzhou City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "78518", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Asia (05): China", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=78518", "date": "2008-05-03 20:00:20", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (04): EASTERN & HONG KONG\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 3 May 2008\nSource: Shanghai Daily online [edited]\n<http://www.shanghaidaily.com/sp/article/2008/200805/20080503/article_358174.htm>\n\n\nLethal virus claims more children\n---------------------------------\nA virus has spread rapidly, killing at least 22 children and\ninfecting more than 3300 others in Fuyang City, local authorities\nsaid yesterday [2 May 2008]. The situation is so serious that the\ncity now faces quarantine.\n\nEnterovirus 71 (EV71) began spreading in Fuyang, Anhui Province, in\nearly March 2008 and by the early hours of yesterday [2 May 2008],\n3321 children had been infected by the virus, up from 2946 registered\na day earlier, said Wang Yan, a government spokesman. A total of 978\nchildren remain in hospital, 48 of them in a critical condition, Wang\nsaid.\n\nA total of 32 medical specialists sent by the Ministry of Health and\nthe provincial health department have arrived in Fuyang to direct\nproceedings. The province has upgraded its response plan for public\nhealth emergencies from class 3 to 2, which means the provincial\ngovernment has the power to quarantine patients and control traffic in\nand out of Fuyang, Xinhua news agency reported. Another 3 cities in\nother parts of the country have also reported cases of enterovirus 71.\n[See ProMED archives listed below].\n\nEnteroviruses are spread mostly through contact with infected\nblisters or feces and can cause high fever, paralysis and swelling of\nthe brain or its lining. Infection can lead to high mortality rates\nin more serious cases and no vaccine is available.\n\nEV71 cases usually peak from March to July. It began spreading in\nFuyang in early March 2008 as hospitals in the city started to take\nin children with fever, blisters, mouth ulcers and rashes on the\nhands and feet. Some were diagnosed with brain, heart and lung damage.\n\nAll cases in Fuyang were children aged below 6, most of them under 2\nyears of age. There are about 400 000 children below the age of 5 in\nFuyang. In a bid to stop the virus spreading, all kindergartens in\nFuyang began the 3-day May Day holiday 2 days early. More than 700\nbeds have been put into use in Fuyang's hospitals to treat the sick\nchildren. Another 1200 beds have been prepared for future patients.\n\nZhejiang, Hong Kong\n-------------------\nMeanwhile, 5 children were confirmed with EV 71 in Hangzhou City,\nZhejiang Province, as of Wednesday night [30 Apr 2008], and 10 people\nin Hong Kong have also been stricken by the virus as of yesterday.\nHong Kong last year had a total of 12 EV 71 cases. One of the Hong\nKong victims is a woman, who caught the virus from her 4-year-old\ndaughter on 24 Apr 2008. Both have recovered and been released from hospital.\n\nHubei\n-----\nThe Hubei Province Health Department said EV 71 hit 340 young\nchildren by 5pm on Thursday [1 May 2008]. No deaths were reported and\nno new cases have been detected since Wednesday [30 Apr 2008].\n\n[Byline: Lydia Chen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The current outbreak of human enterovirus 71-associated HFMD in\nChina appears to be most severe in the city of Fuyang in the province\nof Anhui. Since the the previous report from Anhui dated 2 May 2008\n(see: \"Hand, foot & mouth disease - Asia: China (Hubei), Malaysia\n(Sarawak) 20080502.1511\"), the number of cases in Fuyang city has\nrisen from 2946 to 3321 and the number of deaths from 21 to 22. It is\nnot immediately clear why Fuyang city should be at greater risk.\n\nA map of the provinces of China showing the affected eastern provinces\n& Hong Kong is available at\n<http://www.chinamapxl.com/political-map.html>.\nA map of Anhui province showing the location of the city of Fuyang in\nthe northwest of the province is available at\n<http://www.mapsofworld.com/china/provinces/anhui/map-of-anhui.html>.\n- Mod.CP/JW]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia: China (Hubei), Malaysia\n(Sarawak) 20080502.1511\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (Anhui), WHO 20080501.1504\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (Anhui) 20080429.1481\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Anhui), Singapore 20080429.1472\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore, Brunei 20080427.1456\n....................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2008-05-02 00:00:00", "2008-05-02 00:00:00", "2946-03-16 00:00:00", "1200-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-04-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2008-05-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2008-05-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fuyang City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zhejiang Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anhui", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fuyang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hubei", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zhejiang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hangzhou City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "77264", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - China (04): eastern & HK", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=77264", "date": "2008-05-03 20:00:20", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (04): EASTERN & HONG KONG\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 3 May 2008\nSource: Shanghai Daily online [edited]\n<http://www.shanghaidaily.com/sp/article/2008/200805/20080503/article_358174.htm>\n\n\nLethal virus claims more children\n---------------------------------\nA virus has spread rapidly, killing at least 22 children and\ninfecting more than 3300 others in Fuyang City, local authorities\nsaid yesterday [2 May 2008]. The situation is so serious that the\ncity now faces quarantine.\n\nEnterovirus 71 (EV71) began spreading in Fuyang, Anhui Province, in\nearly March 2008 and by the early hours of yesterday [2 May 2008],\n3321 children had been infected by the virus, up from 2946 registered\na day earlier, said Wang Yan, a government spokesman. A total of 978\nchildren remain in hospital, 48 of them in a critical condition, Wang\nsaid.\n\nA total of 32 medical specialists sent by the Ministry of Health and\nthe provincial health department have arrived in Fuyang to direct\nproceedings. The province has upgraded its response plan for public\nhealth emergencies from class 3 to 2, which means the provincial\ngovernment has the power to quarantine patients and control traffic in\nand out of Fuyang, Xinhua news agency reported. Another 3 cities in\nother parts of the country have also reported cases of enterovirus 71.\n[See ProMED archives listed below].\n\nEnteroviruses are spread mostly through contact with infected\nblisters or feces and can cause high fever, paralysis and swelling of\nthe brain or its lining. Infection can lead to high mortality rates\nin more serious cases and no vaccine is available.\n\nEV71 cases usually peak from March to July. It began spreading in\nFuyang in early March 2008 as hospitals in the city started to take\nin children with fever, blisters, mouth ulcers and rashes on the\nhands and feet. Some were diagnosed with brain, heart and lung damage.\n\nAll cases in Fuyang were children aged below 6, most of them under 2\nyears of age. There are about 400 000 children below the age of 5 in\nFuyang. In a bid to stop the virus spreading, all kindergartens in\nFuyang began the 3-day May Day holiday 2 days early. More than 700\nbeds have been put into use in Fuyang's hospitals to treat the sick\nchildren. Another 1200 beds have been prepared for future patients.\n\nZhejiang, Hong Kong\n-------------------\nMeanwhile, 5 children were confirmed with EV 71 in Hangzhou City,\nZhejiang Province, as of Wednesday night [30 Apr 2008], and 10 people\nin Hong Kong have also been stricken by the virus as of yesterday.\nHong Kong last year had a total of 12 EV 71 cases. One of the Hong\nKong victims is a woman, who caught the virus from her 4-year-old\ndaughter on 24 Apr 2008. Both have recovered and been released from hospital.\n\nHubei\n-----\nThe Hubei Province Health Department said EV 71 hit 340 young\nchildren by 5pm on Thursday [1 May 2008]. No deaths were reported and\nno new cases have been detected since Wednesday [30 Apr 2008].\n\n[Byline: Lydia Chen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The current outbreak of human enterovirus 71-associated HFMD in\nChina appears to be most severe in the city of Fuyang in the province\nof Anhui. Since the the previous report from Anhui dated 2 May 2008\n(see: \"Hand, foot & mouth disease - Asia: China (Hubei), Malaysia\n(Sarawak) 20080502.1511\"), the number of cases in Fuyang city has\nrisen from 2946 to 3321 and the number of deaths from 21 to 22. It is\nnot immediately clear why Fuyang city should be at greater risk.\n\nA map of the provinces of China showing the affected eastern provinces\n& Hong Kong is available at\n<http://www.chinamapxl.com/political-map.html>.\nA map of Anhui province showing the location of the city of Fuyang in\nthe northwest of the province is available at\n<http://www.mapsofworld.com/china/provinces/anhui/map-of-anhui.html>.\n- Mod.CP/JW]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Asia: China (Hubei), Malaysia\n(Sarawak) 20080502.1511\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (03): (Anhui), WHO 20080501.1504\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (02): (Anhui) 20080429.1481\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Anhui), Singapore 20080429.1472\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore, Brunei 20080427.1456\n....................cp/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The Public Health Office in\nnorthern Lampang Province Friday [23 Nov 2007] ordered the Prachawit\nSchool to close its kindergarten classes after about 10 kids were\nfound to have contracted the disease, local news network \"The Nation\" reported.\n\nOn Thursday [22 Nov 2007], the office ordered Assumption School in\nLampang to close its kindergarten classes following the outbreak of\nthe disease. Also in Lambang, local authorities on Friday [23 Nov\n2007] ordered a nursery to close after 16 children there contracted HFMD.\n\nMeanwhile, in central Chon Buri Province, several schools in Sattahib\ndistrict were ordered to be on alert following an outbreak of HFMD at\na school. About 10 students of Ban Sattahib School got the disease\nand received treatment at 2 hospitals in the district, prompting the\ndistrict health office to inform other schools to be on alert.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness of\ninfants and children, most frequently affecting children under 10\nyears of age and infants. It is a human disease unrelated to the\nfoot-and-mouth disease affecting ruminants and other animals. HFMD is\ncharacterised by fever and vesicles in the mouth and on distal\nextremities. Complications are uncommon in most outbreaks, but rare\nneurological damage has been associated with some outbreaks. HFMD is\nmoderately contagious. Infection is spread from person to person by\ndirect contact with nose and throat discharges, saliva, fluid from\nblisters, or the stool of infected persons. A child is most\ncontagious during the first week of the illness. Individual cases and\noutbreaks of HFMD occur worldwide, more frequently in summer and early autumn.\n\nA variety of enteric picornaviruses has been associated with HFMD,\nthe most frequently observed being Human coxsackievirus A16 and Human\nenterovirus 71. The etiologic agent in the current outbreak of HFMD\nin Thailand has not been determined as yet; previously a virus\nidentified as Echovirus type 11 was the cause of a HFMD outbreak in a\nhospital nursery in Thailand (Clin Infect Dis. 2005 Nov 1;41(9):\n1361-2). As well as the diversity of etiologic agents associated with\nHFMD, there is considerable genetic heterogeneity in the case of\nspecific viruses. For example, molecular epidemiological analyses of\nrecent Human enterovirus 71 isolates in the Western Pacific Region\nhas indicated that 2 major genogroups of Human enterovirus 71 have\nbeen circulating in Australia, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan and Japan.\nRecent Human enterovirus 71 isolates in Mainland China constitute a\nnew distinct genetic cluster, subgenogroup C4.\n\nInformation on the identity of the virus currently circulating in\nThailand would be welcomed.\n\nA map of the provinces of Thailand can be accessed at:\n<http://www.ourweb.info/01/maps/thailand/index2.shtml>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Beijing) 20070713.2253\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) 20070530.1741\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) 20070514.1540\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (02) 20070516.1560\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (03) 20070520.1604\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong)(04) 20070524.1667\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India (Calcutta) 20070923.3160\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Selangor) 20070924.3171\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Maldives 20070529.1719\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20070424.1338\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Sri Lanka (Colombo) 20070311.0869\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (HCM city) 20070926.3193\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20060907.2535\n2002\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20020621.4559\n....................cp/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The Public Health Office in\nnorthern Lampang Province Friday [23 Nov 2007] ordered the Prachawit\nSchool to close its kindergarten classes after about 10 kids were\nfound to have contracted the disease, local news network \"The Nation\" reported.\n\nOn Thursday [22 Nov 2007], the office ordered Assumption School in\nLampang to close its kindergarten classes following the outbreak of\nthe disease. Also in Lambang, local authorities on Friday [23 Nov\n2007] ordered a nursery to close after 16 children there contracted HFMD.\n\nMeanwhile, in central Chon Buri Province, several schools in Sattahib\ndistrict were ordered to be on alert following an outbreak of HFMD at\na school. About 10 students of Ban Sattahib School got the disease\nand received treatment at 2 hospitals in the district, prompting the\ndistrict health office to inform other schools to be on alert.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness of\ninfants and children, most frequently affecting children under 10\nyears of age and infants. It is a human disease unrelated to the\nfoot-and-mouth disease affecting ruminants and other animals. HFMD is\ncharacterised by fever and vesicles in the mouth and on distal\nextremities. As well as the diversity of etiologic agents associated with\nHFMD, there is considerable genetic heterogeneity in the case of\nspecific viruses. For example, molecular epidemiological analyses of\nrecent Human enterovirus 71 isolates in the Western Pacific Region\nhas indicated that 2 major genogroups of Human enterovirus 71 have\nbeen circulating in Australia, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan and Japan.\nRecent Human enterovirus 71 isolates in Mainland China constitute a\nnew distinct genetic cluster, subgenogroup C4.\n\nInformation on the identity of the virus currently circulating in\nThailand would be welcomed.\n\nA map of the provinces of Thailand can be accessed at:\n<http://www.ourweb.info/01/maps/thailand/index2.shtml>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Beijing) 20070713.2253\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) 20070530.1741\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) 20070514.1540\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (02) 20070516.1560\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (03) 20070520.1604\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong)(04) 20070524.1667\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India (Calcutta) 20070923.3160\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Selangor) 20070924.3171\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Maldives 20070529.1719\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20070424.1338\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Sri Lanka (Colombo) 20070311.0869\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (HCM city) 20070926.3193\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20060907.2535\n2002\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20020621.4559\n....................cp/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The Public Health Office in\nnorthern Lampang Province Friday [23 Nov 2007] ordered the Prachawit\nSchool to close its kindergarten classes after about 10 kids were\nfound to have contracted the disease, local news network \"The Nation\" reported.\n\nOn Thursday [22 Nov 2007], the office ordered Assumption School in\nLampang to close its kindergarten classes following the outbreak of\nthe disease. Also in Lambang, local authorities on Friday [23 Nov\n2007] ordered a nursery to close after 16 children there contracted HFMD.\n\nMeanwhile, in central Chon Buri Province, several schools in Sattahib\ndistrict were ordered to be on alert following an outbreak of HFMD at\na school. About 10 students of Ban Sattahib School got the disease\nand received treatment at 2 hospitals in the district, prompting the\ndistrict health office to inform other schools to be on alert.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness of\ninfants and children, most frequently affecting children under 10\nyears of age and infants. It is a human disease unrelated to the\nfoot-and-mouth disease affecting ruminants and other animals. HFMD is\ncharacterised by fever and vesicles in the mouth and on distal\nextremities. Complications are uncommon in most outbreaks, but rare\nneurological damage has been associated with some outbreaks. HFMD is\nmoderately contagious. Infection is spread from person to person by\ndirect contact with nose and throat discharges, saliva, fluid from\nblisters, or the stool of infected persons. A child is most\ncontagious during the first week of the illness. Individual cases and\noutbreaks of HFMD occur worldwide, more frequently in summer and early autumn.\n\nA variety of enteric picornaviruses has been associated with HFMD,\nthe most frequently observed being Human coxsackievirus A16 and Human\nenterovirus 71. The etiologic agent in the current outbreak of HFMD\nin Thailand has not been determined as yet; previously a virus\nidentified as Echovirus type 11 was the cause of a HFMD outbreak in a\nhospital nursery in Thailand (Clin Infect Dis. 2005 Nov 1;41(9):\n1361-2). As well as the diversity of etiologic agents associated with\nHFMD, there is considerable genetic heterogeneity in the case of\nspecific viruses. For example, molecular epidemiological analyses of\nrecent Human enterovirus 71 isolates in the Western Pacific Region\nhas indicated that 2 major genogroups of Human enterovirus 71 have\nbeen circulating in Australia, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan and Japan.\nRecent Human enterovirus 71 isolates in Mainland China constitute a\nnew distinct genetic cluster, subgenogroup C4.\n\nInformation on the identity of the virus currently circulating in\nThailand would be welcomed.\n\nA map of the provinces of Thailand can be accessed at:\n<http://www.ourweb.info/01/maps/thailand/index2.shtml>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Beijing) 20070713.2253\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) 20070530.1741\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) 20070514.1540\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (02) 20070516.1560\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (03) 20070520.1604\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong)(04) 20070524.1667\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India (Calcutta) 20070923.3160\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Selangor) 20070924.3171\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Maldives 20070529.1719\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20070424.1338\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Sri Lanka (Colombo) 20070311.0869\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (HCM city) 20070926.3193\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20060907.2535\n2002\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20020621.4559\n....................cp/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For example, molecular epidemiological analyses of\nrecent Human enterovirus 71 isolates in the Western Pacific Region\nhas indicated that 2 major genogroups of Human enterovirus 71 have\nbeen circulating in Australia, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan and Japan.\nRecent Human enterovirus 71 isolates in Mainland China constitute a\nnew distinct genetic cluster, subgenogroup C4.\n\nInformation on the identity of the virus currently circulating in\nThailand would be welcomed.\n\nA map of the provinces of Thailand can be accessed at:\n<http://www.ourweb.info/01/maps/thailand/index2.shtml>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Beijing) 20070713.2253\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) 20070530.1741\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) 20070514.1540\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (02) 20070516.1560\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (03) 20070520.1604\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong)(04) 20070524.1667\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India (Calcutta) 20070923.3160\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Selangor) 20070924.3171\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Maldives 20070529.1719\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20070424.1338\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Sri Lanka (Colombo) 20070311.0869\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (HCM city) 20070926.3193\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20060907.2535\n2002\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20020621.4559\n....................cp/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The Public Health Office in\nnorthern Lampang Province Friday [23 Nov 2007] ordered the Prachawit\nSchool to close its kindergarten classes after about 10 kids were\nfound to have contracted the disease, local news network \"The Nation\" reported.\n\nOn Thursday [22 Nov 2007], the office ordered Assumption School in\nLampang to close its kindergarten classes following the outbreak of\nthe disease. Also in Lambang, local authorities on Friday [23 Nov\n2007] ordered a nursery to close after 16 children there contracted HFMD.\n\nMeanwhile, in central Chon Buri Province, several schools in Sattahib\ndistrict were ordered to be on alert following an outbreak of HFMD at\na school. About 10 students of Ban Sattahib School got the disease\nand received treatment at 2 hospitals in the district, prompting the\ndistrict health office to inform other schools to be on alert.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness of\ninfants and children, most frequently affecting children under 10\nyears of age and infants. It is a human disease unrelated to the\nfoot-and-mouth disease affecting ruminants and other animals. HFMD is\ncharacterised by fever and vesicles in the mouth and on distal\nextremities. Complications are uncommon in most outbreaks, but rare\nneurological damage has been associated with some outbreaks. HFMD is\nmoderately contagious. Infection is spread from person to person by\ndirect contact with nose and throat discharges, saliva, fluid from\nblisters, or the stool of infected persons. A child is most\ncontagious during the first week of the illness. Individual cases and\noutbreaks of HFMD occur worldwide, more frequently in summer and early autumn.\n\nA variety of enteric picornaviruses has been associated with HFMD,\nthe most frequently observed being Human coxsackievirus A16 and Human\nenterovirus 71. The etiologic agent in the current outbreak of HFMD\nin Thailand has not been determined as yet; previously a virus\nidentified as Echovirus type 11 was the cause of a HFMD outbreak in a\nhospital nursery in Thailand (Clin Infect Dis. 2005 Nov 1;41(9):\n1361-2). As well as the diversity of etiologic agents associated with\nHFMD, there is considerable genetic heterogeneity in the case of\nspecific viruses. For example, molecular epidemiological analyses of\nrecent Human enterovirus 71 isolates in the Western Pacific Region\nhas indicated that 2 major genogroups of Human enterovirus 71 have\nbeen circulating in Australia, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan and Japan.\nRecent Human enterovirus 71 isolates in Mainland China constitute a\nnew distinct genetic cluster, subgenogroup C4.\n\nInformation on the identity of the virus currently circulating in\nThailand would be welcomed.\n\nA map of the provinces of Thailand can be accessed at:\n<http://www.ourweb.info/01/maps/thailand/index2.shtml>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Beijing) 20070713.2253\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) 20070530.1741\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) 20070514.1540\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (02) 20070516.1560\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (03) 20070520.1604\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong)(04) 20070524.1667\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India (Calcutta) 20070923.3160\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Selangor) 20070924.3171\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Maldives 20070529.1719\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20070424.1338\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Sri Lanka (Colombo) 20070311.0869\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (HCM city) 20070926.3193\n2006\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20060907.2535\n2002\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20020621.4559\n....................cp/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease\n(HFMD) began in late April 2007 in the city of Linyi in Shandong province,\nthe Xinhua News Agency said.\nAbout 470 patients had recovered by Friday [18 May 2007], and another 393\npeople -- mostly children -- were still sick, with more than half still in\nthe hospital, the Xinhua News Agency said, citing Bao Wenhui, the deputy\ndirector of the provincial health department.\nThe latest information was probably a response to media reports earlier\nthis week that said more than 2 dozen children had died and that there had\nbeen a cover-up. The reports also said the true figures had not been\nreleased to prevent public panic. Local health officials dismissed those\nreports as rumors.\nChina has in the past been accused of foot-dragging in releasing\ninformation about outbreaks of diseases such as bird flu and severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome, or SARS. A 2 year old girl diagnosed as a probable\nHFMD patient died on 29 Apr 2007, but no other deaths have been reported\nsince, Xinhua stated. HFMD is common in young children and is characterized\nby fever, mouth sores and a rash with blisters. It is not related to foot\nand mouth disease, which infects cattle, sheep and swine. The US Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) describes HFMD as mild and says\nnearly all patients recover in 7 to 10 days without medical treatment. But\n[rarely] the disease may also lead to more serious and fatal diseases such\nas encephalitis or a type of paralysis, according to CDC.\nXinhua said local health departments have launched a public awareness\ncampaign and quarantined children who are sick. Shandong [province]\nreported 2477 cases of HFMD in 2005, including one death, and 3030 cases in\n2006, 2 of which were fatal, the report said.\n--\ncommunicated by\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n[This thread is hereby now cut. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (02) 20070516.1560\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) 20070514.1540\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20070424.1338\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Sri Lanka (Colombo) 20070311.0869\n2006\n---\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India (Kerala) 20061024.3044\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20060907.2535\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (08) 20060821.2355\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (07) 20060730.2103\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (06) 20060725.2050\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (06) 20060717.1961\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (05) 20060714.1946\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (HK), Malaysia (Sarawak) 20060711.1909\n..................cp/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease\n(HFMD) began in late April 2007 in the city of Linyi in Shandong province,\nthe Xinhua News Agency said.\nAbout 470 patients had recovered by Friday [18 May 2007], and another 393\npeople -- mostly children -- were still sick, with more than half still in\nthe hospital, the Xinhua News Agency said, citing Bao Wenhui, the deputy\ndirector of the provincial health department.\nThe latest information was probably a response to media reports earlier\nthis week that said more than 2 dozen children had died and that there had\nbeen a cover-up. The reports also said the true figures had not been\nreleased to prevent public panic. Local health officials dismissed those\nreports as rumors.\nChina has in the past been accused of foot-dragging in releasing\ninformation about outbreaks of diseases such as bird flu and severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome, or SARS. A 2 year old girl diagnosed as a probable\nHFMD patient died on 29 Apr 2007, but no other deaths have been reported\nsince, Xinhua stated. HFMD is common in young children and is characterized\nby fever, mouth sores and a rash with blisters. It is not related to foot\nand mouth disease, which infects cattle, sheep and swine. The US Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) describes HFMD as mild and says\nnearly all patients recover in 7 to 10 days without medical treatment. But\n[rarely] the disease may also lead to more serious and fatal diseases such\nas encephalitis or a type of paralysis, according to CDC.\nXinhua said local health departments have launched a public awareness\ncampaign and quarantined children who are sick. Shandong [province]\nreported 2477 cases of HFMD in 2005, including one death, and 3030 cases in\n2006, 2 of which were fatal, the report said.\n--\ncommunicated by\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n[This thread is hereby now cut. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (02) 20070516.1560\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) 20070514.1540\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20070424.1338\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Sri Lanka (Colombo) 20070311.0869\n2006\n---\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India (Kerala) 20061024.3044\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20060907.2535\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (08) 20060821.2355\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (07) 20060730.2103\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (06) 20060725.2050\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (06) 20060717.1961\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (05) 20060714.1946\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (HK), Malaysia (Sarawak) 20060711.1909\n..................cp/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
