For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "sars", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-05-18 00:00:00", "2477-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Shandong province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Linyi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shandong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kerala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SHANDONG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "28642", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - India (Calcutta)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=28642", "date": "2007-05-20 13:00:01", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (SHANDONG) (03)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sun 20 May 2007\nSource: Canada.com, Canadian Press [edited]\n<http://www.canada.com/topics/news/world/story.html?id=c7dac7a0-f19e-4247-bdb1-e8564109ef3a&k=88653>\n\nAn outbreak of a viral disease common in children has sickened almost 900\npeople in eastern China, but the outbreak has been contained, state media\nreported on Sat 19 May 2007. The outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease\n(HFMD) began in late April 2007 in the city of Linyi in Shandong province,\nthe Xinhua News Agency said.\nAbout 470 patients had recovered by Friday [18 May 2007], and another 393\npeople -- mostly children -- were still sick, with more than half still in\nthe hospital, the Xinhua News Agency said, citing Bao Wenhui, the deputy\ndirector of the provincial health department.\nThe latest information was probably a response to media reports earlier\nthis week that said more than 2 dozen children had died and that there had\nbeen a cover-up. The reports also said the true figures had not been\nreleased to prevent public panic. Local health officials dismissed those\nreports as rumors.\nChina has in the past been accused of foot-dragging in releasing\ninformation about outbreaks of diseases such as bird flu and severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome, or SARS. A 2 year old girl diagnosed as a probable\nHFMD patient died on 29 Apr 2007, but no other deaths have been reported\nsince, Xinhua stated. HFMD is common in young children and is characterized\nby fever, mouth sores and a rash with blisters. It is not related to foot\nand mouth disease, which infects cattle, sheep and swine. The US Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) describes HFMD as mild and says\nnearly all patients recover in 7 to 10 days without medical treatment. But\n[rarely] the disease may also lead to more serious and fatal diseases such\nas encephalitis or a type of paralysis, according to CDC.\nXinhua said local health departments have launched a public awareness\ncampaign and quarantined children who are sick. Shandong [province]\nreported 2477 cases of HFMD in 2005, including one death, and 3030 cases in\n2006, 2 of which were fatal, the report said.\n--\ncommunicated by\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n[This thread is hereby now cut. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (02) 20070516.1560\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) 20070514.1540\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20070424.1338\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Sri Lanka (Colombo) 20070311.0869\n2006\n---\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India (Kerala) 20061024.3044\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20060907.2535\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (08) 20060821.2355\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (07) 20060730.2103\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (06) 20060725.2050\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (06) 20060717.1961\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (05) 20060714.1946\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (HK), Malaysia (Sarawak) 20060711.1909\n..................cp/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease\n(HFMD) began in late April 2007 in the city of Linyi in Shandong province,\nthe Xinhua News Agency said.\nAbout 470 patients had recovered by Friday [18 May 2007], and another 393\npeople -- mostly children -- were still sick, with more than half still in\nthe hospital, the Xinhua News Agency said, citing Bao Wenhui, the deputy\ndirector of the provincial health department.\nThe latest information was probably a response to media reports earlier\nthis week that said more than 2 dozen children had died and that there had\nbeen a cover-up. The reports also said the true figures had not been\nreleased to prevent public panic. Local health officials dismissed those\nreports as rumors.\nChina has in the past been accused of foot-dragging in releasing\ninformation about outbreaks of diseases such as bird flu and severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome, or SARS. A 2 year old girl diagnosed as a probable\nHFMD patient died on 29 Apr 2007, but no other deaths have been reported\nsince, Xinhua stated. HFMD is common in young children and is characterized\nby fever, mouth sores and a rash with blisters. It is not related to foot\nand mouth disease, which infects cattle, sheep and swine. The US Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) describes HFMD as mild and says\nnearly all patients recover in 7 to 10 days without medical treatment. But\n[rarely] the disease may also lead to more serious and fatal diseases such\nas encephalitis or a type of paralysis, according to CDC.\nXinhua said local health departments have launched a public awareness\ncampaign and quarantined children who are sick. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "sars", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-05-18 00:00:00", "2477-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Shandong province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Linyi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shandong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kerala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SHANDONG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10467", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10467", "date": "2007-05-20 13:00:01", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (SHANDONG) (03)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sun 20 May 2007\nSource: Canada.com, Canadian Press [edited]\n<http://www.canada.com/topics/news/world/story.html?id=c7dac7a0-f19e-4247-bdb1-e8564109ef3a&k=88653>\n\nAn outbreak of a viral disease common in children has sickened almost 900\npeople in eastern China, but the outbreak has been contained, state media\nreported on Sat 19 May 2007. The outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease\n(HFMD) began in late April 2007 in the city of Linyi in Shandong province,\nthe Xinhua News Agency said.\nAbout 470 patients had recovered by Friday [18 May 2007], and another 393\npeople -- mostly children -- were still sick, with more than half still in\nthe hospital, the Xinhua News Agency said, citing Bao Wenhui, the deputy\ndirector of the provincial health department.\nThe latest information was probably a response to media reports earlier\nthis week that said more than 2 dozen children had died and that there had\nbeen a cover-up. The reports also said the true figures had not been\nreleased to prevent public panic. Local health officials dismissed those\nreports as rumors.\nChina has in the past been accused of foot-dragging in releasing\ninformation about outbreaks of diseases such as bird flu and severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome, or SARS. A 2 year old girl diagnosed as a probable\nHFMD patient died on 29 Apr 2007, but no other deaths have been reported\nsince, Xinhua stated. HFMD is common in young children and is characterized\nby fever, mouth sores and a rash with blisters. It is not related to foot\nand mouth disease, which infects cattle, sheep and swine. The US Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) describes HFMD as mild and says\nnearly all patients recover in 7 to 10 days without medical treatment. But\n[rarely] the disease may also lead to more serious and fatal diseases such\nas encephalitis or a type of paralysis, according to CDC.\nXinhua said local health departments have launched a public awareness\ncampaign and quarantined children who are sick. Shandong [province]\nreported 2477 cases of HFMD in 2005, including one death, and 3030 cases in\n2006, 2 of which were fatal, the report said.\n--\ncommunicated by\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n[This thread is hereby now cut. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (02) 20070516.1560\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) 20070514.1540\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20070424.1338\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Sri Lanka (Colombo) 20070311.0869\n2006\n---\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India (Kerala) 20061024.3044\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20060907.2535\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (08) 20060821.2355\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (07) 20060730.2103\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (06) 20060725.2050\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (06) 20060717.1961\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak) (05) 20060714.1946\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (HK), Malaysia (Sarawak) 20060711.1909\n..................cp/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Among the new cases reported up to 10 a.m. local\ntime (0200 GMT) on Sunday, 10 children have been hospitalized, said\nState Deputy Chief Minister George Chan. Six of the children were\nadmitted to the Miri hospital, 2 to the hospital in Bintulu and the\nrest in Sibu and Limbang, said Chan, who is also Chairman of the\nState Disaster Relief Management Committee.\nThe latest figure brought the total number of children infected since\nthe disease broke out early this year [2006] to 13 800, Chan said at\na news conference in Kuching, capital of the state. Throughout the\nstate, Sibu registered the highest number with 3025 cases, followed\nby Miri (2872), Kuching (2125), Bintulu (1761) and Sarikei (946). So\nfar, the disease has claimed 13 lives, including 7 who have tested\npositive for Enterovirus 71 (EV71).\nHFMD can be spread from person to person by direct contact with the\nnasal discharge, saliva, feces and fluid from the rash of an infected\nperson and indirectly by contaminated articles. Children are more\nvulnerable to the disease, while adults can carry the virus without\nshowing any symptoms of infection, said local health authorities.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to Podin et al. (BMC Public Health. 2006 Jul 7;6:18),\nsince 1997, Sarawak has experienced 3 major outbreaks of human\nenterovirus 71 infection, in 1997, 2000 and 2003. The predominant\nstrains circulating in these outbreaks were from genogroup B,\nalthough the strains isolated during each outbreak were genetically\ndistinct from each other. Human enterovirus 71 outbreaks have\noccurred in a cyclical pattern every 3 years, with Coxsackievirus A16\nco-circulated with human enterovirus 71. It is to be hoped that when\nthe current outbreak subsides, a period of 2 years remission can be\nexpected. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (HK), Malaysia (Sarawak) 20060711.1909\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Among the new cases reported up to 10 a.m. local\ntime (0200 GMT) on Sunday, 10 children have been hospitalized, said\nState Deputy Chief Minister George Chan. Six of the children were\nadmitted to the Miri hospital, 2 to the hospital in Bintulu and the\nrest in Sibu and Limbang, said Chan, who is also Chairman of the\nState Disaster Relief Management Committee.\nThe latest figure brought the total number of children infected since\nthe disease broke out early this year [2006] to 13 800, Chan said at\na news conference in Kuching, capital of the state. Throughout the\nstate, Sibu registered the highest number with 3025 cases, followed\nby Miri (2872), Kuching (2125), Bintulu (1761) and Sarikei (946). So\nfar, the disease has claimed 13 lives, including 7 who have tested\npositive for Enterovirus 71 (EV71).\nHFMD can be spread from person to person by direct contact with the\nnasal discharge, saliva, feces and fluid from the rash of an infected\nperson and indirectly by contaminated articles. Children are more\nvulnerable to the disease, while adults can carry the virus without\nshowing any symptoms of infection, said local health authorities.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to Podin et al. (BMC Public Health. 2006 Jul 7;6:18),\nsince 1997, Sarawak has experienced 3 major outbreaks of human\nenterovirus 71 infection, in 1997, 2000 and 2003. The predominant\nstrains circulating in these outbreaks were from genogroup B,\nalthough the strains isolated during each outbreak were genetically\ndistinct from each other. Human enterovirus 71 outbreaks have\noccurred in a cyclical pattern every 3 years, with Coxsackievirus A16\nco-circulated with human enterovirus 71. It is to be hoped that when\nthe current outbreak subsides, a period of 2 years remission can be\nexpected. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (HK), Malaysia (Sarawak) 20060711.1909\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Among the new cases reported up to 10 a.m. local\ntime (0200 GMT) on Sunday, 10 children have been hospitalized, said\nState Deputy Chief Minister George Chan. Six of the children were\nadmitted to the Miri hospital, 2 to the hospital in Bintulu and the\nrest in Sibu and Limbang, said Chan, who is also Chairman of the\nState Disaster Relief Management Committee.\nThe latest figure brought the total number of children infected since\nthe disease broke out early this year [2006] to 13 800, Chan said at\na news conference in Kuching, capital of the state. Throughout the\nstate, Sibu registered the highest number with 3025 cases, followed\nby Miri (2872), Kuching (2125), Bintulu (1761) and Sarikei (946). So\nfar, the disease has claimed 13 lives, including 7 who have tested\npositive for Enterovirus 71 (EV71).\nHFMD can be spread from person to person by direct contact with the\nnasal discharge, saliva, feces and fluid from the rash of an infected\nperson and indirectly by contaminated articles. Children are more\nvulnerable to the disease, while adults can carry the virus without\nshowing any symptoms of infection, said local health authorities.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to Podin et al. (BMC Public Health. 2006 Jul 7;6:18),\nsince 1997, Sarawak has experienced 3 major outbreaks of human\nenterovirus 71 infection, in 1997, 2000 and 2003. The predominant\nstrains circulating in these outbreaks were from genogroup B,\nalthough the strains isolated during each outbreak were genetically\ndistinct from each other. Human enterovirus 71 outbreaks have\noccurred in a cyclical pattern every 3 years, with Coxsackievirus A16\nco-circulated with human enterovirus 71. It is to be hoped that when\nthe current outbreak subsides, a period of 2 years remission can be\nexpected. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (HK), Malaysia (Sarawak) 20060711.1909\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Sarawak)(07)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2080", "date": "2006-04-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - SOUTHEAST ASIA (02)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed, 5 Apr 2006 14:53:46 -0400 (EDT)\nFrom: Alfonso Rodriguez, M.D.<ajrm_msds@yahoo.es>\nSource: Borneo Bulletin, Brunei Darussalam, 5 Apr 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.brunei-online.com/bb/wed/apr5b3.htm>\n\nA 16-month-old toddler died from hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) in\nSarawak on Tuesday, bringing the death toll from the illness in 2006 to 9,\nofficials said.\nThe boy was admitted to a hospital in Miri on Saturday in critical\ncondition and could not be saved because his parents had sought treatment\ntoo late, Sarawak Deputy Chief Minister George Chan was quoted as saying by\nnational news agency Bernama.\nChan said 7857 infections have been reported in the state this year, but\nthe number of new cases has declined and only 39 patients remain hospitalised.\nAuthorities in Sarawak in early March 2006 shut all 1600 kindergartens,\nday-care centers and preschools to stop the disease from spreading among\nchildren -- the main victims of the illness. The premises reopened Monday\nafter the number of infections fell.\nChan said health officials would beef up enforcement and inspection of all\neducation premises, and those found to have 2 or more cases would be\nimmediately closed until cleared of the disease. State health officials\ncould not be reached for comments.\nHand, foot and mouth disease is mildly contagious and rarely fatal. It\nmainly strikes children below age 10 and is unrelated to the illness in\ncattle known as foot and mouth disease.\nOfficials said the disease seems to emerge cyclically every 3 years in\nSarawak. It spread this year to neighbouring Brunei, where a boy died\nrecently of the disease. Some children in Kedah were also affected but no\ndeaths were reported.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[An interactive map of Malaysia can be accessed at:\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&code=&code=MY&code=SG&pcode=>,\nor\n<http://www.lonelyplanet.com/mapshells/south_east_asia/malaysia/malaysia.htm>.\n- Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - It\nmainly strikes children below age 10 and is unrelated to the illness in\ncattle known as foot and mouth disease.\nOfficials said the disease seems to emerge cyclically every 3 years in\nSarawak. Malaysia (Sarawak) (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1958", "date": "2006-04-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - SOUTHEAST ASIA (02)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed, 5 Apr 2006 14:53:46 -0400 (EDT)\nFrom: Alfonso Rodriguez, M.D.<ajrm_msds@yahoo.es>\nSource: Borneo Bulletin, Brunei Darussalam, 5 Apr 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.brunei-online.com/bb/wed/apr5b3.htm>\n\nA 16-month-old toddler died from hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) in\nSarawak on Tuesday, bringing the death toll from the illness in 2006 to 9,\nofficials said.\nThe boy was admitted to a hospital in Miri on Saturday in critical\ncondition and could not be saved because his parents had sought treatment\ntoo late, Sarawak Deputy Chief Minister George Chan was quoted as saying by\nnational news agency Bernama.\nChan said 7857 infections have been reported in the state this year, but\nthe number of new cases has declined and only 39 patients remain hospitalised.\nAuthorities in Sarawak in early March 2006 shut all 1600 kindergartens,\nday-care centers and preschools to stop the disease from spreading among\nchildren -- the main victims of the illness. The premises reopened Monday\nafter the number of infections fell.\nChan said health officials would beef up enforcement and inspection of all\neducation premises, and those found to have 2 or more cases would be\nimmediately closed until cleared of the disease. State health officials\ncould not be reached for comments.\nHand, foot and mouth disease is mildly contagious and rarely fatal. It\nmainly strikes children below age 10 and is unrelated to the illness in\ncattle known as foot and mouth disease.\nOfficials said the disease seems to emerge cyclically every 3 years in\nSarawak. It spread this year to neighbouring Brunei, where a boy died\nrecently of the disease. Some children in Kedah were also affected but no\ndeaths were reported.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[An interactive map of Malaysia can be accessed at:\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&code=&code=MY&code=SG&pcode=>,\nor\n<http://www.lonelyplanet.com/mapshells/south_east_asia/malaysia/malaysia.htm>.\n- Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (HK), Malaysia (Sarawak)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1937", "date": "2006-04-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - SOUTHEAST ASIA (02)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed, 5 Apr 2006 14:53:46 -0400 (EDT)\nFrom: Alfonso Rodriguez, M.D.<ajrm_msds@yahoo.es>\nSource: Borneo Bulletin, Brunei Darussalam, 5 Apr 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.brunei-online.com/bb/wed/apr5b3.htm>\n\nA 16-month-old toddler died from hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) in\nSarawak on Tuesday, bringing the death toll from the illness in 2006 to 9,\nofficials said.\nThe boy was admitted to a hospital in Miri on Saturday in critical\ncondition and could not be saved because his parents had sought treatment\ntoo late, Sarawak Deputy Chief Minister George Chan was quoted as saying by\nnational news agency Bernama.\nChan said 7857 infections have been reported in the state this year, but\nthe number of new cases has declined and only 39 patients remain hospitalised.\nAuthorities in Sarawak in early March 2006 shut all 1600 kindergartens,\nday-care centers and preschools to stop the disease from spreading among\nchildren -- the main victims of the illness. The premises reopened Monday\nafter the number of infections fell.\nChan said health officials would beef up enforcement and inspection of all\neducation premises, and those found to have 2 or more cases would be\nimmediately closed until cleared of the disease. State health officials\ncould not be reached for comments.\nHand, foot and mouth disease is mildly contagious and rarely fatal. It\nmainly strikes children below age 10 and is unrelated to the illness in\ncattle known as foot and mouth disease.\nOfficials said the disease seems to emerge cyclically every 3 years in\nSarawak. It spread this year to neighbouring Brunei, where a boy died\nrecently of the disease. Some children in Kedah were also affected but no\ndeaths were reported.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[An interactive map of Malaysia can be accessed at:\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&code=&code=MY&code=SG&pcode=>,\nor\n<http://www.lonelyplanet.com/mapshells/south_east_asia/malaysia/malaysia.htm>.\n- Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kedah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brunei", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Penang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Miri", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209476", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - South East Asia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209476", "date": "2005-06-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - TAIWAN (CENTRAL) (03)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 4 Jun 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Central News Agency, 4 Jun 2005 [edited]\n<http://english.www.gov.tw/index.jsp?action=cna&cnaid=10373>\n\nEnterovirus Infections Under Control: DOH\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe current enterovirus outbreak, which has infected 50 children and\nclaimed 5 lives, has been brought under control, Department of Health\nMinister Hou Sheng-mao said Saturday [4 Jun 2005] during an inspection tour\nin the central city of Taichung. \"Although the enterovirus infections are\nat a peak, the general situation has been well-controlled,\" Hou said after\ninspecting Taichung Veterans General Hospital to get a better understanding\nof the outbreak in the central Taiwan area. An encouraging development was\nthat none of the enterovirus strains have mutated significantly, Hou said.\nAs the outbreak is expected to peak in 2 week's time, Hou urged medical\npersonnel and parents with young children to keep alert to prevent any\nfurther spread of the disease. Noting that enteroviruses are transmitted\nvia direct contact with secretions from an infected person or contact with\ncontaminated surfaces or objects, Hou said practicing good personal hygiene\nis critical to preventing infections.\n[Byline: Sofia Wu]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Hou Sheng-mao was quoted as saying that none of the enterovirus strains\n(isolated from the patients) have mutated significantly. Generally\nspeaking, genetic mutation of a viral genome takes place all the time. And\nit happens more readily in RNA viruses (such as EV71 in the family of\npciornaviridae) than in DNA viruses. However, in the context of the current\noutbreak, what Hou meant regarding absence of significant mutation was not\nelaborated, either by himself or by the media. What epidemiologists,\nclinicians and public health authorities are most concerned about are\npathogenicity and/or severity of the disease prior to medication and drug\nresistance of the causative agents responsible for the outbreak when\nsubjected for treatment. Since no unusual trend of the seasonal HFMD\nepidemic was noted, it could be implicated in the aspect of anti-EV71 drug\nresistance. Pyridyl imidazolidinone is a novel class of potent and\nselective human enterovirus 71 inhibitors which target enterovirus 71\ncapsid protein VP1. Site-directed mutagenesis of enterovirus 71 infectious\ncDNA revealed that a single amino acid alteration at the position 192 of\nVP1 can confer resistance to the inhibitory effects of the antiviral drug\n[see reference: Shin-Ru Shih et al. Mutation in Enterovirus 71 Capsid\nProtein VP1 Confers Resistance to the Inhibitory Effects of Pyridyl\nImidazolidinone. Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, September 2004,\nVol. 48 (9):3523-3529]. Further information from the Department of Health,\nTaiwan and colleagues familiar with HFMD and enteroviral infections are\nwelcome. - Mod.RY]\n[The above newswire mentions there are 50 cases and 5 deaths currently\nassociated with this outbreak. In the earlier ProMED-mail report from 23\nMay 2005 (see references below) , there was mention of 29 cases and 3\ndeaths. Prediction that the outbreak will peak in 2 weeks time is a curious\nprediction, and one suspects may be based on prior experiences with - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Taiwan (Central) (02) 20050531.1503\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Taiwan (Central) 20050523.1417\n2004\n----\nEnterovirus infection, acute - Taiwan (Central) 20040511.1273\n2002\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan (02) 20020514.4196\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan 20020405.3883\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan 20020405.3883\n2001\n----\nEnterovirus 71 - Asia-Pacific Region 20010718.1394\n2000\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease, epidemiology 20000729.1256\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan: 1998-1999 20000203.0163\n1999\n----\nEnterovirus 71, clinical correlates 19990927.1726\nEnterovirus 71 - Taiwan 1998: clinical signs 19990821.1463\nEnterovirus 71 genotypes - Malaysia, Japan, Taiwan... 19990821.1452\n1998\n----\nEnterovirus 71, new outbreak - Taiwan 19981001.1956\nEnterovirus 71, new outbreak - Taiwan (02) 19981005.1973\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - Taiwan 19980601.1047\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - Taiwan (25) 19980906.1786\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - Taiwan: CORRECTION 19980709.1292\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children: clinical signs 19980619.1157\nEnterovirus 71 references 19980807.1544\n...........................ry/mpp/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. An encouraging development was\nthat none of the enterovirus strains have mutated significantly, Hou said.\nAs the outbreak is expected to peak in 2 week's time, Hou urged medical\npersonnel and parents with young children to keep alert to prevent any\nfurther spread of the disease. Noting that enteroviruses are transmitted\nvia direct contact with secretions from an infected person or contact with\ncontaminated surfaces or objects, Hou said practicing good personal hygiene\nis critical to preventing infections.\n[Byline: Sofia Wu]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Hou Sheng-mao was quoted as saying that none of the enterovirus strains\n(isolated from the patients) have mutated significantly. Generally\nspeaking, genetic mutation of a viral genome takes place all the time. And\nit happens more readily in RNA viruses (such as EV71 in the family of\npciornaviridae) than in DNA viruses. However, in the context of the current\noutbreak, what Hou meant regarding absence of significant mutation was not\nelaborated, either by himself or by the media. What epidemiologists,\nclinicians and public health authorities are most concerned about are\npathogenicity and/or severity of the disease prior to medication and drug\nresistance of the causative agents responsible for the outbreak when\nsubjected for treatment. Since no unusual trend of the seasonal HFMD\nepidemic was noted, it could be implicated in the aspect of anti-EV71 drug\nresistance. Pyridyl imidazolidinone is a novel class of potent and\nselective human enterovirus 71 inhibitors which target enterovirus 71\ncapsid protein VP1. Site-directed mutagenesis of enterovirus 71 infectious\ncDNA revealed that a single amino acid alteration at the position 192 of\nVP1 can confer resistance to the inhibitory effects of the antiviral drug\n[see reference: Shin-Ru Shih et al. Mutation in Enterovirus 71 Capsid\nProtein VP1 Confers Resistance to the Inhibitory Effects of Pyridyl\nImidazolidinone. Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, September 2004,\nVol. 48 (9):3523-3529]. Further information from the Department of Health,\nTaiwan and colleagues familiar with HFMD and enteroviral infections are\nwelcome. - Mod.RY]\n[The above newswire mentions there are 50 cases and 5 deaths currently\nassociated with this outbreak. In the earlier ProMED-mail report from 23\nMay 2005 (see references below) , there was mention of 29 cases and 3\ndeaths. Prediction that the outbreak will peak in 2 weeks time is a curious\nprediction, and one suspects may be based on prior experiences with - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Taiwan (Central) (02) 20050531.1503\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Taiwan (Central) 20050523.1417\n2004\n----\nEnterovirus infection, acute - Taiwan (Central) 20040511.1273\n2002\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan (02) 20020514.4196\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan 20020405.3883\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan 20020405.3883\n2001\n----\nEnterovirus 71 - Asia-Pacific Region 20010718.1394\n2000\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease, epidemiology 20000729.1256\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan: 1998-1999 20000203.0163\n1999\n----\nEnterovirus 71, clinical correlates 19990927.1726\nEnterovirus 71 - Taiwan 1998: clinical signs 19990821.1463\nEnterovirus 71 genotypes - Malaysia, Japan, Taiwan... 19990821.1452\n1998\n----\nEnterovirus 71, new outbreak - Taiwan 19981001.1956\nEnterovirus 71, new outbreak - Taiwan (02) 19981005.1973\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - Taiwan 19980601.1047\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - Taiwan (25) 19980906.1786\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - Taiwan: CORRECTION 19980709.1292\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children: clinical signs 19980619.1157\nEnterovirus 71 references 19980807.1544\n...........................ry/mpp/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. An encouraging development was\nthat none of the enterovirus strains have mutated significantly, Hou said.\nAs the outbreak is expected to peak in 2 week's time, Hou urged medical\npersonnel and parents with young children to keep alert to prevent any\nfurther spread of the disease. Noting that enteroviruses are transmitted\nvia direct contact with secretions from an infected person or contact with\ncontaminated surfaces or objects, Hou said practicing good personal hygiene\nis critical to preventing infections.\n[Byline: Sofia Wu]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Hou Sheng-mao was quoted as saying that none of the enterovirus strains\n(isolated from the patients) have mutated significantly. Generally\nspeaking, genetic mutation of a viral genome takes place all the time. And\nit happens more readily in RNA viruses (such as EV71 in the family of\npciornaviridae) than in DNA viruses. However, in the context of the current\noutbreak, what Hou meant regarding absence of significant mutation was not\nelaborated, either by himself or by the media. What epidemiologists,\nclinicians and public health authorities are most concerned about are\npathogenicity and/or severity of the disease prior to medication and drug\nresistance of the causative agents responsible for the outbreak when\nsubjected for treatment. Since no unusual trend of the seasonal HFMD\nepidemic was noted, it could be implicated in the aspect of anti-EV71 drug\nresistance. Pyridyl imidazolidinone is a novel class of potent and\nselective human enterovirus 71 inhibitors which target enterovirus 71\ncapsid protein VP1. Site-directed mutagenesis of enterovirus 71 infectious\ncDNA revealed that a single amino acid alteration at the position 192 of\nVP1 can confer resistance to the inhibitory effects of the antiviral drug\n[see reference: Shin-Ru Shih et al. Mutation in Enterovirus 71 Capsid\nProtein VP1 Confers Resistance to the Inhibitory Effects of Pyridyl\nImidazolidinone. Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, September 2004,\nVol. 48 (9):3523-3529]. Further information from the Department of Health,\nTaiwan and colleagues familiar with HFMD and enteroviral infections are\nwelcome. - Mod.RY]\n[The above newswire mentions there are 50 cases and 5 deaths currently\nassociated with this outbreak. In the earlier ProMED-mail report from 23\nMay 2005 (see references below) , there was mention of 29 cases and 3\ndeaths. An encouraging development was\nthat none of the enterovirus strains have mutated significantly, Hou said.\nAs the outbreak is expected to peak in 2 week's time, Hou urged medical\npersonnel and parents with young children to keep alert to prevent any\nfurther spread of the disease. Noting that enteroviruses are transmitted\nvia direct contact with secretions from an infected person or contact with\ncontaminated surfaces or objects, Hou said practicing good personal hygiene\nis critical to preventing infections.\n[Byline: Sofia Wu]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Hou Sheng-mao was quoted as saying that none of the enterovirus strains\n(isolated from the patients) have mutated significantly. Generally\nspeaking, genetic mutation of a viral genome takes place all the time. And\nit happens more readily in RNA viruses (such as EV71 in the family of\npciornaviridae) than in DNA viruses. However, in the context of the current\noutbreak, what Hou meant regarding absence of significant mutation was not\nelaborated, either by himself or by the media. What epidemiologists,\nclinicians and public health authorities are most concerned about are\npathogenicity and/or severity of the disease prior to medication and drug\nresistance of the causative agents responsible for the outbreak when\nsubjected for treatment. Since no unusual trend of the seasonal HFMD\nepidemic was noted, it could be implicated in the aspect of anti-EV71 drug\nresistance. Pyridyl imidazolidinone is a novel class of potent and\nselective human enterovirus 71 inhibitors which target enterovirus 71\ncapsid protein VP1. Site-directed mutagenesis of enterovirus 71 infectious\ncDNA revealed that a single amino acid alteration at the position 192 of\nVP1 can confer resistance to the inhibitory effects of the antiviral drug\n[see reference: Shin-Ru Shih et al. Mutation in Enterovirus 71 Capsid\nProtein VP1 Confers Resistance to the Inhibitory Effects of Pyridyl\nImidazolidinone. Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, September 2004,\nVol. 48 (9):3523-3529]. Further information from the Department of Health,\nTaiwan and colleagues familiar with HFMD and enteroviral infections are\nwelcome. - Mod.RY]\n[The above newswire mentions there are 50 cases and 5 deaths currently\nassociated with this outbreak. In the earlier ProMED-mail report from 23\nMay 2005 (see references below) , there was mention of 29 cases and 3\ndeaths. Prediction that the outbreak will peak in 2 weeks time is a curious\nprediction, and one suspects may be based on prior experiences with - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Taiwan (Central) (02) 20050531.1503\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Taiwan (Central) 20050523.1417\n2004\n----\nEnterovirus infection, acute - Taiwan (Central) 20040511.1273\n2002\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan (02) 20020514.4196\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan 20020405.3883\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan 20020405.3883\n2001\n----\nEnterovirus 71 - Asia-Pacific Region 20010718.1394\n2000\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease, epidemiology 20000729.1256\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan: 1998-1999 20000203.0163\n1999\n----\nEnterovirus 71, clinical correlates 19990927.1726\nEnterovirus 71 - Taiwan 1998: clinical signs 19990821.1463\nEnterovirus 71 genotypes - Malaysia, Japan, Taiwan... 19990821.1452\n1998\n----\nEnterovirus 71, new outbreak - Taiwan 19981001.1956\nEnterovirus 71, new outbreak - Taiwan (02) 19981005.1973\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - Taiwan 19980601.1047\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - Taiwan (25) 19980906.1786\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - Taiwan: CORRECTION 19980709.1292\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children: clinical signs 19980619.1157\nEnterovirus 71 references 19980807.1544\n...........................ry/mpp/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. An encouraging development was\nthat none of the enterovirus strains have mutated significantly, Hou said.\nAs the outbreak is expected to peak in 2 week's time, Hou urged medical\npersonnel and parents with young children to keep alert to prevent any\nfurther spread of the disease. Noting that enteroviruses are transmitted\nvia direct contact with secretions from an infected person or contact with\ncontaminated surfaces or objects, Hou said practicing good personal hygiene\nis critical to preventing infections.\n[Byline: Sofia Wu]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Hou Sheng-mao was quoted as saying that none of the enterovirus strains\n(isolated from the patients) have mutated significantly. Generally\nspeaking, genetic mutation of a viral genome takes place all the time. And\nit happens more readily in RNA viruses (such as EV71 in the family of\npciornaviridae) than in DNA viruses. However, in the context of the current\noutbreak, what Hou meant regarding absence of significant mutation was not\nelaborated, either by himself or by the media. What epidemiologists,\nclinicians and public health authorities are most concerned about are\npathogenicity and/or severity of the disease prior to medication and drug\nresistance of the causative agents responsible for the outbreak when\nsubjected for treatment. Since no unusual trend of the seasonal HFMD\nepidemic was noted, it could be implicated in the aspect of anti-EV71 drug\nresistance. Pyridyl imidazolidinone is a novel class of potent and\nselective human enterovirus 71 inhibitors which target enterovirus 71\ncapsid protein VP1. Site-directed mutagenesis of enterovirus 71 infectious\ncDNA revealed that a single amino acid alteration at the position 192 of\nVP1 can confer resistance to the inhibitory effects of the antiviral drug\n[see reference: Shin-Ru Shih et al. Mutation in Enterovirus 71 Capsid\nProtein VP1 Confers Resistance to the Inhibitory Effects of Pyridyl\nImidazolidinone. Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, September 2004,\nVol. 48 (9):3523-3529]. Further information from the Department of Health,\nTaiwan and colleagues familiar with HFMD and enteroviral infections are\nwelcome. - Mod.RY]\n[The above newswire mentions there are 50 cases and 5 deaths currently\nassociated with this outbreak. In the earlier ProMED-mail report from 23\nMay 2005 (see references below) , there was mention of 29 cases and 3\ndeaths. Prediction that the outbreak will peak in 2 weeks time is a curious\nprediction, and one suspects may be based on prior experiences with - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Taiwan (Central) (02) 20050531.1503\nHand, foot and mouth disease - Taiwan (Central) 20050523.1417\n2004\n----\nEnterovirus infection, acute - Taiwan (Central) 20040511.1273\n2002\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan (02) 20020514.4196\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan 20020405.3883\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan 20020405.3883\n2001\n----\nEnterovirus 71 - Asia-Pacific Region 20010718.1394\n2000\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease, epidemiology 20000729.1256\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan: 1998-1999 20000203.0163\n1999\n----\nEnterovirus 71, clinical correlates 19990927.1726\nEnterovirus 71 - Taiwan 1998: clinical signs 19990821.1463\nEnterovirus 71 genotypes - Malaysia, Japan, Taiwan... 19990821.1452\n1998\n----\nEnterovirus 71, new outbreak - Taiwan 19981001.1956\nEnterovirus 71, new outbreak - Taiwan (02) 19981005.1973\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - Taiwan 19980601.1047\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - Taiwan (25) 19980906.1786\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - Taiwan: CORRECTION 19980709.1292\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children: clinical signs 19980619.1157\nEnterovirus 71 references 19980807.1544\n...........................ry/mpp/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. An encouraging development was\nthat none of the enterovirus strains have mutated significantly, Hou said.\nAs the outbreak is expected to peak in 2 week's time, Hou urged medical\npersonnel and parents with young children to keep alert to prevent any\nfurther spread of the disease. Noting that enteroviruses are transmitted\nvia direct contact with secretions from an infected person or contact with\ncontaminated surfaces or objects, Hou said practicing good personal hygiene\nis critical to preventing infections.\n[Byline: Sofia Wu]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Hou Sheng-mao was quoted as saying that none of the enterovirus strains\n(isolated from the patients) have mutated significantly. Generally\nspeaking, genetic mutation of a viral genome takes place all the time. And\nit happens more readily in RNA viruses (such as EV71 in the family of\npciornaviridae) than in DNA viruses. However, in the context of the current\noutbreak, what Hou meant regarding absence of significant mutation was not\nelaborated, either by himself or by the media. What epidemiologists,\nclinicians and public health authorities are most concerned about are\npathogenicity and/or severity of the disease prior to medication and drug\nresistance of the causative agents responsible for the outbreak when\nsubjected for treatment. Since no unusual trend of the seasonal HFMD\nepidemic was noted, it could be implicated in the aspect of anti-EV71 drug\nresistance. Pyridyl imidazolidinone is a novel class of potent and\nselective human enterovirus 71 inhibitors which target enterovirus 71\ncapsid protein VP1. Site-directed mutagenesis of enterovirus 71 infectious\ncDNA revealed that a single amino acid alteration at the position 192 of\nVP1 can confer resistance to the inhibitory effects of the antiviral drug\n[see reference: Shin-Ru Shih et al. Mutation in Enterovirus 71 Capsid\nProtein VP1 Confers Resistance to the Inhibitory Effects of Pyridyl\nImidazolidinone. Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, September 2004,\nVol. 48 (9):3523-3529]. Further information from the Department of Health,\nTaiwan and colleagues familiar with HFMD and enteroviral infections are\nwelcome. - Mod.RY]\n[The above newswire mentions there are 50 cases and 5 deaths currently\nassociated with this outbreak. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-06-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2005-06-04 00:00:00", "2004-09-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taichung", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207966", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot and mouth disease - Taiwan (central) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207966", "date": "2004-05-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - USA (OHIO)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 26 May 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: ChannelCincinnati.com, Wed 26 May 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.channelcincinnati.com/health/3341313/detail.html>\n\nUSA: Hand, Foot and Mouth Disease Outbreak in Cincinnati\n---------------------------------------------------\nHand, foot and mouth disease has doctors telling parents to keep their\nchildren at home, WLWT Eyewitness News 5's Lisa Cooney reported on Mon 23\nMay 2004. The outbreak is the most common cause of mouth sores that are\noften so painful that children won't want to eat. Consequently, they can\nbecome dehydrated. Parents should look for bumps, some even blister-like,\non the palms of the hands, or on top or between the fingers, Cooney\nreported. Such bumps or blisters also can pop up on the tops of the feet.\nAnd mouth sores can show up on the gums, tongue and throat.\nSummit Pediatrics spokeswoman Dr. Robin Warner said on Monday that they've\nseen many children and taken numerous calls lately. She added that hand,\nfoot and mouth disease is a seasonal illness that usually spreads in\nchildren 6 months to 4 years old. It's also highly contagious, and moves\nthrough day-care groups quickly, Cooney reported.\n\"The fever is usually low-grade, and will last a few days, anywhere from\n100 to 102 degrees,\" she said. A children's fever reducer and pain reliever\nwill help. And when the fever's gone, children can go back to day-care or\nschool. But the mouth sores may need more attention, Cooney reported.\n\"What we usually recommend is a little antacid like Maalox or Mylanta in\nthe mouth,\" Warner said. \"On the younger (patients), you can get an oral\nsponge and kind of swish it around on the blisters.\"\nThe disease is difficult to prevent because the virus is airborne. Parents\nshould encourage plenty of cool liquids.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease occurs globally. In developed countries hand,\nfoot and mouth disease is generally mild and often associated with\noutbreaks of Coxsackie A virus infection. In East Asian countries in recent\nyears, the disease has been associated with outbreaks of enterovirus 71\ninfection and can be more severe, with a small proportion of children\nexperiencing neurological complications, occasionally with fatal outcome.\nInformation on the etiology of the current outbreak in Ohio would be\nwelcomed. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n\nHand, foot & mouth disease, children - China (HK) 20040521.1370\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (HK SAR) 20040427.1177\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) 20040315.0722\n2003\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cincinnati", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207918", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot and mouth disease - Taiwan (Central)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207918", "date": "2004-05-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - USA (OHIO)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 26 May 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: ChannelCincinnati.com, Wed 26 May 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.channelcincinnati.com/health/3341313/detail.html>\n\nUSA: Hand, Foot and Mouth Disease Outbreak in Cincinnati\n---------------------------------------------------\nHand, foot and mouth disease has doctors telling parents to keep their\nchildren at home, WLWT Eyewitness News 5's Lisa Cooney reported on Mon 23\nMay 2004. The outbreak is the most common cause of mouth sores that are\noften so painful that children won't want to eat. Consequently, they can\nbecome dehydrated. Parents should look for bumps, some even blister-like,\non the palms of the hands, or on top or between the fingers, Cooney\nreported. Such bumps or blisters also can pop up on the tops of the feet.\nAnd mouth sores can show up on the gums, tongue and throat.\nSummit Pediatrics spokeswoman Dr. Robin Warner said on Monday that they've\nseen many children and taken numerous calls lately. She added that hand,\nfoot and mouth disease is a seasonal illness that usually spreads in\nchildren 6 months to 4 years old. It's also highly contagious, and moves\nthrough day-care groups quickly, Cooney reported.\n\"The fever is usually low-grade, and will last a few days, anywhere from\n100 to 102 degrees,\" she said. A children's fever reducer and pain reliever\nwill help. And when the fever's gone, children can go back to day-care or\nschool. But the mouth sores may need more attention, Cooney reported.\n\"What we usually recommend is a little antacid like Maalox or Mylanta in\nthe mouth,\" Warner said. \"On the younger (patients), you can get an oral\nsponge and kind of swish it around on the blisters.\"\nThe disease is difficult to prevent because the virus is airborne. Parents\nshould encourage plenty of cool liquids.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease occurs globally. In developed countries hand,\nfoot and mouth disease is generally mild and often associated with\noutbreaks of Coxsackie A virus infection. In East Asian countries in recent\nyears, the disease has been associated with outbreaks of enterovirus 71\ninfection and can be more severe, with a small proportion of children\nexperiencing neurological complications, occasionally with fatal outcome.\nInformation on the etiology of the current outbreak in Ohio would be\nwelcomed. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n\nHand, foot & mouth disease, children - China (HK) 20040521.1370\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (HK SAR) 20040427.1177\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) 20040315.0722\n2003\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - In East Asian countries in recent\nyears, the disease has been associated with outbreaks of enterovirus 71\ninfection and can be more severe, with a small proportion of children\nexperiencing neurological complications, occasionally with fatal outcome.\nInformation on the etiology of the current outbreak in Ohio would be\nwelcomed. - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cincinnati", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205835", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease, children - China (HK) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205835", "date": "2004-05-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - USA (OHIO)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 26 May 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: ChannelCincinnati.com, Wed 26 May 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.channelcincinnati.com/health/3341313/detail.html>\n\nUSA: Hand, Foot and Mouth Disease Outbreak in Cincinnati\n---------------------------------------------------\nHand, foot and mouth disease has doctors telling parents to keep their\nchildren at home, WLWT Eyewitness News 5's Lisa Cooney reported on Mon 23\nMay 2004. The outbreak is the most common cause of mouth sores that are\noften so painful that children won't want to eat. Consequently, they can\nbecome dehydrated. Parents should look for bumps, some even blister-like,\non the palms of the hands, or on top or between the fingers, Cooney\nreported. Such bumps or blisters also can pop up on the tops of the feet.\nAnd mouth sores can show up on the gums, tongue and throat.\nSummit Pediatrics spokeswoman Dr. Robin Warner said on Monday that they've\nseen many children and taken numerous calls lately. She added that hand,\nfoot and mouth disease is a seasonal illness that usually spreads in\nchildren 6 months to 4 years old. It's also highly contagious, and moves\nthrough day-care groups quickly, Cooney reported.\n\"The fever is usually low-grade, and will last a few days, anywhere from\n100 to 102 degrees,\" she said. A children's fever reducer and pain reliever\nwill help. And when the fever's gone, children can go back to day-care or\nschool. But the mouth sores may need more attention, Cooney reported.\n\"What we usually recommend is a little antacid like Maalox or Mylanta in\nthe mouth,\" Warner said. \"On the younger (patients), you can get an oral\nsponge and kind of swish it around on the blisters.\"\nThe disease is difficult to prevent because the virus is airborne. Parents\nshould encourage plenty of cool liquids.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease occurs globally. In developed countries hand,\nfoot and mouth disease is generally mild and often associated with\noutbreaks of Coxsackie A virus infection. In East Asian countries in recent\nyears, the disease has been associated with outbreaks of enterovirus 71\ninfection and can be more severe, with a small proportion of children\nexperiencing neurological complications, occasionally with fatal outcome.\nInformation on the etiology of the current outbreak in Ohio would be\nwelcomed. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n\nHand, foot & mouth disease, children - China (HK) 20040521.1370\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (HK SAR) 20040427.1177\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) 20040315.0722\n2003\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore (08)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2198811", "date": "2000-10-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - MALAYSIA & SINGAPORE (03)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia & Singapore 20000920.1626\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia & Singapore (02) 20000925.1658\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore (06) 20001005.1715\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Hong Kong 20000818.1374\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Japan 20000720.1200\nHand, foot & mouth disease, epidemiology 20000729.1256\nDate: 6 Sep 2000\nFrom: ProMED-mail\nSource: Agence France Presse English, Fri 6 Oct 2000 04:17 GMT [edited\n\nFirst Victim of Suspected Hand, Foot & Mouth Disease in Malaysia\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nA highly contagious virus which has killed 4 children in Singapore has\nclaimed its first victim in Malaysia with the death of a boy aged 3,\nreports said Friday. The Star and New Straits Times reported that the boy\ndied on Tue 3 Oct 2000 in the southern city of Johor Baru, just across the\nborder from Singapore. Senior state health official Nooraini Baba was\nquoted by the Star as saying the results of blood tests were still awaited.\nBut she said the boy had symptoms of hand, foot and mouth disease; i.e.,\nlesions on his hands, feet and around his mouth.\nIn Singapore, a total of 30 children have been hospitalized with the virus\nin the past week and doctors have reported a total of 408 children showing\nsymptoms of the disease since Sun 1 Oct 2000, when authorities ordered them\nto report all cases. The move followed the deaths on Saturday of a toddler\nand his 14- month-old sister. The 2 victims had rashes on their hands and\nmouth and foot ulcers. The 2 two-year-olds who died last month are also\nbelieved to have succumbed to the virus.\nChild-care centers and kindergartens remain closed across Singapore while a\ngovernment task force investigates the deaths. Hand, foot and mouth disease\nis a viral infection usually confined to children below 10 years of age and\nspread by direct contact with bodily fluids. The virus normally has only a\nmild impact on affected children but in certain cases can provoke a fatal\nreaction. An outbreak of the disease left 50 children dead in the Malaysian\nstate of Sarawak in 1997 and 78 died from the virus in Taiwan in 1998.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n......................jw/cp/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The Star and New Straits Times reported that the boy\ndied on Tue 3 Oct 2000 in the southern city of Johor Baru, just across the\nborder from Singapore. Senior state health official Nooraini Baba was\nquoted by the Star as saying the results of blood tests were still awaited.\nBut she said the boy had symptoms of hand, foot and mouth disease; i.e.,\nlesions on his hands, feet and around his mouth.\nIn Singapore, a total of 30 children have been hospitalized with the virus\nin the past week and doctors have reported a total of 408 children showing\nsymptoms of the disease since Sun 1 Oct 2000, when authorities ordered them\nto report all cases. The move followed the deaths on Saturday of a toddler\nand his 14- month-old sister. The 2 victims had rashes on their hands and\nmouth and foot ulcers. The 2 two-year-olds who died last month are also\nbelieved to have succumbed to the virus.\nChild-care centers and kindergartens remain closed across Singapore while a\ngovernment task force investigates the deaths. Hand, foot and mouth disease\nis a viral infection usually confined to children below 10 years of age and\nspread by direct contact with bodily fluids. The virus normally has only a\nmild impact on affected children but in certain cases can provoke a fatal\nreaction. An outbreak of the disease left 50 children dead in the Malaysian\nstate of Sarawak in 1997 and 78 died from the virus in Taiwan in 1998.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n......................jw/cp/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The Star and New Straits Times reported that the boy\ndied on Tue 3 Oct 2000 in the southern city of Johor Baru, just across the\nborder from Singapore. Senior state health official Nooraini Baba was\nquoted by the Star as saying the results of blood tests were still awaited.\nBut she said the boy had symptoms of hand, foot and mouth disease; i.e.,\nlesions on his hands, feet and around his mouth.\nIn Singapore, a total of 30 children have been hospitalized with the virus\nin the past week and doctors have reported a total of 408 children showing\nsymptoms of the disease since Sun 1 Oct 2000, when authorities ordered them\nto report all cases. The move followed the deaths on Saturday of a toddler\nand his 14- month-old sister. The 2 victims had rashes on their hands and\nmouth and foot ulcers. The 2 two-year-olds who died last month are also\nbelieved to have succumbed to the virus.\nChild-care centers and kindergartens remain closed across Singapore while a\ngovernment task force investigates the deaths. Hand, foot and mouth disease\nis a viral infection usually confined to children below 10 years of age and\nspread by direct contact with bodily fluids. The virus normally has only a\nmild impact on affected children but in certain cases can provoke a fatal\nreaction. An outbreak of the disease left 50 children dead in the Malaysian\nstate of Sarawak in 1997 and 78 died from the virus in Taiwan in 1998.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n......................jw/cp/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The Star and New Straits Times reported that the boy\ndied on Tue 3 Oct 2000 in the southern city of Johor Baru, just across the\nborder from Singapore. Senior state health official Nooraini Baba was\nquoted by the Star as saying the results of blood tests were still awaited.\nBut she said the boy had symptoms of hand, foot and mouth disease; i.e.,\nlesions on his hands, feet and around his mouth.\nIn Singapore, a total of 30 children have been hospitalized with the virus\nin the past week and doctors have reported a total of 408 children showing\nsymptoms of the disease since Sun 1 Oct 2000, when authorities ordered them\nto report all cases. The move followed the deaths on Saturday of a toddler\nand his 14- month-old sister. The 2 victims had rashes on their hands and\nmouth and foot ulcers. The 2 two-year-olds who died last month are also\nbelieved to have succumbed to the virus.\nChild-care centers and kindergartens remain closed across Singapore while a\ngovernment task force investigates the deaths. Hand, foot and mouth disease\nis a viral infection usually confined to children below 10 years of age and\nspread by direct contact with bodily fluids. The virus normally has only a\nmild impact on affected children but in certain cases can provoke a fatal\nreaction. An outbreak of the disease left 50 children dead in the Malaysian\nstate of Sarawak in 1997 and 78 died from the virus in Taiwan in 1998.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n......................jw/cp/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Malaysia & Singapore (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2198743", "date": "2000-10-06 23:50:00"}, {"archive_id": "2198739", "headline": "PRO> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2198739", "date": "2000-09-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - SINGAPORE\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth dis. - Canada (Alberta & Ontario) 20000722.1213\nHand, foot & mouth disease, epidemiology 20000729.1256\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Hong Kong 20000818.1374\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Japan 20000720.1200\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Japan: background 20000723.1221\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia 20000325.0433\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (02) 20000328.0458\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (03) 20000521.0806\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan: 1998-1999 20000203.0163\nHand, foot & mouth disease surveillance - Japan 20000729.1260\n1998\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease, fatal - Singapore 19980628.1200\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) 19980716.1341\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) (02) 19980729.1438\nDate: 13 Sep 2000 09:21:36 +0800\nFrom: CHIA Hwee-Pin <cofchp@nus.edu.sg>\nSource: Straits Times (Singapore) [edited\n<http://straitstimes.asia1.com.sg/primenews/pri6_0913.html>\n\nSuspected death due to Hand, Foot & Mouth Disease\n--------------------------------------------------\nSingapore: A 2-year-old toddler died on Sunday [10 Sep 2000 as a result of\na suspected outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease [HFMD which struck a\nchild-care centre in Sengkang. 4 other toddlers at the centre appear to\nhave been affected by the disease. The Ministry of Environment (MENV) has\nshut down the centre as a precautionary measure until further notice. The\ncondition of the 4 children is unknown because an investigation into the\noutbreak is on-going.\nThe MENV said in a statement last night that it was notified yesterday\nafternoon of the outbreak of the disease after investigations confirmed\nthat the death of the boy was linked to the disease. The boy had developed\na high fever and rashes on his body on Friday On Sunday afternoon, he\nstarted to vomit blood and he was taken to the Kandang Kerbau Women's and\nChildren's Hospital. Doctors pronounced the boy dead about 12 hours later.\nThe MENV is in the process of contacting parents of children who are\nenrolled at the centre to advise them to take their children to a doctor if\nthey suffer from symptoms of the disease. Symptoms include a fever lasting\nfor 2 to 3 days, a sore throat and runny nose, mouth ulcers and rashes.\nSufferers may also feel nauseous, weak and suffer from diarrhea. HFMD is\nnot serious usually, although it can cause rare complications which result\nin death, the MENV stated. It usually spreads through direct contact with\nbodily fluids of patients or items used by them. Those who want more\ninformation should call the Quarantine and Epidemiology Department on\n7319-758 or 7319-751.\n--\nDr. Hwee-Pin CHIA\nAssistant Professor\nDept of Community, Occupational and Family Medicine\nNational University of Singapore\n<cofchp@nus.edu.sg>\n[HFMD is predominantly a disease of childhood. It can be a consequence of\ninfection by Enterovirus 71 or one of several coxsackieviruses,\nCoxsackievirus A16 being the most common. Enterovirus 71 has been the most\nfrequent cause of HFMD in Southeast Asia and the Far East in recent years.\nTypical cases of HFMD exhibit vesicles and ulcers in the mouth, and a\nvesicular exanthema affecting the palms and soles of feet. The course of\nthe disease is usually mild and death is unusual. The vomiting of blood\ndescribed in this case suggests that other factors may have been involved.\nIt is not clear why HFMD is suspected in this case. Virus can be readily\nisolated from vesicular lesions and laboratory confirmation of infection is\nstraightforward. Further information is awaited. -Mod.CP\n.........................................cp/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2000-09-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sengkang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2198733", "headline": "PRO> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2198733", "date": "2000-09-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - SINGAPORE\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth dis. - Canada (Alberta & Ontario) 20000722.1213\nHand, foot & mouth disease, epidemiology 20000729.1256\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Hong Kong 20000818.1374\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Japan 20000720.1200\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Japan: background 20000723.1221\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia 20000325.0433\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (02) 20000328.0458\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (03) 20000521.0806\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan: 1998-1999 20000203.0163\nHand, foot & mouth disease surveillance - Japan 20000729.1260\n1998\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease, fatal - Singapore 19980628.1200\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) 19980716.1341\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) (02) 19980729.1438\nDate: 13 Sep 2000 09:21:36 +0800\nFrom: CHIA Hwee-Pin <cofchp@nus.edu.sg>\nSource: Straits Times (Singapore) [edited\n<http://straitstimes.asia1.com.sg/primenews/pri6_0913.html>\n\nSuspected death due to Hand, Foot & Mouth Disease\n--------------------------------------------------\nSingapore: A 2-year-old toddler died on Sunday [10 Sep 2000 as a result of\na suspected outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease [HFMD which struck a\nchild-care centre in Sengkang. 4 other toddlers at the centre appear to\nhave been affected by the disease. The Ministry of Environment (MENV) has\nshut down the centre as a precautionary measure until further notice. The\ncondition of the 4 children is unknown because an investigation into the\noutbreak is on-going.\nThe MENV said in a statement last night that it was notified yesterday\nafternoon of the outbreak of the disease after investigations confirmed\nthat the death of the boy was linked to the disease. The boy had developed\na high fever and rashes on his body on Friday On Sunday afternoon, he\nstarted to vomit blood and he was taken to the Kandang Kerbau Women's and\nChildren's Hospital. Doctors pronounced the boy dead about 12 hours later.\nThe MENV is in the process of contacting parents of children who are\nenrolled at the centre to advise them to take their children to a doctor if\nthey suffer from symptoms of the disease. Symptoms include a fever lasting\nfor 2 to 3 days, a sore throat and runny nose, mouth ulcers and rashes.\nSufferers may also feel nauseous, weak and suffer from diarrhea. HFMD is\nnot serious usually, although it can cause rare complications which result\nin death, the MENV stated. It usually spreads through direct contact with\nbodily fluids of patients or items used by them. Those who want more\ninformation should call the Quarantine and Epidemiology Department on\n7319-758 or 7319-751.\n--\nDr. Hwee-Pin CHIA\nAssistant Professor\nDept of Community, Occupational and Family Medicine\nNational University of Singapore\n<cofchp@nus.edu.sg>\n[HFMD is predominantly a disease of childhood. It can be a consequence of\ninfection by Enterovirus 71 or one of several coxsackieviruses,\nCoxsackievirus A16 being the most common. Enterovirus 71 has been the most\nfrequent cause of HFMD in Southeast Asia and the Far East in recent years.\nTypical cases of HFMD exhibit vesicles and ulcers in the mouth, and a\nvesicular exanthema affecting the palms and soles of feet. The course of\nthe disease is usually mild and death is unusual. The vomiting of blood\ndescribed in this case suggests that other factors may have been involved.\nIt is not clear why HFMD is suspected in this case. Virus can be readily\nisolated from vesicular lesions and laboratory confirmation of infection is\nstraightforward. Further information is awaited. -Mod.CP\n.........................................cp/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
