China (Hong Kong) (02) 19980729.1438\nDate: 13 Sep 2000 09:21:36 +0800\nFrom: CHIA Hwee-Pin <cofchp@nus.edu.sg>\nSource: Straits Times (Singapore) [edited\n<http://straitstimes.asia1.com.sg/primenews/pri6_0913.html>\n\nSuspected death due to Hand, Foot & Mouth Disease\n--------------------------------------------------\nSingapore: A 2-year-old toddler died on Sunday [10 Sep 2000 as a result of\na suspected outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease [HFMD which struck a\nchild-care centre in Sengkang. 4 other toddlers at the centre appear to\nhave been affected by the disease. The Ministry of Environment (MENV) has\nshut down the centre as a precautionary measure until further notice. The\ncondition of the 4 children is unknown because an investigation into the\noutbreak is on-going.\nThe MENV said in a statement last night that it was notified yesterday\nafternoon of the outbreak of the disease after investigations confirmed\nthat the death of the boy was linked to the disease. The boy had developed\na high fever and rashes on his body on Friday On Sunday afternoon, he\nstarted to vomit blood and he was taken to the Kandang Kerbau Women's and\nChildren's Hospital. Doctors pronounced the boy dead about 12 hours later.\nThe MENV is in the process of contacting parents of children who are\nenrolled at the centre to advise them to take their children to a doctor if\nthey suffer from symptoms of the disease. Symptoms include a fever lasting\nfor 2 to 3 days, a sore throat and runny nose, mouth ulcers and rashes.\nSufferers may also feel nauseous, weak and suffer from diarrhea. HFMD is\nnot serious usually, although it can cause rare complications which result\nin death, the MENV stated. It usually spreads through direct contact with\nbodily fluids of patients or items used by them. Those who want more\ninformation should call the Quarantine and Epidemiology Department on\n7319-758 or 7319-751.\n--\nDr. Hwee-Pin CHIA\nAssistant Professor\nDept of Community, Occupational and Family Medicine\nNational University of Singapore\n<cofchp@nus.edu.sg>\n[HFMD is predominantly a disease of childhood. It can be a consequence of\ninfection by Enterovirus 71 or one of several coxsackieviruses,\nCoxsackievirus A16 being the most common. Enterovirus 71 has been the most\nfrequent cause of HFMD in Southeast Asia and the Far East in recent years.\nTypical cases of HFMD exhibit vesicles and ulcers in the mouth, and a\nvesicular exanthema affecting the palms and soles of feet. The course of\nthe disease is usually mild and death is unusual. The vomiting of blood\ndescribed in this case suggests that other factors may have been involved.\nIt is not clear why HFMD is suspected in this case. Virus can be readily\nisolated from vesicular lesions and laboratory confirmation of infection is\nstraightforward. Further information is awaited. -Mod.CP\n.........................................cp/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2000-09-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sengkang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2198606", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2198606", "date": "2000-09-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - SINGAPORE\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nHand, foot & mouth dis. - Canada (Alberta & Ontario) 20000722.1213\nHand, foot & mouth disease, epidemiology 20000729.1256\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Hong Kong 20000818.1374\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Japan 20000720.1200\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Japan: background 20000723.1221\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia 20000325.0433\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (02) 20000328.0458\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (03) 20000521.0806\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan: 1998-1999 20000203.0163\nHand, foot & mouth disease surveillance - Japan 20000729.1260\n1998\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease, fatal - Singapore 19980628.1200\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) 19980716.1341\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) (02) 19980729.1438\nDate: 13 Sep 2000 09:21:36 +0800\nFrom: CHIA Hwee-Pin <cofchp@nus.edu.sg>\nSource: Straits Times (Singapore) [edited\n<http://straitstimes.asia1.com.sg/primenews/pri6_0913.html>\n\nSuspected death due to Hand, Foot & Mouth Disease\n--------------------------------------------------\nSingapore: A 2-year-old toddler died on Sunday [10 Sep 2000 as a result of\na suspected outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease [HFMD which struck a\nchild-care centre in Sengkang. 4 other toddlers at the centre appear to\nhave been affected by the disease. The Ministry of Environment (MENV) has\nshut down the centre as a precautionary measure until further notice. The\ncondition of the 4 children is unknown because an investigation into the\noutbreak is on-going.\nThe MENV said in a statement last night that it was notified yesterday\nafternoon of the outbreak of the disease after investigations confirmed\nthat the death of the boy was linked to the disease. The boy had developed\na high fever and rashes on his body on Friday On Sunday afternoon, he\nstarted to vomit blood and he was taken to the Kandang Kerbau Women's and\nChildren's Hospital. Doctors pronounced the boy dead about 12 hours later.\nThe MENV is in the process of contacting parents of children who are\nenrolled at the centre to advise them to take their children to a doctor if\nthey suffer from symptoms of the disease. Symptoms include a fever lasting\nfor 2 to 3 days, a sore throat and runny nose, mouth ulcers and rashes.\nSufferers may also feel nauseous, weak and suffer from diarrhea. HFMD is\nnot serious usually, although it can cause rare complications which result\nin death, the MENV stated. It usually spreads through direct contact with\nbodily fluids of patients or items used by them. Those who want more\ninformation should call the Quarantine and Epidemiology Department on\n7319-758 or 7319-751.\n--\nDr. Hwee-Pin CHIA\nAssistant Professor\nDept of Community, Occupational and Family Medicine\nNational University of Singapore\n<cofchp@nus.edu.sg>\n[HFMD is predominantly a disease of childhood. It can be a consequence of\ninfection by Enterovirus 71 or one of several coxsackieviruses,\nCoxsackievirus A16 being the most common. Enterovirus 71 has been the most\nfrequent cause of HFMD in Southeast Asia and the Far East in recent years.\nTypical cases of HFMD exhibit vesicles and ulcers in the mouth, and a\nvesicular exanthema affecting the palms and soles of feet. The course of\nthe disease is usually mild and death is unusual. The vomiting of blood\ndescribed in this case suggests that other factors may have been involved.\nIt is not clear why HFMD is suspected in this case. Virus can be readily\nisolated from vesicular lesions and laboratory confirmation of infection is\nstraightforward. Further information is awaited. -Mod.CP\n.........................................cp/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. China (Hong Kong) (02) 19980729.1438\nDate: 13 Sep 2000 09:21:36 +0800\nFrom: CHIA Hwee-Pin <cofchp@nus.edu.sg>\nSource: Straits Times (Singapore) [edited\n<http://straitstimes.asia1.com.sg/primenews/pri6_0913.html>\n\nSuspected death due to Hand, Foot & Mouth Disease\n--------------------------------------------------\nSingapore: A 2-year-old toddler died on Sunday [10 Sep 2000 as a result of\na suspected outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease [HFMD which struck a\nchild-care centre in Sengkang. 4 other toddlers at the centre appear to\nhave been affected by the disease. The Ministry of Environment (MENV) has\nshut down the centre as a precautionary measure until further notice. The\ncondition of the 4 children is unknown because an investigation into the\noutbreak is on-going.\nThe MENV said in a statement last night that it was notified yesterday\nafternoon of the outbreak of the disease after investigations confirmed\nthat the death of the boy was linked to the disease. The boy had developed\na high fever and rashes on his body on Friday On Sunday afternoon, he\nstarted to vomit blood and he was taken to the Kandang Kerbau Women's and\nChildren's Hospital. Doctors pronounced the boy dead about 12 hours later.\nThe MENV is in the process of contacting parents of children who are\nenrolled at the centre to advise them to take their children to a doctor if\nthey suffer from symptoms of the disease. Symptoms include a fever lasting\nfor 2 to 3 days, a sore throat and runny nose, mouth ulcers and rashes.\nSufferers may also feel nauseous, weak and suffer from diarrhea. HFMD is\nnot serious usually, although it can cause rare complications which result\nin death, the MENV stated. It usually spreads through direct contact with\nbodily fluids of patients or items used by them. Those who want more\ninformation should call the Quarantine and Epidemiology Department on\n7319-758 or 7319-751.\n--\nDr. Hwee-Pin CHIA\nAssistant Professor\nDept of Community, Occupational and Family Medicine\nNational University of Singapore\n<cofchp@nus.edu.sg>\n[HFMD is predominantly a disease of childhood. Enterovirus 71 has been the most\nfrequent cause of HFMD in Southeast Asia and the Far East in recent years.\nTypical cases of HFMD exhibit vesicles and ulcers in the mouth, and a\nvesicular exanthema affecting the palms and soles of feet. The course of\nthe disease is usually mild and death is unusual. The vomiting of blood\ndescribed in this case suggests that other factors may have been involved.\nIt is not clear why HFMD is suspected in this case. Virus can be readily\nisolated from vesicular lesions and laboratory confirmation of infection is\nstraightforward. China (Hong Kong)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2198444", "date": "2000-03-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - MALAYSIA\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org/>\nSee Also\n1999\n----\nEnterovirus 71, clinical correlates 19990927014419\nEnterovirus 71, fatal - China (Hong Kong) (02) 19990605201705\nEnterovirus 71, treatment - Japan 19990711160807\nEnterovirus 71 - Asia 19991226225820\nEnterovirus 71 - Australia (Western) (03) 19990730152336\nEnterovirus 71 - China (Hong Kong) 980701201715\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - Taiwan (25) 980906001148\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children: clinical signs 980619232936\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic - China (Hong Kong) (06) 980921155207\nHand, foot & mouth disease, fatal - Singapore 980628100055\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) (02) 980729233123\n1997\n----\nEncephalitis, enterovirus 71 - Malaysia (02) 971020235540\nDate: Fri, 24 Mar 2000 09:24:02 -0600\nFrom: Clyde Markon <docmarkon@worldnet.att.net>\nSource: Sarawak Tribune, Online, 24 Mar 2000\n<http://www.jaring.my/tribune>\n\nMukah is the latest district to join other divisions in registering a rise\nin incidence of hand, foot and mouth disease. But the State Health\nDepartment (SHD) has yet to ascertain the exact number of children infected\nwith this disease despite the increased number of cases also recorded in\nBintulu, Kuching, Marudi, Serian, Sibu and Miri.\nState Health Department (SHD) director Dr Yao Sik Chi told the Tribune\nyesterday that parents should heed the department's advice to observe\nstrict personal hygiene. \"Getting early treatment for their children and\nthe regular washing of hands would help bring down the incidence of this\ndisease,\" he advised. \"Parents with children below five must wash hands\nbefore eating and avoid crowded places\", he added.\nParents should not compromise on personal hygiene as the disease could only\nbe spread from human to human, he said. Dr Yao had directed all medical\nstaff at the divisional and district levels to alert parents of children\ninfected by the disease to seek early medical treatment at the nearest\nhospitals and clinics. He hoped nursery operators too would cooperate by\nobserving strict personal hygiene, and send home children suspected of\nbeing infected by the disease. Meanwhile, University Malaysia Sarawak\n(Unimas) director of Health and Community Medicine, Professor Dr Jane\nCardoza, agreed that prevention was most effective to fight the disease.\n\"Keeping hands clean by washing with water before any intake of food is the\nbest practice for parents and children. The hot and dry weather should be\ngood reason to observe strict personal hygiene,\" she said.\nOn Wednesday, Deputy Chief Minister Datuk Amar Dr George Chan said the\ngovernment did not want to be caught unprepared this time. In mid-1997,\nthe Coxsackie outbreak took the lives of 31 children under five years old,\nwith 911 treated at hospitals and clinics. A total of 3,334 children were\ntreated nationwide for this viral infection. The outbreak also put the\ncountry on medical alert, forcing the temporary closure of nurseries and\nswimming pools in the State. The State government allocated nearly RM1\nmillion for research on the Coxsackie disease. The government also took\nsteps to ensure there would be no future recurrence of the disease in the\nState.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n.............................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Singapore 980628100055\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) (02) 980729233123\n1997\n----\nEncephalitis, enterovirus 71 - Malaysia (02) 971020235540\nDate: Fri, 24 Mar 2000 09:24:02 -0600\nFrom: Clyde Markon <docmarkon@worldnet.att.net>\nSource: Sarawak Tribune, Online, 24 Mar 2000\n<http://www.jaring.my/tribune>\n\nMukah is the latest district to join other divisions in registering a rise\nin incidence of hand, foot and mouth disease. But the State Health\nDepartment (SHD) has yet to ascertain the exact number of children infected\nwith this disease despite the increased number of cases also recorded in\nBintulu, Kuching, Marudi, Serian, Sibu and Miri.\nState Health Department (SHD) director Dr Yao Sik Chi told the Tribune\nyesterday that parents should heed the department's advice to observe\nstrict personal hygiene. \"Getting early treatment for their children and\nthe regular washing of hands would help bring down the incidence of this\ndisease,\" he advised. \"Parents with children below five must wash hands\nbefore eating and avoid crowded places\", he added.\nParents should not compromise on personal hygiene as the disease could only\nbe spread from human to human, he said. Dr Yao had directed all medical\nstaff at the divisional and district levels to alert parents of children\ninfected by the disease to seek early medical treatment at the nearest\nhospitals and clinics. He hoped nursery operators too would cooperate by\nobserving strict personal hygiene, and send home children suspected of\nbeing infected by the disease. Meanwhile, University Malaysia Sarawak\n(Unimas) director of Health and Community Medicine, Professor Dr Jane\nCardoza, agreed that prevention was most effective to fight the disease.\n\"Keeping hands clean by washing with water before any intake of food is the\nbest practice for parents and children. The hot and dry weather should be\ngood reason to observe strict personal hygiene,\" she said.\nOn Wednesday, Deputy Chief Minister Datuk Amar Dr George Chan said the\ngovernment did not want to be caught unprepared this time. In mid-1997,\nthe Coxsackie outbreak took the lives of 31 children under five years old,\nwith 911 treated at hospitals and clinics. A total of 3,334 children were\ntreated nationwide for this viral infection. The outbreak also put the\ncountry on medical alert, forcing the temporary closure of nurseries and\nswimming pools in the State. The State government allocated nearly RM1\nmillion for research on the Coxsackie disease. The government also took\nsteps to ensure there would be no future recurrence of the disease in the\nState.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n.............................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. MALAYSIA\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org/>\nSee Also\n1999\n----\nEnterovirus 71, clinical correlates 19990927014419\nEnterovirus 71, fatal - China (Hong Kong) (02) 19990605201705\nEnterovirus 71, treatment - China (Hong Kong) (02) 980729233123\n1997\n----\nEncephalitis, enterovirus 71 - Malaysia (02) 971020235540\nDate: Fri, 24 Mar 2000 09:24:02 -0600\nFrom: Clyde Markon <docmarkon@worldnet.att.net>\nSource: Sarawak Tribune, Online, 24 Mar 2000\n<http://www.jaring.my/tribune>\n\nMukah is the latest district to join other divisions in registering a rise\nin incidence of hand, foot and mouth disease. But the State Health\nDepartment (SHD) has yet to ascertain the exact number of children infected\nwith this disease despite the increased number of cases also recorded in\nBintulu, Kuching, Marudi, Serian, Sibu and Miri.\nState Health Department (SHD) director Dr Yao Sik Chi told the Tribune\nyesterday that parents should heed the department's advice to observe\nstrict personal hygiene. \"Getting early treatment for their children and\nthe regular washing of hands would help bring down the incidence of this\ndisease,\" he advised. \"Parents with children below five must wash hands\nbefore eating and avoid crowded places\", he added.\nParents should not compromise on personal hygiene as the disease could only\nbe spread from human to human, he said. Dr Yao had directed all medical\nstaff at the divisional and district levels to alert parents of children\ninfected by the disease to seek early medical treatment at the nearest\nhospitals and clinics. He hoped nursery operators too would cooperate by\nobserving strict personal hygiene, and send home children suspected of\nbeing infected by the disease. Meanwhile, University Malaysia Sarawak\n(Unimas) director of Health and Community Medicine, Professor Dr Jane\nCardoza, agreed that prevention was most effective to fight the disease.\n\"Keeping hands clean by washing with water before any intake of food is the\nbest practice for parents and children. The hot and dry weather should be\ngood reason to observe strict personal hygiene,\" she said.\nOn Wednesday, Deputy Chief Minister Datuk Amar Dr George Chan said the\ngovernment did not want to be caught unprepared this time. In mid-1997,\nthe Coxsackie outbreak took the lives of 31 children under five years old,\nwith 911 treated at hospitals and clinics. A total of 3,334 children were\ntreated nationwide for this viral infection. The outbreak also put the\ncountry on medical alert, forcing the temporary closure of nurseries and\nswimming pools in the State. The State government allocated nearly RM1\nmillion for research on the Coxsackie disease. The government also took\nsteps to ensure there would be no future recurrence of the disease in the\nState.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n.............................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Japan: background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2198291", "date": "2000-03-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - MALAYSIA\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org/>\nSee Also\n1999\n----\nEnterovirus 71, clinical correlates 19990927014419\nEnterovirus 71, fatal - China (Hong Kong) (02) 19990605201705\nEnterovirus 71, treatment - Japan 19990711160807\nEnterovirus 71 - Asia 19991226225820\nEnterovirus 71 - Australia (Western) (03) 19990730152336\nEnterovirus 71 - Taiwan 1998: clinical signs 19990821234913\nEnterovirus 71 genotypes - Malaysia, Japan, Taiwan... 19990821212226\n1998\n----\nEnterovirus 71, new outbreak - Taiwan (02) 981005172918\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - China (Hong Kong) 980701201715\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - Taiwan (25) 980906001148\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children: clinical signs 980619232936\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic - China (Hong Kong) (06) 980921155207\nHand, foot & mouth disease, fatal - Singapore 980628100055\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) (02) 980729233123\n1997\n----\nEncephalitis, enterovirus 71 - Malaysia (02) 971020235540\nDate: Fri, 24 Mar 2000 09:24:02 -0600\nFrom: Clyde Markon <docmarkon@worldnet.att.net>\nSource: Sarawak Tribune, Online, 24 Mar 2000\n<http://www.jaring.my/tribune>\n\nMukah is the latest district to join other divisions in registering a rise\nin incidence of hand, foot and mouth disease. But the State Health\nDepartment (SHD) has yet to ascertain the exact number of children infected\nwith this disease despite the increased number of cases also recorded in\nBintulu, Kuching, Marudi, Serian, Sibu and Miri.\nState Health Department (SHD) director Dr Yao Sik Chi told the Tribune\nyesterday that parents should heed the department's advice to observe\nstrict personal hygiene. \"Getting early treatment for their children and\nthe regular washing of hands would help bring down the incidence of this\ndisease,\" he advised. \"Parents with children below five must wash hands\nbefore eating and avoid crowded places\", he added.\nParents should not compromise on personal hygiene as the disease could only\nbe spread from human to human, he said. Dr Yao had directed all medical\nstaff at the divisional and district levels to alert parents of children\ninfected by the disease to seek early medical treatment at the nearest\nhospitals and clinics. He hoped nursery operators too would cooperate by\nobserving strict personal hygiene, and send home children suspected of\nbeing infected by the disease. Meanwhile, University Malaysia Sarawak\n(Unimas) director of Health and Community Medicine, Professor Dr Jane\nCardoza, agreed that prevention was most effective to fight the disease.\n\"Keeping hands clean by washing with water before any intake of food is the\nbest practice for parents and children. The hot and dry weather should be\ngood reason to observe strict personal hygiene,\" she said.\nOn Wednesday, Deputy Chief Minister Datuk Amar Dr George Chan said the\ngovernment did not want to be caught unprepared this time. In mid-1997,\nthe Coxsackie outbreak took the lives of 31 children under five years old,\nwith 911 treated at hospitals and clinics. A total of 3,334 children were\ntreated nationwide for this viral infection. The outbreak also put the\ncountry on medical alert, forcing the temporary closure of nurseries and\nswimming pools in the State. The State government allocated nearly RM1\nmillion for research on the Coxsackie disease. The government also took\nsteps to ensure there would be no future recurrence of the disease in the\nState.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n.............................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Singapore 980628100055\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) (02) 980729233123\n1997\n----\nEncephalitis, enterovirus 71 - Malaysia (02) 971020235540\nDate: Fri, 24 Mar 2000 09:24:02 -0600\nFrom: Clyde Markon <docmarkon@worldnet.att.net>\nSource: Sarawak Tribune, Online, 24 Mar 2000\n<http://www.jaring.my/tribune>\n\nMukah is the latest district to join other divisions in registering a rise\nin incidence of hand, foot and mouth disease. But the State Health\nDepartment (SHD) has yet to ascertain the exact number of children infected\nwith this disease despite the increased number of cases also recorded in\nBintulu, Kuching, Marudi, Serian, Sibu and Miri.\nState Health Department (SHD) director Dr Yao Sik Chi told the Tribune\nyesterday that parents should heed the department's advice to observe\nstrict personal hygiene. \"Getting early treatment for their children and\nthe regular washing of hands would help bring down the incidence of this\ndisease,\" he advised. \"Parents with children below five must wash hands\nbefore eating and avoid crowded places\", he added.\nParents should not compromise on personal hygiene as the disease could only\nbe spread from human to human, he said. Dr Yao had directed all medical\nstaff at the divisional and district levels to alert parents of children\ninfected by the disease to seek early medical treatment at the nearest\nhospitals and clinics. He hoped nursery operators too would cooperate by\nobserving strict personal hygiene, and send home children suspected of\nbeing infected by the disease. Meanwhile, University Malaysia Sarawak\n(Unimas) director of Health and Community Medicine, Professor Dr Jane\nCardoza, agreed that prevention was most effective to fight the disease.\n\"Keeping hands clean by washing with water before any intake of food is the\nbest practice for parents and children. The hot and dry weather should be\ngood reason to observe strict personal hygiene,\" she said.\nOn Wednesday, Deputy Chief Minister Datuk Amar Dr George Chan said the\ngovernment did not want to be caught unprepared this time. In mid-1997,\nthe Coxsackie outbreak took the lives of 31 children under five years old,\nwith 911 treated at hospitals and clinics. A total of 3,334 children were\ntreated nationwide for this viral infection. The outbreak also put the\ncountry on medical alert, forcing the temporary closure of nurseries and\nswimming pools in the State. The State government allocated nearly RM1\nmillion for research on the Coxsackie disease. The government also took\nsteps to ensure there would be no future recurrence of the disease in the\nState.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n.............................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A total of 3,334 children were\ntreated nationwide for this viral infection. The outbreak also put the\ncountry on medical alert, forcing the temporary closure of nurseries and\nswimming pools in the State. Singapore 980628100055\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) (02) 980729233123\n1997\n----\nEncephalitis, enterovirus 71 - Malaysia (02) 971020235540\nDate: Fri, 24 Mar 2000 09:24:02 -0600\nFrom: Clyde Markon <docmarkon@worldnet.att.net>\nSource: Sarawak Tribune, Online, 24 Mar 2000\n<http://www.jaring.my/tribune>\n\nMukah is the latest district to join other divisions in registering a rise\nin incidence of hand, foot and mouth disease. But the State Health\nDepartment (SHD) has yet to ascertain the exact number of children infected\nwith this disease despite the increased number of cases also recorded in\nBintulu, Kuching, Marudi, Serian, Sibu and Miri.\nState Health Department (SHD) director Dr Yao Sik Chi told the Tribune\nyesterday that parents should heed the department's advice to observe\nstrict personal hygiene. \"Getting early treatment for their children and\nthe regular washing of hands would help bring down the incidence of this\ndisease,\" he advised. \"Parents with children below five must wash hands\nbefore eating and avoid crowded places\", he added.\nParents should not compromise on personal hygiene as the disease could only\nbe spread from human to human, he said. He hoped nursery operators too would cooperate by\nobserving strict personal hygiene, and send home children suspected of\nbeing infected by the disease. Meanwhile, University Malaysia Sarawak\n(Unimas) director of Health and Community Medicine, Professor Dr Jane\nCardoza, agreed that prevention was most effective to fight the disease.\n\"Keeping hands clean by washing with water before any intake of food is the\nbest practice for parents and children. The hot and dry weather should be\ngood reason to observe strict personal hygiene,\" she said.\nOn Wednesday, Deputy Chief Minister Datuk Amar Dr George Chan said the\ngovernment did not want to be caught unprepared this time. In mid-1997,\nthe Coxsackie outbreak took the lives of 31 children under five years old,\nwith 911 treated at hospitals and clinics. A total of 3,334 children were\ntreated nationwide for this viral infection. The outbreak also put the\ncountry on medical alert, forcing the temporary closure of nurseries and\nswimming pools in the State. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-09-27 01:44:19", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-08-21 23:49:13", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kuching", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2197242", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease  - Taiwan: 1998-1999", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2197242", "date": "1998-06-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE, FATAL - SINGAPORE\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nEnterovirus 71 epidemic, children - Taiwan (13) 980625193748\nEV-71 & HFMD-linked child deaths - Japan (Osaka) 1997 980623221208\nDate: Sat, 27 Jun 1998 12:20:21 +0800\nFrom: Dr. M. Vadivale <vale@pop.jaring.my>\nSource: Straits Times <http://straitstimes.asia1.com/pages/sin6_0627.html>\n[edited - ES\n\nA 2-1/2-year-old Singapore boy has died of severe complications from hand,\nfoot and mouth disease, the first death of its kind here since 1993.\nThe disease is caused by a virus that is from the same family as\nenterovirus 71, which is linked to the deaths of 50 children in Taiwan.\nHowever, the boy and his family have not travelled to Taiwan recently, so\nhealth authorities believe the death may be a sporadic case of hand, foot\nand mouth disease with severe complications.\nThe Health (MOH) and Environment (ENV) ministries said in a joint statement\nyesterday that it will take one to four weeks for laboratory tests to\nconfirm which virus was responsible for the infection. In the meantime,\nthey have taken several steps: Doctors have been alerted to look out for\nsuch cases, refer serious ones to a hospital and notify ENV's Quarantine\nand Epidemiology Department. All hospitals have been alerted and are\nprepared to handle patients with severe hand, foot and mouth disease.\nGuidelines for collecting and handling specimens for laboratory testing\nhave been issued to all hospitals and paediatricians. Child-care centres\nand kindergartens have been told to maintain high hygiene and health\nstandards.\nWhile the World Health Organisation has not called for travel restrictions\nto Taiwan, health authorities here suggest taking precautions, such as\npractising a high standard of hygiene and avoiding crowded places and the\nsharing of personal items.\nTouching on the case of the dead boy, Dr Phua Kong Boo, clinical head,\npaediatric medicine at the KK Women's and Children's Hospital, said that\nthe boy suffered from a fever, mouth ulcers and was vomiting on June 16.\nBy June 18, he became very drowsy. A day later he was breathless and taken\nto a hospital. He went into a fit, collapsed and was taken to KK in a\ncritical condition, later the same day.\nHe was diagnosed to have enterovirus infection with complications of\nencephalitis and myocarditis. His condition did not improve and he died on\nThursday. Investigations showed that two cousins and an elder sister had\nrecovered from similar but mild infections, several days to about six weeks\nbefore the boy came down with the symptoms.\nDr Phua added that the disease in its mild form is very common. According\nto MOH, there were 358 cases last year and 290 so far this year. MOH added\nthat it has not detected any case of enterovirus 71 infection here so far\nthis year.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Vadivale <vale@pop.jaring.my>\nSource: Straits Times <http://straitstimes.asia1.com/pages/sin6_0627.html>\n[edited - ES\n\nA 2-1/2-year-old Singapore boy has died of severe complications from hand,\nfoot and mouth disease, the first death of its kind here since 1993.\nThe disease is caused by a virus that is from the same family as\nenterovirus 71, which is linked to the deaths of 50 children in Taiwan.\nHowever, the boy and his family have not travelled to Taiwan recently, so\nhealth authorities believe the death may be a sporadic case of hand, foot\nand mouth disease with severe complications.\nThe Health (MOH) and Environment (ENV) ministries said in a joint statement\nyesterday that it will take one to four weeks for laboratory tests to\nconfirm which virus was responsible for the infection. In the meantime,\nthey have taken several steps: Doctors have been alerted to look out for\nsuch cases, refer serious ones to a hospital and notify ENV's Quarantine\nand Epidemiology Department. All hospitals have been alerted and are\nprepared to handle patients with severe hand, foot and mouth disease.\nGuidelines for collecting and handling specimens for laboratory testing\nhave been issued to all hospitals and paediatricians. Child-care centres\nand kindergartens have been told to maintain high hygiene and health\nstandards.\nWhile the World Health Organisation has not called for travel restrictions\nto Taiwan, health authorities here suggest taking precautions, such as\npractising a high standard of hygiene and avoiding crowded places and the\nsharing of personal items.\nTouching on the case of the dead boy, Dr Phua Kong Boo, clinical head,\npaediatric medicine at the KK Women's and Children's Hospital, said that\nthe boy suffered from a fever, mouth ulcers and was vomiting on June 16.\nBy June 18, he became very drowsy. A day later he was breathless and taken\nto a hospital. He went into a fit, collapsed and was taken to KK in a\ncritical condition, later the same day.\nHe was diagnosed to have enterovirus infection with complications of\nencephalitis and myocarditis. His condition did not improve and he died on\nThursday. Investigations showed that two cousins and an elder sister had\nrecovered from similar but mild infections, several days to about six weeks\nbefore the boy came down with the symptoms.\nDr Phua added that the disease in its mild form is very common. According\nto MOH, there were 358 cases last year and 290 so far this year. MOH added\nthat it has not detected any case of enterovirus 71 infection here so far\nthis year.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
